div.note: Sir: Guyon is the only protagonist in the FQ thus entitled on the title page of his legend.
antique: ancient

antique: Also â€˜anticâ€™, i.e. ludicrous or grotesque. Cf. Donne, Elegy 9, â€˜The Autumnalâ€™: â€˜Name not these living death-heads unto me, / For these, not ancient, but antique beâ€™ (43-4). This wordplay introduces an ambiguity that runs throughout the proem, which pretends to worry about whether Spenserâ€™s fiction possesses the dignity and authority of antiquity or is merely a gothic extravagance.
history: narrative
history: In early modern usage, either factual (the modern sense) or a purely imaginary (a common synonym for â€˜storyâ€™).
Of some: by some

living aire: A good example of the freedom with which Spenser commonly transfers epithets, here from â€˜noneâ€™ to â€˜aireâ€™, and of the distinctive quality this freedom lends to the verse: half-animating the air itself, such phrasing contributes to a pervasive fluidity in the boundary between allegorical agents and their physical environments.
antiquities: Cf. I.pr.2.3-4, imploring the muse to â€˜Lay forth out of thine everlasting scryne / The antique rolles, which there lye hidden stillâ€™.
no body: Anticipating the contrast between faith in that which is unseen and knowledge that is available to the senses (the body), elaborated in st. 3 and 4.
better sense: As opposed to the senses through which a â€˜body can knowâ€™ (see 4.4n).
advize: consider

red: A favorite word of Spenserâ€™s both for its convenience in rhyming and for its lexical range. Here primarily a synonym for its rhyming partner â€˜discoveredâ€™, it also suggests the activities of conjecture, interpretation, declaration, and, of course, construal of a text. Its range is suggested by the way Spenser punningly enfolds the verb into its rhyming partners â€˜discover-redâ€™ and â€˜measur-redâ€™.
late age: recent ages, as opposed to antiquity

Indian Peru: Early explorers had believed that Peru was India. By 1590 the difference was well understood. The passage thus suggests, through the rhyming play on â€˜redâ€™ and â€˜discoveredâ€™ (with its accented last syllable), that Peru was initially both discover-read and misread.
Amazons huge river: Francisco de Orellana in 1541-42 was the first European to sail the Amazon.

fruitfullest Virginia: Named after Elizabeth in 1584. The epithet combines colonial motives, asserting the economic value of newly discovered lands, with a Protestant adaptation of the Virgin Maryâ€™s paradoxical status as fecund virgin.

3.3-8Â Spenser is here imitating Ariosto, OF 7.1 and Chaucer, LGW Prol. 12-15. Spenser fuses these more or less playful references with an echo of Heb 11:1: â€˜Now faith is the grounde of things, which are hoped for, and the evidence of things which are not seneâ€™; the rest of chapter 11, an extended definition of faith, is evoked more broadly in the proem. Hamilton 2001 also notes a reminiscence of Giordano Brunoâ€™s astronomical speculations in the 1584 treatise De l'Infinito Universo e Mondi (â€˜On the Infinite Universe and Worldsâ€™). This fusion of literary, religious, and scientific allusions creates an ambiguous, distinctively Spenserian tonal irony.
misweene: misconceive, suppose incorrectly
happily: by chance or good fortune

4.1-5Â The keen-scented hound tracking textual "feet" is a Renaissance commonplace applied to the seeker of rare manuscripts or to the humanist editor filling in manuscript lacunae (Passannante 2011: 90), but Spenser in these lines appears to be tracking the source in Lucretius, De Rerum Natura 1.400-409. An emphasis on moving beyond the realm of perception is distinctive to both passages, and Spenserâ€™s â€œcertain signesâ€ may echo vestigia certa from Lucretius.

yet: Culminating the series of four begun at 3.1 (â€˜Yet all these wereâ€™), this yet stretches the adversative sense of its predecessors into a temporal notion of prolonging, integral to the argument that the unseen may be what we havenâ€™t seen yet.
certein signes: Cf. John 4:48: â€˜Then said Jesus unto Him, Except ye se signes and wonders, ye wil not beleveâ€™. Extends the resonance of the allusion to Hebrews in st. 3.
here sett: May refer to the positioning of words in a piece of writing or to the setting of type on the page.

sondrie place: Playing the geographical sense of â€˜placeâ€™ against its use as the designation for a passage in a text, familiar from the glosses to the Geneva Bible. â€˜Placeâ€™ in this sense is a vernacular equivalent for the more learned expression loci communes.

ne let him then admyre: The romance topos of the marvelous, canvassed extensively in Italian Renaissance criticism, passes into travel narratives and other New World discourses as a trope of discovery (Greenblatt 1992). Spenserâ€™s proem has evoked the wonder of geographical discovery in a characteristically ambiguous register, half-serious and half-playful, that lends this phrase its edge of irony: the reader who would â€˜wonderâ€™ at newly discovered worlds (3.9) should not wonder at the inadequacy of his common sense to apprehend the marvels of Spenserâ€™s text.

sence: Powers of interpretation (cf. 2.1, â€˜with better senseâ€™, and 3.4, â€˜witless manâ€™), but playing also on the five senses, or â€˜witsâ€™ and the â€˜common senseâ€™ that synthesizes them (thus Thomas Wilson 1553 says that â€˜The common sense...is therefore so called, because it geveth judgement, of al the five outwarde sensesâ€™ [112]). These â€˜outwardâ€™ or bodily senses were contrasted with the â€˜inward senseâ€™, i.e. faculties of mind or spirit. This ambiguity concentrates into a single word the playful pretense that Faeryland is a geographical location like Peru, able to be discovered by the outward senses, rather than a textual â€˜placeâ€™ (4.2n) accessible only to the intellect.
nâ€™ote: might not
nâ€™ote: A pseudo-Chaucerian contraction for â€˜ne moteâ€™, might not. (See glossary entry.)

fine footing: Elusive tracks or artful metricsâ€”an ambiguity parallel to those of â€˜redâ€™, â€˜placeâ€™, and â€˜senceâ€™. The line may thus be paraphrased â€˜That canâ€™t track fancy (poetic) footwork without a bloodhoundâ€™. In 1596 Spenser will repeat the pun on â€˜footingâ€™, referring to Faeryland as â€˜these strange waies, where never foote did use, / Ne none can find, but who was taught them by the Museâ€™ (VI.pr.2.7-9).

fayrest: Spenser more than once links â€˜faeryâ€™ (4.1, 8) to â€˜fayreâ€™ (4.7) and â€˜fayrestâ€™ as if it expressed the comparative degree of a beauty whose superlative is embodied in the queen (cf. 1.pr.2.5). This ambiguity cuts against the wordplay elsewhere in the proem that tends to disembody Faeryland, and thus implies that it can be â€˜redâ€™ in both senses (intellectually as well as corporeally; see 4.4n) only in Elizabeth.

this fayre mirrhour: A favorite metaphor of Spenserâ€™s, elaborated in all but one of the proems and in many other texts; for examples, see Am 7 and 45, HL 196, and HB 181, 224. Here its seeming simplicity is complicated by the association between â€˜fayreâ€™ and â€˜Faeryâ€™, by the implication that Elizabeth is the mirror in which Faeryland may be â€˜redâ€™, and by the assertion in the immediately following lines that Faeryland reflects the past as well as the present.

4.7-9 According to early modern constitutional theory, the monarch possesses two â€˜bodiesâ€™: the personal body of the mortal individual and the undying â€˜body politicâ€™, through which the monarch personifies the realm. These lines evoke the body personal in Elizabethâ€™s â€˜faceâ€™ and the body politic in her â€˜realmesâ€™, concluding with her lineage, which traces the genealogy of each.

covert vele: Echoes biblical accounts of Moses veiling his face to temper the â€˜gloryâ€™ or radiance that shone from it after he spoke with God (Exod 34:30). At 2 Cor 3:13 St. Paul reinterprets the passage allegorically, suggesting that what Moses hid was not the radiance but its fading. If there is also a glance at the legal term femme covert (the legal status, or rather non-status, of a married woman), it would carry strong irony, given the queenâ€™s unmarried state. Both vele and shadowes echo standard Renaissance discussions of fiction in general and of allegory in particular.

shadowes light: Shadows that are trivial or facetious (continuing the pretense from st. 1 that fiction is somehow disreputable), in contrast to the rhyming use (at 5.5) as illumination. But the paradox of â€˜shadowes lightâ€™ reintroduces the sense of illumination as a secondary reference, and it thus plays against the superficial sense of â€˜lightâ€™ as trivial.

Guyon: The name may come from heroes of French romance, particularly the medieval metrical romance Guy of Warwick, where the name â€˜Guyâ€™ is regularly varied to â€˜Guyonâ€™ for rhyme; Guyâ€™s two-part career, as questing knight and then as pilgrim, offers a template for the pairing of Guyon and the Palmer in Book II (King 2007). Guy was especially well known because the English earls of Warwick, Robert and Ambrose, claimed descent from him (Cooper 2007: 185). The name also echoes Gihon, one of the four rivers of Paradise, associated with Temperance (Fowler 1960), and may additionally, as Camden thought, recall Ital guido guide (1605:82). In the Golden Legend it is glossed as â€˜wrestlerâ€™ (1955:112). See SpE s.v. â€˜Guyonâ€™.

rule: The term has a range of meanings here, among them the fundamental principle of temperance, the body of writings that make up its lore, the standard by which it is measured, and its reign or governance.

goodly doth appeare: Cf. â€˜to some appeareâ€™ (3.9). This verbal echo belongs to the pattern of contrasts running throughout the language of the proem, suggesting that Temperance will â€˜appearâ€™ to the inward rather than the outward senses. This suggestion is reinforced by the rhyming partner â€˜heareâ€™(5.8), since hearing Guyonâ€™s adventures is an activity of the common sense whereas the rule of Temperance can appear only to the intellect (see 4.4n).
Mordant and Amavia: Sir Mordant is first named at 49.9, Amavia not until ii.45.8. Their names are glossed by the poet at 55.4-5.
conning: cunning

Architect: Combines an echo of â€˜Archimagoâ€™ with the Greek root Ï„ğœ€ÎºÏ„Ï‰Î½ tektÅn builder, from Ï„ğœ€Ï‡Î½Î· technÄ“ art or craft, emphasizing the techniques and technology of deceit (cf. wyle, artes, meanes, engines, practick witt, stales, traynes, spyals, and snares in the ensuing lines).
cancred: ulcerated; figuratively, â€˜infectedâ€™ with evil
Princes late displeasure: At I.xii.35-36 Unaâ€™s royal father has Archimago clapped in irons.

bands . . . shackles emptie lefte: At Rev 20:1-3 an angel is said to bind Satan for a thousand years, after which he is â€˜loosed . . . for a little seasonâ€™. Lexically, â€˜bandsâ€™ in early modern English are not yet distinct from â€˜bondsâ€™ (see Glossary), which may either unite or imprison: cf. I.xii.34.4, where Una describes Archimagoâ€™s purpose as â€˜breaking of the band betwixt us twaineâ€™ (herself and Redcrosse), and I.ix.1.9, where Arthur is said to have â€˜redeemd the Redcrosse knight from bandsâ€™.
suborned wyle: At I.xii.25-28 Archimago bears false witness against Redcrosse, to which Una responds at 34.1 that he has been â€˜subornedâ€™.

Eden lands: The kingdom Una will inherit is first identified by its rivers (I.vii.43.6-9), then named in the â€˜falsed lettersâ€™ addressed to Unaâ€™s father as â€˜most mighty king of Eden fayreâ€™ (I.xii.26.1).
Redcrosse explained this obligation at I.xii.18.
caytives: caitiffsâ€™

caytives: Either the hands belong to wretches (Hamilton 2001 suggests â€˜menialsâ€™) or Spenser is referring to Archimagoâ€™s erstwhile captors as â€˜captivesâ€™, less a transferred epithet than a reversed one. Cf. â€˜her captive Parents deareâ€™ (I.xi.1.2) in contrast with â€˜victorious handesâ€™ at 2.6.

cleene: Archimago escapes â€˜cleeneâ€™ in the sense of â€˜entirelyâ€™ (also, no doubt, â€˜dexterouslyâ€™), but the word combines complex senses related to the opposition in the early cantos of Book II between mixture and purity. Compare 10.4, â€˜virgin cleeneâ€™, ii.arg.4, â€˜banish cleaneâ€™, and Guyonâ€™s failed effort at ii.3.4 to â€˜cleeneâ€™ Ruddymaneâ€™s â€˜guilty hands from bloody goreâ€™.
algates: altogether
late ygoe: not long ago
At I.xii.42 the narrator speaks of the narrative itself as a â€˜weather-beaten shipâ€™, with the break between books figured as its temporary harbor.
food: 16th-c spelling of â€˜feudâ€™ suggests that Archimago feeds on hatred.
offend: injure or attack (in biblical use, to stumble)
drift: purpose
engins: contrivances
practick: crafty; experienced; concerned with practice (opposed to â€˜theoreticâ€™)

fayre fyled tonge: At. I.i.35.7 he â€˜well could file [smooth or polish] his tongueâ€™; this usage may recall Chaucerâ€™s Pardoner and Pandarus, both of whom file their tongues (CT Gen Pro 712; T&C 2.1681).
credit: reputation, credibility
stales: decoys
traynes: snares or baits
privy spyals: secret spies
ketch him at a vauntage: the modern idiom would be â€˜catch him at a disadvantageâ€™
to win occasion: An innocuous phrase, but it foreshadows the emergence of a full-blown allegory of Furor and Occasion in canto iv.

5.4-5 Archimago transfers his enmity from Redcrosse to Guyon according to the network of alliances forged by the knights and their virtues, symbolized by the â€˜goodly golden chayne, wherewith yfere / The vertues linked are in lovely wizeâ€™ (I.ix.i.1-2). Here, Archimago both anticipates an alliance not yet pledged and, ironically, in trying to prevent it brings it about (cf. 34.1-2).
a goodly knight: Redcrosse is â€˜that godly knightâ€™ at 2.3.
5.8-9 Archimagoâ€™s first view of Guyon finds no chink in his armor.
countenance demure: Echoes the description of Fidelia and Speranza at I.x.12.4.
demure: sober, reserved
amate: dismay
an Elfin borne: A fairy rather than a human knight like the Saxon Redcrosse (I.x.65.1-5) or the â€˜Briton Princeâ€™ Arthur (I.pr.2.6, where â€˜Britonâ€™ may be taken as synonymous with â€˜Welshâ€™).
mickle worship: great honor
lists: bounded space of combat
debate: armed encounter

Sir Huon: Protagonist of a popular 13th-century French romance, a version of which was translated into English in the early decades of the sixteenth century. Since Oberon will later be identified with Henry VIII (II.x.75-76), this allusion may trace Guyonâ€™s knighting to the generation preceding Spenser and his queen, suggesting that Huon â€˜came withâ€™ Oberon to Faeryland in a literary sense when he was â€˜translatedâ€™ into English literature during the reign of Henry VIII. Since Huon is a principal source for Spenserâ€™s notion of Faeryland, the poet may here be tipping his hat to the vernacular romance tradition.
als: also
comely: appropriate or suitable
comely: In ME usage, â€˜applied in courtesy to those of noble stationâ€™ (OED).

Palmer: A pilgrim, so called because travelers returning from the Holy Land sometimes carried palm leaves. Also a flat piece of wood used by the stricter Elizabethan schoolmasters to spank recalcitrant students on the palms of their hands.

clad in black attyre: At I.i.4.5-6 the narrator describes Una covered with â€˜a blacke stole . . . / As one that inly mourndâ€™, a phrase recalled at xii.41.9 when Redcrosse, returning to Faerie court, â€˜Una left to mourneâ€™.
stire: stir
stire: Cf. v.2.9, where the word clearly describes the effects of a spur. With a possible play on â€˜steerâ€™, given the Palmerâ€™s tendency to manage Guyon.
aread: conjecture

7.8-9 Cf. the tensions in the opening procession of Book I, where Una rides slowly on a donkey while Redcrosse both spurs his steed and reins it in. Both passages reflect the tradition descending from Platoâ€™s Phaedrus in which the passions are represented as a horse resistant to the bit.

with equall steps: With steps matching the pace of the aged Palmer; perhaps with a contrastive allusion to Aen 2.724, where Ascanius accompanies his father out of Troy non passibus aequis (â€˜not with equal stepsâ€™).

note.p: St. 8-34 Each book of the 1590 FQ begins by separating virtuous companions: first Una and Redcrosse, then Guyon and the Palmer, and in III a group consisting of Arthur, Timias, Guyon, and Britomart. In Books I and II this effect is accomplished through the combined efforts of Archimago and Duessa.

Guyonâ€™s encounter with Duessa is modeled in part on an episode in Book 4 of Trissinoâ€™s Lâ€™Italia Liberata dai Goti in which the knight Corsamonte, on his way to free a band of his comrades held captive by the enchantress Acratia, is deceived by another enchantress, Ligridonia, posing as a wronged maiden. (For a detailed account, see Lemmi 1928, excerpted in Var 2.443-44.)

div.note: 8.1-2 In contrast with his initial impression of Guyon as impregnable (5.8-9), Archimago spies an opportunity in the tension between the Palmerâ€™s â€˜slow paceâ€™ and the knightâ€™s â€˜trampling steedâ€™.
weened well to: thought he would
uncouth wyle: unrecognized trick
weened well to: The verb â€˜to weenâ€™ was still current in Elizabethan usage, but the combination â€˜weened wellâ€™ is more common in ME.
clew: ball of yarn or thread
faire countenance: The 1596 reading, â€˜a faire countenanceâ€™, probably reflects compositorial uncertainty as to whether â€˜countenanceâ€™ is disyllabic or trisllabic.

humble misers sake: Archimago, an old man asking the knight to â€˜stay your steedâ€™, slyly imitates the Palmer. (â€˜Miserâ€™, from the Latin adjective for â€˜unfortunateâ€™, here means â€˜miserable personâ€™ rather than one who hoards wealth.)
languorous constraynt: sorrowful affliction or compulsion

10.3-9 Archimago here retells the stripping of Duessa (I.viii.46). As the Spenserian narratorâ€™s rival for control over the storyline, he relates Duessaâ€™s exposure as if it were Sansloyâ€™s assault on Una I.vi.4-6. Cf. also Rev 17:16, where the ten horns of the beast â€˜shall make [the whore] desolate and nakedâ€™, glossed in the Geneva Bible as foretelling the overthrow of Rome by formerly subject nations.
lewd rybauld: These terms have a range of meanings, but context suggests â€˜lascivious, sexually unprincipled villainâ€™.
advaunst: put forth, put into action

â€‹advaunst: Only in the following line does it become clear that the word is an adjective modifying â€˜lustâ€™ rather than a verb with â€˜rybauldâ€™ as its subject, a stylistic effect in which â€˜advaunstâ€™ seems to retreat as the reading moves forward.
corps: body
sheene: beautiful

10.5-8 The syntax is: â€˜to spoil her corpse, so fair . . . as never more fair was seen on earth with living eyeâ€™. Multiple inversions push the stylistic tension between advancing and retreating so far as to endanger comprehension, even as â€˜percing speechâ€™ and â€˜piteous moneâ€™ (9.5) have made the listener impatient for information. Archimago is already exploiting the weakness he has spied (8.1-2).
knight: Archimago hasnâ€™t said the â€˜lewd rybauldâ€™ was a knight. Guyon, â€˜halfe wrothâ€™ (11.1), is leaping to conclusions.
drew: dragged
drew: Cf. â€˜tractâ€™ at 12.7.
bent: aimed

12.1-3. Cf. Malory VI.10: â€˜â€˜What?â€™ seyde Sir Launcelot, â€˜is he a theff and a knyght and a ravyssher of women? He doth shame unto the order of knyghthode, and contrary unto his oth. Hit is pytÃ© that he lyvythâ€™â€™ (163).
fact: deed
fact: From L factum thing done, the neuter perfect passive participle of the verb facere to do.
treachour: traitor
12.7-9 Cf. II.pr.4.4-5, â€˜nâ€™ote without an hound fine footing traceâ€™. Guyon is on the wrong track, following the wrong hound.
tract: trace

tract: From the Latin trahere to drag or draw. In connection with â€˜footingâ€™ and the attendant pun on metrics, the secondary sense of tract as â€˜treatiseâ€™ (from L tractatus) may contribut to the sustained analogy between the action narrated in the poem and the action of reading it.

chaleng: OED recognizes the use of this verb as a technical term for the baying of hunting dogs only from the late 17th-c, though the present instance would seem to qualify. Earlier meanings include impeach, reprove, and call to account.
that crafty Squire: First reference to Archimago as Duessaâ€™s squire.

13.4-5 More misdirection: Archimago as bloodhound promised to conduct Guyon to the â€˜treachourâ€™ knight, but takes him instead to see Duessa in her supposedly ravished stateâ€”extending his strategy of plying the knight with passionate outcries and provocative imagery while frustrating his desire for information.
blubbered: â€˜Blubberâ€™, facetious in modern usage, is conventional in ME and early modern descriptions of weeping; cf. â€˜blubbred face with tearesâ€™ (III.viii.32.3).
bedight: clothed or furnished
For thy: therefore

doe dew: This homophonic doubling signals the pervasive concern of Book II with obligation, the performance of revenge, and the conspicuously unstated alternative of baptism, figured in Redcrosseâ€™s combat with the dragon as balm flowing from a tree that â€˜overflowed all the fertile plaine, / As it had deawed been with timely raineâ€™ (I.xi.48.4-5). The repetition here introduces â€˜dewâ€™ as a key term, repeated at 22.9, 25.4, 28.9, 40.6, 47.7, 57.5, 60.7, and ii.1.2, all in variations on the sense of obligation or propriety. This series culminates in the Palmerâ€™s reference to fountains â€˜from their source indewdâ€™ with secret powers, and â€˜with moisture deawdâ€™ (ii.6.1, 4), which returns to the baptismal â€˜dewâ€™ of I.xi.48, but in a mystified, paganized version.
dreriment: Coined by Spenser from â€˜drearyâ€™, by analogy to merry/merriment. Synonyms are â€˜drerihedâ€™ and â€˜drerinessâ€™, all three frequently said to be â€˜ghastlyâ€™.
teene: grief
bespake: said to her
liefe: dear
wayment: bewail or lament
voluntarie: self-willed (cf. â€˜wilfull bentâ€™), but also freely chosen, deliberate
reave: plunder
read: judge or pronounce
read: Guyon also â€˜mis-readsâ€™ the man in the continued analogy between the narrated action and the action of reading (see 12.7-9n).
gentle Lady: The status of the victim defines the crime.
or her wrong: or wrong her
read: declare
With â€˜sooneâ€™ in the next line, â€˜shortâ€™ stresses the knightâ€™s impatience.
short: speedy
quartred all the field: Divided the surface of the shield into four equal parts.
by my head: An oath common from ancient times but proscribed in the gospels: â€˜Neither shalt thou sweare by thine head, because thou canst not make one heare white or blackeâ€™ (Matt 5:36).
Guyon: First mention of the knight by name in the narrative proper.
amis: In early modern usage the adverb, meaning â€˜wronglyâ€™, is sometimes a noun meaning â€˜evil deedâ€™.
ywis: indeed, certainly
I present was: Cf. FQ Letter 66-73.
enterpris: undertake
Thâ€™aventure of the Errant Damozell: The first occurrence of this title (cf. III.i.24.7). In Book I the term â€˜errantâ€™ is applied only to the knight.
fairely quit him: fully acquit himself

20.5 Guyon seems to be tripping over his proverb. The distinction between â€˜wrongsâ€™ that can be mended and â€˜shameâ€™ that cannot be is difficult to apply to a wrong that shames the victim: cf. 17.8, â€˜her wrong through mightâ€™, 18.2, â€˜who hath ye wrought this shamfull plightâ€™, and 20.7, where Guyon invites the lady to â€˜see the salving of your blotted nameâ€™.
salving: cleansing
As: i.e., disguising herself as
well aguisd: suitably dressed

well aguisd: Here linked to its rhyming partners â€˜disguysdâ€™ and â€˜devisdâ€™ to stress that the appearance is plausible but false; contrast 31.9, where the Palmer describes Redcrosse as seeming â€˜goodly . . . aguizdâ€™ with the device on his shield.
Cf. I.viii.45-50.
late: recently
forlorne and naked: Cf. Rev 17:16, â€˜desolate and nakedâ€™.

revest: From L vestire to clothe. In 16th-c usage, specifically to vest in ecclesiastical robes, a sense immediately relevant to Duessa as the Catholic Church. Controversy over the use of priestly vestments was a central theme of the English Reformation; dissenting priests were stripped of their vestments when excommunicated.
habiliments: accessories
irrenowmed: not famous
irrenowmed: Part of a contrast between shame and fame that runs throughout the stanza: cf. â€˜praise and fameâ€™, â€˜advaunced hyeâ€™, â€˜against his praiseâ€™.
engine: stratagem

23.9. Archimago attacks not only the protagonists but the ideal form of the poem itself, targeting the alliances among virtues and their patron knights that form the joints in the poemâ€™s allegorical armature. See 5.4-5n

vertues like: If â€˜vertuesâ€™ is a plural noun, â€˜similar virtuesâ€™; if it is a possessive, the phrase may be construed as â€˜affection for virtueâ€™, â€˜virtueâ€™s similitudeâ€™, or â€˜virtueâ€™s equalâ€™.

now he Guyon guydes: As opposed to 7.8, where the Palmer â€˜ever with slow pace the knight did leadâ€™. The use of present tense, abandoned in the next line, accentuates the return to present action after three stanzas of background information.
fact: deed
fact: See 12.4n.

in secret shrowd, / To fly the vengeaunce: Archimagoâ€™s description of the Redcrosse knightâ€™s physical and moral disposition transvalues the description provided by the narrator in the preceding stanza. See 10.3-9n.

outrage dew: â€˜Dueâ€™ can be seen to modify â€˜vengeanceâ€™ (the vengeance due for his outrage), but its proximity to â€˜outrageâ€™ is ironically apt to describe the stripping of Duessa as originally characterized by the narrator.
do him rew: make him regret it
25.9 Guyon here attacks without first issuing a challenge, in bad form.
26.1-9 In describing the knightsâ€™ near-combat, Spenser echoes OF 36.37-38, where Bradamante almost attacks Ruggiero.
pricke: spur

embrace: The etymology (Fr bras arm) and the common meaning (â€˜to clasp in arms affectionatelyâ€™) play against â€˜warlike armesâ€™, a reminder that these combatants ought to be embracing in the usual sense.
embrace: to mount (a shield) on the arm
rest: â€˜A contrivance fixed to the right side of the cuirass to receive the butt-end of the lance when couched for the charge, and to prevent it from being driven back upon impactâ€™ (OED).
rencounter: encounter in battle
in equall race: Echoing 7.9.
affrap: A Spenserianism for which OED records one other instance (III.ii.6.4). Probably formed from â€˜frapâ€™, to strike upon.
27.1 The contrasting accents on the repeated word (mercÃ­, mÃ©rcy) distinguish between human pardon (from OF crier merci I cry you pardon) and divine mercy.
hardiment: daring, or a daring deed
shame mine honour shent: Cf. his condemnation of Redcrosse at 11.2.
inclyning: yielding, bowing, or adopting a favorable disposition
me behoveth rather to upbraid: â€˜it is appropriate to scold me insteadâ€™
that heavenly Mayd: Guyon will identify the image on his shield to Arthur at II.ix.4.1-2. Redcrosse, having attended Faery court in Cleopolis, recognizes it.

28.8 Upton hears in the phrase â€˜decks and armesâ€™ a Virgilian echo: a golden coat of mail given by Aeneas as a prize during the games is described as decus et tutamen in armis (â€˜a glory [ornament] and defense in battleâ€™; Aen 5.262). The echo is both aural (decus . . . in armis) and conceptual, since both phrases balance the functions of ornament and armament, as does the phrase â€˜faire defenceâ€™ at the end of the line.
at one: reconciled
at one: With a suggestion of â€˜atoneâ€™.
bevers: visors
comportaunce: conduct
comportaunce: OED gives this as the earliest recorded use; from L comportare to carry together, emphasizing mutuality.
saliaunce: sally or assault
saliaunce: OED records only this instance.
governaunce: The action of temperance in regulating the passions. This word appears seven times in FQ, all in Book II.
you guided: See 24.1n.

St. 30 The opening and closing references to â€˜shameâ€™ in this stanza mark it, together with its repeated companion terms â€˜blameâ€™, â€˜fameâ€™, and â€˜praiseâ€™, as a thematic keyword for the episode. Cf. the culminating exchange between the Palmer and Redcrosse at 32.1 and 33.2.
fond encheason: silly reason
infamous: deserving infamy; detestable
faitour: impostor
ill bested: badly off
red: declared
red: See II.pr.2.2n.
30.2,7 The lamely repeated rhyme stresses Guyonâ€™s chagrin at having been deceived and marks his belated recognition that he chose the wrong guide (cf. 7.8-9, 24.1, 29.9 and notes).
earnest unto game: A loosely formulaic phrase (cf. I.xii.8.7) familiar from Chaucer and the vernacular romance tradition.

By this: The elliptical phrase allows â€˜by this timeâ€™ to suggest as well â€˜by this meansâ€™ (Hamilton 2001). Post hoc/propter hoc equivocation is frequent in FQ; here it marks the Palmerâ€™s return as a consequence of Archimagoâ€™s flight.
his aged Guide: This designation for the Palmer confirms a second thematic keyword for the episode (see 30.2,7n; also 32.6-8n and 33.4-5n).

perfect cognizaunce: Complete recognition, in contrast to the series of missed and belated recognitions leading up to it. The sense of cognizaunce as a heraldic badge or token is also relevant, although here the narrator specifies that the Palmer recognizes Redcrosse because he has seen him at Faery court.
late avizd: recently observed
aguizd: arrayed
aguizd: See 21.9n.
32.1-5 Confirms the promise revealed to the Redcrosse knight on the Mount of Contemplation at I.x.55-61.
32.1 Cf. Phil 4:4, â€˜Rejoyce in the Lord alway, againe I say, rejoyceâ€™, as well as Luke 10:20, â€˜rejoyce, because your names are written in heavenâ€™.
32.4 Cf. Paulâ€™s reference to â€˜my felowe laborers, whose names are in the boke of lifeâ€™ (Phil 4:3); also Rev 3:5, 13:8, 17:8, 20:12, 21:27.

note.p: 32.6-8 See 7.9n and 26.5n. Having got off on the wrong foot, Guyon here starts over from the proper â€˜markeâ€™. â€˜Race to ronneâ€™ recalls the language of steps, haste, and delay that pervades the episode. It also echoes 1 Cor 9:24, â€˜Knowe ye not, that they which runne in a race, runne all, yet one receiveth the price? so runne, that ye may obteineâ€™, and Heb 12:1-2, â€˜Wherefore, let us also, seing that we are compassed with so great a cloude of witnesses, cast away everie thing that presseth downe, and the sinne that hangeth so fast on: let us runne with patience the race that is set before us, Loking unto Jesus the autor and finisher of our faith, who for the joye that was set before him, endured the crosse, and despised the shame, and is set at the right hand of the throne of Godâ€™.
Taken together, lines 6-7 imply both that Guyonâ€™s quest follows upon Redcrosseâ€™s, beginning where he left off, and that Guyon is starting over from scratch.

div.note: 32.8 This line culminates the emphasis on guidance (see 31.2n) as it completes the Palmerâ€™s reprise in stanzas 31 and 32 of the episodeâ€™s key terms.

33.4-5 Cf. Luke 17:10, â€˜So likewise ye, when ye have done all those things, which are commanded you, say, We are unprofitable servants: we have done that which was our duetie to doeâ€™. Redcrosseâ€™s modesty here may be less than modest, since readers of Book I can hardly fail to recall that much of what he did, he did as he ought not. His language may therefore be truer than he knows: not only â€˜attribute nothing more than goodwill to meâ€™, but more accurately, â€˜more than you attribute goodwill to me, attribute nought: nothing, nothingness, and sinâ€™. Cf. I.x.1.8, â€˜If any strength we have, it is to illâ€™. The doctrine of imputed grace, whether in Luther or in Calvin, stresses the unqualified surrender of individual will to divine initiative.
pageant: allegorical tableau or procession

pageant: This theatrical term, repeated at 36.2, anticipates the repetition of â€˜spectacleâ€™ in â€˜Pitifull spectacleâ€™ at 40.1 and 40.9. Together these references evoke a pagan milieu of ritual and tragedy as one important context for the episode. Cf. ii.1.2, â€˜due ritesâ€™.

next ensues: The poemâ€™s time-scheme is symbolic rather than realistic. FQ Letter 70-74 indicates that Guyonâ€™s quest begins the day after Redcrosseâ€™s (cf. 31.6, â€˜late avizdâ€™), yet here Guyon setting forth encounters Redcrosse returning. The poem is consistently inconsistent in treating its parallel quests as both simultaneous and sequential.
mote ye thee: may you thrive
as well can wish your thought: Either â€˜as well as your thoughts can wishâ€™ or â€˜as your thoughts may well wishâ€™.
thewes: moral qualities; habits of conduct
courteous conge: ceremonious farewell
34.2 On the linking of the virtues, see I.ix.18.9n and 5.4-5n.
steedy: steady (because held with a firm grip); trusty

34.7-9 These lines epitomize the moral lesson of the episode. The pairing of â€˜intemperaunceâ€™ with â€˜wrathâ€™ suggests the traditional distinction between concupiscible and irascible passions (those caused by pleasure, such as lust, and those caused by pain, such as wrath). Duessaâ€™s role in provoking Guyon, preceded by Archimagoâ€™s vivid description of her violent rape, demonstrates how intimately the two passions may be related.
his hasty steps to stray: See 12.7-9n.
yfere: together

35.5-9 This episode varies from the account given in FQ Letter 70-74, suggesting a late revision. At ii.43, a further account of how Guyonâ€™s quest was initiated will accommodate the change. The episode offers an elaborate set of parallels to that of Fradubio and Fraelissa in Book I (ii.29-45), signaled by a number of verbal echoes. For examples cf. I.ii.29.8-9 with II.i.35.6 and I.ii.31.1 with II.i.35.7.
dearnly: dismally
dolefull lay: A sad song or lyric, and hence a conspicuously literary periphrasis for â€˜lamentâ€™; cf. the â€˜Doleful Lay of Clorindaâ€™ (1595).
their forward steps they stay: Cf. â€˜hasty steps to strayâ€™, â€˜he stayd his steedâ€™, and â€˜equall stepsâ€™ (7.9, 9.1, and 34.9).

note.p: st. 36-56 The episode of Mortdant and Amavia has been persuasively interpreted as an allegory based on the Pauline account Mosaic law in Romans 7 (Kaske 1993, 1999). The principal characters appear to be derived from the 1576 Geneva glosses to Romans. Chapter 7 opens with a similitude meant to explain the dominion of the Law over a man â€˜as long as he livethâ€™:
2. For the woman which is in subjection to a man, is bounde by the law to the man, while he liveth: but if the man be dead, she is delivered from the law of the man.

3. So then, if while the man liveth, she take another man she shalbe called an adulteresse: but if the man be dead, she is free from the Law, so that she is not an adulteresse, though she take another man.
4. So ye, my brethren, are dead also to the Law by the body of Christ, that ye should be unto another, even unto him that is raised up from the deade, that we should bring forth fruite unto God.

Amavia, refusing to be delivered from â€˜the law of the manâ€™, remains bound to Mortdant under the Law even after his death. The gloss to Romans 5:14 contains a similar hint for the character of Ruddymane. The verse reads, â€˜But death reigned from Adam to Moses, even over them also that sinned not after the like maner of the transgression of Adam, which was the figure of him that was to comeâ€™. The â€˜like maner of the transgression of Adamâ€™ refers to enacted sin; the verse asserts that, by virtue of original sin, death reigned even over those who personally committed no transgression. The gloss explains, â€˜he meaneth yong babes, whiche neyther had the knowledge of the law of nature, nor any motion of concupiscence, much lesse committed any actuall sinneâ€™.

div.note: 36.1-3 These lines are echoed by Robert Greene in Selimus, Emperor of the Turks (1594): â€˜O! you dispensers of our hapless breath, / Why do ye glut your eyes, and take delight / To see sad pageants of menâ€™s miseries?â€™ (1278-80). The noun â€˜dispensersâ€™, with its familiar pun on the poetâ€™s name, offers a rhetorical wink-and-a-nod to insiders (see Cummings 1971: 95, along with CV 5.3, FQ II.ix.29.1 and xii.42.8, and notes).
careless: negligent or uncaring
doome: verdict
pageaunts: Cf. 33.6.
36.4 â€˜As obliged by the heavens to live while despising lifeâ€™ or â€˜as obliged by the heavens to suffer lifeâ€™s maliceâ€™.
warne death from: forbid death to, order death away from

36.6 Cf. Aen 4.660, where Dido stabs herself with the cry â€˜Sic, sic juvat ire sub umbrasâ€™ (â€˜Thus, thus I go gladly into the darkâ€™). Spenserâ€™s line, along with basic elements of the situation (the bloody hands, the loverâ€™s suicide) may be travestied in Thisbeâ€™s death speech from A Midsummer Nightâ€™s Dream: â€˜O sisters three, / Come, come to me / With hands as pale as milk. / Lay them in gore, / Since you have shore / With shears his thread of silkâ€™ (5.2.323-28). The amorous lyric quality in Amaviaâ€™s wooing of death at once parodies her name (see 55.3-5n) and recalls the rhetoric of Despair in passages like I.ix.40.
froward: unfavorable; adverse
froward: Cf. â€˜forward stepsâ€™ (35.9); forward/froward and toward/fromward form pairs analogous to â€˜concupiscibleâ€™ and â€˜irascibleâ€™ (34.7-9 and note).
thee deignes to hold in living state: sees fit to keep you alive
embrewd: soaked; dyed; defiled

embrewd: Cf. 50.9. For the hands stained with blood, see Vewe: â€˜As they vnder Oneale cryeâ€”Landergabo that is the bloddye hande whch is Oneales badgeâ€™ (2187-89). Upton first noted this connection, offering a passage from Camdenâ€™s Annales to gloss the historical allegory: â€˜Thus did Shan Oneal come to his bloody end: A man he was who had stained his hands with blood, and dealt in all the pollutions of unchaste embraces.â€”The children he left by his wife, were Henry and Shan: but he had several more by O-donnellâ€™s wife, and others of his mistressesâ€™ (31-32). Hadfield and Maley 1997 add that â€˜the bloody hand is the traditional symbol of Ulsterâ€™ (59).

pledges: Children, considered as symbols of love and duty between their parents, were called â€˜pledgesâ€™ (cf. I.x.4.9), but here Amavia describes her childâ€™s bloodstained hands as tokens of her own innocence. Cf. also 34.2, â€˜With right hands plighted, pledges of good willâ€™. The series witness . . . attest . . . pledges figures a legal scenario in which the baby is called upon to bear witness, with its bloody hands offered as a guarantee, or bond, subject to forfeit if the witness does not testify.
thrild: pierced
Hynd: doe
launched: lanced

her bleeding life: Cf. Aen 9.349, purpuream . . . ille animam (â€˜his red lifeâ€™); the dying Rhoetus in this passage also cum sanguine mixta / vina refert moreins (â€˜dying casts up wine mixed with bloodâ€™).
the sad pang: death-spasm
straict: straight, immediately
the thick: thicket; densest part of the wood
the thick: OED cites no instance earlier than 1681 for the figurative meaning â€˜point of greatest intensityâ€™, but Guyon does find himself â€˜in the thick of itâ€™ in that sense as well.

halfe dead, halfe quick: Echoing the biblical expression â€˜the quick [living] and the deadâ€™ (Acts 10:42, 2 Tim 4:1, 1 Pet 4:5). With its rhyme-partner â€˜thickâ€™, quick also echoes SC March 73-74: â€˜Tho peeping close into the thicke, / Might see the moving of some quickeâ€™.
goreblood: â€˜blood shed in carnageâ€™ (OED)
thick: May modify either the stream or the blood.

spectacle: Cf. 33.6 and 36.3 and note the repetition in line 9. The emphasis on pity suggests a tragic perspective and prepares for repeated echoes in the following stanzas of the death of Dido in Aen 4.
smart: sharp physical pain; grief or affliction
hart: Following the image of the â€˜gentle Hyndâ€™ at 38.6, the pun on â€˜hartâ€™ as â€˜stagâ€™ is unavoidable.
ray: Beray, meaning defile or befoul, although the abbreviated form makes it just possible to read â€˜arrayâ€™, clothe. Cf. ii.3-10, where the fountain refuses any defilement.

40.5-9 Editors have seen these lines as echoing Ezek 16, where the personified â€˜word of the Lordâ€™, instructing the prophet to â€˜cause Jerusalem to knowe her abominacionsâ€™, declares: â€˜And when I passed by thee, I sawe thee polluted in thine owne blood, and I said unto thee, when thou wast in thy blood, Thou shalt live: even when ye wast in thy blood, I said unto the, Thou shalt liveâ€™ (16:1-2, 6). The Geneva gloss reads in part: â€˜whereby is ment that before God wash his Church, and give life, there is nothing, but filthines and deathâ€™. This would associate Ruddymane with the Pauline subject prior to baptism, but a more likely reference for the episode is found in the Geneva gloss to Romans 5:14 (see st. 36-56n), which associates Ruddymane with the subject not only prior to baptism but â€˜without the Lawâ€™. Spenser may also be recalling Gowerâ€™s Confessio Amantis: â€˜The child lay bethende in hire blod / Out rolled fro the moder barm, / And for the blod was hot and warm, / He basketh him aboute thrinneâ€™ (3.312-15).
embay: soak
with blood besprincled: Presumably Amaviaâ€™s blood.

yett being ded: The phrase works in overlapping grammatical constructions: (1) â€˜rosy red did paint his cheeks, yet [despite his] being deadâ€™; and (2) â€˜yet [despite his] being dead, he seemed to have been a goodly personageâ€™. The phrase sits oddly at the stanzaâ€™s pivot point (line 5), but rather than turning from life to death or from appearance to reality, the lines sustain a gruesome incongruity. First Amaviaâ€™s blood, soiling the grass and besprinkling her loverâ€™s armor, contrasts with the blood still animating his â€˜ruddy lipsâ€™ and â€˜red . . . cheekesâ€™; then the false appearance created by this coloring is dispelled by the qualification â€˜yett being dedâ€™, followed by the past tense of â€˜Seemd to have beeneâ€™â€”only to return in the next lineâ€™s description of him as â€˜Now in his freshest flowreâ€™. The reference to â€˜loves rageâ€™ returns us to Amavia and her fury in preparation for the adversative of the alexandrine (â€˜But thatâ€™), which reasserts the actuality of the knightâ€™s death. This dissonance-effect carries over from the description of the bloody babe in the second half of st. 40.
41.6 The subject of the verb, â€˜heâ€™, is elided.
lusty hed: lustiness, exuberant vitality; also lustfulness
41.8 Cf. â€˜bold furieâ€™ (57.8); there may also be an echo of Jer 51.7 (â€˜therefore do the nacions rageâ€™; see 52.2n).
St. 42 Guyon responds with fear, then pity (cf. ii.1.3, â€˜their sad Tragedieâ€™).
starke: rigid, unyielding
attone: at once
42.6-9 Cf. I.iii.8.3-5 for the transformation of Unaâ€™s lion by pity.
grudging: growling or grumbling
courage: heart or spirit
stoupe: submit
St. 43-44 Cf. the Dwarfâ€™s efforts to revive Una when she hears of Redcrosseâ€™s defeat at I.vii.21-25.
43.2-3 Cf. Aen 4.687: atros siccabat veste cruores (â€˜stanching with her robe the dark streams of bloodâ€™).
in her veynes did hop: Cf. A Midsummer Nightâ€™s Dream 5.287-88 with s.d.: â€˜Ay, that left pap, / Where heart doth hop: [Stabs himself.]â€™.
44.2-3 Proverbial (Smith 1970, no.123), but gruesomely inappropriate to a knife-wound.
impatient smart: Cf. 40.1 and note. The phrase condenses physical pain with the mental pain of unwilling suffering.

44.8-9 The phrase â€˜untimely dateâ€™, meaning premature end of life, leaves its rhyming partner, â€˜help never comes too lateâ€™, dangling helplessly. (For the proverb, see Smith 1970, no. 379). â€˜Untimely dateâ€™ may also echo Virgilâ€™s description of Didoâ€™s death at Aen 4.697 as ante diem subitoque accensa furore (â€˜hapless before her day and fired by sudden madnessâ€™). If so, the allusion is especially poignant since the belated â€˜helpâ€™ that comes to Dido finishes off her suicide out of pity.
sad: heavy
45.4-5, 9 Cf. 36.7, â€˜loathed lightâ€™.

she nothing drad: Unlike â€˜one out of a deadly dream affrightâ€™, she did not dread anything â€˜deadlyâ€™. Cf. I.i.2.9; given the typically chivalric context for the phrase, its irony here is mordant.

46.3 Cf. Aen 4.690-91: ter sese attollens cubitoque adnixa levavit; / ter revoluta toro est (â€˜Thrice rising, she struggled to lift herself upon her elbow; thrice she rolled back on the couchâ€™). Cf. also I.vii.24.1-4 and GL 3.46.1-4: Gli apri tre volte, e i dolci rai del cielo / cercÃ² fruire e sovra un braccio alzarsi, / e tre volti ricadde, e fosco velo / gli occhi adombrÃ² , che stanchi al fin serrarsi (â€˜Three times he strove to view heavâ€™nâ€™s golden ray, / And raised him on his feeble elbow thrice, / And thrice he tumbled on the lowly lay, / And three times closâ€™d again his dying eyesâ€™; trans. Fairfax).
46.4 Cf. Aen. 4.686: semianimemque sinu germanam amplexa fovebat (â€˜and, throwing her arms around her dying sisterâ€™).
46.9 Versions of this proverb appear at I.ii.34.4 and I.vii.40.9 (see Smith 1970, no. 761).

47.1-5: Cf. Aen 4.688-89: illa gravis oculos conata attollere rursus deficit; infixum stridit sub pectore volnus (â€˜She, essaying to lift her heavy eyes, swoons again, and the deep-set wound gurgles in her breastâ€™); GL 3.45.7-8: e gli occhi, châ€™a pena aprir si ponno, / dura quiete preme e ferreo sonno (â€˜And lifted up his feeble eyes unneath, / Oppressâ€™d with leaden sleep of iron deathâ€™; trans. Fairfax).
sight: sighed
foltring: faltering
lett: hinder
redrest: Presumably through vengeance, as in Guyonâ€™s oath at 61.7-8.
infest: attack
infest: From L infestare and the related noun infestus hostile or aggressive.
priefe: proof; test or trial
cast to compas: try to accomplish

die with you in sorrow: Cf. Aen 4.678-79: eadem me ad fata vocasses; / idem ambas ferro dolor atque eadem hora tulisset (â€˜Thou shouldst have called me to share thy doom; the same sword-pang, the same hour had taken us both!â€™).
49.2-3 Amaviaâ€™s congealed tears invert Rev 7:17 (repeated at 21:4), â€˜and God shal wipe away all teares from their eyesâ€™, presumably because of the impiety ascribed to her in line 2.

sence: The primary meaning here is â€˜comprehensionâ€™, but the word is slippery in context since Amaviaâ€™s sorrows may in part be defined by her failure (and Mordantâ€™s) to surpass the bodily senses. Cf. II.pr.4.4 and note.

49.7-9 The language of pricking and green grass echoes both our first glimpse of Redcrosse (I.i.1) and Arthurâ€™s description of the sensual â€˜jollityâ€™ that precedes his dream of Gloriana (I.ix.12.5-13.3).

Sir Mortdant: This spelling anticipates the poetic etymology at 55.4, deriving from L mors death and mortuus dead in combination with dare to give. (The English word â€˜mordantâ€™ actually derives from French and Latin roots meaning biting or corrosive.) Spenserâ€™s etymology associates the knight with Adam as the source of original sin. Cf. 32.6-7, where the Palmer tells Redcrosse that their quest begins where his ended, Redcrosse having just exited from â€˜Eden landsâ€™ after his victory over sin and death. Cf. also Rom 5:12: â€˜by one man sinne entred into the worlde, and death by sinne, and so death went over all men: for asmuche as all men have sinnedâ€™.

50.2 Cf. I.ii.31.7: â€˜O too deare love, love bought with death too deareâ€™. The Fradubio episode is parallel to this one in many respects, particularly as a cautionary tale about the dangers of exclusively sensual love and an allegory of life without baptism.
equall: impartial
equall: Cf. 49.2. Cf. also Matt 5:45 and Ezek 18:25 on Godâ€™s treatment of the just and the unjust.
Vouchsafed: were graciously willing

51.2-4 Precursors to Spenserâ€™s Acrasia include Trissinoâ€™s Acratia (spelled â€˜Acraziaâ€™ in the index; Var 2.444), Tassoâ€™s Armida (GL 16), Ariostoâ€™s Alcina (OF 6-8, 10), and Homerâ€™s Circe (Od 10). Her name corresponds to the Greek noun ğ›¼ÎºÏÎ±Ïƒğœ„Î± akrasia lack of self-control. As â€˜false enchauntresseâ€™, she condenses the roles of Duessa and Archimago into a single figure.
fordonne: put to death

dronken mad: Cf. Jer 51:7: â€˜Babel [Babylon] hathe bene as a golden cuppe in the Lords hand, that made all the earth drunken: the nacions have drunken of her wine, therefore do the nacions rageâ€™. The Geneva gloss adds â€˜By whom the Lord powred out the drinke of his vengeance, to whom it pleased himâ€™. Cf. Rev 14:8: â€˜And there followed another Angel, saying, Babylon that great citie is fallen, it is fallen: for she made all nations to drinke of the wine of the wrath of her fornicationâ€™; also 17:4, â€˜And the woman was arayed in purple and skarlet, and gilded with golde, and precious stones, and pearles, and had a cup of gold in her hand, full of abominations, and filthines of her fornicationâ€™. These suggest a link a link between Acrasiaâ€™s charmed cup (55.3) and Duessaâ€™s â€˜golden cupâ€™ at I.viii.14 based on taking literally the Biblical trope of spiritual fornication.

words and weedes: Cf. the Palmersâ€™s restraining â€˜wordsâ€™ at 34.7, and the â€˜Palmers weedâ€™ that Amavia puts on. The â€˜weedesâ€™ here are drugs; cf. Virgilâ€™s reference to the potentibus herbis of Circe (Aen 7.19), following Od 10:290, where Hermes warns Odysseus, â€˜She will mix thee a potion, and cast drugs into the foodâ€™ (Ï„ÎµÏ…Î¾ÎµÎ¹ Ï„Î¿Î¹ ÎºÏ…ÎºÎµÏ‰, Î²Î±Î»ÎµÎµÎ¹ Î´â€™ ÎµÎ½ Ï†Î±ÏÎ¼Î±ÎºÎ± Ïƒğœ„Ï„á¿³, teuxei toi kykeÅ baleei dâ€™ en pharmaka sitÅ).

52.6 Amavia here ascribes Mordantâ€™s delinquency to original sin rather than to any special moral failing on his part. She echoes biblical usage of â€˜fleshâ€™; cf. Matt 26:41, Rom 6:19, and especially Rom 8.
53.1-3 Nine months had passed.
forbeare: part with, surrender

53.5-7 Lucina is the Roman goddess of childbirth and hence a poetic term for â€˜midwifeâ€™. To say that â€˜she cameâ€™ and that Amaviaâ€™s midwives were â€˜the Nymphsâ€™ is either literally true or, more likely, a euphemistic way of saying that there was no midwife. The repetition of the name would reinforce this irony. Cf. the birth of Tristram in the Morte Dâ€™Arthur (Malory 8.1).
54.5 Cf. Rom 7:7: â€˜I knewe not sinne, but by the Lawâ€™.
54.6-7 Amavia, dressed â€˜in Palmers weedâ€™ (52.8), here plays the Palmerâ€™s role.
reprive: redeem

55.3-6 Cf. arg.3 and 49.9 and notes. The inscription functions as a riddle to which the solution is the names of the characters, although â€˜Amaviaâ€™ seems to elide or compress L Amaviva. The name has been glossed as combining L amo I love + vita life with L amavi I have loved and the Hebrew HevÃ¡h: â€˜And the man called his wives name HevÃ¡h, because she was the mother of all livingâ€™ (Gen 3:20); it may also echo John 12:25, â€˜He who loveth his life, shall lose itâ€™. The name â€˜Amaviaâ€™ may also recall â€˜Amataâ€™, wife of Latinus and mother of Lavinia, whose suicide is described at Aen 12.593-611. Bacchus is the Greek god of wine; the Nymph, unexplained at this point in the narrative, will be identified by the Palmer at ii.7-10. Acrasiaâ€™s curse uses the â€˜linkeâ€™ between Bacchus and the Nymph to destroy that between Mordant and Amavia.
cup thus charmd: See 52.2n; cf. the golden cup of Fidelia at I.x.13.2-5.
him parting she deceived: Cf. Rom 7:11 â€˜For sinne toke occasion by the commadement, and disceived me, and thereby slew meâ€™.

55.6 Upton cites Heliodorus, Ethiopica: ÎºÎ±Î¸Î±ÏÎ±Ï‚ ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ Ï„Î±Ï‚ Î½Ï…Î¼Ï†Î±Ï‚ Ï‰Ï‚ ÏƒÎ¿Î¹ Ï†Î¯Î»Î¿Î½ ÎºÎ±Î¹ Î±ÎºÎ¿Î¹Î½Ï‰Î½Î·Ï„Î¿Ï…Ï‚ Ï„Î¿Ï… Î”Î¹Î¿Î½Ï…ÏƒÎ¿Ï… (Katharas soi tas numphas hÅs soi philon kai akoinÅnÄ“tous tou Dionysou, translated by Upton â€˜I drink to you the nymphs that are pure and unlinked with Bacchusâ€™; 5.16.1.4). For the dilution of wine with water as a conventional emblem of temperance, and for the allegorical reading of water as doctrine and wine as â€˜ardent willâ€™ (Pierre Bersuire, Morale reductorium [1517]), see Fowler (1960: 147-48). Fidelia bears a â€˜cup of gold, / With wine and water fild up to the hightâ€™ at I.x.13.2-3, alluding to the wine and water mingled in the communion chalice. On this symbolism cf. John 19:23, â€˜And there followed another Angel, saying, Babylon that great citie is fallen, it is fallen: for she made all nations to drinke of the wine of the wrath of her fornicationâ€™; also 1 John 5:6, â€˜This is that Jesus Christ that came by water and blood: not by water onely, but by water and blood: and it is that Spirit, that beareth witnesse: for that Spirit is truethâ€™.
well: wellspring, fountain

dead suddeinly he down did sincke: Cf. Rom 7:9-10: â€˜but when the commandement came, sinne revived, But I dyed: and the same comandement which was ordeined unto life, was founde to be unto me unto deathâ€™.
56.1 The timing and abruptness of Amaviaâ€™s death emphasize that losse of love, to her that loves to live entails loss of life.
wreath: twist aside
57.2 Guyonâ€™s moralizing response proclaims the spectacle of Mordtant and Amavia to be an emblem of mortal human nature.
tyre: attire
her basest part: the passions
her: Probably refers either to â€˜feeble natureâ€™ or to 'passion' rather than to â€˜reasonâ€™.
57.7-9 The distinction between irascible and concupiscible passions, first evoked at 34.7-9, becomes explicit in this formulation.
(said he): Ambiguous, indicating either that the Palmer replies or that Guyon continues to speak

squire: Square, an instrument used by carpenters to measure angles, and a common emblem of temperance as â€˜golden meanâ€™ (hence â€˜golden squireâ€™). Cf. Fowler (1960: 143). The reference to Aristotleâ€™s notion of virtue as a mean between vices of excess and deficiency anticipates the schematic allegory to follow in canto ii.
Nor . . . tene: â€˜Nor seethe in disheartened grief and sorrowful vexationâ€™. Church 1758 proposes emending frye to fryze (freeze).
doome: judgment

in the meane: â€˜In the meantimeâ€™ (pending â€˜eternall doomeâ€™); the echo of line 2 suggests that to bury Amavia is temperate in its deferral of judgment. Watkins finds in the discussion about burying Amavia a recollection of Virgilâ€™s lines describing Proserpineâ€™s hesitancy to cut the lock of hair that will release Dido into death (Aen 4.696-99; Watkins 1995: 121-23). Punning on the Aristotelian definition that will organize the next cantoâ€”temperance as a mean between excess and deficiencyâ€”Spenser here emphasizes the temporality of temperance; see â€˜Introductionâ€™ 00 on the Pauline and Lutheran notion of patience as suffering in hope.
vouchsafe: allow
equall doome: Cf. 36.2, 49.2, and 50.3.
the commen In of rest: Death is an inn because the travelers who stop there are en route to their final destination.

59.6-9 At Aen 6.321-330, the Sybil explains to Aeneas that unburied souls cannot cross the river Styx to gain their final rest for a hundred years, and he â€˜pit[ies] in soul their cruel lotâ€™ (sortemque animi miseratus iniquam; 332).

teene: Possibly a variant spelling of the verb â€˜tineâ€™, meaning â€˜to close; to enclose in something; to hedge inâ€™ (OED). â€˜Buriallâ€™ would then be a noun modifier, and the line might be paraphrased, â€˜But religious reverence doth [with] burial enclose both alikeâ€™.
59.9 Echoing â€˜good and badâ€™ from line 2, Guyon here asserts that to lie â€˜unburied [because] badâ€™ is as shameful as to die in sin.

St. 60-61 The act of burial corresponds to the office of the sixth beadman in the House of Holiness (I.x.42), though Guyon carries out a ceremony at odds with Christian practice. In 61 his oath of vengeance and his ritual mingling of blood, earth, and hair strongly mark the pagan character of his â€˜Religious reverenceâ€™ (59.6), and of his response to the episode more broadly. This emphasis on pagan ritual and revenge sorts oddly with Guyonâ€™s recognition at 27.6 of â€˜The sacred badge of my Redeemers deathâ€™ on the shield of the Recrosse knight, but there too Guyon was intent on revenge, a motif that recalls the argument of Despair in Book I: â€˜life must life, and blood must blood repayâ€™ (ix.43.6).
60.1-4 The two â€˜bodiesâ€™ have a single â€˜closed eyeâ€™, and seem to be placed together in a single grave (â€˜itâ€™, 60.3).

to engrave: To entomb, with a latent pun on inscription that, like the motif of revenge, recalls Despairâ€™s combined emphasis on the law and the â€˜table plainâ€™ in which the torments of the damned are depicted (I.ix.47.5, 49.6-9).

sad Cypresse: Cf. I.i.8.9, â€˜the Cypresse funerallâ€™. In glossing SC Nov 145, E.K. refers to Cypress as â€˜used of the old Paynims in the furnishing of their funerall Pompe. and properly the signe of all sorrow and heavinesseâ€™; in Arcadia Sidney refers to â€˜Cypresse braunches; wherewith in olde time they were woont to dresse gravesâ€™ (1590, 308). Cf. Aen 3.63-4, stand Manibus arae, / caeruleis maestate vittis atraque cupresso (â€˜altars are set up to the dead, made mournful with sombre fillets and black cypressâ€™).
embrave: adorn
utmost obsequy: final ceremony
Bynempt: swore
ay: ever
61.2 Cf. Aen 4:704 on Irisâ€™s release of Dido from suffering: dextra crinem secat (â€˜with her hand shears the lockâ€™).

61.5-6 Cf. Ruth 1:17: â€˜Where thou dyest, wil I dye, and there wil I be buryed. the Lord do so to me and more also, if oght but death departe thee and meâ€™, echoed at 1 Sam 3:17. The care of widows and orphans is the office of the seventh beadman in the House of Holiness, I.x.43.

guiltie blood: The guilt is Acrasiaâ€™s insofar as she causes the bloodshed; original sin would also make the blood itself a source of guilt, but cf. ii.4.4 and 4.10, where the Palmer will apparently reject this reading. Christian teaching would likewise hold Amavia guilty of shedding her own blood, a reading the present context resists.

face: Personification; the rhetorical term for personification, â€˜prosopopoeiaâ€™, from Gk Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÏ‰Ï€Î¿Î½ prğœŠsÅpon face or person (from Ï€ÏÎ¿Ï‚ prğœŠs to + Ï‰Ïˆ ğœŠps face) and Ï€Î¿Î¹ğœ€Ï‰ poiein to make.
golden Meane: Refers to Aristotleâ€™s concept of virtue as a mean between the excess and deficiency of a given quality (Nic Eth 2.6-9). Cf. Horace on the aurea mediocritas (Odes 2.10.5).
Extremities: The extremes of excess and deficiency, as at 38.4; also the hands as they flank the â€˜faceâ€™.
cleane: completely
cleane: Cf. â€˜clensdâ€™ (arg. 1).
sad Tragedie: Cf. â€˜pitifull spectacleâ€™ (i.40.1, 9).

uptyde: The awkward sense of neatly tidying up, in contrast to the dÃ©noument (unravelling) proper to tragedy, extends to the unapt repetition of up as the knight picks the â€˜litle babeâ€™ up off the ground, and prepares for the shocking incongruity of the childâ€™s blissful obliviousness to the â€˜sad Tragedyâ€™ of its birth.
blandishment: alluring behavior
innocent: ignorant
innocent: Ironically not â€˜innocentâ€™ in a spiritual sense, as the surrounding language of blood and guilt insists with its repeated implication of original sin.
in . . . balefull ashes bred: Cf. the phoenix, a common Renaissance emblem of resurrection.
livelyhed: inheritance
2.6 Links the baby with its bloody hands to the bleeding branch in the Fradubio episode at I.ii.30.6-9.

2.7-8 Cf. John 15:6, â€˜If a man abide not in me, he is cast forthe as a branche, and witherethâ€™. Guyonâ€™s conclusion (â€˜Such is the state of menâ€™) might seem to assume the absence of grace, in contrast to the implications of the phoenix; like the texture of allusion to Romans in this and the previous canto, the metaphor of the babe as a branch torn from its trunkâ€”in contrast to the conventional image of the genalogical treeâ€”depicts life itself as a form of death.

St. 3-4 The image of the phoenix (2.6) recalls the well in which Redcrosse is restored at I.xi.29-30 (cf. the simile comparing the â€˜new-borneâ€™ knight to an Eagle at I.xi.34). Guyonâ€™s failed effort to wash the babyâ€™s hands in this well has been diversely interpreted as an allegory of baptism and of Mosaic Law. See The Thirty Nine Articles IX, on original sin; XVI, on sin after baptism; and XVIII, on the insufficiency of the Law for salvation. Paul discusses these topics in Rom 5-7; see esp. 6:2-4: â€˜Howe shall we, that are dead to sinne, live yet therein? Knowe ye not, that all we which have bene baptized into Jesus Christ, have bene baptized into his death? We are buried then with him by baptisme into his death, that like as Christ was raysed up from the dead to the glorie of the Father, so we also should walke in newnesse of lifeâ€™. The language and imagery of these cantos suspend Temperance in the interval between baptism-into-death and resurrection into newness of life.
3.3 Cf. I.viii.40.3, â€˜Entire affection hateth nicer handsâ€™.
diverse: leading in different directions
diverse: Cf. I.i.10.9. Refers to the alternative hypotheses set forth in the next stanza; figuratively, plays out the characteristic pun on 'maze' in Spenserian 'amazement'.
in lieu of: in place of

in lieu of innocense: This interpretation of the stigma contradicts the hypothesis that the babe smiles on his dead parents 'As . . . innocent / Of that was doen' (1.7-8). The infantâ€™s shocking combination of inherited guilt and ignorance of sin suggest to Paulâ€™s description of life prior to the Mocaic law (Rom 7:9, â€˜For I once was alive, without the Lawâ€™).
Imprinted: Cf. the pun on 'engrave' at i.60.1 and note; as a token of divine wrath the stigma would similarly be associated with the motif of revenge and the rhetoric of Despair at I.ix.47-49.
bloodguiltinesse: Normally, â€˜guilty of bloodshedâ€™, but here perhaps â€˜guilt inhering in the bloodâ€™; see 3.4 and i.61.8 and notes. The word occurs twice more in FQ, at 30.3 and at II.vii.19.5.
4.6-8 These lines treat Mordant and Amavia as a single body: because he drank, â€˜they dronkâ€™, and â€˜their bloodâ€™ is infected. In line 8 they become a single â€˜tronckâ€™. See i.60.1-4n.
charme and veneme: Cf. i.52.3, â€˜words and weedesâ€™.
4.7 The conjecture of 'secret filth' infecting the parents' blood implies venereal disease.

4.9 Since the bodies have not been dead long enough to decay their stench calls for explanation, although the 'great contagion' of this conjecture may blur the line between a natural cause like disease and a supernatural cause like sin.
at gaze: bewildered
to bord: to address
to bord: From the sense of coming up alongside a ship in order to go aboard.
hart amated: emotionally confounded
5.4 'Out of your ignorance you build up great wonderment/a great prodigy', referring at once to the conjectures of st. 4 and to the 'wavering wonder' that gives rise to them.
vertues: powers
5.8-9 â€˜Whoever has the knowledge to have selected among waters based on their secret powers has been able to use them to effect wonders far beyond the ordinaryâ€™.
indewd: invested
indewd: The pun on the rhyming partner (invested with dew = in-dewed) aptly folds the action of supplying moisture back into the 'sourse', Dame Nature's breast.

great Dame Nature: A frequent character in medieval allegories from Alain de Lisleâ€™s De Planctu Naturae to Chaucerâ€™s Parlement of Fowles, the goddess Nature appears at TCM vii.5.1 and disappears at vii.59.9; Alain and Chaucer are mentioned at vii.9. Faunus, Diana, and another nymph (Molanna) also figure in TCM, along with an etiological fable about rivers.

Floraes painted lap: Flora is the Roman goddess of flowering plants, associated with natural fertility; cf. her image in Boticelliâ€™s Primavera. Contrast her appearance in Redcrosseâ€™s lustful dream (I.i.48.9) and E.K.â€™s reference to her as a Roman prostitute (SC March gloss to 16).

guifte of later grace: Echoing Rom 5:15: â€˜But yet the gift is not so, as is the offence: for if through the offence of one, many be dead, muche more the grace of God, and the gift by grace, which is by one man Jesus Christ, hathe abunded unto manyâ€™.
vertue: Cf. 5.6.

St. 7-9 Cf. the enchanted well and indwelling nymph at I.vii.4-6. Spenser may base the fable of the wellâ€™s nymph on the legend of St. Winifred. For Draytonâ€™s account of â€˜the sacred fount of Winifridâ€™, see Polyolbion 10.124-164. There is a corresponding well in the episode from Trissino that Spenser draws on in Book II (Lâ€™Italia 4.673-697; see i.8-34n).
hartlesse Hynd: timid doe
hartlesse Hynd: With a pun on â€˜hartâ€™ as stag, â€˜doe without a mateâ€™.
Robucke: the male of a species of deer found in Europe and Asia

Dan Faunus: See 6.2n. Faunus is a wood-god, identified with Pan and associated with fertility but also specifically with amorous pursuit: Horace calls him Nympharum fugientum amator (â€˜lover of the flying nymphsâ€™; Odes 3.18.1).

chace: Since the stanza form calls for a â€˜bâ€™-rhyme to end line 7, editors often emend to â€˜prayâ€™ (prey) or â€˜rayâ€™. Some who consider the repetition of â€˜chace, / And chacedâ€™ to be deliberate have devised interpretations for the violation; Kellogg and Steele 1965 note â€˜four other passages in Book II, and nine altogether in The Faerie Queene, in which the early editions give a non-rhyming word in a position where an obvious synonym would rhyme . . . . The other imperfect rhymes in Book II are at ii.42.6, iii.28.7, viii.29.7, and xii.54.7â€™.
of shame affrayd: See i.20.5, 30.1-9 and notes.

Diana: The goddess of chastity and of the hunt. The nymphâ€™s invocation of Diana and subsequent metamorphosis mark this episode as a self-conscious imitation of Ovidâ€™s Metamorphoses; often cited are the transformations of Daphne in Book 1, Arethusa in Book 5, Biblis in Book 9, and Acis in Book 13.
dismayd: With its rhyme-partner â€˜maydâ€™, emphasizes the paradox that the nymph can remain a maid (virgin) only by ceasing to be a maid (girl).

mate: The play on 'mayd' and 'mate' suggests by way of a pun that the miraculous well left Guyon 'amated' at 5.3 because its singularity derives from the nymph's refusal to be 'amated' (matched, joined) by Faunus. The fountainâ€™s nymph is, therefore, figuratively the antithesis of the water that mixes with wine in the curse Acrasia uses to deceive Mortdant: â€˜So soone as Bacchus with the Nymphe does linckeâ€™ (i.55.6 and note).

vertues: moral qualities; natural properties
tryde: proven

10.2-9 The Palmerâ€™s interpretation of the bloody hands as a testament to Amaviaâ€™s â€˜innocenceâ€™ neglects the Christian belief that suicide is a mortal sin; his sense of them as a â€˜sacred Symboleâ€™ calling for â€˜revengementâ€™ violates the Biblical injunction against revenge, and aligns Amavia uncomfortably with Duessa, in the preceding episode, as a distressed damsel appealing for vengeance. (See i.37.8n for the topical allusion in the 'bloody hand'.)
innocence: See 1.7-8, 4.3, and i.37.6-9. In the theological allegory, the mother 'in her last testament' bequeaths not innocence but original sin.
Symbole: OED identifies this as the earliest recorded use of the word in its modern sense to mean something that stands for something else.
dwell: Cf. Romans 7.17, 'the sin that dwelleth in me'.
moniment: warning or memorial
sell: saddle

11.7-12.4 The import of Guyonâ€™s loss is suggested by the shared etymology of â€˜chivalryâ€™ and â€˜cavalryâ€™ from L caballarius horseman. In Le Morte Darthur, Sir Lamerok berates his brothers, unhorsed in jousting, by demanding â€˜What is a knyght but whan he is on horseback? For I sette nat by a knytht whan he is on footeâ€™ (10.48).
barbes: protective coverings for the chest and flanks of a war-horse
double burden: his own armor and that of Mordant
Built on a rocke: Cf. the â€˜wise man, which hathe buylded his house on a rockeâ€™ at Matt 7:24.
by equall shares in equall fee: The sisters inherit equal shares and equal rights to hold those shares.
drew them in partes: divided them into factions
13.7-9: Cf. Aristotle: â€˜the extreme states are contrary both to the intermediate state and to each other, and the intermediate to the extremesâ€™ (Nic Eth 2.8).

Medina: From L mediana in the middle, and perhaps also medens physician. Cf. SC Julye 234, Thomalinâ€™s emblem, In medio virtus, glossed by E.K. with reference to â€˜the saying of olde Philosophers, that vertue dwelleth in the middest, being environed with two contrary vicesâ€™. At Julye 236 this motto is counterpoised by Morrellâ€™s emblem, In summo foelicitas, which replies to Thomalinâ€™s â€˜with continuaunce of the same Philosophers opinion, that albeit all bountye dwelleth in mediocritie, yet perfect felicitye dewlleth in supramacieâ€™. The philosophers in question, who start out in the plural and then seem to coalesce into a single figure, are apparently Aristotle and Plato respectively.
enterprize: take in hand
enterprize: From L inter between and prendere to take.
courted: paid courteous attention to
15.6 â€˜Beyond what would normally be the rational capacity of one so youngâ€™ (the paradoxical excess of the golden mean).
her selfe . . . did frame: directed her efforts and actions
wanton: Has a wide range of possible meanings, from â€˜undisciplinedâ€™ to â€˜amorousâ€™ to â€˜lewd and lasciviousâ€™.
Accourting: Cf. â€˜comely courtedâ€™ at 15.2 above; this courting may simply be extravagant (â€˜lavishâ€™), or it may be amorous. OED cites only this instance.
countenaunce: make a show of or pretend
countenaunce: OED cites only this instance for the sense â€˜make a show of or pretendâ€™.

Huddibras: The â€˜great . . . nameâ€™ of an early English king whose role in Briton moniments resembles that of Medina rather than of his namesake in this episode: â€˜Next Huddibras his realm did not encrease, / But taught the land from wearie wars to ceaseâ€™ (x.25.4-5). The knightâ€™s name associates him here with his chief quality (Huddi hardy + Fr bras arm) and with his armor of â€˜shyning brasâ€™; cf. Job 6.12, â€˜is my flesh of brasse?â€™
17.8 He was more temperamental than courageous.
Sansloy: Last seen at the close of I.vi engaged in combat with Sir Satyrane.
middle space: Medinaâ€™s proper turf.
the scorned life to quell: Their rage is ultimately suicidal.

20.6-7 See 12.6-9n and 20.5n; the conflict between extremes not only disturbs the occupants of the castle but threatens its foundations (â€˜raysdâ€™ = â€˜raisedâ€™, but the secondary sense â€˜razedâ€™ threatens).
fouldring: flashing
fouldring: From L fulgere to flash and fulgur lightning-flash.
enraunged: arranged in an orderly fashion

21.5-9 The anticlimax of â€˜to understondâ€™ emphasizes the comedy of Guyunâ€™s rushing in wielding sword and shield complete with Homeric epithet (â€˜sunbroadâ€™) in order to â€˜pacifieâ€™ the combatantsâ€”not â€˜as well he canâ€™ (which the meter would favor), but â€˜well as he canâ€™, which turns out to be not very well. Having lost his horse and borne his armor as a â€˜burdenâ€™ (12.4), Guyon is learning the limited value of armor and weapons in achieving temperance.
lybicke: Lybian
lybicke Ocean: Presumably the desert with its wave-like dunes, since bears and tigers would be unlikely to fight in a literal ocean.
surbet: footsore, bruised
surbet: Cf. III.iv.34.5.

St. 24 Cf. Ariosto, OF 21.53.1-6: Come ne lâ€™atro mar legno talora, / che da duo venti sia percosso e vinto, / châ€™ora uno inanzi lâ€™ha mandato, et ora / un altro al primo termine respinto, / e lâ€™han girato da poppa e da prora, / dal piÃ¹ possente al fin resta sospinto (â€˜As a ship on the high seas will sometimes be driven and buffeted by two winds, and one wind will thrust it onwards until the opposing wind blows it back whence it came; and it is slewed round, stem and tern, by the winds until the stronger of the two prevailsâ€™).
conduct: handling

dismade: Dismayed, i.e. discouraged, but the secondary pun â€˜dis-madeâ€™ undercuts the narratorâ€™s double . . praise (25.9) by suggesting that Guyonâ€™s intervention partakes of the same destructive impulses that motivate the combatants. Cf. 20.5-7 and notes, and note further how Guyon ceases to be differentiated from the other two knights in 26.1-27.1, where the adjectives â€˜valiauntâ€™, â€˜miserableâ€™, and â€˜furiousâ€™ apply equally to all three.
darraine: engage in (combat)
darraine: With an emphasis (ironic, here) on the orderly drawing up of ranks in preparation for battle (cf. â€˜enraungedâ€™, 21.4).
triple warre: Cf. 13.7-9n.
jarre: strife
St. 27-33 Cf. IV.iii.46-52, where Cambina reconciles Triamond and Cambel.
tresses torne, / And naked brest: Conventional signs of grief.
bad: past tense of â€˜bidâ€™ (command)
bad: The line-ending floats â€˜not goodâ€™ as a momentary (and apt) possibility.
pursew the end of: not put a stop to, but fight to the finish of
revoke: restrain, hold in check; or call back (to a state of reason)
fell: ferocious

Erinnys: The Erinyes (Roman name, Furies) are spirits of vengeance in Greek myth. Cf. â€˜mortal vengeaunceâ€™ and â€˜fowle revenging rageâ€™ at 30.4 and 30.9, as well as i.61.7, ii.10.8, and the repetition of â€˜bloodguiltinesseâ€™ cited in ii.4.5n. See also E.K.â€™s gloss to SC Nov 164 naming the three Furies.
29.2-3 At Aen 7.456-57 one of the Furies, Allecto, flings a torch at Turnus et atro / lumine fumantis fixit sub pectore taedas (â€˜and fixed in his breast the brand, smoking with lurid lightâ€™).
parts: attributes
thrust: stab
thrust: By metathesis, a 16th-c form of â€˜thirstâ€™.
liefest: dearest
jarre: strife
lovely Concord: See IV.x.34-35.
31.3 Cf. i.57.7-8, â€˜The strong it weakens with infirmitie, / And with bold fury armes the weakest hartâ€™.
Olive girlond: Cf. SC Apr 124, â€˜Olives bene for peaceâ€™.
meeds: rewards
appall: subdue
abase: bow
requests: petitions
requests: Subjects petitioning the king were heard by a part of the council called the Court of Requests.

32.9 I.e., they gave their word as knights to observe the terms of the treaty.
treague: truce
treague: From medieval Latin treuga and Goth triggwa, covenant.
grace to reconcile: to restore good feeling or mutual regard
grace to reconcile: L gratiam reconciliare.
to spoile / Themselves of soiled arms: to take off their armor, soiled in combat
froward: stubborn, perverse
all were they: although they were
34.6-8 Cf. Ps 39:11, â€˜When thou wt [with] rebukes doest chastise man for iniquitie, thou as a mothe makest his beautie to consume: surely every man is vanitieâ€™.
grutch: grouch or grudge
frett: consume
thâ€™utter: the outermost
cheare: hospitality
Elissa: From Gr ÎµÎ»Î±ÏƒÏƒÏ‰Î½ elassÅn (â€˜too little, inferiorâ€™). Cf. 34.9: having â€˜too littleâ€™ appetite for pleasure, she presumably considers the â€˜cheare . . . too mutchâ€™.
solace: enjoyment
froward: hostile
governaunce: conduct

Perissa: from Gr Ï€ÎµÏÎ¹ÏƒÏƒoÏ‚ perissos (â€˜too much, excessiveâ€™), would be the sister who â€˜thought her [Medinaâ€™s] cheare too litleâ€™ (34.9). Throughout these stanzas Spenser plays with the irony of apparent opposites that actually mirror each other.
light: frivolous; also, wanton or unchaste

measure in her mood: In late medieval music â€˜moodâ€™ is a technical term used in describing aspects of rhythm, as for example in the singing of psalms. OED cites Sternhold et al. 1572: â€˜To set out a full and absolute knowledge of the nature of the Scale: what moodes there are, & how many: what is perfection, what imperfection . . .â€™ (sig. Aviiv).
poured out in pleasure: Cf. I.vii.7.2, where Redcrosse lies â€˜pourd out in loosnesseâ€™.
exceeded her owne might: outdid herself
tire: attire
pranck: adorn
mineon: companion kept for sexual favors
francker franion: less restrained paramour
parts: qualities
Malecontent: A common character-type in Elizabethan and Jacobean drama; eventually (1604) the title of a play attributed to John Marston.
hardiment: boldness
extremities: points of utmost intensity
extremities: Cf. arg.3n.
outrage: extravagance
forward . . . froward: Cf. i.37.1n.
accorage: hearten
kept . . . her selfe in heed: kept watch over herself
attempered: harmonized
39.3-4 The turn from feasting to storytelling is repeated several times in Homer and Virgil, e.g. Il 1.469, Od 8.430-32, Aen 1.723, Aen 8.184-85.

39.8-9 Cf. Aen 2.1-2: Conticuere omnes intentique ora tenebant. / inde toro pater Aeneas sic orsus ab alto (â€˜All were hushed, and held their gaze bent upon him; then from his lofty couch father Aeneas thus beganâ€™).
lofty seige: place of honor
shene: bright
sustene: sustain
40.9 Echoing Ps 85:10, â€˜Mercie and trueth shal mete: righteousnes and peace shal kisse one anotherâ€™.
Idole: image

Idole: It is conventional to say that a monarch is the earthly resemblance of Godâ€™s magnificence. It is possible as well to suspect that offering â€˜sacred reverenceâ€™ to a mortal â€˜idolâ€™ might evoke the sense, â€˜Any thing or person that is the object of excessive or supreme devotion, or that usurps the place of God in human affectionâ€™ (OED), but the poet is careful not to say so.
magnificence: Identified in FQ Letter as â€˜the perfection of all the restâ€™ of the virtues, and as represented â€˜in the person of Prince Arthureâ€™ (38-39).

Order of Maydenhead: Una tells Arthur that she was drawn to Glorianaâ€™s court to seek aid against the dragon by the fame of â€˜that noble order hight of maidenhedâ€™ (I.vii.46.4), alluding to the Elizabethan Order of the Garter. For subsequent references see II.ix.6.6 and IV.iv.17-25.
42.6-43.9 This account revises the version given at FQ Letter 49-52 and 70-74, where the Palmer arrives at court with the infant Ruddymane already in hand.
make: The rhyme-scheme calls for â€˜holdâ€™, and some editors emend.

42.7 Traditionally the year was thought to begin on March 25, but Spenser begins SC in January, and more than half of the â€˜Generall Argumentâ€™ is given over to a defense of this choice. If Gloriana holds her feast on the twelve days of Christmas, then this line probably refers to January 1.
44.1-2 Three months have passed.
roiall presence: Referring to the Presence Chamber, where the Queen, surrounded by her attendants, received visitors.

entrold: Cf. Zurcher 2007: â€˜a curious and apparently textually corrupt word . . . that has excited the confusion and creativity of editors for three centuries. Its situation as a rhyme-word at the end of the fourth line of its stanza . . . links â€˜worldâ€™ to â€˜holdâ€™ and â€˜toldâ€™, which without . . . some phonetically hingeing or elastic word cannot be knit successfully together; its function as a phonetic bridge, with the trill moving metasthetically between â€˜entroldâ€™ and â€˜entorldâ€™ (a feat more straightforward in Elizabethan pronunciation than our own), strongly suggests that Spenser intended this exact spelling. . . . [T]he word itself also combines . . . enroll and enter--the Tudor legal senses of which words make semantic sense in a passage where Guyon is swearing a sacred oath to avenge the loss of Ruddymane's parents . . .â€™ (52).
45.1-4 Medina already knows the moral she wants the story to illustrate.
bale: suffering
45.5 I.e., misfortune or evil often leads to or procures good results when treated as an example.
46.1-3 Cf. SpE s.v. â€˜constellationsâ€™. Orion has set beneath the horizon, followed in the night sky by the constellation Hydra.
wist: knew

Braggadocchio: Adds an augmentative suffix from Italian to the English â€˜bragâ€™, perhaps reflecting a common Tudor prejudice against â€˜Italianateâ€™ manners. Coined by Spenser, the name became an English noun meaning boastful swagger.

Belphoebe: Prefixes the Italian bella handsome to the Greek name for the goddess of the moon; cf. ii.44.1, where â€˜faire Phebeâ€™ anticipates and translates the name. Cf. also FQ Letter 36-37, where Spenser explains his invention of the name as an epithet for Queen Elizabeth â€˜according to your owne [Raleghâ€™s] excellent conceipt of Cynthia, (Phoebe and Cynthia being both names of Diana)â€™.

behight: One of Spenserâ€™s creative archaisms. Here may mean named or mentioned, with reference to Guyonâ€™s account of his quest at dinner the night before (ii.43-45). But since the OE meaning is to promise or vow, the sense â€˜pledgedâ€™ is also relevant.

many-folded: Cf. Il 7.220, where Ajax carries â€˜a shield of bronze with sevenfold bullâ€™s hideâ€™ (Ï‡Î±Î»ÎºÎµÎ¿Î½ ÎµÏ„Î±Î²oÎµÎ¹Î¿Î½, o Î¿Î¹ Î¤Ï…Ï‡ğœ„Î¿Ï‚ ÎºÎ±Î¼Îµ Ï„ÎµğœÏ‡Ï‰Î½; chalkeon etaboeion, o oi Tuchios kame tenchÅn).
