The epithet â€˜seven-foldedâ€™ is picked up by classical poets (e.g. Ovid, Virgil); it reappears at II.v.6.2-3 (Guyonâ€™s â€˜seven-folded shieldâ€™) and III.ii.25.7 (Arthegallâ€™s â€˜shield enveloped sevenfoldâ€™).
CongÃ©: formal farewell
conjure: put under oath
conjure: Etymologically, â€˜swear togetherâ€™.
all that gentle noriture ensueth: everything that follows from, or is proper to, an aristocratic upbringing
Ruddymane: Combining â€˜ruddyâ€™ with L manus hands to translate the epithet â€˜bloody-handedâ€™.
2.8-9 The narrator seems unaware that teaching Ruddymane vengeance might be inconsistent with his training in â€˜vertuous loreâ€™ (because vengeance is sinful or belongs to the Christian God).

3.1-5, 9 The halting rhythm and the pun on â€˜bootâ€™ suggest an amused perspective on Guyonâ€™s predicament, while the Palmer footing it â€˜no more aloneâ€™ recalls the knightâ€™s too-hasty response to Archimago and Duessa in canto i. These suggestions are gathered up in the final line of the stanza, where we read that Guyon â€˜rushed in on footeâ€™ to aid Amavia, abandoning his horse and spear.
Patience perforce: Proverbial (Smith 1970, no. 598).
kestrell kynd: a small breed of hawk that supports itself by facing into the wind

kestrell kynd: As a term of contempt it means something like windbag: thus Nashe in 1596 refers to â€˜One of these kistrell birds, called a wind-suckerâ€™ (Saffron Walden Kij). Making Braggadocchio into a species of hawk, the phrase recalls by way of a pun the argumentâ€™s statement that he â€˜is of fayre / Belphoebe fowle forlorneâ€™.
vaine: vein
vaine: With a pun on â€˜vaingloryâ€™.

full light: â€˜Lightâ€™ functions both as an adverb meaning â€˜nimblyâ€™ and as adjective meaning, in a military sense, â€˜lightly armedâ€™, while also suggesting that Braggadocchio lacks gravitas. â€˜Full lightâ€™ is thus a complex oxymoron: being altogether or entirely frivolous, he is fully empty.

jollity: Carries a range of meanings including festivity, sexual pleasure, gallantry, splendor, jocularity, and, most immediately relevant, insolent presumption. The concentrated assonance of the back-vowels helps make the point, reinforced by the link between â€˜swellâ€™ and the wind-sucking behavior of the kestrell (4.4n).
personage: Close in range of meanings (physical appearance, image) to â€˜personâ€™, but more important-sounding. The personage is what Braggadocchio impersonates, taken in by his own imposture.
portaunce: carriage or bearing
gree: favor
tâ€™advaunce his first degree: To get a promotion, now that he has knighted himself.
avaunting: Boasting, with an ironic echo of â€˜advaunceâ€™ (5.9).
bravery: Both bravado (looking back to â€˜avauntingâ€™) and finery (looking forward to line 4).
prank: show off
ranck: headlong, recklessly
dead dog: A Biblical insult specific to the books of Samuel: 1 Sam 24:14, 2 Sam 9:8, 2 Sam 16:9.
thrall: slave or prisoner
Miser: wretch
Offall: piece of refuse
hold of him in fee: Legal phraseology (to hold land by virtue of oneâ€™s submission to a feudal lord) marking the scene as a parody of the homage ritual.
liegeman: vassal sworn to the service of his feudal lord

note.p: Trompart: From Fr tromper to deceive, by analogy to English â€˜trumpâ€™, â€˜trumpantâ€™, â€˜trumperyâ€™, also derived from tromper and its forms trompant and tromperie. Parodies the â€˜trumpets sterneâ€™ of I.pr.1.4 much as Trompart parodies the function of the epic poet to â€˜blazon forthâ€™ praise; the name thus seems to emerge comically from the â€˜bellowesâ€™ of the preceding line.

Trompart and Braggadocchio have been read at least since Upton 1758 as glancing satirically at the courtship of Elizabeth by the duc dâ€™Alencon and his agent Simier. For the literary antecedents of these characters in Ariosto, OF, and other texts, see the article on each in SpE.

div.note: vaunting eye: Translating the name â€˜Braggadocchioâ€™ through a pun on Ital occhio eye (Hamilton 2001).

10.3-4 Note the echo of 4.5 in â€˜Vainegloriousâ€™ and the expansion of 4.4 (â€˜kestrell kindâ€™) in â€˜when fluttring wind does blow / In his light winges, is lifted up to skyeâ€™â€”amplifying both the argumentâ€™s anticipatory pun on â€˜fowleâ€™ and the name â€˜Trompartâ€™ as associated with bellows and trumpet.

10.8-9 Honor as the reward of virtue (opposed to honor â€˜without desertâ€™) is most highly regarded among those who are nobly descended; or, honor as the reward of virtue carries its blossom (praise) within its seed (noble deeds).
Archimage: Last seen at i.25 provoking Guyon to attack Redcrosse.
thondring with his feet: With Braggadocchio in the saddle, even the horseâ€™s gallop turns to bombast; the pun on â€˜feetâ€™ extends the parody of epic poetry (cf. 10.1n).
Efsoones: promptly
11.7-9 Archimagoâ€™s adversarial role both mirrors and opposes the linking of the virtues; cf. i.5.4-5n and i.34.2n.
golden sell: Repeated from ii.11.6.
sell: saddle

through hard assay forgone: â€˜Lost in a difficult adventureâ€™ or â€˜renounced in a difficult testâ€™. â€˜Despightâ€™ in line 8 may favor the first possibility, whereas at 17.6-9 Braggadocchio will elaborate the second.
12.7-8 â€˜Has sworn never to wear another sword until he has avenged himself of that outrageâ€™.
weened well: confidently supposed
foyle: defeat
Tho: then
louting: bowing down

13.7-8 Archimagoâ€™s lies typically misrepresent events that have occurred in the narrative, as if he were competing with the narrator for control over the course of the story; cf. i.10.3-9n and 11.7-9n.
gin: either the general quality of cunning or a specific trick
wreak: punish or avenge
14.3 As if their lives had been entrusted to him.
doughtie valiaunce: stout courage
meed: reward
areed: declare
prowest: worthiest; most brave or gallant
approved: tested or proven.
hard assay: Cf. 12.6.
to quayle: I.e. to daunt or overawe. Given the way bird-references flock to Braggadocchio it is difficult not to hear a pun on â€˜quailâ€™.
wotest: know
on even coast: Hamilton 2001 compares FQ 1596 IV.iii.24.8 on equall cost, suggesting that the phrases may mean either on level ground or on even terms.

17.6-9 A more boastful explanation than the one offered by Trompart at 12.6-8. Cf. OF 14.43 and 23.78, where Ariostoâ€™s Mandricardo, armed only with a spear, swears he will bear no sword but Orlandoâ€™s.
17.7 Comically echoing â€˜Seven at one strokeâ€™, the motto of the â€˜brave tailorâ€™ in a folktale from the â€˜Jackâ€™ cycle. See SpE s.v. â€˜folkloreâ€™.
Perdy: a mild oath
Perdy: From ME â€˜par dieuâ€™, â€˜by Godâ€™.
blive: promptly
purchase to: obtain for
what mote that Monster make: What could bring about that wonder (L monstrum marvel or prodigy).
of: off

20.4 Cf. Ps 53:5, â€˜There they were afraied for feare, where no feare wasâ€™; Lev 26:36, â€˜the sounde of a leafe shaken shall chase themâ€™; and Wisd Sol 17:1-18, â€˜whether it were an hyssing winde . . . these feareful things made them to swoneâ€™.
bug: ghost, scarecrow, or hobgoblin

20.5 FE corrects â€˜vntoâ€™ in this line to â€˜greatlyâ€™. 1596 and 1609 read â€˜their haire on end does reareâ€™, which we take to be authorial revision rather than correction of compositorial error.
faine: dissemble
Eft: then or soon (archaic)

21.3-4 In Sidneyâ€™s New Arcadia the shepherd Dametas â€˜fell down flat of my faceâ€™ when frightened by a bear, and is seen â€˜lying with his breast and head as farre as he could thrust himselfe into a bush: drawing up his legges as close unto him as hee coulde: for, like a man of a very kind nature, soone to take pittie of himselfe, he was full resolved not to see his owne deathâ€™ (ed. Dennis 1970, 83-84). Sidney left the revision of his New Arcadia (published in 1590) unfinished at his death in 1586. It is not known whether Spenser saw a copy in manuscript.
Eftsoone: then or soon (archaic)
great worth: elevated rank
stately portance: dignified bearing
stately portance: Contrast with the â€˜gay portaunceâ€™ (5.7) that Braggadocchio ascribes to the court.

borne of heavenly birth: The surmise of divinity is a frequent motif in Spenser. See SC Apr 163-65 and note, where the emblems trace this courtly compliment back to Aeneasâ€™s wondering recognition of his divine mother, Venus, disguised as a maiden huntress in the woods outside Carthage. Many of the terms used to describe â€˜Elizaâ€™ in Colinâ€™s song reappear in the description of Belphoebe. The phrasing â€˜borne of . . . birthâ€™ is pure redundancy unless the verb also suggests the past participle of â€˜bearâ€™ (carry, endure), a nuance supported by the proximity of â€˜portanceâ€™, which means â€˜bearingâ€™. At Aen 1.405, Aeneas recognizes the disguised Venus by her stride: et vera incessu patuit dea (â€˜and in her step she was revealed, a very goddessâ€™).

note.p: St. 22-31 These ten stanzas comprise a blazon, or formal pictorial description of female beauty. The primary motive is honorific, but satiric touches can be discerned. The passage interweaves echoes from Tassoâ€™s Rinaldo, Ariostoâ€™s OF, Virgilâ€™s Aen, and Song Sol, which Ponsonby in 1591 (Complaints, â€˜The Printer to the Gentle Readerâ€™) says he â€˜understandsâ€™ Spenser to have translated, although no such text survives.

The Virgilian echoes come from separate but related passages. They include details from the description of Venus as she appears to her son virginis os habitumque gerens et virginis arma (â€˜with a maidenâ€™s face and mien, and a maidenâ€™s armsâ€™; Aen 1.315): namque umeris de more habilem suspenderat arcum / venatrix dedratque comam diffudere ventis, / nuda genu nodoque sinus collecta fluentis (â€˜For from her shoulders in huntress fashion she had slung the ready bow and had given her hair to the winds to scatter; her knee bare, and her flowing robes gathered in a knotâ€™; Aen 1.318-20). These details link Belphoebe also to Diana, whom Venus partly impersonates with her virginal disguise; thus when Virgil compares Dido to Diana later in Book 1, the description echoes that of Venus: illa pharetram / fert umero gradiensque deas supereminet omnis (â€˜she bears a quiver on her shoulder, and as she treads overtops all the goddessesâ€™; 1.500-501). Spenser mingles both passages in the blazon, suggesting that Belphoebe (and allegorically, Elizabeth) combines the beauty of Venus with the chastity of Diana.

div.note: 22.3-4 Her face shines (L clarus) without blemish because the four humors are well-blended in her physical constitution. Cf. Song Sol 4:7, â€˜Thou art all faire, my love, and there is no spot in theeâ€™.

22.5-6 Cf. SC Feb 130-32, â€˜Lilly white, and Cremsin redde, . . . Colours meete to clothe a mayden Queeneâ€™. The pairing of lilies and roses, frequent in Renaissance poetry, goes back to Song Sol 2:1, â€˜I am the rose of the field, and the lilie of the valleisâ€™. Its use to describe the complexion of the face, also conventional, may owe something to Song Sol 5.10, â€˜My welbeloved is white and ruddy, the chiefest of ten thousandâ€™. Also influential are Virgilâ€™s description of Laviniaâ€™s blush, mixta rubent ubi lilia multa / alba rosa (â€˜white lilies blush with many a blended roseâ€™; Aen 12.68-69) and Ovidâ€™s description of Corinnaâ€™s blush, Quale rosae fulgent inter sua lilia mixtae (â€˜Like roses gleaming among the lilies where they mingleâ€™; Amores 2.5.37).

ambrosiall: Resembling ambrosia, variously the nectar, food, or ointment of the Gods, which has the power to confer immortality; cf. Virgilâ€™s description of Venus: ambrosiaeque comae divinum vertice odorem / spiravere (â€˜and from her head her ambrosial tresses breathed celestial fragranceâ€™; Aen 1.403-4).

22.8-9 Belphoebeâ€™s cheeks evidently combine the powers of the well and tree of life in Eden (I.xi.30.1, 48.7-8). As indirect royal praise, this stanzaâ€™s hyperbolic attribution to Elizabeth of both divinity and the power to convey it to her beholders comes perilously close to blasphemyâ€”or mockery. As Sidney in the New Arcadia drily observes of the queen of Laconia, â€˜She was a queen and therefore beautifulâ€™ (The Countess of Pembrokeâ€™s Arcadia, ed. Evans 159).

23.1-2 Expanding the epithet â€˜Cleare as the skyeâ€™ (22.3n), these lines will be echoed in FH, where â€˜lampeâ€™ and its forms recur as figures for eyes, beauty, light-giving heavenly bodies, Christ, and Godâ€™s Beloved (e.g. HL 131, HB 59, HHL 170, HHB 274). This pattern reflects both the Neoplatonic definition of beauty as light and the biblical associations of â€˜lampâ€™ (which appears some three dozen times from Exodus to Revelations).

23.2-9 The conventional notion of female beauty as a fire kindled in heaven, which is then darted out through the eyes to pierce the beholderâ€™s gaze, is elaborated in FH, which also develop the contrast between the effects of cupidity (HL 106-140) and those of chaste love (HL 169-203). Spenser seems to be glancing at Ariostoâ€™s description of Alcinaâ€™s eyes: intorno cui par châ€™Amor scherzi e voli, / e châ€™indi tutta la faretra scharchi / e che visibilmente i cori involi (â€˜around which Love seemed to play and flutter, and from whence he would empty his quiver, and which would visibly steal heartsâ€™; OF 7.12.4-6; trans. modified from Waldman 1974).
persant: piercing
bereavâ€™d: took away

24.1-6 Presumably Love has not yet engraved any triumphs in the broad, white expanse of Belphoebeâ€™s forehead, since her face remains â€˜withouten . . . blotâ€™ (22.3) and the infinitive verbs (for Love . . . to engrave, / And write) suggest rather an inviting prospect than a finished inscription. All good and honour must therefore be red in the blank smoothness of the tabletâ€™s untouched, virginal surface rather than in the text of Cupidâ€™s battles and triumphsâ€”all the more likely if, as 23.9 informs us, Belphoebeâ€™s majesty breaks his warlike instruments. Less elaborately, Ariosto compares Alcinaâ€™s fronta lieta (â€˜serene browâ€™) to terso avorio (â€˜polished ivoryâ€™; OF 7.11.7). Tasso mentions Clariseâ€™s fronte dâ€™avorio (â€˜brow of ivoryâ€™; Rin 1.55.5), while of the Queen of Media he says, Sembrava a lei châ€™Amor quivi locato / Tutte le sue vittrici insegne avesse, / E quale in carro suol di palme ornato / Trionfator altier, lieto sedesse (â€˜It seemed that Love had leased to her all his triumphant insignia, and that in his carriage ornamented with palms, the proud victor sat happilyâ€™; Rin 9.15.1-4).
table: tablet
dropping honey: Cf. Song Sol 4:11, â€˜Thy lippes, my spouse, droppe as honie combesâ€™.
rubins: rubies

rubins: Cf. Am 15.8, â€˜if Rubies, loe, hir lips be Rubies soundâ€™, and 81.10, â€˜The gate with pearles and rubyes richly dightâ€™. This and the lily-rose image from 22.6 are conventional enough that echoes may be incidental, but both occur together with the ivory brow in a single stanza of Tasso (Rin 1.55); cf. also RS 737.1-2: Quellâ€™Angelica voce che si frange / tra bianche perle e bei rubini ardenti (â€˜That angelic voice [voice of Angelica] that breaks forth between white pearls and [bei] fiery rubiesâ€™; Rizzoli 1.713). Ariosto combines coral and pearls with the lily and rose in the description of Isabel: interotta da fervidi signiozzi, / che dai corali e da le preziose / perle uscir fanno i dolci accenti mozzi. / Le lacrime scendean tra gigli e rose (â€˜ardent sighs kept interrupting the flow of soft words which issued brokenly from her coral lips, which parted to disclose such precious pearls. Her tears descended between lily and roseâ€™; OF 12.94.2-5; trans. Waldman, modified in last line).
silver sound: â€˜Silverâ€™ is one of Spenserâ€™s favorite adjectives: cf. SC June 61 and note.

25.1-2 Cf. Am 40.3-4: â€˜on each eyelid sweetly doe appeare / an hundred Graces as in shade to sitâ€™, and SC June 25 gloss: â€˜thys same Poete in his Pageaunts sayth. An hundred Graces on her eyeledde satte. etc.â€™.
belgardes: amorous glances
belgardes: Coined by Spenser from Ital bel guardo, â€˜lovely lookâ€™.

retrate: Either retreat (from Fr retraite and L retrahere) or portrait (from Ital ritratto). For Spenserâ€™s repeated play on the etymology of drawing and the metaphor of tracking, see II.i.12.7n. Here the combination of portraying-and-withdrawing repeats the dynamic of Loveâ€™s inscription at 26.1-6.

25.6-7 Cf. I.iv.2, â€˜Mirrour of grace and Majestie divineâ€™; this echo followed closely by â€˜soveraineâ€™ brings the reference to Elizabeth near the surface. She is a reflection both of her Godâ€™s grace and of his majesty, and (therefore) a reminder of her mortal subjectsâ€™ allegiance to their sovereign. For the link between â€˜monimentâ€™ and L monere to remind see glossary.

25.8-9 The inexpressibility topos makes explicit the back-and-forth between inscription and erasure or withdrawal reflected in the preceding lines. Spenser has translated (and intensified) Ariostoâ€™s reference to painting: Di persona era tanto ben formata, / quanto meâ€™ finger san pittori industri (â€˜She was so beautifully modeled, no painter, however much he applied himself, could have achieved anything more perfectâ€™; OF 7.11.1-2).
descrive: describe or write down
camus: tunic

Purfled upon with many a folded plight: Ambiguous because of the doubled prepositions, and because â€˜purfledâ€™ can mean either â€˜embroidered [upon]â€™ or â€˜bordered [with]â€™. The simplest construal is to read as if a comma separated upon from with, which then would begin a new descriptor. Thus unfolded, the line might be paraphrased, â€˜Embroidered and having many pleatsâ€™.
aygulets: spangles

26.9 The pattern of writing/withdrawing in the blazon, made explicit by the inexpressibility topos, is now made literal by the unfinished alexandrine, â€˜brokenâ€™ like Cupidâ€™s darts (23.9). Other half-lines appear at II.viii.55.9, III.iv.39.7, III.vi.26.4 (1590 only), and III.ix.37.5.

embayld: Spenser appears to be fusing the verbs â€˜baleâ€™, to hoop or bind, and â€˜embayâ€™, to surround. In TCM he will refer to Faunus in the custody of Dianaâ€™s nymphs as â€˜within their baileâ€™ (VII.vi.49.2); he uses the verb embay several times to describe immersion in a liquid, most recently at II.i.40.7 where Ruddymane â€˜did embay / His little handsâ€™ in his motherâ€™s blood.
gilden buskins of costly Cordwayne: Knee-boots made of fine leather (named for the Spanish town of Cordova, where it was made), ornamented with gold-leaf.
bendes: bands
entayld: engraved
curious antickes: elaborately wrought grotesque figures
aumaled: enamelled
Before: in front
entrayld: interwoven

27.7-9 As Hamilton 2001 notes, this description suggests virginity (â€˜that none might seeâ€™) and thus evokes the phrase â€˜virgin knotâ€™. Ariosto has little to say about Alcinaâ€™s attire; it is her biondo chioma lunga that he describes as annodata (â€˜her long blond tresses . . . gathered in a knotâ€™; OF 7.11.3). Tasso describes Clariceâ€™s gambe snelle / sino al ginocchio ricoprendo ornava / di cuoio azzurro, e qual con aurei nodi / era da poi legato in mille modi (â€˜slender legs, up to the knee adorned with a covering of sky-blue leather, which was tied with golden knots a thousand waysâ€™; Rin 5.13.4-8). For the Virgilian echo, see 22-31n.

28.1-4 Cf. Song Sol 5:15: â€˜His leggs are as pillers of marble, set upon sockets of fine goldeâ€™, and 1 Cor 6:19: â€˜Know ye not, that your bodie is the temple of the holie Gost . . .â€™. Given the discreet but persistent attention in the preceding lines to Belphoebeâ€™s â€˜golden fringeâ€™ and â€˜fouldings close enwrappedâ€™, the â€˜temple of the Godsâ€™ supported by these â€˜faire marble pilloursâ€™, which typologically represents the body as a whole, may be somewhat comically localized in the genitals. In such a reading, the festival crowds resorting to the temple become a preposterously indecorous image, perhaps travestied from the description of Didoâ€™s first approach to Aeneas: regina ad templum, forma pulcherrima Dido, / incessit, magna iuventum stipante caterva (â€˜the queen, Dido, moved towards the temple, of surpassing beauty, with a vast company of youths thronging about herâ€™; Aen 1.496-97).
port: gait or bearing
port: Cf. â€˜stately portanceâ€™ (21.9).
play: The stanza-form calls for a b-rhyme here (cf. ii.7.7n); Church 1758 suggests â€˜sportâ€™.
knit: fastened
bauldricke: leather belt or girdle

bauldricke: Derived from the cingulum militare given by Roman emperors when awarding knighthood to equestrian soldiers. For the traditional use of the baldric as a symbol of knighthood (and in some contexts of chastity or temperance), see Leslie (1983:172-74).
Athwart: across, usually (as here) diagonally
29.5-7 For a visual analogue of Spenserâ€™s emphasis on the baldric as accentuating Belphoebeâ€™s breasts, see the band running across the breast of the Virgin Mary in Michelangeloâ€™s first PietÃ¡.

young fruit in May: Ariosto describes Alcinaâ€™s breasts as due pome acerbe, e pur dâ€™avorio fatte, that vengono e van come onda al primo margo, / quando piacevole aura il mar combatte (â€˜a pair of apples, not yet ripe, fashioned in ivoryâ€™, that â€˜rose and fell like the sea-swell at times when a gentle breeze stirs the oceanâ€™; OF 7.14.3-5, trans. Waldman). The Chorus in Tassoâ€™s Aminta sings about a golden age when naked virgins unveiled le poma del seno acerbe e crude (â€˜the young and unripe apples of their bosomsâ€™; I.2.692).

29.8-9 Cf. Ariosto: Non potria lâ€™altre parti veder Argo: / ben si puÃ² guidicar che corrisponde / a quel châ€™appar di fuor quel che sâ€™asconde (â€˜Argus himself could not see them entire, but you could easily judge that what lay hidden did not fall short of what was exposed to viewâ€™; OF 7.14.6-8, trans. Waldman).
crisped: curled

30.1-5 Tasso says that Rinaldo saw il crin parte ondeggiar al vento / parte in belli aurei nodi avolto e stretto (â€˜part of the hair to flutter in the wind, and part in lovely golden knots tightly woundâ€™; Rin 1.54.3-4). For the Virgilian echo, see 22-31n.
flouring: blossoming
flouring: Combines â€˜floweringâ€™ and â€˜flourishingâ€™, both from L florere.
rude: natural, uncultivated
rude: Cf. line 6.
30.8-9 For a visual analogue to this description see Boticelliâ€™s Primavera.

31.1-2 Another echo from the first book of the Aeneid (see 21.9n and 28.1-4n), once again alluding to Didoâ€™s appearance on her first approach to Aeneas: qualis in Eurotae ripis aut per iuga Cynthi / exercet Diana choros (â€˜Even as on Eurotasâ€™ banks or along the heights of Cynthus Diana guides her dancing bandsâ€™; 1.498-99). Eurotas is the principle river in Laconia, named after a legendary king of the region; Cynthus is a hill on the island of Delos where the goddess Diana was born, from which Roman poets derived the epithet â€˜Cynthiaâ€™.

that famous Queene / Of Amazons: Penthesilea, at whose picture Aeneas is gazing when Dido approaches him: ducit Amazonidum lunatis agmina peltis / Penthesilea furens mediisque in milibus ardet, / area subnectens exsertae cingula mammae, / bellatrix, audetque viris concurrere virgo (â€˜Penthisilea in fury leads the crescent-shielded ranks of the Amazons and rages amid her thousands; a golden belt binds her naked breast, while she, a warrior queen, dares battle, a maid clashing with menâ€™; Aen 1.490-93).

whom Pyrrhus did destroy: Most classical authors report that Penthesilea was slain at Troy by Achilles, not his son Pyrrhus. The exception is Dares Phrygius in de bello Troj (Upton 1758, qtd Var 2.218), but as Upton points out, this exception was the version that entered into the romance tradition, where Spenser would have found it echoed by Lydgate, Caxton, and Sir Philip Sidney.

31.7-9 According to Apollodorus, Proclus, and other classical sources, Penthesilea was first seen by Priam when she came to be purified of guilt for the accidental slaying of her sister Hippolyte while hunting (the fate that threatens Braggadocchio in Spenserâ€™s episode). Presumably â€˜The dayâ€™ refers forward to line 8, not backward to line 6: Caxton and Lydgate, for example, both report that Penthesilea fought with Pyrrus and the Myrmidons for a month before she was slain (III.96; Troy Book IV.4260-64). Spenser does seem to have picked up details from Caxtonâ€™s account: the verb â€˜succourâ€™ appears there in connection with Penthesilia (â€˜When she knew that the Greeks had beseiged Troy, she went to succor it with a thousand Virgins, for the love of Hectorâ€™; III.93), and at the end of her first dayâ€™s combat with the Greeks, â€˜Queen Penthasilia returned into the City with glory and honour where King Priamus received her with joy, and gave her many rich jewelsâ€™ (The Destruction of Troy, in Three Books [ed 1670], III.94).
hartlesse: without courage or passion
Groome: a male servant
right haunch: Tassoâ€™s Clarice is likewise pursuing a deer wounded entro la spalla destra (â€˜in the right shoulderâ€™; Rin 1.53.8).
stedfast arrow: An arrow well-trimmed for accurate flight. Cf. Ascham 1545: â€˜To make the ende compasse heauy with the fethers in fliyng, for the stedfaster shotyngâ€™ (2.127).

St. 33 Following closely the address of Aeneas to Venus:â€˜nulla tuarum audita mihi neque visa sororum, / oâ€”quam te memorem, virgo? namque haud tibi voltus mortalis, / nec vox hominem sonat; o dea certe!â€™ (â€˜None of thy systers have I heard or seenâ€”but by what name should I call thee, O maiden? for thy face is not mortal, nor has thy voice a human ring; O goddess surely!â€™; Aen. 1.326-28; cf 21.9n). Tassoâ€™s Rinaldo asks Clarice qual che vi siate, o donna o dea (â€˜whatever you may be, woman or goddessâ€™; Rin 1.58.6). The topos originates with Odysseusâ€™ address to Nausicaa: â€˜I beseech thee, O queen,--a goddess art thou, or art thou mortal?â€™ (Od 6.149-50).
goodlyhed: Excellence either of appearance or of character (a deferential mode of address).
mewd: hidden
mewd: Hawks and falcons are â€˜mewedâ€™, or enclosed in a cage, while moulting; barnyard poultry are â€˜mewedâ€™ for fattening.
to marke the beast: to pinpoint its location
stowre: predicament
wight: creature or being
emprize: chivalric undertaking

nest . . . crest . . rowze: Cf. arg.3-4n, 4.4n, and 10.3-4n, reinforcing the sense of â€˜rowzeâ€™ (both technical and rare) as a reference to the action of a hawk in ruffling its feathers. Cf. I.xi.9, where the dragon shaking his scales is compared to an eagle that â€˜His aery plumes doeth rouzeâ€™.

St. 36 The mock-epic simile in this stanza unpacks the diction of 35.6-9 while reversing the species implied: Braggadocchio is no longer hunter but prey (or no longer â€˜Scarcrowâ€™, as at 7.1, but scared crow). These passages culminate a series of jesting references to birds at arg.4, 6.4, 7.1, 10.3-4, and 34.3.
silly: defenseless
fowle: Pun intended.
prune: preen
transmewd: transmuted
transmewd: Echoing â€˜mewdâ€™ at 34.3.
38.2 Braggadocchio awkwardly conflates Belphoebeâ€™s â€˜wordsâ€™ with the â€˜deedsâ€™ and â€˜vertueâ€™ they praise (37.8-9)â€”as might be expected of one whose deeds exist only in words.
Above the Moone: Cf. â€˜O fairest under skieâ€™ (38.1), and Aen. 1.379: fama super aethera notus (â€˜my fame is known above the starsâ€™).

with laurell girlond cround: Cf. I.i.9.1-2, â€˜The Laurell, meed of mightie Conquerours, / And Poets sageâ€™. As a conqueror who awards himself the laurel for purely verbal feats of arms, Braggadocchio offers a moment of sly self-parody by the poet whom Helgerson describes as a â€˜self-crowned laureateâ€™ (1983); cf. 10.1n.
St. 39 Cf. st. 5; Braggadocchio is himself en route to the court, where he hopes â€˜to be receivâ€™d / For such as he him thought, or faine would beeâ€™.
is fit . . . is fitt: Cf. 37.4, â€˜Soone into other fitts he was transmewdâ€™.
St. 40 The irony of putting this speech into the mouth of a character identified with queen Elizabeth is unmistakable. For precedents in Boiardo and Tasso, see OI 2.1.36-36 and GL 17.61-63.

who his limbs with labours, and his mynd / Behaves with cares: Who exercises his limbs with activity and regulates his mind with attention to serious matters (as Spenserâ€™s own paraphrase in the next two lines suggests).
she: honor

41.7-9 Reprising the contrast from Book I between the House of Pride (iv.2.8-9) and the House of Holiness (x.5.9), which in turn restate Matt 7:13-14. These passages also echo Hesiod, Works and Days 287-91: â€˜Badness can be got easily and in shoals: the road to her is smooth, and she lives very near us. But between us and Goodness the gods have placed the sweat of our brows: long and steep is the path that leads to her, and it is rough at the firstâ€™.
42.5-6 At this point Braggadocchio corresponds neither to Aeneas beholding Venus in the Aen nor to Ruggiero greeting Alcina in OF, but to Ruggiero when Angelica escapes from his grasp (11.1-9).
bastard: debased; unauthorized
Pesaunt: Here, a broad term of abuse implying both low social status and contemptible character.
fowle blott: For the pun on fowle, see the notes to the argument and subsequent references throughout the canto; blott signifies â€˜disgraceâ€™.

leave so proud disdain: Presumably Braggadocchio should mean to say that she leaves â€˜with so muchâ€™ proud disdain; what he actually says is that she leaves the disdain behind, which implies that it is his, not hers (at 46.6-9 it passes over to Guyonâ€™s horse). He projects his own affect onto Belphoebe more coherently in line 6, â€˜Ne carâ€™d he greatly for her presence vayneâ€™.
Perdy: a mild oath
grace: mark of divine favor
Weening: supposing
chevalree: knightly skills of combat, esp. (as here) horsemanship
erne: yearn
Furor: madness fueled by anger

arg.1 Aquinas writes that â€˜the first reaction of anger is called wrath; enduring anger is called ill-will; when it seeks an opportunity for revenge it is [furor] . . . the Greek word Î¸Ï…Î¼Ï‰ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ thymosis, which in Latin becomes furor, may imply both quickness to anger and a firm intention to obtain revengeâ€™ (Summa I, qu. 21, art. 108-11, translation modified).

occasion: See OED for the personification of Occasion in 15th- to 17th-c usage, typically as a figure representing opportunityâ€”a commonplace that dates back to late antiquity in the Roman poets Ausonius and Phaedrus, appears in the Greek Anthology, and is illustrated in contemporary emblem books such as Whitney (1586, no. 181, In Occasionem). Given the extended allegory of sin and the law in canto i, with its texture of allusions to Romans 5-7, the mention of â€˜occasionâ€™ here will also recall Paulâ€™s celebrated definition of the law as the â€˜occasionâ€™ of sin (Rom 7:8); the provocative inversion of causality on which Paul insists (the law creates sin) foreshadows the repeated compounding of cause and consequence in this episode. Cf. also Paulâ€™s admonition against using â€˜liberty as an occasion unto the fleshâ€™ (Gal. 5:13-16).

Phaon (Phedon 1596): Phaon is the young man addressed by Sappho in Ovidâ€™s Heroides 15. Phedon is mentioned by Aulus Gellius (Noctes Atticae 2.18) and by Ficino (In convivium 6.16) as a handsome young man rescued by Socrates from sexual slavery.
vulgar . . . seed: the common people
pretence: purpose or intention
borne: carried; born;
native influence: birth rather than training
native influence: â€˜Seedâ€™ and â€˜bloodâ€™ stress ancestry, but â€˜influenceâ€™ also suggests the effect of the stars at nativity.

skill to ride: Etymologically, chivalry, originally a synonym for â€˜cavalryâ€™, but in extended use a term for both the military skills and the ethos of gallantry specific to armed knights in the late Middle Ages.
faine: â€˜pretendâ€™ (feign), with a play on â€˜wishâ€™ (fain)
menage: handle
As a noun, â€˜menageâ€™ names the ability both to ride horses and to train them.

2.2 The repetition of â€˜menageâ€™ emphasizes the allegorical connection, reinforced by the ambiguity of the pronoun â€˜hisâ€™, between the knightâ€™s horse and the knightâ€™s passionate nature. Cf. the tensions in the opening procession of Book I, where Una rides slowly on a donkey while Redcrosse both spurs his steed and reins it in, or in the first canto of Book II, where Guyon rushes ahead leaving the Palmer behind. Such passages reflect the tradition descending from Platoâ€™s Phaedrus in which the passions are represented as a horse resistant to the bit (cf. 34.1-2, â€˜most wretched man / That to affections does the bridle lendâ€™). Here the passion in question is pride, humbled by the need to go on foot; in canto i, it was anger leading to haste.
yeed: go
yeed: In ME, â€˜yeedâ€™ is the past tense of â€˜goâ€™; the infinitive â€˜to yeedâ€™ appears only in pseudo-archaic usage by 16th-c poets.
slide: go astray

3.2, 5 See 10.2-5n. Spenserâ€™s equivocations echo the simile describing Aeneasâ€™s glimpse of Dido in the underworld: qualem primo qui surgere mense / aut vidut aut videsse putat per nubila lunam (â€˜even as, in the early month, one sees or fancies he has seen the moon rise amid the cloudsâ€™; Aen 6.454). Milton echoes this echo in a conspicuously Spenserian moment at the close of PL 1, when â€˜Some belated peasant sees / Or dreams he seesâ€™ a fairy dance by moonlight (781-88).
agree: conciliate
in hast it to agree: For Guyonâ€™s tendency to respond â€˜in hasteâ€™, see i.13.1-2, i.39.2, ii.25.1, and especially ii.21.6-7.

3.5-7 In â€˜Slander, A Warningâ€™ (an essay widely known in the Renaissance), Lucian describes a painting by Apelles that shows Slander â€˜haling a youth by the hairâ€™ (Works 4.2). He explains that Apellesâ€”falsely accused of conspiracy and nearly executedâ€”transformed his experience into an allegorical painting. For a full account of the Renaissance literary and pictorial tradition to which Lucianâ€™s brief essay gave rise, see Cast (1981).

note.p: st. 4-5 Spenserâ€™s allegorical portrait of the â€˜wicked Hagâ€™â€”not named until the Palmer identifies her as Occasion at 10.9â€”draws upon literary and iconographic traditions for several related figures, including Occasion, Penitence, Fortune, Envy, Discord, and Punishment. Within these traditions, the attributes, appearances, and accoutrements of such figures continually alter as the concepts they embody are redefined. Kiefer (1979), for example, describes the gradual conflation of Fortune with Occasion in the literature, emblems, paintings, and imprese of the Italian Renaissance, as the medieval view of an arbitrary force imposed upon largely passive victims yields to a rival conception of Fortune as a variable set of conditions to be met and mastered by the resourceful human agent.

Occasion is regularly depicted in emblems as a naked young woman with winged heels, not a lame hag clothed in rags. The lameness of Spenserâ€™s hag in 4.3 may echo a verse from Horace used by Van Veen in Horatii Flacci Emblamata (Plate 27a): raro antecedentem scelestum / deseruit pede Poena claudo (â€˜Punishment with her lame foot rarely forsakes the fleeing criminalâ€™; Odes III.ii.31-32); it may also echo Homer, who says that the sharp-tongued detractor Thersites was â€˜bandy-legged and lame in one footâ€™ (Il 2.217). See Var 2.225-27 and Manning and Fowler (1976).

Beyond these echoes, Spenser recombines elements from at least three sources, Lucian, Ausonius, and Boiardo. From Lucian he takes the image of the young man dragged by the hairâ€”transferring it from Calumny, a beautiful woman, to his â€˜mad manâ€™. (The theme of calumny will resurface when this young manâ€™s story is revealed). Unlike Calumny, Spenserâ€™s â€˜wicked Hagâ€™ comes stalking after the young man dragged by his hair, in the place of Lucianâ€™s Penitence. As a provocateur in this oddly trailing position, she reflects a persistent motif in canto iv wherein temporal sequences are reversed.

In Ausonius, Epigram 33, Occasio and Metanoea (Regret) appear together as a before-and-after pair. Boiardo offers a similar conception: Orlando, failing to grasp the forelock of Fata Morgana, is set upon by a hag with a flail who identifies herself as â€˜Penitenzaâ€™ (OI II.ix.1-20). The forelock is a familiar attribute of Occasion, as in the proverb â€˜Seize occasion (opportunity, time) by the forelockâ€™ (Smith 1970, no. 777) and in the emblem tradition illustrating it, e.g. Whitneyâ€™s In occasionem: â€˜What meanes longe lockes before? that suche as meete / Maye houlde at firste, when they occasion finde. / The head behinde all balde, what telles it more? / That none shoulde houlde, that let me slippe beforeâ€™ (lines 9-12; see arg.2n).

Spenser joins the forelock of opportunity to the abusive speech of Calumny, the â€˜vengeaunceâ€™ visited upon her victims by Punishment, and the trailing position of Penitence. This conception mingles figures of consequence with those of cause, suggesting, for example, a connection between the youth dragged along by his hair in st. 3 (consequence) and the forelock (st. 4) by which â€˜cause is caughtâ€™ (44.6). This compounding of before-and-after reflects the broad irony by which characters in the canto, having mistaken an allegorical figure for the causes of wrath (arg.2n) as the conventional emblem of an opportunity to be grasped, find themselves pursued by the uncontrolled fury they have sought (cf. 32.1n).

div.note: 4.1-2 Cf. Lucianâ€™s description of Penitence, as translated by Melanchthon: A tergo, lugubri habitu, pullata laceraque Poenitentia subsequitur (â€˜Following behind in mourning guise, black-robed and with torn hair, comes [I think he named her] Repentanceâ€™). Bull conjectures that Spenser read pullata as â€˜filthyâ€™ rather than â€˜blackâ€™ (1997, n10).
nâ€™ote: could not, a contraction of â€˜ne moteâ€™
walke: â€˜move brisklyâ€™ (unlike her feet)

5.1 Cf. Jas 3.6: â€˜set among our members . . . [the tongue] defileth the whole bodie, and setteth on fire the course of nature, and is set on fyre of hellâ€™; to which the Geneva gloss adds â€˜the intemperancie of the tongue is as a flame of hel fyreâ€™.
raught him: â€˜brought himâ€™, from ME past tense of â€˜reachâ€™ in the sense of â€˜give, passâ€™ (OED).
impetuous: rash
6.3 See ii.21.5-9n for Guyonâ€™s previous effort to pacify with force.
mighty hands: Cf. Medinaâ€™s contrast between â€˜mighty handsâ€™ and â€˜rightful causeâ€™ at ii.29.8-9.
6.8 The madmanâ€™s lack of governance (7.2) is anticipated here in the disarticulated flailing of his hand-to-hand combat, which resembles a tantrum.
wist: knew
avengement: Trisyllabic.
mickle: much
governaunce: See i.29.9n for the link to Guyonâ€™s rash anger in the opening episode of Book II.
wyde: Echoing the efforts of passion â€˜from the right way . . . to draw him [Guyon] wideâ€™ (2.7).
blent: blinded
reason blent through passion: Cf. I.ii.5.7, â€˜The eie of reason was with rage yblentâ€™.
at randon: Randomly; from OF randir to run fast, hence also impetuously (cf. 6.3).
menaging / Of armes: skilled handling of weapons
menaging / Of armes: Cf. 1.9, 2.2; Guyonâ€™s skill is contrasted to the madmanâ€™s lack of governance (7.2).
nathemoe: not at all
more enfierced: provoked to greater fierceness
The first of several suggestions that in wrestling with the figure of rage Guyon wrestles himself.
villein . . . clownish: peasant . . . rustic
villein . . . clownish: Cf. the emphasis on social class in st. 1, and note the contrast between â€˜clownish fistesâ€™ and â€˜manly faceâ€™.
in the place: right then and there
in the place: For the figurative treatment of space in this episode, see 32.4n.
emboyling: boiling, agitated
unbrace: loosen

10.2-5 Echoing the equivocations at 3.2 and 3.5, the Palmer tells Guyon that he only â€˜seems to seeâ€™ Furor. Having personified both Furor and Occasion as embodied agents whose features, actions, and accoutrements call for interpretation, the allegory now insists they are not really embodied agents after all. Spenserâ€™s allusion to the â€˜Calumny of Apellesâ€™ topos, with its emphasis on the artistic processes of embodiment and depiction (see 3.5-7n), anticipates this self-conscious undoing of personification. The Palmerâ€™s decoding sheds light as well on the motif of inverted cause and consequence (st. 4-5n), which complements the transposition of self and other whereby Guyon misreads his own affective state as an embodied adversary (8.8-9n).

10.6-9 Here as often, names are disclosed not when a character first appears, but in a climactic moment, to signal that the characterâ€™s nature has been revealed. In this instance, the moment of naming confirms an interpretation in which personification as such is revealed to be a symptom of rage.

10.9 The Palmer seems less concerned that Guyon repress angerâ€™s consequences than that he discern its causes. To disentangle self from other in dealing with rage is also to clarify the relation of causes to consequences.

St. 11 Cf. 2 Cor 11:12: â€˜that I may cut away occasion, from them which desire occasionâ€™. The Palmerâ€™s advice that anger needs to be prevented (L pre + venire to come before) arrives belatedly, much as Occasion, with whom he says Guyon â€˜Must first beginâ€™, trails after the fury she provokes, introduced with the words â€˜And him behyndâ€™ (4.1). On the episodeâ€™s play with hysteron proteron, see the notes to 10.2-5 and st. 4-5.
amenage: domesticate
amenage: From mÃ©nage as household, but cf. 1.9, 2.2, and 8.3-4. The emergence of this term as a motif underlines the allegory of horsemanship as anger-management.
corage: wrath
eath: easy
ydle: unoccupied
wood: mad

11.9 Blocking a river without stopping its source will cause it to flood. Cf. Smith (1970, no. 731), â€˜The stream (current, tide) stopped swells the higherâ€™, and Prov 17:14, â€˜The beginning of strife is as one that openeth the waters; therefore or [ere] the contention be medled with, leave offâ€™. The Palmerâ€™s advice points to the consequences (flooding) of not attending to causes (stopping the source).
emprise: undertaking
hent: seized
12.2-3 Belatedly realizing the proverb â€˜to seize occasion by the forelockâ€™ (Manning and Fowler 1976: 264).
nâ€™ould she stent: she would not cease
nâ€™ould she stent: â€˜nâ€™ouldâ€™ is a contraction of â€˜ne wouldâ€™, â€˜stentâ€™ a form of â€˜stintâ€™.
he: Guyon
an yron lock: Evoking the branks, or scoldâ€™s bridle, â€˜a kind of iron framework to enclose the head, having a sharp metal gag or bit which entered the mouth and restrained the tongueâ€™ (OED).
the last help: Both Furor and (as lines 4-5 retroactively suggest) the hands she uses to summon him.
note: could not
defaste: undone

defaste: The sense â€˜destroy, demolishâ€™ reflects the Latin roots of the word (de + facere to make, to do). Given the cantoâ€™s emphasis on allegorical personification, the sense â€˜mar the face, disfigureâ€™, with its proximate etymology in Fr deffacer (de + face face), suggests that Furorâ€™s defeat is accomplished by undoing the personfication that had given a face and body to an affective state.
at earst: promptly
quaild: daunted
reâ€™nforced: reinforced

hundred yron chaines . . . And hundred knots: See Jupiterâ€™s prophecy of the Augustan pax in Virgil: Furor impius intus / saeva sedens super arma et centum vinctus aÃ«nis / post tergum nodis fremet horridus ore cruento (â€˜within, impious Rage, sitting on savage arms, his hands fast bound behind with a hundred brazen knots, shall roar in the ghastliness of blood-stained lipsâ€™; Aen 1.294-96).
strakes: streaks
15.5-6 Wrathâ€™s eyes similarly give off sparks of fire in the House of Pride (I.iv.33.5-6).

15.5-9 The red of Furorâ€™s eyes, the copper of his hair, and the yellow- or orange-brown of his beard are all conventional signs of an irascible temperament. Humoral theory ascribed this temperament to an excess of choler, called â€˜yellow bileâ€™ and often associated with the color red.
rank: extreme

Guyon Furor had captivd: On the episodeâ€™s deliberate confounding of self and other, see notes to 8.8-9 and 10.2-5. The question whether Guyon will â€˜captiveâ€™ Furor or be â€˜captivdâ€™ by him has been the crux of the passage; here, the juxtaposition of names underlines the reversibility of the syntax even as context resolves the question.

lying on ground, all soild with blood and mire: The posture of this â€˜wretched Squireâ€™ echoes that of the prostrate Mortdant in canto i: cf. â€˜the soiled grasâ€™ upon which â€˜the dead corse of an armed knight was spred, / Whose armour all with blood besprincled wasâ€™ (41.1-3).
respyre: Literally, to breathe; figuratively, â€˜To breathe again, after distress, trouble, etc.; to recover hope, courage, or strengthâ€™ (OED).
recured: Combining the senses of â€˜curedâ€™ and â€˜recoveredâ€™.

caytives: Wretchâ€™s, villainâ€™s, but the more specific sense â€˜captiveâ€™sâ€™, followed by the doubling of â€˜thrallâ€™, emphasizes the circularity of Furor as a form of self-captivity or self-defeat.

St. 17-35 The following inset narrative derives from Ariosto (OF 4.42-6.61) and reappears in Shakespeareâ€™s Much Ado About Nothing (see Evans 2010 on the relations among the three texts). Spenserâ€™s is the only version related in the first person. Tales of friendship destroyed by love (or love destroyed by false friendship) have a distinguished history that includes Chaucerâ€™s â€˜Knightâ€™s Taleâ€™ and Shakespeareâ€™s Othello. The story recalls Archimagoâ€™s use of a fabricated tale and a disguised female to provoke Guyon at II.i.9-30, and his earlier use of disguised sprights to enrage Redcrosse at I.ii.3-6.
17.2-5 These lines introduce a self-exculpating motive that reappears throughout the squireâ€™s tale.
whelming: engulfing

whelming: In earlier usage, the mention of Fortune refers to the downward turn of her wheel; the sense of submerging under water also recalls Fortuneâ€™s association with the sea in the emblem books. Using the term to describe her â€˜lapâ€™ may recall the Palmerâ€™s complaint to Gloriana that the â€˜wicked Fayâ€™ Acrasia had â€˜many whelmd in deadly paineâ€™ (ii.43.3-4), especially as it anticipates the reiterated association of the Bower of Bliss with various female laps (v.36.3, vi.14.6-7, vi.15.4-5, xii.76.9). Fortuna and Occasion were sometimes described as beautiful (or depicted as nude) to emphasize their potentially deceptive allure.
weake wretch: Either one who is helpless and miserable or one who is morally feeble and hence contemptible.
mischiefe: misfortune
trech: trick

trech: Not in OED; probably formed from ME â€˜trecheâ€™, to deceive or betray. The c-rhymes in this stanza are revised or corrected in 1596, replacing â€˜her guileful trechâ€™ with â€˜through occasionâ€™ to rhyme with â€˜weakest oneâ€™ and â€˜light uponâ€™.
18.3 The shared breast of their nurse identifies the two as foster-brothers.
Attonce: together

It was my fortune: Echoes both the opening of st. 18, â€˜It was a faithless Squireâ€™, and the emphasis on fortune and â€˜hapâ€™ in st. 17. The squire, who characterizes â€˜Misfortuneâ€™ in terms of female sexual allure (17.5n) even though he knows his male friend to be the source of the â€˜guilful trechâ€™ (17.8) that brought him to mischief, fails even now to distinguish his fortune from his misfortune.
partake: inform

Philemon: From Gk Ï†Î¹Î»Î·Î¼Ï‰Î½ philÄ“mÅn affectionate. A common Greek proper name, it became the title of â€˜The Epistle of Paul to Philemonâ€™ and hence a Christian name of some currency in 16th-c England.
privitie: personal business, intimacy, or secrets
grace: favor
grace: Cf. â€˜gratiousâ€™ (20.4), meaning courteous or benevolent, with a secondary sense of charming or pleasing.
Affyaunce: betrothal
mariage make: Cf. Epith 216-17: â€˜sacred ceremonies . . . / The which do endlesse matrimony makeâ€™.
falser: very false
toward: approaching
toward: The related sense â€˜favorable or propitiousâ€™ is also relevant.
assynd: allotted
distaind her honorable blood: stained her familyâ€™s honor
stay: pause
stay: Phaonâ€™s diction in this stanza is marked by legalisms, including treason, assynd, bynd, and stay.
sad: Relevant senses include wise, discreet, sober, grave, mature, sorrowful, and distressing.

infixed: Used twice previously in the poem, both times to describe the action of stinging, first by Errourâ€™s brood (I.i.23.6) and then by the Dragon in Eden (I.xi.11.8). Cf. â€˜out wrestâ€™ (23.5) and â€˜mortall stingâ€™ (33.5).
engreeved: â€˜filled with griefâ€™
engreeved: Given the legal coloring of Phaonâ€™s diction in this passage, the sense â€˜made into a grievance, taken as a ground of accusationâ€™ may be relevant (OED).

sacred band: Cf. 18.6. Phaonâ€™s language reflects a set of attitudes and social practices characteristic of early modern friendship in one of its specific forms: a learned tradition, with classical and medieval roots, in which the formal exchange of vows solemnizes a degree of intimacy, intensity of affect, and sense of mutual obligation that modern custom more often reserves to the marriage relation or domestic partnership.
boorded: approached
boulted: sifted
boulted: The proverb means that Philemon has found out the truth. Spenser may be echoing Chaucer, CT Nunâ€™s Priest 7.3240: â€˜But I ne kan nat bulte it to the brenâ€™.

groome of base degree: A groom is a serving-man or other male of inferior position. Phaon and Philemon have both been identified as squires (16.2, 18.1), a rank just below knighthood. The distance between Phaonâ€™s rank and that of the groom is real, then, but may be less than the distance between himself and his lady of â€˜great degreeâ€™. His phrasing recalls the ME romance â€˜The Squire of Low Degreeâ€™, which similarly turns on a deception that keeps the squire apart from his beloved, the kingâ€™s daughter.
partener Paramoure: partner by way of sexual desire

partener Paramoure: The adverbial sense of â€˜Paramoureâ€™ reflects its derivation from OF par amour, by or through love. Spenser here plays the sexual sense against the polite usage in which it meant â€˜for the sake of loveâ€™ or â€˜if you pleaseâ€™. Partener glances at its synonym â€˜parcenerâ€™, familiar in such standard legal phrases as â€˜parcener per le cours de commune leyâ€™ and â€˜parcener per le customeâ€™ (partner in the course of common law, partner by custom). Spenserâ€™s mock-legalese implies that the â€˜groome of base degreeâ€™ is a â€˜parcener per amourâ€™, that is, a joint tenant in Claribell by virtue of an adulterous liaison.
that: that which
nearer move: more closely affect
gracelesse: Unregenerate, lacking decency; cf. 21.1, 20.4, and 25.4, â€˜more pleasing to appeareâ€™.
embosome: cherish; conceal
Pryene: From L prae before + iens going. Gk Ï€Ï…Ï pyr â€˜fireâ€™ is also suggested by the reference to â€˜blazing prideâ€™ at 26.3. Note the alliterative link to â€˜proud through praiseâ€™ at 27.1.
25.7-9 Cf. 17.4-8, 19.1 for the recurrent emphasis on fortune.
deface: outshine

deface: Immediate context suggests the sense â€˜outshine by contrastâ€™, but the word and its etymology also link Phaonâ€™s tale to the preceding episodeâ€™s concern with the poetics of â€˜impersonationâ€™ (see 14.3n).
blent: blinded
blent: Cf. 7.7. She blinds â€˜their blazing prideâ€™ by outshining it. In ME the verb can also mean to conceal or put out of sight.
Claribell: From L clara famous or bright + bella beauty.

as thou art: The rhyming pair (â€˜all her artâ€™) pointedly contrasts the being ascribed to Pryene with the artifice attributed to Claribellâ€”ironically, since Pryene will soon be dressed in Claribellâ€™s identity.

26.8 Pryeneâ€™s impersonation of Claribell, mingling social advancement with pride in â€˜gorgeous geareâ€™, recalls the themes of Braggadocchioâ€™s knightly imposture in the previous canto (see esp. iii.5) as well as the emphasis throughout this canto on the trope of allegorical personification.
treachour: traitor; deceiver
treachour: At 17.8 Phaon ascribed the â€˜guilful trechâ€™ to Fortune; here he more properly ascribes it to Philemon, but the accusation still serves to shift his own guilt onto another.

did remove: Hamilton suggests â€˜moved againâ€™ (2001), although OED does not record such a usage. Alternatively, Phaon may be saying that Philemon â€˜transferredâ€™ the deception to him; â€˜Me leadingâ€™ suggests that Phaon is as much self-deceived as betrayed by another.
engin: plot, scheme
27.6 Phaon does not recognize himself as the subject of â€˜hisâ€™ tragedy.
proper: own
weend: supposed
assayd: afflicted
assayd: According to OED influenced by â€˜assailâ€™.
28.8-9 â€˜I would rather suffer death ten thousand times than the pain of jealousy and the shame of disgraceâ€™.
deathes: Disyllabic.

priefe: Proof, test. The action of passing through (â€˜provingâ€™) death is central to Book II, from the allegorical tableau of Mortdant and Amavia in canto i to Guyonâ€™s swoon in canto viii and Arthurâ€™s confrontation with Maleger in canto xi.
gealous worme: serpent of jealousy
repriefe: disgrace
chawing: chewing; ruminating
29.6-7 â€˜For when, asked the cause of my outrageous deed, I laid out [my justification] for all to see . . .â€™.

30.1-5 The movement from â€˜my selfeâ€™ to â€˜himâ€™, reinforced by the repetition of â€˜firstâ€™, shows Phaon displacing the cause of his â€˜hellish furyâ€™ to a source outside himself, in keeping with the self-exculpatory motives of his tale. In replacing himself with another as the source of his rage, Phaon enacts the reversal central to the allegory in this canto (see 10.2-5n).
vengeable despight: cruel injury
vengeable despight: Suggesting an outrage that calls for vengeance (cf. 29.2).
faytour: impostor

washt away his guilt: Sardonic reference to absolution. In a Book marked by failed absolutions (Ruddymane in canto ii, Pilate in canto vii), Phaonâ€™s poison is the one instance of efficacious â€˜washingâ€™.
31.4-5 Playing on the Latin etymology of the name (see 25.6n).

first . . . last: In a canto filled with reversals of sequence (see 4-5n and 10.2-5n), Pryeneâ€™s move from first to last in Phaonâ€™s program of vengeance suggests that he imagines himself to be working back from consequences to causes (see 30.1-5n). That his confidence is deluded may be suggested by the phrase â€˜poursewing my fell purposeâ€™, which implies that he is chasing his own anger.

ghastly dreriment: â€˜Drerimentâ€™ is coined by Spenser from â€˜drearyâ€™, by analogy to merry/merriment; synonyms are â€˜drerihedâ€™ and â€˜drerinessâ€™. â€˜Drerimentâ€™ appears 12 times in FQ, and is â€˜ghastlyâ€™ a third of the time.
enforst: compelled; reinforced

32.1 The rage that â€˜enforstâ€™ Phaonâ€™s flight takes embodied form as the â€˜mad manâ€™ who pursues him. This emergence of the allegorical personification out of passionate delusion reverses, and retroactively explains, the Palmerâ€™s earlier undoing of the personification allegory (see notes to 10.2-5 and 10.9).
Till: Spenser often uses temporal succession to imply causality.

in middle space: Allegorically the place where extremes are moderated (see ii.20.3); also the rhetorical space in which the relations of first/last, cause/effect, and self/other are subject to chiasmus, or reversal.
32.5 The pattern of self/other reversal is mirrored in the chiasmus of the pronoun sequence â€˜I her . . . he meâ€™.
sore chauffed: severely chafed; raged
32.8 The metaphor acknowledges that Furorâ€™s power arises from Phaonâ€™s â€˜heatâ€™.
me doen to dye: they have almost killed me
stubborne handeling: ruthless treatment
mortall: deadly
mortall: Also, characteristic of mortal existence; capable of depriving the soul of grace (as in â€˜mortal sinâ€™).
diseasd: Afflicted with illness, but the rhyme-partner â€˜easdâ€™ calls attention to the broader meaning implicit in the etymology: deprived of comfort, tormented.

St. 34 For the polarity of strength and weakness as central to temperance, cf. i.57.7-8, â€˜The strong it weakens with infirmitie, / And with bold fury armes the weakest hartâ€™, and ii.31.3, â€˜Weake she makes strong, and strong thing does increaceâ€™.
affections: passions
the bridle lend: See 2.2n.
betimes: speedily; before it is too late
perfect: mature or complete
perfect: From L perfectus fully grown.
34.7-8 Cf. xi.1.1-4 and the attacks on Almaâ€™s castle in cantos ix and xi.

St. 35 Abraham Fraunce quotes these lines in full in Arcadian Rhetoric (1588, E3r) as an example of polyptoton, â€˜the repetition of a word in different cases or inflections within the same sentenceâ€™ (OED). The four passions on which the elaborate patterning of the syntax is based correspond to the four humors: wrath to choler, jealousy to phlegm, grief to black bile, and love to blood.
do thus expell: This and the verb phrases in lines 6-8 are to be construed as imperatives; cf. Col. 3:8: â€˜But now put ye away even all these things, wrath, angre, maliciousnesâ€™.
filth: lust; sins of the flesh

35.4-5 â€˜The fire bred from sparks, the weed bred from a little seed, the flood bred from drops, and filth bred the Monsterâ€™. The lines employ a version of zeugma known as syllepsis: three intransitive clauses are paralleled with a fourth transitive clause, all linked by zeugma to the verb â€˜breedeâ€™. The effect, in an episode concerned with reversals of sequence, is unsettling.
delay: allay; dilute or temper
outweed: weed out
mischiefe: Cf. the squireâ€™s self-exculpating accusation against â€˜Misfortuneâ€™ at 17.8, and â€˜Unluckyâ€™ in line 1
governaunce: Cf. Guyonâ€™s â€˜goodly governaunceâ€™ (i.29.8n) and Furorâ€™s manifest lack of it (7.2).
36.4-5 Cf. John 5:14, â€˜Sinne no more, least a worse thing come unto theeâ€™.
read: tell
advaunce: bring forth; raise up

Phaon: Ovidâ€™s Sappho, yearning for Phaon, laments Uror, ut indomitis ignem exertibus Euris / fertilis accensis messibus ardet ager (â€˜I burnâ€”as burns the fruitful acre when its harvests are ablaze, with untamed east-winds driving on the flameâ€™; Heroides 15.9-10).
advaunce: With tendentious senses implied: extol, promote, elevate, put forward as a claim. Cf. â€˜rayse . . . to honourâ€™ in line 9.
Coradin: Gray suggests L cor heart + Atin (2006); cf. 42.5.
37.1 As at 32.3, succession implies causality.
varlet: male servant
varlet: May be used as a synonym for either â€˜groomâ€™ or â€˜squireâ€™
soyld: Cf. Phaon â€˜Lying on ground, all soild with blood and myreâ€™ (16.4).
bashed not / For: â€˜was unabashed byâ€™
Guyons lookes: Guyonâ€™s glances
eyglaunce at him shot: Punning on â€˜glanceâ€™ as a blow or impact, as in Hakluyt: â€˜they saile away, being not once touched with the glaunce of a shotâ€™ (1589: 1.153).
field . . . wreath: Heraldic terms referring to the surface of the shield and to the ornamental border in which the motto is inscribed.

Burnt I doe burne: See arg.2n. This riddling motto makes its first person pronoun at once the subject and the object of its doubled verb: â€˜I burn (myself/another) because I am burntâ€™. It thus condenses the play with cause and consequence, self and other, that runs throughout the canto: â€˜Having been burnt by another/myself, I burn myself/others as if in an act of retributionâ€™.
redoubted: dreaded or respected
dartes: javelins or light spears
flit: swift
dight: prepared

place: Cf. the â€˜middle spaceâ€™ of 32.4. The varletâ€™s belated claim to have preempted this space of figuration extends the cantoâ€™s exploration of the relation between preventative and precipitate action.

39.6-9 Instead of rising to the bait, Guyon lets go the â€˜opportunityâ€™ for rage presented by the varletâ€™s â€˜great boldnessâ€™, checking his scorn in order to discover the cause; the internal rhyme â€˜not to grow of noughtâ€™ emphasizes that Guyon has learned the Palmerâ€™s lesson: â€˜who so will raging Furor tame / Must first beginâ€™ with â€˜Occasion, the roote of all wrathâ€™ (10.9-11.2).
to him, that mindes his chaunce tâ€™abye: â€˜to him who intends to take his chancesâ€™, responding to the challenge at 39.5; â€˜abyeâ€™ in this sense is influenced by â€˜abideâ€™.
assay: proven worth
stay: wait for

Pyrochles: Gk Ï€Ï…Ï pyr fire + Î¿Ï‡Î»ÎµÏ‰ ochleÅ to be swept away. The correction in FE, reducing the consonant cluster of â€˜Pyrrh-â€™ to â€˜Pyr-â€™, may be calculated to reduce the possibility that a reader will construe the syllable as metrically promoted. In classical quantitative scansion, a syllable spelled â€˜Pyrrhâ€™ might be regarded as â€˜long by positionâ€™ and therefore metrically prominent; the correction thus seems to confirm that the first syllable is not to be regarded as promoted by its orthography and that the first foot of the line therefore conforms to Spenserâ€™s iambic. (For more on Spenserâ€™s interest in the relation of quantitative meter to English verse practice, see the introduction to Letters).
Cymochles: Gk ÎºÏ…Î¼Î± kuma wave + Î¿Ï‡Î»ÎµÏ‰ ochleÅ to be swept away. For both brothersâ€™ names, meter suggests that the accent should fall on the second syllable.
Acrates: See II.i.51.2-4n on the etymology of Acrasia as â€˜lack of self-controlâ€™.

41.7-9 Phlegeton is the river of fire in the classical underworld, crossed by Duessa and Sansjoy at I.v.33.3 on their way to visit Aesculapius. Jarre is discord; Herebus is Erebus, generally the region of the underworld. Hesiod, Theog 123-25, makes Erebus and Night the children of Chaos. In making Erebus the son of Aeternitie, Spenser may be adapting Boccaccio (Gen Deor 1.1), who derives Night from Herebus and Litigium (Jarre), who in turn derive from Demogorgon and Aeternitie.

41.8 The hypermetric line creates an unusual double alexandrine in this stanza. The isochronic tendencies of these lines build on the marked pattern of repetition begun in lines 6-7 to intensify the archaic theogonic turn given to the brothersâ€™ genealogy.
race: ancestry
Drad: dreaded
derring doe: Bold action, courage, a usage derived from misunderstanding of the ME idiom, which meant â€˜daring [to] doâ€™; cf. SC Oct 65 gloss by E.K., â€˜manhoode and chevalrieâ€™.
His am I: i.e. his attendant

Atin: From Gr Î±Ï„Î· atÄ“ (â€˜mischiefâ€™ or â€˜ruinâ€™), + OF atine incitement to battle (Heiatt 1975: 185); the line thus suggests that Atin is not only Pyrochlesâ€™ attendant but his occasion, riding ahead to start the cycle of fury anew. Ate, the Greek goddess of discord who provoked the Trojan War (II.vii.55.4-9) will appear as a character in Book IV.
stead: place
stead: Cf. 39.3n.
confusion: destruction
behight: commanded

note.p: 44.1-7 The Palmerâ€™s comment in these lines brings out the implicit irony of an allegorical figure who combines the iconography of strife with that of opportunity (Occasio; see st. 4-5n). Only from the point of view of Atin and his lord, Pyrochles, does strife appear as an opportunity to be â€˜caughtâ€™ by the forelock. The rhyming pair â€˜seekeâ€™ and â€˜followes ekeâ€™ (like the epithet â€˜mad manâ€™, repeated from 3.5) link Pyrochlesâ€™ reversal of sequence to the predicament initially faced by Guyon and then elaborated in
Phaonâ€™s tale (see notes to 30.1-5 and 31.5-6).

div.note: rusty: reddish-brown with dried blood

cause is caught: â€˜occasion [for anger] is seizedâ€™. In formulating the reversal of sequence by which Pyrochles, already inflamed, looks for a reason to be angry, this phrase condenses the cantoâ€™s sustained meditation on cause and effect with its reversals of pursuit.
upbray: reproach (cause to be blamed)
silly: defenseless

45.5-7 Echoing Didoâ€™s bitter reproach to Aeneas: egregiam vero laudem et spolia ampla refertis / tuque puerque tuus; magnum et memorabile numen, / una dolo divum si femina victa duorum est (â€˜Splendid indeed is the praise and rich the spoils ye win, thou and thy boy [Ascanius]; mighty and glorious is the power divine, if one woman is subdued by the guile of two gods!â€™; Aen 4.93-95).
thrillant: piercing
vengeable despight: See 30.3n; here â€˜despightâ€™ suggests rather â€˜contemptâ€™ than â€˜injuryâ€™.
intended: guided
empight: implanted itself

46.6-8 Cf. Eph 6.16, â€˜Above all, take the shield of faith, wherewith ye may quench all the fyrie dartes of the wickedâ€™, and Whitney, Calumniam contra calumniatorem virtus repellit (â€˜virtue beats back slander against the slandererâ€™; 1586, no. 138b, trans. Green 1866).

arg.2-4 In 1596 these lines are revised to read â€˜And Furors chayne unbinds, / Of whom sore hurt, for his revenge / Atin Gymochles findsâ€™ (â€˜Gâ€™ for â€˜Câ€™ in Cymochles being an error carried over from the 1590 text). This change extends the summary of the action beyond Atinâ€™s departure, related at 25.4-9, to include his discovery of Cymochles in the Bower, described in st. 28-36.
apply: devote
frame: shape or discipline
stubborne perturbation: Alluding to the Gk etymology shared by the names of the brothers Pyrochles and Cymochles: á½€Ï‡Î»ÎµÏ‰ ochleÅ to be swept away, to disturb by tumult.
embatteiled: apparelled for combat

2.4-5 A consistent allegory of the elements fire (anger) and water (desire) attaches to the brothers in this canto, culminating in Pyrochlesâ€™ failed baptism (vi.42-51). These lines introduce the motif by mingling the apparent opposites, perhaps to suggest that they are closely related (allegorically brothers) after all; cf. i.34.7-9 for the anticipation of this hint in the combination of wrath and concupiscence that overtakes Guyon in his near-assault on Redcrosse.
stire: stir, excite to action
chaffar: bandy

chaffar: Literally, exchange for profit (cf. Mother Hubberd 1159, â€˜He chaffred Chayres in which Churchmen were setâ€™). Cf. i.25.9 and note; Guyon here encounters his own previous error, now objectified in Pyrochles.

prickt: Allegorically the knight is spurring his own animal passions, represented by the horse he rides; cf. 36.1 and 38.9, where Atin pricks the recumbent Cymochles first with â€˜his sharp pointed dartâ€™ and then â€˜with spurs of shame and wrongâ€™.
smouldring: suffocating
smoke: to go with the â€˜sparkling fireâ€™ of 2.6, both suggested by the etymology of the name â€˜Pyrochlesâ€™ (see iv.37.4-7 and 41.2n)
sturdy: in ME and early modern usage, violent, fierce, or cruel; cf. E.K.â€™s gloss to SC Feb 149, â€˜Sterne strife) said Chaucer .s. fell and sturdy.â€™
sell: saddle
truncked: truncated

St. 4-5 The accidental beheading of your opponentâ€™s horse is bad form in chivalric romance. For variations on this typical incident, see Bevis of Hampton 1885-98, Morte Dâ€™Arthur 10.42, OI 3.8.38, and OF 24.105-6.
shent: scolded
5.7 It is unclear how Pyrochles would know anything about Guyonâ€™s past behavior.
the upper marge / Of his sevenfolded shield: See iii.1.9n. Spenserâ€™s phrase here may translate Aen 12.925, clipei extremos septemplicis orbis, (â€˜the sevenfold shieldâ€™s utmost circleâ€™).
targe: shield
bever: visor
disarme: disable
disarme: Punning grimly on the idea of cutting the arm off altogether; cf. vi.14.6-7, where Phaedria lays Cymochlesâ€™ â€˜head disarmed / In her loose lapâ€™.
bate: bit
dint: blow
grieved: afflicted with pain and/or mental suffering
entyre: inwardly and utterly

added flame unto his former fire: Cf. I.i.19.3 where Una urges Redcrosse to â€˜Add faith unto your force, and be not faintâ€™; the alliterative echoes as well as the similar formulation make Pyrochles a parody of holiness; instead of godly virtue to righteous effort, he adds anger to itself.
molt: melted
approved: proven
warlike gyre: A combat maneuver that involves circling sharply around to strike.
saufgard: safety; defensive stance
foynd: thrust
throwes: violent strokes
athwart: obliquely
tâ€™illude: to deceive

St. 10 Cf. Timon of Athens 4.3.336-8: â€˜wert thou the unicorn, pride and wrath would confound thee and make thine own selfe the conquest of thy furyâ€™. The lionâ€™s trick is referred to in Julius Caesar 2.1.203-5 and described in Topsell 1607, which also characterizes the unicorn as â€˜a beast of an untamable natureâ€™ (p. 557). Job 39:13 asks, â€˜Canst thou binde the unicorne?â€™
him . . . applyes: â€˜Places himself in contact withâ€™; possibly a comic echo of the cantoâ€™s opening line.
precious horne: Thought to have magical medicinal properties.
fayld: deceived
fayld: From L fallere to decieve; cf. III.xi.46.9, â€˜So lively and so like, that living sence it fayldâ€™.
queint: quenched, extinguished
the Saint: Gloriana
the Saint: Cf. i.28.7, â€˜that faire image of that heavenly Maydâ€™, and IV.pr.4.2, â€˜But to that sacred Saint my soveraigne Queeneâ€™.
offer of: opportunity for

offer of: The irony implicit in â€˜offerâ€™ is contradicted by Pyrochlesâ€™ cry for mercy in lines 7-9, but cf. his call for death at vi.45.5 and his scornful rejection of Arthurâ€™s offered mercy at viii.51-52.
12.8 â€˜Do not judge your force according to the unjust judgment of fortuneâ€™ (Hamilton 2001). Smith 1909, following Jortin 1734, suggests â€˜butâ€™ for â€˜byâ€™.
maugre: A verb expressing defiance: â€˜damn her spiteâ€™.
advizement slow: As opposed to â€˜hasty wrothâ€™.
thâ€™equall die: impartial luck
thâ€™equall die: With a pun on die.
hazardry: gambling, taking risks
grated: clenched
sandy: yellowish red
sandy: Cf. Furorâ€™s red eyes, copper hair, and tawny beard (iv.15.5-9n).
14.9 â€˜Whose bounty he wondered at more than his might, yet he wondered at bothâ€™; or, â€˜Whose bounty was greater than his might, yet he wondered at bothâ€™.
St. 15 The narrator addresses Guyon in similar terms at III.i.7.5-9.
15.5 â€˜Yet soon gained far more than he had lostâ€™.
15.9 Cf. Guyonâ€™s self-defeating combat with Furor, iv.8.8-9.
16.1 Echoing Medinaâ€™s exhortation, â€˜O fly from wrath, fly, O my liefest Lordâ€™ (ii.30.5).
lesser partes: The bodily sources of the passions, internal organs and humors.
jarre: discord
hartmurdring love: Like that of Mortdant and Amavia.
16.7-9 Echoing Redcrosseâ€™s question to Guyon at i.29.5-9.
dread: dreadfulness
St. 17 Pyrochles misconstrues the allegorical tableau as an opportunity for chivalric rescue. See 3.2n and cf. Archimagoâ€™s provocation of Guyon, i.9-11.
17.2-5 It is unclear who could have made this complaint, since Pyrochles arrives just after Atin flees (see 2.9).
bare: unprotected
effort: compulsion
effort: From â€˜efforceâ€™; cf. xii.43.6-7, â€˜wisdomes power, and temperaunces might, / By which the mightiest things efforced binâ€™.
assoyled: released
use: customary behavior
streight: promptly
garre: cause
garre: See E.K.â€™s gloss SC Apr 1.
20.3 Alluding to the theological point that human nature resists grace; Furor belongs entirely to the â€˜lesser partesâ€™ that â€˜moveâ€™ war within the self (16.1-2).
wood: insane
affronted: confronted
uncouth: strange or unseemly
wroke: avenged
dishabled: belittled
21.7 At i.5.2 Archimago lies in wait for Redcrosse â€˜In hope to win occasion to his willâ€™.
entise: incite or inflame
entise: Probably from L titio firebrand.
durt: mud
22.6-9 Cf. Jas 3:6, â€˜And the tongue is fireâ€™ and iv.5.1.

Stygian: Relating to the river Styx, or more generally the classical underworld of Hades where Styx and four other rivers ran. Normally Phlegethon is the infernal river associated with fire (cf. â€˜flaming Phlegetonâ€™ at vi. 50.9). OED notes that Styx (Gk Î£Ï„Ï…Î¾) is etymologically linked to â€˜hateâ€™ and â€˜hatefulâ€™.
disdeignd: regarded with indignation
wretched man: Cf. Rom 7:24 â€˜O wretched man that I am! who shall deliver me from the body of this death?â€™
gan him dight: prepared himself
25.4-9 Atin, having fled at the close of the previous canto (iv.46.9, v.2.1), here flees a second time.
late: lately
for terrour of his name: I.e., â€˜to make his reputation more terrifyingâ€™.
26.8-9 When Redcrosse fights Sansloy, Sansfoyâ€™s shield is displayed on a tree as the spoils (with Duessa) of the combat (I.v.5.7-8).
Dame: From L domina, suggesting domination or command.
St. 27-35 These stanzas offer a preview of the â€˜Bowre of Blisseâ€™, extensively described in the final canto of Book II. A number of specific verbal echoes link the two passages.
Acrasia: See i.51.2-4n for the etymology of the name.
hewes: shapes
mewes: cages
by kynd: by nature

lust and loose living . . . he has pourd out his ydle mynd: Cf. I.vii.7.1-3, where Redcrosse pours â€˜out in loosnesseâ€™ with his â€˜Dameâ€™ Duessa; the lustful activity seems to have a similar weakening effect on both Cymochles and the hero of Book I.
delices: delights

28.7 The mollification of Mars by Venus, derived from the invocation to Lucretius De Rerum (1.1-49) is a common topos in the iconography and Neoplatonic philosophy of the Italian Renaissance that recurs with frequent variations in FQ. Cf. I.pr.3.7-9n.

29.1-2 The idea that artâ€™s imitation of nature can turn into a rivalry is common in early modern discussions of art and literature. Spenser harks back to Ovidâ€™s description of the grotto sacred to Diana (Met 3.155-62), by way of Tasso, GL 16.9-12. Spenser will develop this topos with extensive echoing of both passages in canto xii.
wanton Yvie: Sacred to Bacchus, ivy is wanton because it clings to everything; see I.i.48.9n.
fragrant Eglantine: Sweet-briar, a species of rose featuring â€˜strong hooked prickles, pink single flowers, and small aromatic leavesâ€™ (OED).
prickling armes: â€˜Eglantineâ€™ derives from L aculentus prickly.
Zephyrus: the west wind; cf. Chaucer, CT Gen Pro, â€˜And Zephyrus eke with his sweete breath / Inspired hath in every holt and heeth / The tendre croppesâ€™ (3-5).
pumy stones: lava rock
Traveiler: one who journeys; one who labors
thristy: thirsty
display: sprawl

31.2-5 These lines mingle references to the oak, sacred to Jove (Od 14.327-28, repeated at 19.296, and Met 1.106), and the poplar, sacred to Hercules (Idylls 2.121 and Ecl 7.61; Georg 2.66; Aen 5.134, 8.276-77). Olympick Jove further suggests the olive, used to crown victors at the Olympic Games (Statius, Thebaid 6.5-8).
Nemus: Where Hercules slew the Nemean lion.
comfort: delight, refreshment
displaid: Cf. 30.7.
follies: lewd actions
follies: From Fr folie, akin to the modern theatrical use, as context indicates.
disaray: undress
disaray: With a glance at â€˜put into disorderâ€™.
meet habiliments: proper attire

32.9 The description of the damsels as both â€˜nakedâ€™ and â€˜decktâ€™ may simply mean that they are adorned with jewelry, not garments. But the apparent contradiction, underlined by the juxtaposition â€˜naked, decktâ€™, extends the confusion of art and nature (29.1-2n) to the female body, suggesting that this body is â€˜ornamentedâ€™ by nature. Cf. the description of Belphoebe, where details of her attire and its highly ornamented description (â€˜golden fringeâ€™, â€˜close enwrappedâ€™ knots, â€˜the temple of the Godsâ€™, breasts that â€˜through her thin weed their places only signifideâ€™) signify anatomical features not otherwise revealed (iii.26-29).

St. 33-34 Upton identifies these stanzas as a direct translation of GL 16.18-19. The contrast between the aggressive solicitation of the maidens and Cymochlesâ€™ feigned slumber emphasizes the perversity of his desire to â€˜steale a snatchâ€™ of what is so freely offered.
aggrate: gratify
glancing: casting momentary looks; flashing or shining

dropping like honey dew: Cf. Prov. 5.3, â€˜For the lippes of a strange woman drop as an honie combe, and her mouth is more soft then oyleâ€™. The Geneva gloss adds, â€˜By oyle and honie he meaneth flattering and craftie intisementsâ€™.
bathed kisses: Perhaps an ellipsis for â€˜bathed [him with] kissesâ€™.
embrew: soak or pour
sugred licour: sweet fluid
sugred licour: From L liquor liquidity.
all for tryall: Repetition and orthography suggest a pun.
wanton eies: Echoing the â€˜wanton Yvieâ€™ of 29.3.
snatch: hurried grab; fragment; portion seized on; a trap or snare
conceipt: fantasy
conceipt: Either the general power of conceiving, or a specific notion. The spelling recalls an etymological link to L capere seize, reinforced by the phrase â€˜steale a snatchâ€™.
receipt: recipe or ingredients
receipt: Also â€˜act of receivingâ€™, in pointed contrast to Cymochlesâ€™ fantasy of seizing.
St. 35 For the topos of rousing an erstwhile warrior from his lapse into sensuality, cf. Aen 4.265-76, OF 7.57-64, and GL 16.32-33.
Acrates: For the etymology linking this name to â€˜Acrasiaâ€™ see iv.41.6 and i.51.2-4n.
dart: Cf. the poison darts borne by Atin on his first appearance at iv.38.7, and the recurrent association of Pyrochles with â€˜prickingâ€™ (3.3n).
36.2 Cf. GL 16.33.2-3: qual viltÃ lâ€™alleta? / Su su (â€˜what sloth doth thee infect? / Up, upâ€™; trans. Fairfax).
prowest: worthiest, most brave or gallant
weetlesse: unaware
sencelesse ground: An unconventional instance of transferred epithet, since in fact the ground is senseless.
utmost grudging spright: final unwilling breath and/or spirit
Furies: See ii.29.2n.
deare dismay: costly defeat
pricketh . . . pricks: See 3.3 note.
immodest: lewd
immodest: From L modus measure, by way of immodestus excessive, immoderate. See 37.4 for the only other use in the poem.

St. 1 Paraphrasing Nic Eth 2.3, to the effect that pleasure is harder to resist than anger. Aristotle adds that both art and virtue address themselves to what is difficult, since the greater the difficulty, the greater the success. The analogy between art and virtue is especially resonant for FQ.
Continence: self-restraint
Continence: The ability to â€˜containâ€™ appetites and impulses. In Aristotle, ÎµÏ…ÎºÏÎ±Ï‚Î¹Î± eukrasia. Cf. akrasia in i.51.2-4n.
uneathes: not easily
faine: eagerly

abstain: Transitive use is unusual, according to OED â€˜probably a literary imitation of the trans. use of L abstinereâ€™. It means either that â€˜feeble natureâ€™ can hold her enemies at bay or that she can keep herself away from them. The 1596 reading, â€˜restraineâ€™, is more conventional and less equivocal.
St. 2-19 Some narrative details in this episode derive from OI; see Var 2.240-41; Kostic, Spenserâ€™s Sources 272-80 and 368.
Gondelay: Gondola
Gondelay: A light skiff with cabin amidships, rising to a point on each end.
arbours: Vines or shrubs trained on a lattice or other framework.

Pope Jone: Legendary medieval figure reported to have held the papacy in the 9th century while disguised as a man. Cf. Boccaccio, De mulieribus claris CI, De Iohanna anglica papa (â€˜Joan, an Englishwoman and Popeâ€™). The phrase as merry as Pope Joan was proverbial (Smith 1970, no. 529); Foxe, quoting the proverb, associates its mirth with â€˜the pleasures of Venus, Bacchus, and Ceresâ€™ (Actes 1583, 159). Pope Joan was invoked often by anti-Catholic polemicists in the 16th century, but in 1587 the French antiquary de Raemond debunked the legend using methods of humanist textual scholarship, and by 1596 Spenser has replaced this proverb with the phrase â€˜that nigh her breth was goneâ€™.
3.7-9 Cf. Aristotleâ€™s disapproval of vacuous laughter at Nic Eth 4.8.
barke: ship
painted: artificially colored

St. 5 Echoing Homer on the ships of the Phaecians, which â€˜have no pilots, nor steering-oars . . but of themselves understand the thoughts and minds of menâ€™ (Î¿Ï… Î³Î±Ï Î¦Î±Î¹Î·ÎºÎµÏƒÏƒÎ¹ ÎºÏ…Î²ÎµÏÎ½Î·Ï„Î·ÏÎµÏ‚ ÎµÎ±ÏƒÎ¹Î½, / Î¿Ï…Î´ÎµÏ„Î¹ Ï€Î·Î´Î±Î»Î¹â€™ ÎµÏƒÏ„Î¹, Ï„Î± Ï„á¾½ Î±Î»Î»Î±Î¹ Î½Î·ÎµÏ‚ ÎµÏ‡Î¿Ï…ÏƒÎ¹Î½: / Î±Î»Î»á¾½ Î±Ï…Ï„Î±Î¹ Î¹ÏƒÎ±ÏƒÎ¹ Î½Î¿Î·Î¼Î±Ï„Î± ÎºÎ±Î¹ Ï†ÏÎµÎ½Î±Ï‚ Î±Î½Î´ÏÏ‰Î½; on gar phaiÄ“kessi kybernÄ“tÄ“res easin, / oudeti pÄ“daliâ€™ esti, ta tâ€™ allai nÄ“es echousin: / allâ€™ autai isasi noÄ“mata kai phrenas andrÅn, Od 8.557-9). Similar boats appear in OF 30.11 and GL 14.57-65.
liquid: transparent
liquid: As a modifier for air or sky, a distinctively Spenserian usage, following poetic use of L liquidus by Virgil, Horace, and other Roman authors.
pin: wooden peg
apply: steer
apply: From nautical senses of L applicare â€˜to bring (a ship to a destination), to landâ€™ (OED).
wanton: frivolous
wanton: Implying a promiscuity not limited to sex.
purpose: conversation
purpose: â€˜That which is propounded; a proposition, a question, an argument; a riddleâ€™ (OED). Phaedriaâ€™s purpose lacks, as it were, purpose.
