merry tales: A phrase that appears in the titles of popular jestbooks like Merie tales by Skelton, one of four volumes Spenser lent Gabriel Harvey in 1578.
feign: fashion
feign: From L fingere to shape or pretend.
toys: flirtatious behaviors
aguize: deck
plight: braided
frigot: frigate, a small light ship built for speed
sovenaunce: memory
sovenaunce: From L subvenÄ«re to come into the mind.
8.8-9 Cf. the role of Medina at ii.27-32.
and what that usage ment: cf. I.iii.32.8, â€˜what the Lyon mentâ€™.
cott: â€˜A small roughly-made boat, used on the rivers and lakes of Ireland; a â€œdug-outâ€â€™ (OED).

Phaedria: From Gk Ï†Î±Î¹Î´ÏÎ¿Ï‚ phaidros glittering, cheerful; cf. arg.1. Familiar from Euripides, Seneca, Ovid, Virgil, and Renaissance mythographers as the name of the â€˜wanton stepdameâ€™ (I.v.37.5) whose destructive passion led to the death of the chaste Hippolytus.

Idle lake: Cf. Gen 14:3, â€˜the salte Seaâ€™, for which the Geneva gloss reads: â€˜Called also dead Sea, or the lake Asphaltite nere unto Sodom and Gomorahâ€™. Joseph Wybarn in 1609 seems to be making this connection when he refers to those who have â€˜drowned themselves in the dead sea of pleasureâ€™; a marginal gloss beside the phrase refers readers to â€˜The Legend of Phaedria in the 2. booke of the Faeyerie Queeneâ€™ (Sp All, 120).
swelling Neptune . . . thundring Jove: waves . . . storms
waste and voyd: uncultivated and uninhabited
waste and voyd: Cf. 11.9-12.1 for its fertility.

floted: Cf. Conti Myth 9.6 on the island of Delos as instabilis per illud tempus, sub vndis forte e delitescebat (â€˜unstable and at that time as it happened hidden under the wavesâ€™; 273.33); also Aen 3.73-77, and Met 6.189-91. Other classical references to floating islands are found in Homer, Herodotus, Pindar, Pliny the Elder, Pliny the Younger, Hyginus, and Lucian. Early maps show floating â€˜Isles of St. Brandanâ€™ in various parts of the Atlantic, and European navigators went in search of them. See Hereford Mappa Mundi, Richard of Haldingham (1280); Paolo Toscanelliâ€™s World Map (1476); Erdapfel globe, Martin Behaim (1492); one helpful source is Peter De Rooâ€™s History of America Before Columbus According to Documents and Approved Authors; J.B. Lippencott Company; 1900; the first chapter of the second volume is completely dedicated to the legend and history of the islands.

12.1-2 Cicero, in de Oratore, imagines Odysseus, when Calypso and Circe offer him immortality, declaring his preference for ut Ithacam illiam in asperrimis saxulis, tamquam nidulum (â€˜that Ithaca of his, lodged like a tiny nest upon the roughest of small cragsâ€™; I.196); cf. Od 9.29-36. Transferred to a simulacrum of the Bower of Bliss, the simile insinuates the localeâ€™s seductive allure as a false image of the home one longs for.

12.6-7 Initiates a series extending into st. 13 that inventories the bounty of the island entirely through negation. Cf. Gen 2:5: â€˜And every plant of the fielde, before it was in the earth, and every herbe of the field, before it greweâ€™.
arborett: little tree
arborett: The first recorded use in OED.

St. 13 Cited by Robert Alott in Englandâ€™s Parnassus (1600) as an example of â€˜the choysest Flowers of our Modern Poetsâ€™ (475). The first six lines had been adopted by Thomas Watson in 1593 for The Tears of Fancie (51).
ditt: words for music
ditt: From ME â€˜diteâ€™ (something written) by association with â€˜dittyâ€™ (song).
fild: filled or defiled
head disarmd: Literally unhelmeted, but the comical pun calls attention to the idea that Cymochlesâ€™ mind is defenseless.
fearing not be harmd: Ellipsis for â€˜not tâ€™ be harmdâ€™, with the contraction assimilated to the final â€˜tâ€™ in â€˜notâ€™.
charmd: From L carmina song.

St. 15-17 Phaedriaâ€™s song mingles allusions to classical, Biblical, and Italian precedents, including the Lotus-eaters in Od 9, Gen 3:10, Matt 6:25-34, and the Sirenâ€™s lullaby to Rinaldo in Tasso (GL 14.62-64).
15.1-3 â€˜O man, who takes toilsome pains, behold how the flowers, etc., make themselves an example to youâ€™.
15.4-5 â€˜While nature, not at all envious, throws them forth out of her fruitful lapâ€™.
pompous: magnificent, full of pomp
E.K. glosses flowre deluce as â€˜Flowre delice, that which they use to misterme, Flowre de luce, being in Latine called Flos delitiarumâ€™ (SC Apr 144). L deliciae delights, charms.
to them . . . yield: I.e., â€˜yield to their exampleâ€™.
stoure: turmoil
16.9 â€˜She leaves all the worrying to Mother Natureâ€™.
17.1-2 Echoing Ps 8:6-8, to which the Geneva gloss reads, â€˜By the temporal gifts of mans creation he is led to consider the benefites which he hathe by his regeneration through Christâ€™.
Who shall him rew, that: â€˜Who is going to pity the man thatâ€™.
thrist: thirst (by metathesis)
wordly: 1596 â€˜worldlyâ€™, of which wordly is an archaic form, as in Skeltonâ€™s phrase â€˜wordly wondreâ€™ (Vox Populi xi.38).
slouthfull: Echoing its root-word â€˜slowâ€™.
griesy: 1596 â€˜grieslyâ€™. Related forms, both similar to the modern â€˜grislyâ€™, horrible; in context (cf. slouthfull), 1590 also puns on â€˜greasyâ€™. Cf. agrise at 46.7.
wefte: wafted, i.e. sailed
strond: strand, i.e. the shore
where him she byding fond: â€˜Where she found him waitingâ€™.
sad: serious
tooke a boord: In colloquial use, â€˜sexually accommodatedâ€™.

19.7-9 Cf. 4.8-9, â€˜but Atin by no way / She would admit, albe the knight her much did prayâ€™. Phaedriaâ€™s gondola responds to her wishes, suggesting that her motions are self-willed (see st. 10); hence Guyonâ€™s â€˜guideâ€™ (20.1) must be excluded. Cf. xii.3.1, where the Boatman rowing Guyon and the Palmer to Acrasiaâ€™s island bids the Palmer â€˜stere arightâ€™.
flitt: swift
obaying to her mind: See st. 5n.
guize: conduct
guize: Cf. â€˜styleâ€™ at 22.1.
reare: begin
jollity: pleasure, with sexual connotation
gibe: taunt
geare: jeer
bonds: boundaries
23.2-5 Cf. what the narrator says about winds and tides at 20.8-9, and Phaedriaâ€™s own comments on her navigation at 10.2-9.
mote: must

fields did laugh: Cf. Ps 65:13, where pastures and valleys â€˜showte for joye, and singâ€™ because they are covered with sheep and corn; the Geneva gloss adds, â€˜That is, the dumme creatures shall not onely reioyce for a time for Gods benefites, but shal continually singâ€™. For discussion of this echo and comparison of eight different English translations of the Biblical passage, see Shaheen (1976: 52, 190-91). Cf. Petrarchâ€™s phrase Ridono i prati (RS 310.5, â€˜the meadows laughâ€™), Lucretiusâ€™ invocation to Venus in De Rerum, tibi suavis daedala tellus / summittit flores, tibi rident equora ponti (â€˜for you the wonder-working earth puts forth sweet flowers, for you the wide stretches of ocean laughâ€™; 1.7-8), and Arthurâ€™s memory of the day he dreamed of Gloriana: â€˜The fields, the floods, the heavens with one consent / Did seeme to laugh on me, and favour mine intentâ€™ (I.ix.12.8-9).

martiall guize: armor

26.2 Hamilton 2001 suggests plausibly that Guyonâ€™s â€˜posture declares his control over the fountain of affectionsâ€™. John Bulwer in Chirologia (1644) catalogues the hand upon the heart as gesture LII, Conscienter affirmo, glossing it as a token of â€˜sincere asseverationâ€™ (88-89).
thewed: mannered
part: â€˜a piece of conduct, an actâ€™ (OED)
steme: steam

steme: OED cites this as the sole instance in which the sense â€˜to emit, send out in the form of vaporâ€™ is used figuratively to mean â€˜evaporateâ€™. Hamilton 2001 suggests â€˜steepâ€™ or â€˜dissolve in steam,â€™ implying that â€˜stemeâ€™ works with â€˜quenchâ€™ in the next line to portray the â€˜molten heartâ€™, plunged into a cold bath of sloth, expending its heat in steam.

28.7-9 Echoing Deut 28:26, â€˜And thy carkeis shal be meat unto all foules of the ayreâ€™, one of the â€˜threateningsâ€™ levelled against those who defy the Mosaic law. The Geneva gloss stresses that the disobedient will be â€˜cursed bothe in thy life and in thy deathâ€™ because the burial here denied is a â€˜testimonie of the resurrectionâ€™. Cf. also the taunts between David and Goliath in 1 Sam 17:44 and 46.
importune: violent
importune: Perhaps with â€˜untimelyâ€™ or â€˜inopportuneâ€™ as a secondary sense.
prepard to field: prepared for combat
valew: valor
valew: â€˜Valueâ€™ and â€˜valorâ€™ are etymologically so intertwined in ME and early modern usage that the phrase inevitably suggests a moral as well as martial equivalence between the combatants.
haberjeons dismayld: â€˜Knocked the metal plates off their sleeveless coats of mailâ€™.
dismayld: â€˜Divested of armorâ€™, with the punning sense â€˜unmannedâ€™.
spalles: shoulders
entayld: carved or engraved
giambeux: leg-armor
giambeux: Hamilton 2001 suggests that this spelling may derive from Chaucer, CT Thopas 875.
grudging: aggrieved by
wroke: vindicated from or avenged for
enhaunst: raised
sway: swing
St. 32-36 Cf. Medinaâ€™s intervention at ii.27-32.
feld: cast down.
feld: The reflexive use of â€˜felledâ€™ is not recognized in OED.
wo worth: woe unto
race: descent
authour: source, cause
in bale to sterve: to die in grief
scarmoges: skirmishes

scarmoges: The â€˜cruellâ€™ game may disarm her skirmishes or they may disarm the game; this ambiguity of syntax, together with the hypallage between her erotic â€˜gameâ€™ and the knightsâ€™ combative â€˜scarmogesâ€™, anticipates the extended troping of love as combat in the ensuing lines.

34.6-9 It is difficult to escape the implication that Phaedria is here proposing a sexual encounter in which she will yield a â€˜pleasaunt victoryâ€™ to both knights, leaving them nothing to fight over. Since hypallage is Greek for â€˜interchange, exchangeâ€™, there may be a witty subtextual parallel between Phaedriaâ€™s rhetoric and her sexual ethos.
Alarmes: calls to â€˜armsâ€™
shend: disgrace
commend: grace or adorn
35.7-9 Cf. the invocation to Cupid at I.pr.3.7-9.
extremities: Cf. ii.38.4, â€˜The strong extremities of their outrageâ€™.
36.3 Prov 15:1, â€˜Soft answer putteth away wrath: but grievous wordes stirre up angreâ€™.
clemency: mildness
that other part: the farther shore of the lake
he light did pas: he regarded lightly
he light did pas: â€˜Lightâ€™ modifies either â€˜heâ€™ or â€˜passâ€™, from Phaedriaâ€™s point of view, but from Guyonâ€™s it modifies â€˜delightâ€™, to which it is drawn by the internal rhyme.
solemne sad: Cf. the description of Redcrosse at I.i.2.8.
coy: modest, reserved
That: i.e. so that

amove: The narrator uses a relatively uncommon sense (â€˜To remove [a person or thing] from a position; to dismiss [a person] from an officeâ€™) to characterize Phaedriaâ€™s displeasure at her failure to â€˜amoveâ€™ Guyon in the more usual sense of arousing him.
The which: Referring to her â€˜swift boteâ€™.
salied: jumped
shard: gap
shard: I.e. the lake regarded as a â€˜perlousâ€™ break in the continuity of â€˜terra firmaâ€™.
tracted . . . trade: tracked . . . path, footprints
invade: assail
famous enimy: Presumably Pyrochles.
passion fraile: an ellipsis for â€˜passion that, strong in itself, makes human nature frailâ€™

which him late did faile: OED labels this construction â€˜the dative of the personâ€™, citing as another example the King James rendering of 1 Kings 2:4, â€˜There shall not faile thee . . . a man on the throne of Israelâ€™. The preposition to is understood.
delayd: cooled, quenched; postponed
St. 41-42 At OI 3.1.20-21, Mandricardo dashes through fire and leaps into a fountain to save himself.
stept: steeped

flasht: For the mingling of fire and water, see v.2.4-5n. The syntax of lines 6-7 is latinate, with â€˜the waves aboutâ€™ serving as the object of both â€˜flashtâ€™ and â€˜sweptâ€™: i.e. he flasht the waves about (with his raging arms) and his armor swept the waves about (so that it was washed clean).
bet: beat
Harrow . . . and well away: A cry of alarm; cf. Chaucer, â€˜John . . . gan to crie â€œHarrow!â€ and â€œWeylaway! / Oure hors is lorn (CT Reeve 4071-73).
dismall: evil or cursed

dismall: Echoing L dies mali evil days; two days of each month were so designated in the medieval calendar. 1590 gives this line as â€˜What dismall day hath lent but this his cursed lightâ€™, a reading that is both nonsensical and hypermetrical; 1596 revises to â€˜What dismall day hath lent this cursed lightâ€™. There is no evidence as to whether the change is compositorial or authorial; we take it to be compositorial, and prefer to correct by removing â€˜but thisâ€™. It is possible that the untenable 1590 reading resulted from a two-stage misconstrual of manuscript copy. If Spenser originally wrote â€˜What dismall day hath lent vs [or â€˜hisâ€™] cursed lightâ€™, and then added â€˜thisâ€™ and â€˜hisâ€™ [or â€˜vsâ€™] side by side above the line as possible replacements, the compositor could have misconstrued the unfinished revision as an insertion (stage one misconstrual). At the same time, he misread â€˜vsâ€™ as â€˜butâ€™: the heavily inked descender on a secretary hand â€˜vâ€™ makes it possible to read it as a â€˜bâ€™, and Spenserâ€™s own terminal â€˜sâ€™ resembles the rounded form of a terminal â€˜tâ€™.
damnifyde: injured; damned
damnifyde: Cf. modern â€˜indemnifyâ€™.
St. 44 In the details of immersion and of death as a means â€˜to respyreâ€™, there is a generalized allusion to the language of Romans 6 on baptism. Cf. i.55.3, 55.9 and notes.
implacable: Accented on the first syllable.
And dying dayly, dayly yet revive: a cruel parody of Paulâ€™s instructions about daily death (Rom 12:1, 1 Cor 15:31).
his owne health remembring now no more: Parallels the lack of â€˜sovenaunceâ€™ at 8.3.

46.6-9 For the muddy waters of Cocytus (Cocyti stagna) in the classical underworld seeVirgil (Aen 6.323-30). In Tasso, Armidaâ€™s castle is surrounded by an asphalt lake (GL 10.61-62, acque . . . bituminose e calde / e steril lago) in which nothing can sink. Cf. also the Stygian marsh in Dante, Inf 7.108-130.
Engrost: thickened
agrise: horrify
arming: belonging to the armor of a knight
hath at earst thee hent: has seized you now
secret bowelles: the hidden recesses of the body cavity
bedight: treated

bedight: â€˜Dightâ€™ has a specifically scriptive range of meanings, â€˜from L dictare to dictate, compose in language, appoint, prescribe, order; in med L to write, compose a speech, letter, etcâ€™ (OED).
livers: The liver was considered the seat of the passions.
Phlegeton: In the classical underworld, a river of fire.
felly: fiercely
priefe: proof, test
qualifyde: tempered, moderated
algates: Hamilton suggests â€˜otherwiseâ€™, a sense not recorded in OED. Usually, â€˜in any caseâ€™ or â€˜by all meansâ€™.

Mamon: Aramaic for â€˜wealthâ€™; see Kellogg and Steele 1965: â€˜The Syriac word was misunderstood by some early commentators of the Gospels who interpreted it as the name of one of the fallen angels and, from the New Testament context, the god of earthly wealthâ€™ (8.1-2n). Where the Geneva Bible translates â€˜Ye can not serve God and richesâ€™ (Matt 6:24, Luke 16:13), the Bishopsâ€™ and other Elizabethan bibles read â€˜God, and mammonâ€™. Spenserâ€™s conception of Mammon as both a god of riches and an underworld deity probably reflects the influence of Boccaccio, Genealogia 8.6, which conflates Pluto, the classical god of the underworld, with Plutus, the god of riches; Conti distinguishes the two but does mention that Strabo identified Pluto as the god of wealth (Myth 250). The descent to Mammonâ€™s cave blends allusions to the heroâ€™s descent to the underworld in classical epic (e.g. Od 11 and Aen 6), Satanâ€™s temptation of Jesus in the wilderness (Matt 4:1-11, Luke 4:1-13), and a number of folktale motifs (e.g., taboos against eating food or touching treasures in the underworld; cf. Thompson, Motif-Index 1955, C211.1 â€“ C211.2.2, C542).
delve: excavation

threasure: the (perhaps silent) â€˜hâ€™ marks the etymology of â€˜treasureâ€™ in L thesis aurum, or the â€˜placingâ€™ of gold, and so glances at the episodeâ€™s biblical concern with where we â€˜lay up treasuresâ€™ (Matt 6:19-21). Cf. 32.9, â€˜before thee laidâ€™, and 33.3, â€˜before mine eyes I placeâ€™.
hore: hoary, white or grey with age

St. 1 The simile of the experienced navigator both looks back to the topic of new world exploration in the proem and anticipates the sense of perilous exploration removed from heavenâ€™s light (3.2) that attends upon Guyonâ€™s venture into the subterranean kingdom of Mammon. Cf. 14.1-5.

a stedfast starre: cf. I.ii.1.2 â€˜the stedfast starreâ€™. Typically Polaris, in the constellation Ursa Minor (also referred to as the lodestar, the Northern Star, or the Pole Star; cf. II.x.4.7, III.iv.53.3). The hint of relativity in the indefinite pronoun might reflect awareness that the identity of the star closest to the pole depends upon the position of the observer in space and time. Thus Taylor 1971 reports the common belief that the southern hemisphere also had a fixed star to match Polaris in the north, the idea being that these two stars were like the ends of the earthâ€™s axis (or â€œaxleâ€) and provided similar navigational aid in their respective hemispheres (162). If Mammonâ€™s cave is deep enough, there might be a reminiscence of Danteâ€™s passage with Virgil through the center of the earth, from the northern to the southern hemisphere, at the close of the Purgatorio.
yblent: obscured

yblent: Past participle of two different verbs, the first meaning â€˜to blindâ€™ and the second meaning â€˜to combineâ€™. The first can sometimes mean â€˜to concealâ€™, while the second, in its p ppl, can mean â€˜confusedâ€™. Spenserâ€™s usage here may itself be a blending of the forms. Cf. 10.5, â€˜fowly blendâ€™, and 13.2, â€˜confoundâ€™.

card and compas: The â€˜cardâ€™ is a chart or geographical description; in combination with â€˜compasâ€™ it might also refer to a card on which the 32 points of the compass are marked, although this tends to be a later usage.
maysters: masters
experiment: experience
maysters: A â€˜Master Marinerâ€™ was the captain of a merchant vessel; here, navigational instruments are personified as the pilotâ€™s teachers (L magister).
apply: steer

2.1 The orthographic resemblance of â€˜guydâ€™ to â€˜Guyonâ€™ suggests that, like the â€˜Pilot well expertâ€™, Guyon deprived of the Palmer will fall back on the â€˜card and compassâ€™ of â€˜his owne vertuesâ€™ as an internalized guide.

2.4-5 Guyon comforted with his own virtues may exemplify Aristotleâ€™s description of â€˜the Great-minded manâ€™ as one â€˜who values himself highly and at the same time justlyâ€™ and who prizes his own self-sufficiency (Nic Eth 4.3, 1123b-1125a). The episode tests the limits of self-sufficiency, reached when Guyon collapses in st. 66.
yode: went
reedes: judges
wastfull: uninhabited
desert: desolate

wildernesse: See Matt 4:1, â€˜Then was Jesus led aside of the Spirit into the wildernes, to be tempted of the devilâ€™. The Spiritâ€™s role in leading Jesus into the wilderness is more explicit in other translations. Cf. King James: â€˜Then was Jesus led up of the Spirit into the wilderness to be tempted of the devil.â€™ The gloss to the New International Version notes that the Greek for â€˜temptedâ€™ can also mean â€˜testedâ€™.
Whereas: where
3.6-9 Mammonâ€™s description suggests the appearance of a blacksmith; cf. st. 35-36.

bleard: See Langland, Piers Plowman 5.190 [Text B], where Avarice has â€˜two blered eyghenâ€™, and Matt 6:23, â€˜if thine eye be wicked, then all thy bodie shalbe darkeâ€™. The emphasis through the cantoâ€™s opening is on concealment and on vision obscured by layers of darkness, mist, or grime, presumably because â€˜Regard of worldly mucke doth fowly blendâ€™ (10.5). Meanwhile the tissue of allusions to the Sermon on the Mount links this episode with Phaedriaâ€™s song at II.vi.15-17.
bedight: clothed
overgrowne with rust: See Matt 6:19, â€˜Lay not up treasures for your selves upon the earth, where the mothe and canker [Bishopsâ€™ Bible: â€œrustâ€] corruptâ€™.

underneath enveloped: A gold surcoat surrounds the iron that, beneath the gold, is overgrowne with rust, like another surcoat. The phrasing is difficult but, in its tendency to confound the opposites of â€˜underneathâ€™ and â€˜envelopedâ€™, evokes the action of the episode, in which Mammon leads Guyon underground to entrap him with the sight of hidden gold. As in the Bower of Bliss, where the â€˜Virgin Rose . . . fairer seemes, the lesse ye see her mayâ€™ (xii.74.4-6), the secrecy of the treasure adds to its allure.
entayle: ornamental carving
mould: fashioning
antickes: grotesques
told: counted
feede his eye: Combines the two principal motifs of the canto, feeding (2.4-5) and gazing (3.6 and note).
never could be spent: The treasure is â€˜horeâ€™ (arg.2) because it is hoarded, withheld from circulation.

5.3-4 Earlier cantos have explored water as a purifying element; in Mammonâ€™s cave raw materials undergo purification by fire. The recurrent emphasis on looking as a kind of feeding suggests an analogous tempering by heat in the form of digestion, an analogy that will become explicit in canto ix.

rude: From L rudis unwroughtâ€”but also â€˜inexperiencedâ€™, implying by analogy that Guyon himself is â€˜purifideâ€™ by the â€˜devouring elementâ€™ in the course of his â€˜long experimentâ€™ (1.7) in Mammonâ€™s realm.
Mulcibers devouring element: Mulciber, or Vulcan, is the Roman god of fire.
driven, and distent: smelted and beaten out
Ingowes: ingots
Ingowes: In Spenserâ€™s distinctive variation, Hamilton 2001 hears â€˜Ingasâ€™, the Elizabethan form of â€˜Incasâ€™, famous for the city of gold.
moniment: â€˜image and superscriptionâ€™ (cf. Matt 22:20-21; Mark 12:16-17; Luke 20:24-25).
kesars: emperors (from â€˜Caesarâ€™); for the conventional doublet with â€˜kingsâ€™, cf. Teares 570; FQ III.xi.29.9, IV.vii.1.4, V.ix.29.9, and VI.iii.5.7.
right usaunce: See Matt 25:14-30, the Parable of the Talents.
Thereat: thereupon
askaunce: sidelong
askaunce: Indicating â€˜disdain, envy, jealousy, [or] suspicionâ€™ (OED). Cf. SC March 21; FQ III.i.41.6, ix.27.3, and xii.15.2.
read: pronounce
pelfe: Puttenham calls this â€˜a lewd terme to be given to a Princes treasureâ€™ (1589: 3.22.217).

God of the world . . . god below the skye: See arg.1n and 5.7n. Mammonâ€™s self-description (â€˜I me callâ€™; cf. 9.6, â€˜thy godheads vauntâ€™) confounds the distinction Jesus draws between worldly and heavenly jurisdictions. Cf. 2 Cor 4:4, â€˜the god of this worldeâ€™; John 12:31, â€˜the prince of this worldeâ€™.
envye: refuse
principality: Cf. Matt 4:8, â€˜all the kingdomes of the worlde, and the glorie of themâ€™; also Luke 4:5-6.

8.7-9 Contrast the pretense of unfettered bounty in lines 3-4 and 8. The goods for which â€˜men swinck and sweat incessantlyâ€™ may flow from Mammon â€˜into an ample floodâ€™, but the implied direction of the flow (from me into the world) is put in question by the way lines 8-9 move, as it were, upstream to the underground breeding-place of gold. For the tendency of Mammonâ€™s rhetoric to give with one hand what it takes away with the other, see 5.2, 9.5, 10.3, and especially 19.6-9, confirming that Mammon withholds the â€˜ample floodâ€™ of wealth from proper circulation.
hollow: empty or concave; vain
hollow: Cf. â€˜the hollow growndâ€™ (20.8).
eternall: Mammon ascribes divine attributes to worldly goods, here with implicit self-contradiction, since â€˜broodâ€™ as a verb or noun of birth cannot be eternal.
serve and sew: Cf. Matt 4:9, â€˜All these wil I give thee, if thou wilt fall downe, and worship meâ€™.
these mountaines: Conflating the earth with its â€˜broodâ€™ of riches.
nombred francke and free: The verb takes back what the adverbs purport to give freely; cf. the contradiction noted in 8.7n.
thy godheads vaunt: your divinityâ€™s boast; your boasted divinity
derdoing: derring-do
derdoing: See â€˜derring-doâ€™ in glossary.
suit: pursuit
vowed daies: Guyon binds himself with a sacred oath at II.i.61.
bounteous baytes: See 9.5n. Here the noun takes back what the adjective offers, as Mammonâ€™s apparent liberality turns out to be no more than â€˜baitâ€™.
witchest: beguile
witchest: OED records this as the first figurative use of the verb.
blend: blind or defile
blend: See 1.4n.
heroicke: OED records only one prior use of the adjective in this sense (Complaynt of Scotlande, 1549), although Sidney and Puttehnam use it to describe a kind of poetry or poet.
crownes: Also the name of a coin; cf. 5.8-9.
in twinckling of an eye: Cf. Luke 4:5: â€˜The devil . . . shewed him all the kingdomes of the worlde, in the twinkeling of an eyeâ€™.
I kings create: Cf. Prov 8:15, â€˜By me, Kings reigneâ€™, with the Geneva gloss: â€˜honors, dignitie or riches come not of mans wisdome or industrie, but by the providence of Godâ€™.
rowme: appointed place, office, or position
lust: list, i.e. please
read: judge
roote of all disquietnesse: Cf. 1 Tim 6:10: â€˜For the desire of money is the roote of all evilâ€™.

1590 prints â€˜in great dishonourâ€™. The reading we adopt from 1596 is easier to construe, and has been preferred by modern editors; 1590â€™s â€˜inâ€™ implicates the noble heart in the evils it â€˜doth despizeâ€™.
confound: bring to ruin; throw into confusion
incline: bend; dispose
13.8 Cf. Marlowe, 2 Tamburlaine 5.2.26: â€˜Kingdomes made waste, brave cities sackt and burntâ€™.
private state: private life

Caspian sea . . . Adrian gulf: Proverbial for storms. Horace calls the south wind, Auster, Dux inquieti turbidus Hadriae (â€˜stormy master of the restless Adriaticâ€™; Odes 3.3.4-5). See st. 1n: the simile of the storm-tossed voyager reintroduces the motif that implicitly answers Mammonâ€™s question in the second half of the stanzaâ€”men are â€˜fond and undiscreetâ€™ because â€˜Regard of worldly mucke doth fowly blendâ€™ (see notes to 3.6 and 1.4).
14.7-9 â€˜[Why do men] complain when they donâ€™t have money, and find fault with it when they do?â€™

St. 15-17 For the distinction between need and superfluity and the fall from a golden age of simplicity, see Boethius Cons Phil 2.prose.5 and 2.meter.5; Chaucer, â€˜The Former Ageâ€™; Ovid, Met 1.89-150.
empeach: hinder

empeach: This and the two verbs below may reflect the specific phrasing of Chaucerâ€™s translation of the passage from Boethius cited above: â€˜thow wolt achoken the fulfillynge of nature with . . . thinges . . . anoyousâ€™ (2.prose.5).
annoyes: interferes with
accloyes: obstructs, chokes
unreproved: Contrast with 14.9, â€˜complaine, and . . . upbraydâ€™.
truth: sincerity
soveraine: supreme
corn-fed steed: Proverbial; cf. Smith (1970, no. 121), citing Gascoigne: â€˜cornfed beasts, whose bellie is their Godâ€™.

16.6-9 I.e. the pride of later age abused her (the ageâ€™s) plenty and her increase, to the end of excessive, unrestrained pleasure. Note the repeated feminine pronoun, indicating Guyonâ€™s view that when the â€˜antique worldâ€™ degenerates from innocence and purity to â€˜fat swolne encreaceâ€™, it also declines from masculinity to femininity of the sort described by Parker 1987.
wombe: Cf. 8.9, â€˜broodâ€™.
great Grandmother: the earth
17.3-4 Mining is here compared to robbing a temple, the etymological sense of sacrilege (L sacra legere to purloin sacred objects).

17.6-7 â€˜He combined gold and silver into the material cause of his desireâ€™ (OED s.v. â€˜matterâ€™); â€˜compoundâ€™ may also glance at financial senses of the verb that involve agreeing to terms for a payment.

through his veines: Glancing at the veins of ore mined from the earth; Barkan 1975 notes stanzaâ€™s movement â€˜from an anthropomorphic cosmos [â€˜wombeâ€™] to a cosmomorphic human body [â€˜veinsâ€™]â€™ (212).
wage: pledge; sell for wages
life for gold engage: â€˜Pledge your life in exchange for goldâ€™.

19.1-2 Cf. Nic Eth 4.1 (1120a), on the unwillingness of the â€˜Liberal manâ€™ to â€˜receive from improper sourcesâ€™. Guyonâ€™s desire to understand (â€˜Did feed his eyes, and fild his inner thoughtâ€™, 24.4) is contrasted with Mammonâ€™s desire to possess (â€˜to feede his eye / And covetous desireâ€™, 4.8-9). Milton, insisting that â€˜the knowledge and survey of vice is in this world . . . necessary to the constituting of human virtueâ€™, praises Spenser for bringing Guyon through both Mammonâ€™s cave and the Bower of Bliss (II.xii) â€˜that he might see and know, and yet abstainâ€™ (Areop 729).
bereave: plunder
lott: apportioning (of wealth or fortune)
19.6-7 See 1 Cor 2:9, â€˜The things which eye hathe not sene, nether eare hathe heard, nether came into mans heartâ€™.
mew: hiding-place; prison
20.1-5 See John 1:38-9: â€˜And they said unto him, Rabbi . . . where dwellest thou? He said unto them, Come, and seâ€™.
wonne: abode
wonne: Possibly with a hint of the archaic sense â€˜treasureâ€™.

20.6-7 The entrance to Mammonâ€™s cave resembles the exits to the House of Pride (I.v.52.7-53) and the castle of Alma (ix.32), and the â€˜hinder gateâ€™ of the Gardens of Adonis (III.vi.32.9-33.4), which is both an entrance (to the Garden) and an exit (from the state of life).

20.7-9 Cf. Virgil: Ibant obscuri sola sub nocte per umbram / perque domos Ditis vacuas et inania regna ( â€˜On they went dimly, beneath the lonely night amid the gloom, through the empty halls of Dis and his phantom realmâ€™; Aen 6.268-9).

St. 21-25 Spenserâ€™s description of the approach to the underworld draws on Virgil, Aen 6.273-81. Lotspeich 1932: 65-66 adds Statius (see Theb 7.40-62), Cicero (see Nat Deor 3.17), Conti (Myth 622), Chaucer (see CT Knight 1982-2040), and Bocccacio (Genealogia 8.6), which allegorizes Virgilâ€™s House of Dis as a House of Riches.
broad high way: See Matt 7:13, â€˜the wide gate, and broad waye that leadeth to destructionâ€™.
Plutoes: In Roman mythology, Pluto ruled Hades (see arg.1n).
rayne: realm
21.5-6 Cf. 12.7. In general, the personifications of stanzas 21-23 correspond to the evils listed by Guyon in st. 12.

infernall: 1590 prints â€˜internallâ€™, not an impossible reading (cf. III.x.59.8, â€˜internall smartâ€™), but one that awkwardly undercuts the work of projection that turns affects into personages throughout the passage.
strayne: grip, wield
thother side: Cf. Virgilâ€™s adverso in limine (â€˜on the threshold oppositeâ€™, Aen 6.279) in the passage cited above, st. 21-25n.
consort: group
shroud: hide
Lamenting Sorrow: Cf. the allegorical figure of Sorrow in Mirror for Magistrates (1563), Induction 106-112.

horror: Like â€˜shameâ€™ in the preceding line, uncapitalized in 1590. Only 1609 capitalizes â€˜horrorâ€™; both 1596 and 1609 register personification by capitalizing â€˜shameâ€™. We retain the uncertainty of 1590 because the series of capitalized personifications in stanzas 21 and 22 is preceded, at 20.9, by an encompassing but not quite personified 'dread and horror', suggesting that the mechanism of personification is on display in this passage; cf. II.ii.26.4-9 for a comparable play on the uncapitalized personification of 'love'. As these examples show, the distinction between personified and non-personified abstractions is not absolute: it is more like a spectrum than a switchpoint.
23.3-5 On owles and night-ravens as omens, see I.v.30.6-7, Epith 345-6, and SC June 23-24 with gloss by E.K.
dolor: grief, sorrow, or physical pain

Celeno: Chief of the harpies, defilers of the feast Aeneas and his men prepare in Aen 3. Celeno rebukes the Trojan remnant for offering only war in exchange for the cattle they have slaughtered, and utters the cryptic prophecy that they will not build their city in Italy until famine has forced them to devour the tables they eat from.
24.4 On the combination of feeding with gazing, see 4.8n and 19.1-2n.
gaped wide: Cf. Virgil: noctes atque dies patet atri ianua Ditis (â€˜night and day the door of gloomy Dis stands openâ€™; Aen 6.127).
spoile: plunder

25.7 Cf. Hesiod: Î½Ï…Î¾ Î´á¾½ ÎµÏ„ÎµÎºÎµÎ½ ÏƒÏ„Ï…Î³ÎµÏÎ¿Î½ Ï„Îµ ÎœÎ¿ÏÎ¿Î½ ÎºÎ±Î¹ ÎšÎ·ÏÎ± Î¼ÎµÎ»Î±Î¹Î½Î±Î½ / ÎºÎ±Î¹ Î˜Î±Î½Î±Ï„Î¿Î½, Ï„ÎµÎºÎµ Î´á¾½ á½Ï€Î½Î¿Î½, ÎµÏ„Î¹ÎºÏ„Îµ Î´Îµ Ï†á¿¦Î»Î¿Î½ á½ˆÎ½ÎµÎ¹ÏÏ‰Î½ (nyx dâ€™ eteken stygeron te Moron kai KÄ“ra melainan / kai Thanaton, teke dâ€™ Hypnon, etikte de OneirÅn; â€˜And Night bare hateful Doom and black Fate and Death, and she bare Sleep and the tribe of Dreamsâ€™; Theog 211-12).

St. 26-27 The fiend who follows Guyon recalls the â€˜furyâ€™ in the ancient Eleusinian mysteries who followed initiates to enforce their observance of ritual procedures; Spenser could have learned about this from Claudianâ€™s De Raptu Proserpinae (early fifth century A.D.) or Pausaniasâ€™s Description of Greece (second century A.D.)
dismall day: from L dies mali evil days; see vi.43.7n.
stalke: stride
stalke: Includes the sense that he is stalking Guyon.
likte him: pleased him
likte him: Cf. Ben Jonsonâ€™s â€˜On My First Sonâ€™: â€˜For whose sake henceforth all his vows be such, / As what he loves may never like too muchâ€™ (11-12).

27.2-4 These â€˜fatall Stygian lawesâ€™ are derived in part from the myth of Persephone, who remains in the underworld for half the year because she ate seven seeds from a pomegranate (Met 5.530-38), and in part from folktale motifs (see arg.1n).
>Stygian lawes: Laws of the underworld (from Styx, the river the dead must cross over to enter hell), â€˜fatallâ€™ both because they punish with death and because they govern the realm of the dead.
28.3 Arches of stone are said to â€˜hangâ€™ from the vaulted ceiling like pants in tatters. The image evokes something like a â€˜naturalâ€™ gothic arch.

Embost: Ornamented with raised surfaces bulging in relief. OED s.v. â€˜bossâ€™ records a specifically geological sense â€˜applied chiefly to masses of rock protruding through strata of another kindâ€™, although this use is not noted prior to 1605.

of glorious guifte: Although seemingly offered, this gold is hoarded, not given. Accordingly, the preposition suspends guifte as an attribute of the substance, absent an actual giver, gift, or recipient.
28.5 I.e. every rift [was] loaded with rich metal.
ruine: collapse
ruine: From L ruire to fall.

28.7-9 Arachne challenged Athena to a weaving contest and was punished by being turned into a spider; cf. Muiop 257-352 and Met 6.5-145. â€˜High did lifteâ€™ suggests envy or ambition; â€˜cunningâ€™ and â€˜subtileâ€™ suggest a trap; â€˜smokeâ€™ and â€˜cloudsâ€™ recall the â€˜rustâ€™ and â€˜filthy dustâ€™ of 4.1-3 and anticipate the â€˜dust and old decayâ€™ of 29.2.
29.1-5 These lines reprise several motifs from the initial description of Mammon in st. 3 and 4.
hew: color, appearance, or form

29.6-9 Like st. 21-25, these lines echo Virgilâ€™s description of Aeneasâ€™s descent into the underworld: quale per incertam lunam sub luce maligna / est iter in silvis, ubi caelum conditit umbra / Iuppiter, et rebus nox abstulit atra colorem (â€˜even as under the grudging light of an inconstant moon lies a path in the forest, when Jupiter has buried the sky in shade, and black Night has stolen from the world her huesâ€™; Aen 6.270-72). The Virgilian simile is picked up by Tasso, GL 13.2 and 14.37. Spenserâ€™s â€˜lamp, whose life does fade awayâ€™ may also echo Ariostoâ€™s finÃ­ come il debol lume suole, / cui cera manchi (â€˜he ended like a weak flame running low on waxâ€™; OF 24.85.3-4).
bends: bands
weene: expect
30.6-9 Recalling the valley of bones to which the prophet is transported in Ezek 37, although the â€˜dead mens bonesâ€™ in this scene will not be resurrected like their biblical counterparts.
31.2-3 See Acts 12:10: â€˜they came unto the yron gate, that leadeth unto the citie, which opened to them by it owne accordeâ€™. The gate that opens to Peter leads out of imprisonment, not into it.
Commaunded: assigned
nâ€™ill: ne will, i.e. will not (accept)
33.2-4 Guyonâ€™s play on the word happines may allude to the first book of Aristotleâ€™s Nic Eth, where happiness or the â€˜chief goodâ€™ of the soul is defined.

33.8-9 Guyonâ€™s preference for ruling the rich echoes a popular anecdote about the Roman Manius Curius. See Cicero De Senectute 16.56; Elyot retells the story to illustrate a distinction between â€˜abstinenceâ€™ and â€˜continenceâ€™ (1531: 3.17).
sclave: Archaic spelling preserves the etymology from Med L sclavus.
greedie pray: Transferred epithet (if Guyon were greedy, the fiend would not lack his prey).
weened: believed, supposed
take . . . assay: touch
take . . . assay: See arg.1n on the taboo against touching treasures in the underworld.
34.6 â€˜More swiftly than a dove in the clutches of a falconâ€™.
34.7 An exclamation directed to the reader.
decay: downfall
decay: From L de + cadere to fall.
wist: knew of
raunges: fireplaces or grates
pight: placed
tryde: As a term of art in metallurgy, to â€˜tryâ€™ is â€˜to separate (metal) from the ore or dross by meltingâ€™ (OED).
St. 36 This stanza echoes details from Virgilâ€™s description of the cave beneath Mt. Aetna where Vulcanâ€™s team of Cyclops forge a shield for Aeneas (Aen 8.416-51).
dying bronds: embers
Vulcans rage: the fireâ€™s heat
scumd: skimmed
36.7 Milton echoes this line in Paradise Lost at 1.704 in a description of Mammonâ€™s foundry that is indebted to Spenser.
swincke: toil
battailous: combat-ready
staring: In 15th-c. usage, â€˜shiningâ€™; cf 7.5 and note.
Till that: until
Till that: Spenser often uses â€˜thatâ€™ as a complementizer with prepositions.
Avise thee: think it over
withstood: refused
emprise: enterprise, undertaking
noâ€™te: might not
noâ€™te: Contracted form of â€˜ne moteâ€™ (see glossary).
mesprise: misprision, scorn
40.1-2 Cf. â€˜the gate of Hell, which gaped wideâ€™ (24.6).

if that: FE lists â€˜the thatâ€™ as a correction for page 283. We correct â€˜if theâ€™; other plausible candidates appear at 42.4, 42.8, and 43.2. See 37.9 above and 49.8 below for other examples of Spenserâ€™s habitual use of â€˜thatâ€™ as a complementizer with conjunctions and prepositions.
40.6-7 For all of the gold in Mammonâ€™s realm, there is also a great deal of iron: see 4.1, 21.7, 23.2, 30.2, and 36.4. Cf. also the â€˜later timesâ€™ of 18.4 with Met 1.141-44.
weld: wield
stomacke: pride, anger, or stubbornness
portaunce: bearing

the Titans race: A brood of gigantic immortals, the offspring of Uranus and Ge in Greek mythology, who overthrew their father and were overthrown in turn by their own offspring, Zeus and the other Olympian deities.
deface: discredit, abash, or overshadow
glitterand: glittering
glitterand: The archaic suffix reflects OE, Old Frisian, and Old Saxon forms (â€˜-endeâ€™, â€˜-andâ€™) out of which â€˜â€“ingâ€™ evolved in the fifteenth century.
hurtle: brandish
hurtle: OED describes Spenserâ€™s use of the verb in this sense as â€˜erroneousâ€™.
42.5-9 Cf. Guyonâ€™s encounter with Furor at iv.3-10.
dight: prepare
43.1 Underlining the irony of Mammon taking over the Palmerâ€™s role.
Carle: churl
Gyeld: guildhall
Gyeld: On the likelihood of topical references here and elsewhere in the scene to the Royal Exchange, the Templar knights, and the Tower Mint, see Owens 2005: 156-64.
full deare: richly

43.8-9 The third of the temptations that Satan offers to Christ in the wilderness includes â€˜all the kingdomes of the worldeâ€™ (Matt 4:8). Commentators vary as to how closely Mammonâ€™s temptation of Guyon follows Satanâ€™s three temptations of Christ; parallels would be mediated by the extensive body of medieval and renaissance theology devoted to classifying the temptations. Miltonâ€™s treatment of the temptations in Paradise Regained is clearly informed by Spenserâ€™s Mammon episode.
route: crowd
preaced: An archaic spelling of â€˜pressedâ€™; cf. the noun â€˜preaceâ€™ at 46.5 and 48.2.
44.5-9 Cf. Langlandâ€™s description of Lade Meed, Piers Plowman B.2.8-17.
siege: â€˜A seat, esp. one used by a person of rank or distinctionâ€™ (OED).

never earthly Prince . . . pompous pryde display: A parody of Christâ€™s call for simplicity and contentedness in Matt 6:28-29; turning the natural beauty of the lilies (â€˜even Solomon in all his glorie was not arrayed like one of theseâ€™) into an over-abundance of ornamentation and pomp.

St. 46 The â€˜great gold chaineâ€™ held by the â€˜woman gorgeous gayâ€™ (44.6) alludes to the golden chain in Homer with which the other gods sought unsuccessfully to pull Jove down from heaven (Il 8.18-27). The image gains historical resonance as both classical and, later, Christian commentators interpret it as a symbol of cosmic order. Lotspeich 1932 cites as precedents for Spenserâ€™s use of the image Plato, Theat 153D; Boethius, Cons Phil 2.meter.8; Chaucer, Troilus 3.1744-1771, and CT Knight A 2987-93; Rom Rose 16988-9; and Conti Myth 116 (64). See also I.ix.1 and note for Spenserâ€™s use of the chain as a positive symbol linking the virtues and their patron knights in an alliance of â€˜noble mindesâ€™. His use of the symbol here to suggest avarice follows Conti in combining both interpretations.
sty: ascend
dignity: rank or office

dignity: â€˜Ambitionâ€™ was denounced in Elizabethan orthodoxy as a form of rebellion against social order, but if the ranks are links in the chain of ambition, as this line seems to say, then ambition is less a force opposed to hierarchy than its inevitable consequence.
St. 47 Cf. Colinâ€™s satiric portrait of the English court in Colin Clout 688-730.

Philotime: â€˜love of honorâ€™ from Gk Ï†Î¹Î»Î¿Ï‚ philos love + Ï„Î¹Î¼Î· timÄ“ honor (cf. Timon, I.ix.4.1-2; Timias, III.i.18.9). Meter calls for the final â€˜eâ€™ to be voiced, with the primary accent falling on the second syllable.
49.2 Cf. â€˜greatest god below the skyeâ€™ (8.2) and note.
the gods: Mammon, though himself a Biblical figure, seems to recognize only pagan deities.
lust: wish, but also desire sexually
works and merits: Alluding to the theological distinction between works and faith; see OED s.v. â€˜meritâ€™: â€˜Theol. In pl. Good works viewed as entitling a person to reward from Godâ€™.
Gramercy: thanks

Gramercy: An unexpectedly â€˜gentleâ€™ reply, compared to the scorn Guyon has exhibited earlier (st.13-17, 33, 39). Perhaps Guyon has overcome Disdayne after allâ€”but the etymology of â€˜gramercyâ€™ contains a pointed riposte to Mammonâ€™s last offer, for as OED notes, â€˜The primary sense of merci was â€œreward, favour gained by meritâ€; hence grant merci originally meant â€œmay God reward you greatlyâ€™â€™â€™.
and mine unequall fate: â€˜and [I know] my fate [to be] unequalâ€™ to such an â€˜immortal mateâ€™.
yplight: pledged
remove: disavow
forcing it to fayne: Ellipsis for â€˜forcing [himself] to dissemble it [the wrath]â€™ or â€˜forcing it [the wrath] to dissemble [itself]â€™.
redd: declared

51.8-9 Echoing Proteusâ€™s description of caligantem nigra formidine lucum (â€˜the grove that is murky with black terrorâ€™) through which Orpheus passes upon entering the underworld in his quest to recover Euridice (Virgil, Georg 4.467-68).

St. 52 In contrast to the description offered by Claudian, De Raptu 2.290, where Pluto is praising the beauties of the realm he promises to his bride. Pausanius says â€˜black poplars and willowsâ€™ grow there (Desc 10.30.72).
Gall: Gall Oak whose misnamed â€˜fruitâ€™ or â€˜oak-appleâ€™ is a gall, or spongy spherical deformation of the leaf-bud caused by wasp larvae.
Heben: black ebony

Heben: Cf. Georg. 2.117 hebenum, glossed by T. Cooper: â€˜A tree whereof the wode is blacke as jette within, and beareth nor leaves nor fruiteâ€™ (1565, s.v. â€˜Hebenusâ€™). OED cites Gower, Conf. 2. 103, â€˜Of hebenus that slepy treâ€™.
Hellebore: Used as a purgative.

Coloquintida: Cf. 2 Kings 4:38-41: Elisha shreds wild gourds into â€˜the pot of pottageâ€™ during a famine, but the men who eat from it cry out that â€˜death is in the potâ€™. The Geneva gloss identifies the gourds as â€˜colloquintida . . . moste vehement and dangerous in purgingâ€™.
Tetra: Hunt 1883 identifies this as â€˜the tetrum solanum, or deadly nightshadeâ€™ (85).

Samnitis: Not known, but Upton 1758 guesses (because the ancient Samnites dwelt next to the Sabines on the Italian peninsula) that it refers to the savin, used because of its poisonous properties as an anthelminthic and abortifacient.
Cicuta: hemlock

52.6-9 The friend who attends on Socrates at his death is Crito; Critias was an enemy. Commentators have proposed Xenophon, Hellenica 2.3.56, and Cicero, Tusculan Disputations 1.40, as sources for an error here.
last Philosophy: Philosophy of â€˜last thingsâ€™, i.e. the soulâ€™s immortality (which would explain â€˜quaffing gladâ€™); philosophy delivered at the point of death.
Gardin of Proserpina: Cf. Od 10.509-40, where Circe describes the garden Odysseus will pass through on his way to Hades, and st. 52n.
overdight: overspread
entreat: occupy herself with
entreat: Cf. Romeo and Juliet 4.1.40: â€˜My lord, we must entreat the time aloneâ€™.

note.p: golden apples: Mentioned by Claudian, De Raptu: est etiam lucis arbor praevives opacis / fulgentes viridi ramos curvata metallo (â€˜There is, moreover, a precious tree in the leafy groves whose curving branches gleam with living oreâ€™; 2.290-91).

Typology would associate Proserpineâ€™s golden apples with the fruit taken by Eve in Gen 2. Spenser may also allude to the golden bough in Virgil: latet arbore opaca / aureus et foliis et lento vimine ramus, / Iuonini infernae dictus sacer (â€˜There lurks in a shady tree a bough, golden in leaf and pliant stem, held consecrate to nether Junoâ€™; Aen 6.136-38).

div.note: 54.5-6 Herculesâ€™ eleventh labor, to fetch the golden apples of the Hesperides (â€˜great Atlas daughtersâ€™) is discussed by Conti, Myth 622. The labors of Hercules were typologically associated by many Renaissance writers with Christâ€™s victory over evil.

54.8-9 The story of Hippomemes (â€˜thâ€™EubÃ¦an young manâ€™) racing for the hand of Atalanta is told by Ovid (Met 10.560-680) and mentioned by Conti, Myth 624-25. Spenser links the apples of Hercules and Atalanta in Am 77, a dream vision of his belovedâ€™s breast that associates the apples of the Hesperides with those of Song Sol 2.5 (â€˜comfort me with apples: for I am sicke of loveâ€™) and distinguishes them from the fruit in Gen (â€˜yet voyd of sinfull viceâ€™). Cf. the description in the same sonnet of how Cupid transplanted these apples from â€˜paradiceâ€™ into his own garden. Cf. also Ronsard, Amours 1.145.
sold: derived
55.1-3 Ovid tells how Acontius used an apple to trick Cydippe into marrying him (Her 20).

55.4-9 References to the apple of discord as the origin of the Trojan War are found in various classical sources; Conti Myth 555 quotes from Lucian, Ovid, Strabo, and Euripides in his summary of the story. (Spenserâ€™s substitution of Ate for the figure of Eris in Greek myth may proceed by way of Contiâ€™s Discordia).

IdÃ¦an: From Mount Ida, the setting for the Judgement of Paris. The apple thrown â€˜emongest the Godsâ€™ at the wedding of Thetis and Peleus, inscribed â€˜for the fairestâ€™, was claimed by Hera, Athena, and Venus.
fee: wealth
without: beyond
Cocytus: Gk ÎšÏ‰ÎºÏ…Ï„oÏ‚ KÅkytos wailing; one of the rivers in the classical underworld.
of: by
shrightes: shrieks
resounden wide: echo into the distance
liquour: liquid
drouth: thirst
couth: could
ment: intended; signified
ment: The ambiguity raises the question whether Tantalus controls his own meaningâ€” whether he appears as agent or as emblem.
againe: in reply

59.5-9 Details of the scene are drawn from Homer (Od 11.582-92), although the fruits after which Tantalus reaches in Homer (pears, pomegranates, apples, figs, olives) would presumably be edible, unlike the â€˜golden applesâ€™ in Spenser, which nudge Tantalus in the direction of Midas. Tantalus appears in many classical and medieval texts, often as a symbol of greed: cf. Pindar, Olympia 1; Horace, Satires 1.1; Ovid, Ars Am 2.601-6; Dante, Inf 8.31-39; Boccaccio, Genealogia 1.14; Conti Myth 531-535; Alciati, Embemata 85.
59.6 Tantalus sought to test the omniscience of the Gods by serving his own son Pelops to them at a banquet. Pelops was restored to life, Tantalus consigned to hell.
give to eat: Echoing Mark 6:37, â€˜Give ye them to eatâ€™.

St. 60 See 59.2n above; in this stanza one ambiguity is resolvedâ€”Tantalus is told to â€˜beâ€™ an emblemâ€”while another ambiguity opens up. In 1590 Guyon instructs Tantalus to be an emblem of â€˜mind more temperateâ€™, whereas in 1596 and 1609 the instruction reads â€˜Ensample be of mind intemperateâ€™. Either version can make sense: Tantalus may be an emblem of intemperance punished, but if he does â€˜abide the fortuneâ€™ of his â€˜present fateâ€™, he may become an example of â€˜mind more temperateâ€™.

60.6-9 Cf. Rev 16:9, â€˜And men boyled in great heat, and blasphemed the Name of God, which hathe power over these plagues, and they repented not, to give him glorieâ€™. The Geneva gloss identifies the â€˜great heatâ€™ of this passage as â€˜Signifying famine, drought and hote diseases which procede thereofâ€™.
dye: i.e., eternally
drent: drowned
61.4-5 Cf. Isa 1.15: â€˜And when you shal stretch out your hands, I wil hide mine eyes from you: and thogh ye make manie prayers, I wil not heare: for your hands are ful of bloodâ€™.
61.6-9 Pilateâ€™s failed effort to wash his hands of guilt echoes Guyonâ€™s failed attempt to wash the hands of Ruddymane (ii.3).
fayned: â€˜fainedâ€™ (desired) and â€˜feignedâ€™ (pretended)
62.3-9 Based on Matt 27: 22-26.
62.5-7 Echoing Acts 3:14-15.
doome: verdict
62.8-9 Cf. Ps 26.6, â€˜I wil wash mine hands in innocencieâ€™, as well as the Geneva gloss to Isa 1:16: â€˜By this outward washig [sic], he meaneth the spiritualâ€™.

63.7-9 Cf. the stratagem used by Pluto to ensnare Theseus and Pirithous when they journey to Hades to kidnap Persephone: â€˜on the pretence that they were about to partake of good cheer Hades bade them first be seated on the Chair of Forgetfulness, to which they grew and were held fast by coils of serpentsâ€™ (Apollodorus, Epitome 1.24). Cf. I.v.35.8n and Aen 6.617-18: sedet aeternumque sedebit / infelix Theseus (â€˜hapless Theseus sits and evermore shall sitâ€™). For a modern retelling that shows the influence of Spenserâ€™s passage, see Lewis, The Silver Chair. Some commentators suspect a reminiscence of the â€˜forbidden seatâ€™ of the Eleusinian mysteries, as described (for example) by Clement of Alexandria in â€˜Exhortation to the Heathenâ€™: â€˜For Demeter, wandering in quest of her daughter Core [Proserpine], broke down with fatigue near Eleusis, a place in Attica, and sat down on a well overwhelmed with grief. This is even now prohibited to those who are initiated, lest they should appear to mimic the weeping goddessâ€™ (32).
frayle intemperaunce: Transferred epithet: intemperance is itself the frailty.
lust: appetite or desire
beguile the Guyler: Cf. Piers Plowman 18.159-60: â€˜the old law granteth, / That beguilers be beguiledâ€™.

three dayes of men: Cf. Matt 12:40: â€˜For as Jonas was thre dayes, and thre nighs in the whales bellie: so shal the Sonne of man be thre dayes and thre nights in the heart of the earthâ€™. Brooks-Davies 1977 reports that three days â€˜was generally agreed by commentators to be the â€œpermitted timeâ€ granted to Aeneasâ€™ in the underworld (157; Aen 6.537).
outwrought: completed
For thy: therefore

66.2-3 Upton 1758 cites Plutarchâ€™s de genio Socratis as the source for â€˜two nights and one dayâ€™ being â€˜allowed for surveying, according to the sacred mysteries, the infernal regionsâ€™ (490; 590A in Plutarchâ€™s text describes the ritual time allowed for underworld exploration).
66.5-6 Cf. Marlowe, Tamburlaine: â€˜when this fraile and transitory flesh / Hath suckt the measure of that vitall aireâ€™ (II.v.43-44).
in swowne: See vii.66.8-9. Varying designations of Guyonâ€™s state may be tracked through the present canto.
Acrates sonnes: For the etymology shared by Acrates and Acrasia, see i.51.2-4n.
despoyld: stripped of his armor
Whom: Guyon

1.1 OED glosses the exclamatory use of â€˜andâ€™, â€˜expressing surprise at, or asking the truth of, what one has already heardâ€™. Spenser intensifies the sense of wonder by opening with the device, leaving unstated â€˜what one has already heardâ€™. A possibility would be 1 Pet 5:7, â€˜Cast all your care on him: for he careth for youâ€™. Contrast Virgil, tantaene animis caelestibus irae? (â€˜Can resentment so fierce dwell in heavenly breasts?â€™; Aen 1.11). The sense of wonderment at something already there, apprehended yet unapparent, in Spenserâ€™s opening line may intimate the prevenience of grace.
1.2 Biblical precedent for the ministration of angels may be found at Ps 34:7, Matt 4:11, and Heb 1:14.
evilles: sufferings
1.7 Cf. Ps 145:9, â€˜his mercies are over all his workesâ€™.
Angels: From Gk Î±Î³Î³ÎµÎ»Î¿Ï‚ aggelos messenger.
succour: aid, assist, or bring reinforcements to
flitting: unstable
Pursuivant: a royal messenger

militant: Warlike or disposed to combat (cf. â€˜Squadronsâ€™); stationed at the end of the clause, â€˜militantâ€™ describes the manner of angelic â€˜aydâ€™, but other senses are also available: â€˜they militantâ€™ and even â€˜us militantâ€™, where the zeugma draws â€˜ourâ€™ militancy together with â€˜theirsâ€™ (the function of grace according to Calvinist doctrine). On spiritual warfare, see 2 Cor 10:4: â€˜the weapons of our warrefare are not carnalâ€™. Reformed theology distinguished between the Church Militant, comprised of Christians on earth engaged in combat against sin, and the Church Triumphant, comprised of those in heaven who have triumphed over sin. Cf. Eph 6:11-12: â€˜Put on the whole armour of God, that ye may be able to stand against the assaultes of the devil. For we wrestle not against flesh and blood, but against principalities, against powers, and against the worldly governours, the princes of the darkenes of this worlde, against spirituall wickednesses, which are in the hie placesâ€™.
2.7 See Ps 34:7: â€˜The Angel of the Lord pitcheth rounde about them, that feare him, and delivereth themâ€™.
And . . . and . . .and: Polysyndeton, â€˜characterized by the number of connecting particles employedâ€™ (Quintilian, Inst 9.3.51). See 1.1n.

2.9 See Ps 8:4, â€˜What is man, say I, that thou art mindful of him? and the sonne of man, that thou visitest him?â€™ Also 144:3, â€˜Lord, what is man that thou regardest him!â€™, and Job 7:17, â€˜What is man, that thou doest magnifie him, and that thou settest thine heart upon him?â€™
3.2-3 Phaedria denies the Palmer passage on her gondola at vi.19.4-9.
whyleare: formerly
efforced: uttered with effort
efforced: OED cites only this instance.
by and by: immediately
sunne his threasury: On Mammonâ€™s â€˜threasureâ€™, see vii.arg 2n.

senceles dreame: Transferred epithet, applying properly to the dreamer; a dream with no sensory content would be no dream at all. See arg.1n on the ambiguity of Guyonâ€™s state, and compare Redcrosse on the second night of the dragon battle in Book I, lying â€˜as in a dreame of deepe delightâ€™ (50.4) while his wounds are healed by a stream of balm trickling from the tree of life.

Beside his head: See I.ix.22.1-2, â€˜they might perceive his head / To bee unarmdâ€™, and note. Also John 20:12, â€˜[Mary] sawe two Angels in white, sitting, the one at the head, and the other at the feeteâ€™.
equall peares: coevals
his snowy front: L frons forehead. See Matt 28:2-3, â€˜the Angel of the Lord descended from heaven . . . And his countenance was like lightning, and his raiment white as snoweâ€™.
Phoebus: the sunâ€™s
winged sheares: A metaphor for the wings, in which the tenor reappears as an adjective modifying the vehicle.
diverse: multi-colored
like painted Jayes: Cf. Chaucer, Parl 356, â€˜the pekok, with his aungels fetheres bryghteâ€™.

St. 6 The angel is winged like Cupid, but the simile goes on to specify when the resemblance is apt: when Cupid has laid his bow aside (cf. I.pr.3.5) to play with Venus and the Graces, shadowing Christian agape, divine beauty, and grace. For an account of this simile in the context of a Spenserianian â€˜theodicy of Cupidâ€™ that integrates human with divine love, see SpE s.v. â€˜Cupidâ€™ and â€˜angel, Guyonâ€™sâ€™.
IdÃ¦an hill: Mount Ida; see vii.55.6n.
his goodly sisters: The three Graces are reputed daughters of Venus (Servius ad Aen 1.720, Boccaccio Genealogia 3.22, Conti Myth 325). Cf. VI.x.22 and Teares 401-6.
through sleepe beguild: Sleep in Spenser is regularly associated with deception; see ii.46.6-7 and v.34, as well as the extended tableau of the sleeping Verdant at xii.72-80.
childe: In ME ballads and romances, a young noble awaiting knighthood; Spenser uses the term more generally as a chivalric and slightly archaic title designating a young man of gentle birth.
corage bold respire: again breathe courageous spirit
8.1 See Ps 91:11, â€˜For he shal give his Angels charge over thee to kepe thee in all thy waiesâ€™.
arrett: entrust
offend: attack
offend: From L offedere to strike against.
painted: brightly colored
as . . . flight: â€˜As [if he were a] fowle escapt by flightâ€™.
courd: covered

courd: We make an exception here to our policy of modernizing u/v orthography because the spelling â€˜courdâ€™ appears meant to capture a particular pronunciation (a phonetic reduction) in the service of monosyllabic scansion. The phonetically reduced form of â€˜coveredâ€™ allows it to merge with â€˜curedâ€™. OED identifies â€˜cureâ€™ as an elided form of â€˜coverâ€™, although â€˜cureâ€™ (as in â€˜curateâ€™, from L curare to care for) is also relevant. (Cf. recured and note at iv.16.7 and discure as a form of â€˜discoverâ€™ at ix.42.8.)
9.8-9 Cf. Matt 23:37, â€˜I have gathered thy children together, as the henne gathereth her chickens under her wingsâ€™. The syntax (â€˜courd it . . . fromâ€™) indicates a defensive gesture.

newly hatcht: For the hatchling as a conventional symbol of the soulâ€™s immortality, see e.g. Camerarius 1590, Symbolorum et Emblamata Centuria 3.69, Nulla mihi mora est (â€˜death is nothing to meâ€™)
Paynim: heathen
Paynim: The â€˜two sonnes of Acratesâ€™ are not identified as Saracen knights during their earlier appearance in cantos iv-vi.
10.3 Archimago plays the Palmerâ€™s part, as in the first episode of Book 2.
two sonnes of Acrates: See arg.2 and i.51.2-4n.
10.7-8 At vi. 47-51 the brethren encounter Archimago on the shore of the â€˜Idle lakeâ€™ (vi.10.1-2).
dearly: heartily; keenly; at a high cost
11.4-5 Cf. Prov 26:21, â€˜As the cole maketh burning coles, and the wood a fyre, so the contentious man is apt to kindle strifeâ€™.
stryful: strife-full
Atin: See iv.42.5n.
whot: hot
slombred: unconscious; corse: body
slombred: A Spenserianism. Cf I.vii.15.6, the sole instance cited by OED.
debate: combat
brutenesse shendst: stupidity disgrace
comely: In ME usage, â€˜applied in courtesy to those of noble stationâ€™ (OED). Cf. i.7.2.
caytive: vile
stile: title
envy . . . to barke: Cf. SC â€˜To His Bookeâ€™ 5, â€˜And if that Envie barke at theeâ€™. Early modern envy commonly barks and often bites as well.
14.5 Proverbial (Smith 1970, no 336).
14.7-9 Misapplies a well-known saying attributed to Solon the Lawgiver by Herodotus (Persian Wars 1.30) and Plutarch (Parallel Lives, Solon 37).
recke: care
hire: spoils
blame: bring into disrepute

16.4-5 See Mark 15:24 on the soldiers casting lots for Christâ€™s garments; Faithâ€™s rebuke to the Roman soldier who wounds Christâ€™s body on the cross in Langland, Piers Plowman: â€˜Cursede caytyues! Knighthood was it nevere / To misdo a dead body, by daye nor by nyghtâ€™ (Crowley 1550, 18.96-97,); and Achillesâ€™ treatment of Hectorâ€™s corpse in Homer (Il 22.375-404).
weed: garments
trap: deck
dight: decked with trappings
16.9 See Goliathâ€™s threat to David at 1 Sam 17:44, â€˜I wil give thy flesh unto the foules of the heaven, and to the beastes of the fieldâ€™.
heben: ebony
17.7 For the shield covered to protect onlookers from its blinding brightness, see I.viii.19 and OF 2.55-56.
Well kend him so far space: Archimago recognizes Arthur from a distance.
amenaunce: bearing
bylive: â€˜beliveâ€™, immediately
prowest: worthiest, having the most â€˜prowessâ€™
Sarâ€™zins: Saracens

Sarâ€™zins: From late L SaracÄ“ni, the people of Arabia. Applied to Muslim combatants in the Crusades; a medieval etymology going back to Jerome derives the term from the name of Abrahamâ€™s wife Sarah while identifying the Muslims who bear the name as descendants of Hagar.
19.1 The first mention of this lack, although Pyrochles is described at vi.41.3-4 as having abandoned his horse.
faine: willingly
Beteeme: yield
kend: understood, discovered
MedÃ¦wart: Herb also known as â€˜meadow-sweetâ€™. The etymology of the name is uncertain; see OED s.v. â€˜meadwortâ€™.
Aetna: The location of Vulcanâ€™s forge, where both the sword of Turnus and the armor of Aeneas were made.

20.8-9 Virgil reports that the sword of Turnus was tempered in â€˜the Stygian waveâ€™ (Stygia tinxerat unda, Aen 12.91); it was also in the â€˜Stygian lakeâ€™ that Occasion is said to have kindled the fire-brand she brings to Furor (v.22.6-8).
seven times: The number of times Elisha tells Naaman to dip himself in the river Jordan to be cleansed (2 Kings 5:10).
which hidden vertue to it gave: Cf. the near-total invulnerability conferred upon Achilles when, according to Statius, he was dipped in the river Styx as an infant. (Achilleid 1.133-34, 266-71).
fone: ME plural of â€˜foeâ€™, still current in the 16th-c.
his: its

Morddure: From L mordere to bite + durus hard, perhaps by way of Fr; cf. English â€˜mordantâ€™. Sound evokes also Fr mort death, and English â€˜murderâ€™, and may echo â€˜Durlindanaâ€™, the sword of Orlando in OF.
brond: poeticism for â€˜swordâ€™

22.4 See 20.8-9n above, and v.22.6-9, where Occasion arms Furor with â€˜a flaming fyer brondâ€™ that is not a poetically-designated sword but literally a fire-brand: Furor is then â€˜armed with fireâ€™.

His Lords owne flesh: The scriptural resonance of the phrasing, while not a precise echo, does recall the language of passages like John 6:48-60, and in this way touches on the allegory that makes Arthur a type of Christ bringing life to fallen man: â€˜Except ye eat the flesh of the Sone of man, and drinke his blood, ye have no life in youâ€™ (6:53). Johnâ€™s emphasis on this flesh as the only food that can nourish the soul (e.g., 6:48-51 and marginal glosses) may also be relevant to Guyonâ€™s famished state.
vertuous: Morally righteous, but also having occult powers.
salued: saluted
salued: Cf. Caxton, â€˜He salued theym curtoyslyâ€™ (Sonnes of Aymon iii.75.28).
stomachous: angry
demayne: demeanor

magnanimity: The culminating virtue in Aristotleâ€™s Nic Eth. Cf. FQ Letter 38-40, where Spenser uses â€˜magnificenceâ€™ to designate the virtue that is â€˜(according to Aristotle and the rest) . . . the perfection of all the restâ€™, and ascribes this virtue to Arthur.
redoubted: feared or reverenced
cace: condition (of his body)
deface: destroy
deface: If the etymology is taken from L facere, the sense might be â€˜undoâ€™.
ghost: soul or spirit
26.7-8 On the special power of temperate or temporizing language, see 22.1-2, vi.36.3-5, III.ii.15.5-6, IV.ii.2.5-6, IV.ix.14.6-7, and VI.v.30.6-8.
patronage: guardianship

Not to debate the chalenge of your right: To â€˜challenge rightâ€™ is to lay a claim to, or assert a right, so that â€˜not to debate the chalenge of your rightâ€™ means â€˜not to take up the claim (of right) that you have laid/enteredâ€™: Arthur indicates that he is not going to dispute the legal basis of the knightsâ€™ quarrel with Guyon, but rather ask â€˜pardonâ€™ for him on essentially compassionate grounds. At the same time there is a play on the word â€˜chalengeâ€™, because medieval trials of right usually took the form of ordeal, including combat. In a chivalric encounter of this kind, a â€˜challengeâ€™ is a summoning or defiance offered by one contestant to others. Hence the â€˜chalengeâ€™ here might also be â€˜an offer of battle, a defianceâ€™, linked to the â€˜matter of rightâ€™ being contested between the brothers and Guyon; cf. â€˜debateâ€™ as combat at 11.9 and 54.6. (On the concentration of legal diction in this episode see Zurcher 2007:70).
28.2 See Job 9:33: â€˜Neither is there any dayesman to lay his hande betweene usâ€™ (Bishopsâ€™ Bible; Geneva reads â€˜Nether is there any umpire that might laie his hand upon us botheâ€™.
prolong: delay
let: prevent
deare abye: pay dearly
29.1-6 Arthurâ€™s definition of Godâ€™s justice in these lines is based on the second commandment, Exod 20:5.
Nephewes: grandsonâ€™s
Nephewes: From L nepos.
bereave: take away
bereave: Normally the thing taken is valued, with the verb expressing a sense of loss.
streightly: strictly
upreare: Breaks the rhyme-scheme. Hamilton 2001 notes that â€˜â€œupheaueâ€ would satisfy the â€œbâ€ rhyme, though that word is never used in the poem while â€œupreareâ€ is commonâ€™.
felon: villain
Termagaunt: â€˜An imaginary deity held in mediÃ¦val Christendom to be worshipped by Muslimsâ€™ (OED); cf. 33.3.
sad: heavy
noâ€™uld: ne would (would not)
