31.6-7 The notion of a â€˜law of armesâ€™ goes back to Roman authors, but was revived and elaborated in form of the â€˜chivalric codeâ€™ by medieval writers like Jean de Meun and Christine de Pizan. To â€˜strike foe undefideâ€™ was to attack without first issuing a formal challenge; see i.25.9n.
miscreaunt: misbeliever
defast: disfigured; discredited; erased
bent: aimed
32.5 Pyrochles lays â€˜rude handâ€™ on Guyonâ€™s shield at 17.1.
stownd: shock, attack
Mahoune: A form of the name â€˜Mohammedâ€™, but also another imaginary deity held in the Middle Ages to be worshipped by Muslims; see 30.4n.
aby: pay for; cf. 28.8.
Els mote it needes: Otherwise it must (OED s.v. â€˜needsâ€™).
doe him small redresse: give him little help
importable: insupportable
his ground to traverse: to shift his ground
stowre: battle, onslaught
stowre: Etymologically linked to â€˜stormâ€™ (see 48.2).
assay: attack
poynant: piercing
puissant sway: powerful force
gryde: Cf. SC Feb. 4 E.K. gloss, â€˜Gride) perced: an olde word much used of Lidgateâ€™.
plesh: puddle
his Gods: Termagaunt (30.4) and Mahoune (33.3).
rayle: gush
very felnesse: utter rage
Caytive: wretch
brond: See 22.4n.
he: Cymochles
thother: Pyrochles
The one: conflating the knight (now Pyrochles) with his swordstroke.
his owner byte: Pyrochles wields Morddure (see 21.6n and 22.5n).
troncheon: spear-stump
thâ€™other: now Cymochles
truncheon: From L truncus trunk.
hacqueton: jacket worn under the chain mail
importune: inopportune; pressing
dint: blow

38.9-39.2 â€˜But one of the souldiers with a speare perced his side, and forthewith came there out blood and waterâ€™ (John 19:34). For the medieval tradition that locates this wound on the right, see Gurewich (1957: 359b). Cf. 22.5n.
at warde: in a defensive stance
his foot revoke: retreat
raught: reached
as he it ought: as he who owns it (Guyon)
40.7-9 The simile is scriptural: cf. 2 Sam 17:8, Prov. 17:12, Hos 13:8.
wood: mad
yond: savage
yond: OED suggests Spenser may have misunderstood a line from Chaucer: â€˜Beth egre as is a Tygre yond in Yndeâ€™ (CT Clerk IV 1199)â€™.
throwes: strokes
told: numbered
hart-thrilling: heart-piercing

St. 42 Imitated from a simile in Ariosto: Chi ha visto in piazza rompere steccato, a cui la folta turba ondeggi intorno,immansueto tauro accaneggiato, stimulato e percosso tutto 'l giorno (â€˜Imagine a wild bull pent up in a public square, goaded and struck all day long until, in a fit of rage, he breaks out . . . .â€™; OF 18.19.1-4).
42.2 â€˜Once rancor goads him with rageâ€™.
smitt: smote
43.3 The portrait on Guyonâ€™s shield is mentioned previously at i.28.7-8 and v.11.7-8.
For â€˜stowreâ€™, see 35.4n.
noâ€™te: ne mote (may not)
appeached: accused
haubergh: armor that protects the neck and shoulders
thore: through (archaic)
renfierst: re-enfierced
renfierst: OED cites only this instance.
burganet: helmet

45.6-9 See the death of Turnus in Virgil, ast illi solvuntur frigore membra / vitaque cum gemitu fugit indignata sub umbras (â€˜But the otherâ€™s limbs grew slack and chill, and with a moan life passed indignant to the Shades belowâ€™, Aen 12.951-52).
german: brother
frayd: made afraid
Harrow and well away: See vi.43.6 and note.
lenger day: a day longer
47.2 The desire for revenge blends with the desire for death; cf. the confusion of retribution with self-destruction in Pyrochlesâ€™ motto (iv.38.5 and note).
47.4 Pyrochles flies fiercely at Arthur with Arthurâ€™s own sword.
foynd: lunged or thrust
this . . . that: Pyrochles . . . Arthur
Prince Arthur: 1590 prints â€˜Sir Guyonâ€™, an error not corrected until 1609.
49.1-7 See Tassoâ€™s description of the combat between Tancred and Argante (GL 29.17).
50.2-4 Imitated from Virgil Aen 11.721-24; cf. Ovid Met 6:516-18.
Bittur: bittern
Bittur: A smaller cousin of the heron.
sad melancholy: sullen anger
great mind: Magnanimity, from L magna great + animus spirit; see 23.9n and Aristotle, Nic Eth 4.3.
decay: destruction
dismall day: day of doom
dismall day: From L dies mali; see vi.43.7n.
miscreaunce: misbelief
miscreaunce: Cf. 31.6.
liegeman: â€˜A vassal sworn to the service and support of his superior lord, who in return was obliged to afford him protectionâ€™ (OED).
for ay: for ever
valiaunce: valor
sovenaunce: memory
Foole: Cf. Matt 5:22, â€˜whosoever shal say, Foole, shalbe worthie to be punished with hel fyreâ€™.
52.2 Cf. Virgil, utere sorta tua (â€˜use thou thy chanceâ€™; Aen. 12.932). The allusion to Virgilâ€™s Turnus may pass though Tassoâ€™ Argantes at GL 19.26.

52.8-9 The elliptical treatment of the decapitating blow in these lines recalls a similar ellipsis in Virgilâ€™s description of the death of Priam, Aen 2.554-58. In combining a reminiscence of Priamâ€™s death with that of Turnus, Spenser here anticipates Shakespeareâ€™s conflation in Hamlet (2.2.468-497) of the same Virgilian moments.
her sencelesse foe: Transferred epithet: lifeâ€™s foe is senselessness itself.
53.9 See Recrosseâ€™s similar address to Una at I.ix.17.4-5.
the tokens trew: The visible evidence that the Palmerâ€™s words are true.
embayd: bathed
embayd: Possibly with baptismal overtones.
the Patrone of his life: Cf. 26.9, â€˜thy knights last patronageâ€™; also I.ix.17.6, II.xi.16.9.
my liege: See 51.7n.

55.9 This half-line remains in later editions; Church 1758 observes that Arthur may cut Guyon off. If so, then in preempting Guyonâ€™s speech Arthur closes the canto as it opens, with a formal mimesis of the prevenience of grace.
Infant: prince
Infant: From Span Infante.
56.1-3 For the contrasting economies of merit and grace, see 2.8 and vii.49.9n.

56.7-8 â€˜In this way they devised together a substantial conversation about kindness and the courteous giving of graceâ€™. For â€˜aggraceâ€™ as a noun, OED cites only this instance. As a verb it means to convey grace, as at I.x.18.7, where it describes the action of Fidelia in preparing Redcrosse to read scripture.

arg.1-2 Spenserâ€™s â€˜house of Temperanceâ€™ as the dwelling-place of the soul finds precedents in Langlandâ€™s castle of Anima (Piers P 9.48-52), Gowerâ€™s â€˜Almeâ€™ and her castle (Mirrour de Lâ€™omme, 11281-92, 14713-24), and du Bartas Div Wks 1.6; in Paulâ€™s definition of the body as â€˜the temple of the holie Gostâ€™ (1 Cor 6:19); and in Platoâ€™s account of how the body was constructed to house the soul and the passions (Tim 65-75). For a more extensive listing of precedents, see Var 2.285-89. Phineas Fletcher amplifies Spenserâ€™s allegory of the body in The Purple Island (1633); Helkiah Crooke uses the description of Almaâ€™s castle to structure his anatomical textbook Microcosmographia (1615), especially books II-VII (although Crooke, unlike Spenser, in books IV-V does include the â€˜parts of generationâ€™).
sober: serious, dignified, sedate
sober: The word reappears at 1.4 (cf. i.7.7, ii.14.5).
Alma: Ital alma soul; Heb Almah maiden; L alma kind, nourishing.
straunger: Because they are new arrivals to the house of Temperance.
1.1-4 Cf. 1 Cor 12:24, â€˜God hathe tempered the bodie togetherâ€™.
Of all Gods workes: Cf. â€˜all his workes with mercy doth embraceâ€™ (viii.1.7).
adorne: In the technical sense of ornament as betokening cosmos, Gods workes decorate the macrocosm by mirroring its structure. (For ornament as â€˜cosmic imageâ€™, see Fletcher 1964: 108-117.)

government: Cf. â€˜governaunceâ€™ (i.29.8 and note). In the analogy between the body and the body politic, temperance corresponds to government; see 48.9, where the counselors in the tripartite brain counsel Alma â€˜how to governe wellâ€™, and 59.9, where Arthur reads about the reduction of Briton â€˜to one mans governementsâ€™.

indecent: FE corrects 1590 incedent, which better fits the meter and might, as â€˜incidentâ€™, imply an etymological pun on L in + caedere to fall. The metrical torque on â€˜indecentâ€™ suggests a comparable pun on â€˜in descentâ€™.
Distempred: Having the bodily humors thrown out of balance.
incontinent: immediately; concupiscent
his: its
loose: lose

his: â€˜Hisâ€™ is both the neuter and the masculine form of the possessive pronoun in OE and ME. Spenser is writing on the threshold of the change from â€˜hisâ€™ to â€˜itsâ€™ (Shakespeare, for example, varies in his usage), so the pronoun does not decisively distinguish the natural gender of â€˜mans bodyâ€™ as masculine rather than epiceneâ€”especially since that body is â€˜itâ€™, not â€˜heâ€™, in lines 4, 5, and 7.

loose: Carries a strong scriptural sense: â€˜To destroy, ruin, bring to destruction or perditionâ€™ (OED). Hamilton 2001 quotes Elyot on the soul that â€˜loseth hir dignitie, and becommith minister unto the sencesâ€™ (1946: 119-20).

this place: â€˜A particular part of or location in a book or documentâ€™ (OED). The reference to â€˜one and otherâ€™ is indefinite enough to imply that Almaâ€™s castle may be contrasted with any number of incontinent bodies, including Maleger and the rascal route, the transmogrified lovers in the Bower of Bliss, and the many sunderings of the body politic in the chronicle materials of canto x.
yfere: together
yfere: Cf. viii.56.7, â€˜So goodly purpose they together fondâ€™, and note the internal rhyme with â€˜in fayreâ€™.
with gentle court did bord: Addressed in a courteous/courtly manner.
read: learn, study
2.7-8 The portrait on Guyonâ€™s shield is mentioned previously at i.28.7-8, v.11.7-8, and viii.43.2-6.
scord: cut
semblaunt: image; countenance
vertue: power

lively-head: the living original of â€˜that Ladies headâ€™, with a punning use of the suffix -head, corresponding to modern â€˜-nessâ€™ (â€˜livelinessâ€™) or â€˜-hoodâ€™ (â€˜likelihoodâ€™); cf. â€˜Maydenhedâ€™, 6.6.
bounty: goodness; generosity
bounty: Cf. 5.4-5.
hew: form

3.5-9 Through equivocation, the diction and phrasing here blur the line between spiritual qualities and effects of wealth and power, even as they draw the line more firmly between these and the visible beauty of â€˜mortal hewâ€™. As a result the explicit contrast between Gloriana (here and at 5.4-5) and Philotime at vii.44-50 is somewhat hedged.
retraitt: portrait

retraitt: Coined by Spenser, the word combines â€˜portraitâ€™ with â€˜retreatâ€™: the visible â€˜semblauntâ€™ incised in the â€˜substanceâ€™ of the shield retreats from view as it passes over into â€˜the beauty of her mindâ€™.
liefe: beloved
liege: feudal lord
liege: Cf. viii.51.7 and note, viii.55.5.
4.6-7 Cf. the language describing Elizabeth at I.pr.4.3-4, Una at I.xii.21.5-9, and the damsels bathing in Acrasiaâ€™s fountain at II.xii.65.1-2.
countenaunce: appearance; expression; visage; patronage; repute
amenaunce: conduct

to die at her desire: The movement away from the visible image in st. 3-4 is qualified by the erotic charge of this phrasing. See the story of Arthurâ€™s dream at I.ix.13-16 and his response to the shieldâ€™s image at II.viii.43.1-6.
meed: wages; reward
sold: salary (root of soldier)
knights of Maydenhed: Mentioned previously at I.vii.46.4 and II.ii.42.1-5. Faery counterpart to the English Order of the Garter, founded by King Edward III in the late 14th century.
remaine: await
Arthogall: Arthegall, the patron knight of Justice in Book 5.
Sophy: Gk ÏƒÎ¿Ï†Î¹Î± sophia wisdom. Hamilton 2001 notes that Drayton mentions a holy Welsh king bearing this name (1931-41: 41:4.482).

7.5-6 See i.33.6n and â€˜Introductionâ€™ 00 for the symbolic rather than realistic time-scheme of the narrative. The seven solar years mentioned in these lines correspond to the seven years that Almaâ€™s castle has been under siege (12.8), but not to the â€˜three yearsâ€™ Praysdesire says Arthur has sought Gloriana (38.9). 1596 revises these lines: â€˜Seven times . . . Hath walkteâ€™ at 7.5-6 becomes â€˜Now hath . . . Walkt roundâ€™, reducing the number of solar years from seven to one, and â€˜three yearsâ€™ at 38.9 becomes â€˜twelve monethsâ€™. These revisions bring Arthurâ€™s reckoning into alignment with Guyonâ€™s: at the corresponding moment in Book I, Arthur tells Una and Redcrosse he has sought Gloriana for nine months (ix.15.9), and at ii.44.1-4 Guyon reports that his quest has been underway for three months. For â€˜the Sunne with his lamp-burning lightâ€™, cf. Virgil, postera Phoebea lustrabat lampade terras (â€˜The morrowâ€™s dawn was lighting the earth with the lamp of Phoebusâ€™; Aen 4.6).
I have sought the sight: Responding to Guyonâ€™s rhetorical question at 3.1-4.
Fortune: Iconographic details associated with Fortuna appear in Spenserâ€™s portrait of Occcasion (see iv.4-5n).
chevisaunce: chivalric enterprise
chevisaunce: Cf. gloss by E.K. at SC May 92: â€˜sometime of Chaucer used for gaine; sometime of other for spoyle, or bootie, or enterprise, and sometime for chiefdomeâ€™.
subdew: Context suggests â€˜achieveâ€™; OED cites only this example.
9.5-8 On the differing versions of this story see i.35.5-36.1, ii.42.6-43.9, and the note to each.
wagon: chariot
hospitale: hospice
10.7 First mention of Guyon on horseback since the disappearance of his â€˜loftie steedâ€™ at ii.11.5-7.
avale: dismount
loup: loop-hole
loup: An opening in the wall of a castle.
11.3-5 Cf. Timiasâ€™s challenge to Orgoglio at I.viii.3-5.
neare decay: imminent destruction

Seven yeares: Cf. 7.5 and 22.7. Commentators have seen the number as alluding to various learned or proverbial sevens: deadly sins, ages of man, ages of the world, days of creation, number of known planets, or the esoteric numerology of the Roman philosopher Macrobius in his Commentary on the Dream of Scipio (1.6).
villeins: serfs

villeins: Details in the description of these â€˜villeinsâ€™ reflect Ariostoâ€™s account of the strana torma (â€˜fantastic throngâ€™) that attacks Ruggiero on his way to the castle of Logistilla, OF 6.60-67. They also resemble Spenserâ€™s accounts in A Vewe of the Irish and their warlike forbears: â€˜a flyinge / Enymie hydinge him self in woodes and boggesâ€™ (the Irish, at 3968-69); attacking with â€˜atyrrible yell / and Hubbubbeâ€™ (the Scythians and Parthians, at 2175-76); a â€˜confused kynde of march in heapesâ€™ (the Irish, at 3211); and â€˜feirce rvnninge vpon theire / Enemiesâ€™ (the Irish, at 2313-14).
13.6-7 Echoing Virgil: Non iam certamine agresti, / stipitibus duris agitur sudibusve praeustis ( â€˜Not now do they contend in rustic quarrel with heavy clubs or seared stakesâ€™; Aen 7.523-4).
rusty: OED 4.a, â€˜Lacking polish or refinementâ€™ is relevant in context.
steares: steers
heares: hairs
maine: physical force, as in â€˜might and mainâ€™
raskall routs: Common term for a mob; Todd cites its use by Heywood in The First Part of King Edward IV to characterize popular rebellions (1.2.29)
orders: ranks
idle: empty
15.8-9 See Virgilâ€™s description of Aeneas trying to combat shades in the underworld (Aen 6.290-94).

the fennes of Allan: a great bog in central Ireland; New Abbey, the County Kildare property Spenser leased in 1582, was located near its north-eastern border. The simile fuses personal experience with literary allusion: Spenser refers in A Vewe to the attacks of the Irish gnats, â€˜whch in the Countrey doe more annoye the . . . rebels, whilst they kepe the woodes and doe more sharpelie wound them then all theire Enemies swords or speares, whch can seldome come nigh themâ€™ (2089-83); Homer compares the Greeks drawn up to attack the Trojan forces to â€˜the tribes of swarming flies that buzz about the herdmanâ€™s farmstead in the season of springâ€™ (Il 2.469-73).
equipaged: furnished; ordered by rank
17.9 â€˜Received them graciously, as was fittingâ€™.

St. 18-19 Spenserâ€™s description of Alma borrows such details as her golden hair and garland of roses from medieval allegories both of courtly love (e.g. Rom Rose) and of the soul (e.g. Pearl). As mistress of the body-castle, Alma corresponds to the â€˜rational soulâ€™ as defined by Burton: it â€˜includes the powers, and performs the duties of the two other [the sensitive and vegetable souls], which are contained in it, and all three faculties make one soul, which is inorganical of itself, although it be in all parts, and incorporeal, using their organs, and working by themâ€™ (Anatomy 1.1.2.9).
18.9 As the soul, Alma may be wooed by many but is reserved as the bride of Christ.
19.1-2 Cf. Rev 7:9, 13, where the multitude standing before the throne of God are â€˜araied in long white robesâ€™; Geneva gloss reads, â€˜In signe of puritieâ€™.
Braunched: embroidered
tire: head-dress
Rosiere: the branch of a rosebush
liberall: bountiful

note.p: St. 21-32 The balance of the canto is given over to a description and tour of the human body, represented as a medieval castle.

St. 21 describes the material (flesh) from which the walls are built, st. 22 the mystical proportions of the architecture. St. 23 figures the mouth, into which Alma leads the knights (st. 26) as they are allegorically swallowed and digested, rising from the stomach through the breast to the brain. (â€˜Not where he eats,â€™ as Hamlet says of Polonius, â€˜but where he is eatenâ€™; cf. the recurrent image of feeding the eyes in canto vii.) Meanwhile st. 23-26 describe the lips, chin, beard, moustache, nose, tongue, and teeth. St. 27-28 describe the dining hall (throat), governed by Diet and Appetite, followed in st. 29-31 by the kitchen (stomach), cooled by â€˜a great payre of bellowesâ€™ (30.4; the lungs). St. 32.6 mentions a â€˜secretâ€™ waste disposal system â€˜that none might . . . espyâ€™.

div.note: fensible: defensible

21.4-6 Cf. the building of Babel, Gen 11:3: â€˜So thei had brycke for stone, and slyme had they in steade of morterâ€™. Also the creation of Adam, Gen. 2.7: â€˜The Lord God also made the man of the dust of the grounde [Vulgate, de limo terrae], and breathed in his face breath of life, and the man was a living souleâ€™.
AEgyptian slime: Cf. I.i.21, III.vi.8.
king Nine: Ninus, king of ancient Assyria, identified in T. Cooper Thes Ling as founder of Ninevah; associated at I.v.48.1-4 with Nimrod, who is in turn linked with Babel at Gen 10:8-10.

note.p: St. 22 Since the seventeenth century this has been the most commented-upon stanza in the poem. William Austin (1637) and Sir Kenelm Digby (1643) have long been identified as the earliest glossators in this tradition, but recent work on Ben Jonsonâ€™s marginalia establish Jonsonâ€™s copy as the almost certain source of Digbyâ€™s elaborate Observations on the 22. Stanza. Jonson identifies the circle as the human soul and the triangle as the body, with the quadrate fixed between them signifying the principal humors (blood, phlegm, yellow bile, black bile). He also identifies the numbers seven and nine with the â€˜Planetes and the Angells which ar[e] distributed into a Hierarch[y] which governe the bodyâ€™ (Riddell and Stewart 1995, 107, 175-76.)

Specific verbal resemblances link this stanza to a discussion of the nature of the soul in Bryskett's A Discourse of Civill Life (1606), a dialogue in which Spenser figures as a participant. Mills (1973) establishes the probability that the passage in Bryskett is an immediate source for this stanza, and demonstrates the explanatory power for understanding this language of the philosophical context toward which Bryskett points: the â€˜mortalist controversyâ€™ inspired by the dispute between Aquinas and the Muslim scholar Ibn Rushd (known in Europe as Averroes) over the relationship among the vegetative, sensitive, and rational souls and the mens, or contemplative soul.

The tradition that assigns occult symbolism to numbers and geometrical forms derives from Platoâ€™s Timaeus and was elaborated in the early 5th century by Macrobius, who glosses seven, for example, as â€˜the number by which man is conceived, developed in the womb, is born, lives and is sustainedâ€™ (The Dream of Scipio I.vi.62-82; trans. Stahl 112). For further discussion of the intellectual traditions behind this stanza and of the critical tradition it has generated, see Fowler (1964), Mills (1973), Hamilton (2001: 238-39) and D. L. Miller (2006: 148-150).

div.note: 22.4-5 The gendering of the body as feminine and the soul as masculine is a commonplace of Western literature and philosophy, deeply imbedded in Christian and Platonic discourse. As the presence of Alma indicates, the soul is also just as traditionally represented as feminine.
compacted: composed, joined together
goodly diapase: >Complete harmony, alluding to the mathematical basis of scales and intervals in music (the octave as the mean between seven and nine).

thâ€™other: The one behind, as opposed to â€˜The one beforeâ€™. Cf. st. 32; in keeping with the decorum of the Porter and his â€˜larumbellâ€™ at 25.7-8, the stanza describing the mouth maintains a dignified reticence concerning â€˜thâ€™otherâ€™.
23.7-9 Cf. Ps 141:3, â€˜set a watche, O Lord, before my mouth, and kepe the dore of my lippesâ€™.
Jett: black marble
from Ireland: Todd 1805 reports that marble was quarried near Spenserâ€™s residence at Kilcolman.

24.4-5 Almaâ€™s beard remains an awkward detail for interpreters who justify the absence of genitals in the castle architecture by arguing that â€˜as â€˜the temple of the holie Gostâ€™ (1 Cor 6:19), the human body is epicene, containing only what both sexes have in commonâ€™ (Hamilton 2001). Like the supposedly â€˜impersonalâ€™ use of the masculine pronoun, the â€˜epiceneâ€™ body, deriving from the perfect sphere of Platoâ€™s Timaeus, privileges an implicitly masculine definition of â€˜the humanâ€™.
Enchaced: ornamented
wanton: luxuriant

Portcullis: â€˜A strong barrier in the form of a grating of wooden or iron bars, usually suspended by chains above the gateway of a fortress, a fortified town, etc., and able to secure the entrance quickly by being released to slide down vertical grooves in the sides of the gatewayâ€™ (OED).
comely compasse: pleasing proportion
compacture strong: compact construction
compacture strong: The first use recorded by OED.
Barbican: outer fortification
25.5 Spenserâ€™s official position as â€˜secretaryâ€™ defined him as a keeper of secrets.
blazers of cryme: Presumably those who utter slander, sedition or the like.
larumbell: alarm
never out of time: appropriate timing is integral to temperance; see II.iv.4-5n on the iconography of Occasion.
at evening and at prime: Respectively the sixth and first â€˜canonical hoursâ€™ of the Western Church, and hence appropriate â€˜timingâ€™ for prayer.
porch: Cf. Chaucerâ€™s translation of Boethius, Cons Phil 5.metrum.4.1: â€˜The porche (that is to seyn, a gate of the toun of Athenis there as philosophris hadden hir congregacioun to desputen)â€™.
warders: guards
warders: Jonson cites Plutarch on the â€˜Wall, or Parapet of teeth set in our mouth, to restraine the petulancy of our wordsâ€™ (1925-52.8.573).
Tall: handsome; stout
enraunged: from â€˜rankâ€™, arranged in an orderly fashion
obeysaunce: homage
lout: bow
gestes: gestures
drapets: tablecloths
Against: in preparation for [when]
viaundes: victuals
ministred: served
menaged: wielded
Steward: caterer

Steward: Spenserâ€™s duties as a sizar, or scholarship student, at Cambridge would have included waiting at table, and his ancestral name (Fr De Spencier; cf. Proth 130-31n) is synonymous with Steward; hence the pun in CV H.B., addressed to the Muses and referring to the poet as â€˜this rare dispenser of your gracesâ€™ (line 3). This pun is echoed by Richard Carewâ€™s reference to Spenser in 1598 as the â€˜Muses despencierâ€™ (Cummings 1971: 95). For Spenserâ€™s own play with the etymology of his name see 29.1, xii.42.8, V.i.7.5, and notes.
Marshall of the same: Member of a noble household responsible for seating guests on formal occasions.
attone: together (â€˜at oneâ€™)
nicenesse: delicacy
nicenesse: Alma does not out of delicacy omit to show them the kitchen.
dispence: expenditure, provision
dispence: See 27.8n.
raunges: fireplaces or grates

raunges: See vii.35.4 for the corresponding moment in the tour of Mammonâ€™s cave, and cf. vii.5.3-4n with st. 21-32n above for the suggestion that as the knights are allegorically â€˜digestedâ€™ in the castle, Guyon is correspondingly â€˜purifiedâ€™ in his tour of Mammonâ€™s realm.

29.5-7 Galen of Pergamum, a second-century Greek medical writer recognized as authoritative in the Renaissance, characterizes digestion as similar to boiling in a passage that mentions the volcanic Mount Aetna, also known as Mongiball (Nat Fac 3.7).
delay: temper
ordinaunce: management
styre: stir, move
accoyld: gathered
accoyld: OED cites only this instance.
Concoction: In Renaissance physiology, the first stage of digestion, from L con together + cocquere to boil.
Digestion: The second stage of digestion, from L digerere to distribute.
Achates: Provisions, from Anglo-Norman and Middle French achat purchase.
St. 32 Describing the third stage of digestion, elimination.
noyous: harmful
nought: worthless, unfit for consumption; nothing
nought: May represent â€˜naughtâ€™ (as in â€˜naughtyâ€™) or â€˜noughtâ€™, from ne not + aught anything.
secret wayes: Cf. 25.5, â€˜Utterers of secrets he from thence debardâ€™.
close: covertly
close: With a likely glance at â€˜close-stoolâ€™, a toilet.
Port Esquiline: The gate in ancient Rome that led to the sewer and city dump.

note.p: avoided: expelled; evaded

div.note: privily: privately, with a pun on â€˜privyâ€™

their mindes did fill: In contrast to the action of excreting at 32.9, the knights are allegorically feeding on the spectacle of human digestion. One of several places where Spenser plays on the mise en abyme of a human body populated by allegorical homunculi who posses bodies of their own; see 33.8-9n, 38.4n, 43.9n. For the corresponding moment in Mammon's cave, see vii.24.4.
so straunge a sight: Emphasizing the miracle of that which is most familiar, since the â€˜sightâ€™ the knights behold is their own anatomy.

33.5 The knights turn â€˜backe againeâ€™, reversing their descent toward the bodyâ€™s midsection, to ascend into the heart. Appropriately, this turn occurs in the fifth line of the stanza. For analogous moments of discreet turning-away, see 39.6, 44.2-3, 44.6.

33.5-44.5 The function of coupling from which the knights turn aside in 33.5 is represented differently: â€˜digestedâ€™ into the â€˜goodly Parlourâ€™ of the heart (33.6), where the allegory is likewise refined from the corporeal-architectural basis of its first phase to the comedy of manners that ensues as each knight encounters a female personification embodying the form of his desire, and experiences a resulting moment of painful self-consciousness (st. 39, 44). On the shifting of representational modes in this canto see Davis 1981: 124-25.
arras: tapestry

33.8-9 Almaâ€™s royall arras contrasts strikingly with the elaborate tapestries at the House of Busirane (III.xi.28-46) and the Castle Joyeous (III.i.34-38). The chiasmus in Spenserâ€™s phrasing suggests a mirroring in which nothing is reflected back to nothing, and hence an undoing of figuration as such, located appropriately at the (literal) â€˜heartâ€™ of his allegorical figuration of the body. On this reading the tapestry is, paradoxically, a figure for the mise en abyme of representation referred to above (33.3n). Alternatively, Mills suggests that the unwrought tapestry contains â€˜the simplest of perceived sensory forms awaiting conceptualizationâ€™ (1970: 569), reading but as â€˜exceptâ€™ to suggest that the tapestry is not entirely empty.
jolly: amorous; handsome; lively
amate: accompany
amate: The earliest instance of this sense cited by OED.
aggrate: gratify

34.8-9 At 18.2 we are told that Alma â€˜had not yet felt Cupides wanton rageâ€™; for Cupidâ€™s gesture in laying his bow aside, a recurrent motif in FQ, see viii.6n. Cupidâ€™s â€˜fierce warsâ€™ are detailed in Busyraneâ€™s tapestries; see III.xi.29.5, â€˜And eke all Cupids warres they did repeatâ€™.

St. 35 The affections personified in this stanza divide between â€˜someâ€™â€”the forward, or concupiscible passions (associated in canto ii with Perissa and in canto v with Cymochles)â€”and â€˜other someâ€™â€”the froward, or irascible passions (associated with Elissa and Pyrochles).
consort: harmony; fellowship
faund: cringed
coy: disdainful
gnaw a rush: Possibly related to â€˜rushâ€™ as a figure of speech for something unimportant, as in â€˜not worth a rushâ€™.
dispose: prepare

chose . . . by chaunce: See the similar coincidence of chance with choice when the knights select books to read at 59.5 and 60.1. Spenserâ€™s characteristic play with chance and providence suspends the action of the poem between romance errancy and epic destiny, e.g. at I.ix.6-7 and III.iii.24.
light: settle his choice

Poplar braunch: Sacred to Hercules, hence an emblem of heroic labor; Servius reports in his commentary on Virgilâ€™s Eclogues that Hercules made himself a crown of poplar upon his return from Hades (Comm in Verg Buc 7.61). The story of his choosing virtue over pleasure, attributed to Socrates by Xenophon (who relates it in his Memorabilia, 2.1.21-34), established Hercules as a popular Renaissance symbol of temperance.
spill: spoil
thus ill apayd: repayed you so evilly; so dissatisfied you
advise: notice
advise: From L ad to + visere to look at carefully.
Him ill beseemes: mirroring the phrase â€˜beseemes you illâ€™ at 37.9.
three years: 1596 â€˜twelve monethsâ€™; see 7.5n.
sought one: Gloriana
semblaunt: appearance

39.6 See 33.5, 44.2-3 for corresponding moments of turning-aside, which link the self-consciousness of the blushing knights to the pudor (modesty, or Shamefastnes [43.9]) of the allegory at the bodyâ€™s midsection. See 33.5-44.5n.

Praysdesire: See vii.49.1n; Arthurâ€™s anima contrasts with the match made in Hell that Mammon offers Guyon. On the importance of the pair shamefastness and desire of praise as â€˜the most necessarye things to be observed by a maister in his disciples or scholersâ€™, see Elyot 1580: 23.
demayne: demeanor
tyre: attire

40.7-9 Neither â€˜the birdâ€™ nor a source for the story of her sexual violation by Pan has been identified. Upton 1758 notes that Pan had by Echo a daughter named Jynx, who was turned into a bird, and suggests that it may be the cuckoo, which accompanies the figure of Jealousy in Chaucer (CT Knight 1930). Others have suggested the owl, the nightingale, or the turtle-dove, identified by Valeriano as an emblem of Pudicitia (Hieroglyphica 1602: 223-24). Since the bird in question â€˜shonneth vewâ€™ out of shame, perhaps we are not meant to know its name; cf. 25.5.
commoned: kept company
commoned: In ME, also to have sexual intercourse; cf. 42.4, 43.3-4 and notes.
41.2-7 For the literary genealogy of this simile, see Homer, Il 4.141; Claudian, R Pros 1.271-4; Statius, Achill 1.304-8; Ovid, Amor 2.5.34-40, Met 330-32; and Ariosto, OF 10.98-99.
Castory: castor, or castoreum
Castory: If the damsel knows that castoreum is a greasy, strong-smelling, evil-tasting reddish-brown substance extracted from glands in loins of the beaver, it is no wonder that she blushes.

42.4 See 39.6n. The echoes of st. 32 (â€˜secretâ€™, â€˜closeâ€™) are extended in 43.1 (â€˜noughtâ€™) and 44.1 (â€˜priviteeâ€™). For â€˜the secret of your heartâ€™ as Biblical language, see e.g. Ps 44:21, â€˜Shal not God searche this out? for he knoweth the secrets of the heartâ€™; Ps 51:6, â€˜Beholde, thou lovest trueth in the inwarde affections: therefore hast thou taught me wisdome in the secret of mine heartâ€™; 1 Cor 14:25, â€˜And so are the secrets of his heart made manifestâ€™.
devyse: conjecture
42.8-9 Since revealing the source of her discomfort is exactly what will please the damsel least, Guyon's offer â€˜To ease you of that illâ€™ has the opposite effect.
discure: discover

discure: A â€˜reduced formâ€™ resulting from vocalization of the v; cf. â€˜courdâ€™ at viii.9.8 and note. With a possible pun on â€˜dis-cureâ€™, since as the comedy of the scene makes clear, to â€˜discoverâ€™ shamefastness only intensifies its discomfort.

43.3-4. Cf. 39.3-5. In the present situation, Almaâ€™s choice of diction (â€˜that, which ye so much embraceâ€™) seems likely to set off another furious round of blushing, especially as it follows the series of echoes mentioned in 42.4n.
uncouth: unknown, unfamiliar
modestee: temperateness or discretion

modestee: According to Thomas Wilsonâ€™s Art of Rhetoric, â€˜An honest shamefastnessâ€™ (76); shame or discomfiture in Lily, Mother Bombie: â€˜I can neither without danger smother the fire, nor without modestie disclose my furieâ€™ (3.1.5-6).

43.9 Another instance of chiasmus as the trope of mirroring; see 33.8-9n, 38.4n. For â€˜Shamefastnes it selfeâ€™, see the pseudo-Chaucerian Court of Love, â€˜Eke Shamefastenesse was there as I toke hede, / That blushed red, and darst not been aknowe / She lover was . . .â€™ (1198-1200).
44.1-2 Blushing by its nature is not able to be contained â€˜in priviteeâ€™; this is why Guyon turns his face away.
faynd to oversee: pretended not to notice
44.4-5 Apparently the narrator follows Almaâ€™s example in deciding not to notice the knightsâ€™ discomfiture, despite having just described it; see 39.6n.

44.5-58 At 44.6-9 Alma leads the knights up an alabaster stairway (the ten vertebrae of the neck) to view her castleâ€™s circular Turret (44.8, the head), and the allegory once again modulates, this time from the comedy of self-consciousness to an explicitly historical and typological mode, as references to Thebes and Troy (45.6-9) prepare for a comparison with â€˜that heavenly towre, / That God hath built for his owne blessed bowreâ€™ (47.4-5). St. 47-58 describe the three principal chambers of the turret, occupied by â€˜three honorable sages; (47.8): Phantastes (st. 49-52) or the fantasy; an unnamed â€˜man of ripe and perfect ageâ€™ (54.2) who exercises the faculty of judgment (st. 53-54); and the aged Eumnestes with his boy Anamnestes, representing memory and recollection (st. 55-58). In the chamber of Eumnestes the knights come upon the chronicles they will read in canto 10.
thence away them sought: â€˜Invited them to come awayâ€™, echoing 33.5, â€˜Thence backe againe faire Alma led them rightâ€™.
Alablaster: Early modern spelling of â€˜alabasterâ€™, a pure white translucent stone.
compassed around: encompassed, bounded with a circle
survewd: surveyed, overlooked
survewd: Contrasting with its etymological partner â€˜overseeâ€™ at 44.3.
45.6-7 Cadmea, the acropolis at Thebes, built by Cadmus (Met 3.1-130) and destroyed by Alexander the Great in 335 B.C.E.
young Hector: Astyanax, son of Hector, was cast over the battlements of Troy (Met 13.415-17).
over head: literally
herbars: arbours
in watches stead: in place of watchmen

living fire: Belphoebeâ€™s eyes are described as â€˜living lampsâ€™ that dart fire (II.iii.23.1-3); the eyes of the dragon in Eden are compared to flaming beacons (I.xi.15.1-4). In Am Spenser apostrophizes the ladyâ€™s eyes as â€˜full of the living fire / Kindled above unto the maker neereâ€™ (8.1-2), and says they â€˜kindle living fire within my brestâ€™ (7.12). Contrast III.viii.7.1-2 on the witchâ€™s construction of the False Florimell: â€˜In stead of eyes two burning lampes she set / In silver sockets, shyning like the skyesâ€™.
sly: finely crafted
that heavenly towre: the New Jerusalem
that heavenly towre: Cf. the vision shown to Redcrosse by Contemplation at I.x.55-57.

47.4-5 The description of the human headâ€”framed by comparisons to heaven (see 45.2), between which are contained the negative similes (45.6-9, â€˜Not that . . . Nor thatâ€™) referring to great edifices of pagan antiquityâ€”marks another shift in the symbolic mode of the allegory, from the comedy of courtly manners that prevails in the parlor of the heart to a typological mode appropriate to the head as the seat of the immortal soul and of the intellectual faculties of foresight and memory.

47.6-9 Medical tradition descending from Galen identified four ventricles in the human brain, to which were assigned the faculties of fantasy or foresight, judgment, and memory, with fantasy occupying the first two. Chaucer neatly sums up this tradition in CT when he lists the medical authorities studied by the doctor of physic: â€˜Olde Ypocras, Haly and Galyen, / Serapion, Rasiz and Avycenâ€™ (Gen Pro 431-32). E. D. Harvey 2003 offers a well-informed summary of the medieval medical and philosophical traditions that lie behind Spenserâ€™s conception of the animating forces within the body.
St. 48 The negative similes in this stanza parallel those in st. 45.
48.1-2 The Delphic Oracle reportedly declared Socrates the wisest man alive (Plato, Apology 21A).
doome: judgment
by many parts: many times over

48.4-7 Cf. Homer, Î·Î´Ï…ÎµÏ€Î·Ï‚ Î±Î½Î¿ÏÎ¿Ï…ÏƒÎµ Î»Î¹Î³Ï…Ï‚ Î Ï…Î»Î¹Ï‰Î½ Î±Î³Î¿ÏÎ·Ï„Î·Ï‚, / Ï„Î¿Ï… ÎºÎ±Î¹ Î±Ï€Î¿ Î³Î»Ï‰ÏƒÏƒÎ·Ï‚ Î¼ÎµÎ»Î¹Ï„Î¿Ï‚ Î³Î»Ï…ÎºÎ¹Ï‰Î½ ÏÎµÎµÎ½ Î±Ï…Î´Î·: / Ï„Ï‰ Î´á¾½ Î·Î´Î· Î´Ï…Î¿ Î¼ÎµÎ½ Î³ÎµÎ½ÎµÎ±Î¹ Î¼ÎµÏÎ¿Ï€Ï‰Î½ Î±Î½Î¸ÏÏ‰Ï€Ï‰Î½ / ÎµÏ†Î¸Î¹Î±Î¸á¾½, Î¿á¼µ Î¿Î¹ Ï€ÏÎ¿ÏƒÎ¸ÎµÎ½ Î±Î¼Î± Ï„ÏÎ±Ï†ÎµÎ½ Î·Î´á¾½ ÎµÎ³ÎµÎ½Î¿Î½Ï„Î¿ / ÎµÎ½ Î Ï…Î»á¿³ Î·Î³Î±Î¸Îµá¿ƒ, Î¼ÎµÏ„Î± Î´Îµ Ï„ÏÎ¹Ï„Î±Ï„Î¿Î¹ÏƒÎ¹Î½ Î±Î½Î±ÏƒÏƒÎµÎ½ (Ä“dnepÄ“s anorouse ligys PyliÅn agorÄ“tÄ“s, / tou kai apo glÅssÄ“s melitos glykiÅn rheen audm: / tÅ dâ€™ Ä“dÄ“ dyo men geneai meropÅn anthrÅpÅn / ephthiathâ€™ , oÏŠ oi prosthen ama traphen mdâ€™ egenonto / en PylÅ mgathem, meta de tritatoisin anassen; â€˜Nestor, sweet of speech, the clear-voiced orator of the men of Pylos . . . . Two generations of mortal men he had already seen pass away . . . and he was king among the thirdâ€™; Il I.248-52).
praise of pollicies: counsel on the practice of governing
sondry: individually
48.9 Cf. â€˜governmentâ€™ at 1.4 and note.
49.1-3 Identified in both medical and philosophical tradition as phantasia (fantasy), cogitatio (judgment), and memoria (memory).
could one of these comprize: â€˜one of these three could comprehend and contain itâ€™
quicke prejudize: lively ability to anticipate
working: active
thin: insubstantially, intangibly
50.4-5 Cf. Sidney, Defense, arguing that only poets can invent â€˜forms such as never were in natureâ€™.

50.8-9 An unstructured series that may (by the readerâ€™s cogitatio) be analyzed into three groups of fourâ€”although Hippodames remains a joker in this deck, since as a mythological creature it would be classed with the first three terms, but as an exotic natural creature, classed with the second four (see 50.8n).
Centaurs: mythological creatures, half-human, half-horse

Hippodames: Literally, horse-trainers; possibly an error for either â€˜hippocampusâ€™, a mythological sea-horse â€˜having two fore-feet, and the body ending in a dolphinâ€™s or fishâ€™s tail, represented as drawing the car of Neptune and other sea-deitiesâ€™ (OED), or â€˜hippotameâ€™, the 16th-c spelling of â€˜hippopotamusâ€™.

51.1-5 See the similes at I.i.23, describing the attack of Errourâ€™s monstrous brood upon the Redcrosse knight, and st. 16 above, describing the attack of Malegerâ€™s troops upon Arthur and Guyon. To have â€˜a bee in your bonnetâ€™ is a proverbial expression equivalent to having a screw loose; cf. Nicholas Udall 1553, â€˜Who so hath suche bees as your maister in hys headâ€™ (Roister D. [Arb.] 29).
51.6-9 See 50.8-9 for a parallel group of twelve.
Devices: notions, contrivances of the mind
leasings: lies
wonned: dwelt
Phantastes: Gk Ï†Î±Î½Ï„Î±ÏƒÏ„Î·Î¶ phantastes visionary or dreamer.
52.4-6 For these details as signs of melancholy humor, see Burton Anat 1.3.1.1; â€˜sharpe staring eyesâ€™ suggest foresight.

52.8-9 For Saturnâ€™s traditional association with melancholy, see Klibansky, Panofsky, and Saxl 1964. In astrology Saturn is the planet of baleful adversity (the â€˜great Maleficâ€™), â€˜obliqueâ€™ when it stands at an adverse angle to one or more of the other natal planets. It is especially adverse when passing through the twelfth house of the zodiac (â€˜thâ€™house of agonyesâ€™).

St. 53 Cf. Aristotle, Nic Eth 6.5-8: â€˜Practical wisdom [Ï•ÏÎ¿Î½Î·ÏƒÎ¹Ï‚ phronesis] is a rational faculty exercised for the attainment of truth in things that are humanly good and bad . . . . In the popular mind prudence is more associated with the self and the individualâ€”a usurpation of the title of prudence, which actually belongs to all forms and kinds, including those designated as domestic economy, constitution-building, the art of the lawgiver, and political science which again is subdivided into deliberative and judicial scienceâ€™. Such wisdom differs from pure reason, which â€˜apprehends the truth of definitions which cannot be proved by argument, while prudence involves knowledge of the ultimate particular thingâ€™ (6.6, 182).
gestes: deeds
picturals: pictures

picturals: OED cites only this instance. Note that this noun governs the rest of the list, so that the chamber is described as containing not laws, judgments, and the like, but images of these things.
decretals: decrees
science: knowledge
science: From L scientia.
ay thought wittily: ever thought wisely

ripe and perfect age: See 27.8-9 and 27.8n. The verbal echo associates this unnamed figure with Diet (and hence with the poet) as the mindâ€™s steward, governing its digestion of the materials taken in through the senses (â€˜who them did meditateâ€™).
personage: appearance
they declind: decayed
they declind: Sloped downward, following the shape of the skull.
55.5-9 Cf. the description of Contemplationâ€™s weak eyes and strong â€˜sprightâ€™ at I.x.47.1-6
scorse: trade-off
scorse: The only instance of the noun cited by OED.

56.1-3 Another instance of this cantoâ€™s recurrent interest in the mise en abyme (see 33.3 and 33.8-9 notes). An â€˜infiniteâ€™ record of all things, made on the spot â€˜as they did pasâ€™, would be caught in an endless loop, deprived of any temporal or spatial perspective in which to order and contain events (cf. â€˜withouten endâ€™, 58.2; â€˜endlesse exerciseâ€™, 59.2).

immortall scrine: See the â€˜everlasting scryneâ€™ of the Muses at 1.pr.2.3. In both instances the transferred epithet applies properly to the contents rather than to the container. A â€˜scrineâ€™ is a wooden chest in which records or valuables were kept; see Anderson (2008: 82) for the association of â€˜scrineâ€™ with shrine and hence with the body as a temple, as in Nicholas Udallâ€™s translation from Erasmus: â€˜The mynde or solle of manne is covered, and . . . housed or hidden within the tabernacle or skryne of the bodye . . . .â€™ (1542: 145v).
56.6-7 Contrast â€˜immortallâ€™ and â€˜incorruptedâ€™ with the description of Emnestes and his dwelling as â€˜decrepitâ€™, â€˜ruinous and oldâ€™ (55.6, 1).

56.8-9 The â€˜warresâ€™ mentioned in these lines are older than the Trojan war: King Ninus founded Ninevah (see 21.6n), Assaracus was an ancestor of Aeneas, and Inachus was a river god, founder of Argos and father of Io.
The yeares of Nestor . . . Mathusalem: Nestor live three hundred years, according to T. Cooper 1565; MethushÃ©lah, according to Genesis 5:27, â€˜nine hundred sixty and nineâ€™.
57.6-9 Unlike the first two chambers, where imagery predominates, this chamber contains written records.
fett: fetch
Anamnestes: Gk Î±Î½Î±Î¼Î½Î·Ïƒï©Ï‚ anamnesis remembrance.
Eumnestes: Gk ÎµÏ…Î¼Î½Î·ÏƒÏ„Î¿Ï‚ eumnestos well-remembering.
avise: examine
avise: From L videre to see.
59.5, 60.1 chaunced . . . chaunst: On Spenserâ€™s characteristic equivocation between chance and providence, see 36.5-6n.
moniments: written memorials
moniments: From L monere to remind

governements: Echoing â€˜governmentâ€™ at 1.4. The macrocosmic analogy between the temperate body and the well-governed body politic is realized when the chronicle history of British rule is found in Eumnestesâ€™ chamber, although this proves in canto x to be a history largely of misgovernance. In this sense the moniments may be understood as admonitory.
Antiquitee: Associated in Spenser with an ideal era, and hence contrasted to the warning function of moniments.

Spenserâ€™s chronicle of Briton kings relies chiefly on Geoffrey of Monmouthâ€™s Historium Regum Britanniae (c. 1135), with additional material from John Hardyng, Chronicle (1543); John Stowe, Chronicles of England, Scotland and Ireland (1580); Raphael Holinshed, Chronicles (1577, 1587); and A Mirror for Magistrates (1559). Its chief epic antecedent is the procession of Roman worthies in Virgil (Aen 6.756-885).
Brute: Brutus, descendant of Aeneas and legendary founder of Britain, to which he gives his name; see 9.6-13.5 and III.ix.48-50, as well as 69.7n.
Uthers rayne: Uther Pendragon is Arthurâ€™s father. His reign is contemporary with the action of the poem (see st. 68).
rolls: registry
rolls: Cf. â€˜antique Regestersâ€™, ix.59.4.
Elfin Emperours: Rulers of Faeryland, in a chronology fabricated by Spenser.

time of Gloriane: Historically, Gloriana is contemporary with Uther Pendragon, ruling Faery land as he rules Britain; allegorically, she is a figure for Elizabeth I, and in this sense contemporary with Spenser.

St. 1-4 The canto opens with a kind of invocation (a rhetorical question, implicitly answered at 3.6-7). Together with the apostrophe to Elisabeth (4.1), this invocation marks the first four stanzas as a proem-within-the-poem, implying that the chronicles to follow, like a great battle scene in classical epic, call for a special elevation of the poetâ€™s spirit (cf. I.xi.6.6-8.9).

St. 1 Spenserâ€™s stanza translates Ariosto (OF 3.1). Both as a ninth line and in its final word, Spenserâ€™s hexameter (â€˜By which all earthly Princes she doth far surmountâ€™) wittily surmounts the tribute paid to the house of Este in Ariostoâ€™s ottava rima pentameter.

2.1-3 Cf. Ariosto: di cui fra tutti li signori illustri, / dal ciel sortiti a governar la terra, / non vedi, o Febo, che â€˜l gran mondo lustri, / piÃ¹ gloriosa stirpe o in pace o in guerra (â€˜than whom, among all the illustrious lords ordained by heaven to govern the earth, you do not seeâ€”O Phoebus, who light up the great worldâ€”a more glorious lineage in peace or in warâ€™; OF 3.2.1-4).
A labor huge: referring to 1.8, â€˜I recountâ€™.
disparaged: overmatched
St. 3 Once again closely tracking Ariosto (OF 3.3).
MÅ“onian: Homerâ€™s surname was MÃ¦onides (â€˜native of Maeonia,â€™ or Lydia).
quill: plectrum, pipe, or reed pen
Phoebus rote: The lyre of Apollo, god of music and poetry. (Rote, slightly archaic by 1590, designates a medieval stringed instrument.)

3.3-5 In the war between the gods and Titans (parallel to Bruteâ€™s conquest of the giants in England), the giants tried to assault the heavens by piling Mount Ossa on top of Mount Pelion in a battle that took place in Phlegra. See Ovid: adfectasse ferunt regnum caeleste gigantas / altaque congestos struxisse ad sidera montis. / tum pater omnipotens misso perfregit Oympum / fulmine et excussit subiectae Pelion Ossae (â€˜they say that the Giants essayed the very throne of heaven, piling huge mountains, one on another, clear up to the stars. Then the Almighty Father hurled his thunderbolts, shattered Olympus, and dashed Pelion down from underlying Ossaâ€™; Met 1.152-55).
some relish: a little taste
His learned daughters: the muses
report: L re back, again + portare to carry.
blazon: proclaim
this renowmed Prince: Arthur
mace: scepter
Northern starre: Polaris, â€˜the stedfast starreâ€™ at I.ii.1.2 (see vii.1.2n).
that old mans booke: Introduced at ix.59.5-9.

note.p: St. 5-68 Stanzas 5-68.2 contain Spenserâ€™s chronicle of British kings from Brute to Uther Pendragon. Mills (1976) points out that, like the human body, the account of British and Faery dynasties is â€˜Proportioned equally by seven and nineâ€™ (ix.22.7). Briton moniments is summarized in 63 nine-line stanzas that list 62 kings (Arthur will be the 63rd), while the Antiquitee of Faery Lond (70-76) takes up seven stanzas, or 63 lines. Hamilton 2001 adds that 63 is the number of the â€˜grand climactericâ€™, a notion that goes back to Greek astrology, mathematics, and philosophy.

Occurring every seven years in life, climacterics were thought to be turning points. The â€˜grand climactericâ€™ (usually the ninth) was seen an especially dangerous moment of crisis. Spenserâ€™s time-scheme, which identifies Arthur allegorically with the advent of Elizabeth, thus implies that both reigns are historically fraught. Since his history is punctuated by lapses of the royal line when monarchs died childless (36.1, 54.1, 61.8), the allegorical advent of Elizabeth/Arthur may be fraught in part because the succession is disrupted.

div.note: paysd: poised, balanced
5.8 Holinshed reports that England was â€˜joined without any separation of sea to the maine landâ€™ (1965: 1.427).
Celticke mayn-land: Brittany, formerly inhabited by Celtic tribes

6.2-4 The southeastern coast of England is famously lined with white chalk cliffs, the source of the name Albion (L albus white). T. Cooper (1565) suggests a supplementary derivation from Gk OÎ»Î²Î¹Î¿Î½ Olbion happy or blessed, because ancient mariners arriving there considered themselves fortunate.
safety: trisyllabic
6.6 1596 and 1609, which read â€˜safeties sakeâ€™, probably read Spenserâ€™s trisyllabic â€˜safetyâ€™ as disyllabic.
invade: enter, in a neutral sense (L in + vadere to go), but anticipating the hostilities mentioned at 9.9.
hideous: horrific, with the added sense of monstrous size: cf. â€˜Of stature huge and hideous he was, / Like to a Giant for his monstrous hightâ€™ (V.xii.15.1-2).
Roebucke: The roe is a species of small deer; the buck is the male of the species.
liveden: An archaic verb form appropriate to the ancientness of the inhabitants.
to wene: to comprehend or believe
That monstrous error: The error is both that of the antiquarians who credit the story of Diocletianâ€™s daughters, and that of the daughters in the story when they couple with fiends.
assott: besot, make foolish

Dioclesians fifty daughters: Spenser is conflating two similar myths, one of the Assyrian King Diocletian and another of the Egyptian King Daunus. Cf. Holinshed, 1965: 1.434-36. Cf. also Gen. 6:4: â€˜There were gyantes in the earth in those dayes: yea, and after that the sonnes of God came unto the daughters of men, and they had borne them children, these were mightie men, which in olde time were men of renoume.â€™
shene: lovely
companing: copulating

Geaunts: This spelling alludes to an alternative myth of origin for the giants, identified by many Renaissance writers with the Titans of classical myth, descended from Uranus and Ge (sky and earth). See Holinshed 1.3 on the derivation from Gk Î“Î¹Î³Î¹Î½ÎµÏ‚ Gigines, â€˜Borne or bred of or in the earthâ€™ (1965: 1.434). This subtext becomes explicit in 9.1-5, where â€˜this landâ€™ figures as â€˜their owne motherâ€™, â€˜pollutedâ€™ by their â€˜unkindly crimeâ€™, who therefore â€˜gan abhorreâ€™ them even though they were â€˜borne of her owne native slimeâ€™.
See arg.2 and note. Assarac founded Troy; he was great-grandfather to Aeneas, who in turn was great-grandfather to Brutus.

fatall error: fated wandering; see the description of Aeneas as fato profugus (â€˜exiled by fateâ€™), where profugus also has the sense of â€˜fugitiveâ€™ (Aen 1.2). Cf. III.ix.49.1, â€˜by fatall courseâ€™.

groning flore: perhaps a transferred epithet, although the earth (floor) may equally be groaning with the sheer weight of their corpses (see III.ix.50.5-6: â€˜thâ€™earth full cold, / Which quaked under their so hideous masseâ€™).

10.7-9 Spenser follows Geoffrey of Monmouth Historia (28). GoÃ«mot is also known as Goegmagog (cf. Goemagot, III.ix.50.3); Corineus was a general under Brutus who specialized in wrestling giants.

St. 11 Sources for the stories mentioned in this stanza have not been identified, but for evidence suggesting Irish legends as a source for the story of Coulinâ€™s fatal leap, see Forste-Grupp (1999).
Debon: one of Brutusâ€™s followers.

11.6-7 For the story of Albionâ€™s defeat at the hands of Hercules, see Holinshed (1965: 1.433).

Northerne part . . . Albania: Scotland

14.5 Camberâ€™s portion is separated from Logris (England, so called after Locrine) by the Severn river.
St. 15 Overrunning seven consecutive lines of the stanza, this period imitates the aggressive expansion of the Huns (â€˜a nation straungâ€™), halted in the final couplet by Locrineâ€™s defense.

16.2-3 This river appears in the 1574 addition to A Mirror for Magistrates, where the Huns â€˜over Abi streame with haste did hieâ€™ (â€˜Locrinusâ€™ line 65, in Campbell 1946: 80). The 1587 edition of William Harrisonâ€™s Description of Britaine in its account of the Humber does mention an author, â€˜Ptolomie Abie, Leland Aber, as he gessethâ€™ (1807; AMS 1965: 156).

17.6-9 Geoffrey and Holinshed report that Locrine fell in love with Estrild after taking her captive when he defeated Humber, and wished to marry her; he wed his niece, Guendolene (to whom he was promised), only under pressure from her father Corineus. He kept Estrild secretly as a concubine, and after the death of Corineus put aside Guendolene in her favor.

The misreading of â€˜stâ€™ as â€˜flâ€™ would be easy in secretary hand; we conjecture a correction (â€˜stoureâ€™) combined with a revision (â€˜in that impatientâ€™), and adopt the first but not the second.

Brunchildis (â€˜brown-shieldâ€™) saw â€˜The greene shieldâ€™ (Brutusâ€™s surname in the chronicles is â€˜Greenshieldâ€™) dyed red: â€˜vermellâ€™ = vermillion.

Cairleon: From Celtic cair city + â€˜of the Legionâ€™.

26.6-7 The naturally hot wells at Bath have been popular a health resort since Roman times, bringing (â€˜wellingâ€™ forth) prosperity to the surrounding area.

St. 27-32 For the story of King Leyr Spenser draws on Geoffrey, 36-44. Shakespeareâ€™s play (1608) draws on Spenser in turn.

Interestingly, Geoffrey describes Cordelia as the one putting her father to the proof: â€˜Cordellia understood that he had succumbed to the flattery of her sisters and proceeded to answer differently, in order to test himâ€™ (38).

Cambria: Cf. 14.4-5.

Albania: Scotland
30.1-2 Proverbial. Cf. Smith (1970, no. 588).

St. 33 Cf. st. 21. The motif of fratricidal rivalry, introduced by the sons of Madan, is revived by the sons of Goneril and Regan.

CÃ¦cily: Sisillius
CÃ¦cily: Male in Geoffrey.

Arraught: obtained (ppl of â€˜areachâ€™)

St. 35 Cf. 21.3-5n, st. 33n. The motif of fratricidal rivalry recurs yet again. Its cyclical nature is hinted at by the prepositions (â€˜Stird Porrex up to put his brother downeâ€™), but the cycle is clearly spiraling downward when the brothersâ€™ â€˜mother mercilesseâ€™ steps in to avenge the death of Ferrex, and in so doing brings the lineage itself to an end (36.1).

St. 36 On the lapse of Brutusâ€™s lineage see Harper (1910): â€˜Here Spenser has made two additions to Geoffreyâ€™s narrative: the first, that the line of Brutus ended with Ferrex and Porrex, and the second, that the progeny of Brutus ruled 700 years. The first statement has ample authority in Holinshed and Stow. The second seems to be based on the figures in the Polychronicon, quoted by Holinshed, according to which the accession of Dunwallo was 703 years after the arrival of Brutus. Spenser may have identified the accession of the new line with the end of the old, and so have spoken of the 700 years that the line of Brutus reigned. But, while both additions to Geoffreyâ€™s story may thus be accounted for by Holinshed, Spenserâ€™s expansion of this part of his story and his emotional treatment of it, in strong contrast with Warnerâ€™s brevity, suggest an influence from the lament of Eubulus in the Tragedy of Gorboduc. To this lament Spenserâ€™s lines bear a decided resemblanceâ€™ (91).
36.4 See Guyonâ€™s comparison of Ruddymane at ii.2.6 to a â€˜budding braunch rent from the native treeâ€™
moniment: trace, record
a man: Disclosure of his name is deferred, perhaps because, as the founder of a new lineage, he must make rather than inherit his â€˜nameâ€™.
stressed: distressed
loose: scattered, not unified
loose: anticipating Donwalloâ€™s later role (cf. 38.4-5n).

of Logris miscreate: Illegitimately made king of England (Logris; see 14.5n), implicitly in contrast to the precedent established by Donwallo (39.9), who according to Holinshed â€˜caused himselfe with great solemnitie to be crowned . . . and bicause he was the first that bare a crowne heere in Britaine, after the opinion of some writers, he is named the first king of Britaineâ€™ (1965:1.451).
38.4-5 Cf. st. 29. Albany (Scotland) and Cambria (Wales), formerly distinct kingdoms, are now first united into great Britany (39.6).
Albany: accented on the second syllable

39.1-2 The institution of â€˜sacred lawes . . . reveald in visionâ€™ identifies Donwallo with Moses, and insofar as they share divine inspiration, perhaps also with the visionary poet. Donwalloâ€™s visions, not mentioned in the chronicle sources, may be Spenserâ€™s invention.

39.9 Contrast 38.2 and note.
Donwallo: Named only here, at the end of the passage describing his reign (see 37.1n).

St. 40 Geoffrey describes Brennius and Belinus as another pair of fraternal rivals whose conflict closely parallels that of Porrex and Ferrex, although this time the rivalry ends in reconciliation, followed by military victories over France, Germany, and Rome (48-58; see st. 35n). Spenser omits mention of their rivalry and includes the ransacking of Greece, which derives from later chronicles (Harper 1910: 96).
40.2-3 Rome â€˜did assayâ€™ (tested) the â€˜pearelesse prowesseâ€™ of the brothers, a decision that cost the Romans â€˜dearelyâ€™ because it led to the sacking of the city.
40.4 According to Geoffrey, the consuls governing Rome negotiated a treaty with the brothers, then violated the agreement by joining forces against them with the Germans (56).
perjured: trisyllabic, accented on the second syllable

Spenser follows the spelling in Geoffrey; Holinshed gives â€˜Gurguntâ€™.

Easterland: In The First Inhabitation of Ireland (1587), Holinshed mentions Norway, Denmark, and â€œother those parties, called Ostomanni, or . . . Easterlings, bicause they lie East in respect of us, although indeed they are by other named properlie Normans, and partlie Saxonsâ€ (1965: 6.93).

41.6-9 This story, repeated by Geoffrey and other chroniclers, reiterates the mistaken belief that Ireland was first settled by the Spanish (60). Holinshed in First Inhabitation recycles a fanciful etymology that traces the Latin name for Ireland, Hibernia, back to the Latin for Spain, Hiberia (1965:6.1-2). Spenserâ€™s version uses the story to legitimize British sovereignty over Ireland.

found: discovered; devised
layes: laws
Fayes: Faeries

42.7-8 See notes to 39.1-2 and 39.6: here again Spenser goes beyond his sources to associate the royal lawgiver with Faery inspiration personified by a female muse-figure; he is still hedging (â€˜many deemdâ€™) about the authenticity of the inspiration mediated by this equivocal museâ€”but never about the value of the laws so derived.

Sisillus Sifillus in all three early editions. Chronicle sources for this passage record the forms Sicillus, Cecilius, Sicillius, and Sisillus (Harper 1910: 100-01), of which Spenser presumably chose the last. The error of â€˜fâ€™ for long â€˜sâ€™ may easily result from misreading or foul case.

43.9 Geoffrey and other chroniclers report that Morvidus (Spenserâ€™s â€˜Morindusâ€™) was swallowed â€˜like a little fishâ€™ in single combat with a sea monster (62). They also describe his savage treatment of foes defeated in combat.

49.4-5 According to Geoffrey, Nennius was mortally wounded during the first Roman attack (70). Spenser (perhaps following Hardyng) narrates the death of Nennius following the third attack, where it figures as a climax to the series; and he invents the detail that Caesarâ€™s swordâ€” buried with Nennius, according to Geoffrey (71)â€”is â€˜yet to be seene this dayâ€™.

50.2-4 Echoing Romans 8.3, â€˜God sending his owne Sonne, in the similitude of sinful flesh, and for sinne, condemned sinne in the fleshâ€™, and 1 Cor. 15.22, â€˜For as in Adam all dye, even so in Christ shall all be made aliveâ€™.

50.8-9 Geoffrey records that â€˜Kymbelinus . . . was so fond of the Romans that he freely paid them tributeâ€™ (80), which was later refused by his son Guiderius. Holinshed too records that â€˜Kymbeline . . . lived in quiet with the Romansâ€™, adding that he does not know which British ruler refused tribute (1965: 1.479). As Harper 1910 notes, Spenser appears to have followed Harison in transferring â€˜the story of Guiderius to Kimbelineâ€™ (111).

Treachetour: traitor

53.6-9 The movement from â€˜true it isâ€™ to â€˜(they say)â€™ creates a mild version of the effect Milton will achieve at PL 1.746-7 with â€˜thus they relate, / Erringâ€™. According to Matt 27:57-60, Joseph of Arimathea was the disciple who interred Jesus. His association with the Grail of Arthurian romance is legendary but not attested in the chronicles.
54.1 The death of Lucius without heir brings the line of Donwallo to an end, the second extinction of the royal lineage (see 36.1).

Bunduca: Also called â€˜Boadiceaâ€™ (â€˜Boudiccaâ€™ in Tacitus, Agricola 16). On the details of Spenserâ€™s treatment see Harper (1910: 117-120). Spenser mentions Bunduca again at III.iii.54 and Time 106-12.

57.1-4 Spenserâ€™s account here draws on the Mirror for Magistrates.

57.7-8 Allectus, sent from Rome, slew Carausius on the battlefield; Harper conjectures that treacherously may reflect a reference in Mirror for Magistrates to Carausiusâ€™s â€˜trustleless trayneâ€™ (1910: 124). The â€˜robe of Emperoureâ€™ put on by Allectus was presumably the one that, according to Stow, Carausius â€˜usurpedâ€™ when he gained dominion over Britain (1587: 32).

60.6-9 Constantine sent Trahern to reclaim Britain from the usurper Octavius, who â€˜justifiedâ€™ his royal title by defeating the Romans and slaying Trahern.

Maximinian: Probably a variant of Maximian; Holinshed uses both forms. According to Geoffrey, Maximian â€˜the Empire wanâ€™ by conquering Gaul and Germany, but left Britain undefended against the Huns and Picts, who invaded in his absence (106; 108-110).

He: Vortigere
straunge: foreign
hoyes: small boats used to ferry goods and passengers
their: between Vortigere and his sonsâ€™ partisans

aband: abandon
his faire daughters face: According to Geoffrey, Vortigere was smitten by Hengistâ€™s daughter Rowen, and married her (128-30).

66.8-9 Geoffrey reports that Merlin assisted Constantineâ€™s son Aurelius Ambrose (see 67.2, 7) in moving the stones (â€˜Giantâ€™s Ringâ€™) from Ireland to the scene of the massacre (172-4), which Holinshed locates on Salisbury plain (1965: 1.565).

peaceably did rayne, / Till that through poyson stopped was his breath: The story of the kingâ€™s poisoning by a Saxon pretending to be British appears in Geoffrey (176-78) and Holinshed (1965: 1.566).

68.2-3 The pun on Caesar/ceasura (L caedere to cut) underpins the analogy between royal succession and syntax, both of which are interrupted in Spenserâ€™s unpunctuated but metrically unruffled line 2. Since this epic chronology is broadly indebted to the procession of Roman Worthies in Virgil, Aen 6, Spenser may be imitating the grammatical/genealogical rupture of Marcellusâ€™s death at 6.882-83 (see Miller 2003: 70 n.22).

thâ€™Author selfe: Since the â€˜untimely breachâ€™ is caused by the irruption of the present moment of the narrative (the reign of Arthurâ€™s father, Uther Pendragon), there may be a pun: it is â€˜thâ€™Arthur selfâ€™ who must â€˜attend / To finishâ€™ the next chapter of the chronicle.

70.5-9 Spenserâ€™s account of the Promethean creation derives from Conti (Mythologiae 4.6), Horace (Odes 1.16.13-16), and Ovid (Met 1.76-88).

Fay: fairy. The surmise of divinity that inspires this naming is a characteristic Spenserian trope, deriving from Virgil (Aen 1.327-28) and repeated with variations in many contexts, beginning with the emblems to â€˜Aprillâ€™ in SC.

St. 72-75 Commentators have suggested various historical figures, from Osiris and Hercules to Lucius and Constantine, as referents for the early rulers of Faeryland, but the progressive unfolding of the dynasty suggests rather a kind of abstract or historical paradigm, in which conquerors alternate with builders as empire expands. This pattern converges with British history in the figure of Elficleos as Henry VII.
