73.8-9 Echoing Rev 15: 2, â€˜And I sawe as it were a glassie sea . . .â€™. â€˜Hevens thunderâ€™ has an appropriately apocalyptic rumble, but also vividly describes the sound likely to be made by passage across a bridge made of brass.
75.6-9 Arthur, the oldest son of Henry VII, died at age 16. His younger brother Henry took his place both on the throne and in marriage to Catherine of Aragon.

That: either a pronoun referring to â€˜seatâ€™, suggesting that the throne itself has become a monument to Oberon, or an ellipsis for â€˜so thatâ€™, with â€˜remainesâ€™ construed as intransitive (his wide memorial yet remains).

76.4-5 The diplomatic phrasing of these lines omits the reigns of Edward IV and Mary I and forgets that prior to his â€˜last willâ€™ (testament), Henry had designated Mary his successor and had Elizabeth declared illegitimate.

76.6-9 After so many stanzas chronicling the uncertain fortunes of the British throne, the controversy over Elizabethâ€™s failure to produce an heir and subsequent refusal to name a successor makes itself felt even in Spenserâ€™s terms of praise for her (â€˜this howre . . . Long mayst thou Glorian liveâ€™).
desire: i.e., desire to know
desire: Also suggesting desire for their countriesâ€™ welfare.

Maleger: The name suggests both â€˜badly sickâ€™ and â€˜evil-bearingâ€™, from L mal evil + either aeger sick or gerens bearing. In Ovid, â€˜Maleagerâ€™ is the son of Oeneus, King of Calydon, and his wife Althaea. At his birth, the fates cast a log onto the fire, declaring that Maleager and the burning brand shall enjoy â€˜an equal span of lifeâ€™. Althaea snatches the burning brand from the flames and douses it. When Maleager slays her two brothers in a dispute over the killing of the Caledonian boar, she ends his life by casting the log back into the flames (Met 8.525-546).
deface: destroy
deface: From L de + facere make or do.

St. 1 In its emphasis on â€˜captivityâ€™, â€˜infirmityâ€™, â€˜tyrranyâ€™, and the â€˜partes, brought into . . . bondageâ€™, this and the following stanza echo language from Romans chapters 6 and 7: â€˜Nether give ye your membres as weapons of unrighteousnes unto sinâ€™ (6:13); â€˜the infirmitie of your fleshâ€™ (6:19); â€˜my membres, rebelling against the law of my minde, and leading me captiveâ€™ (7:23). These echoes associate the Maleger episode with the deaths of Mortdant and Amavia in canto i.
vellenage: serfdom
vellenage: From L velle â€˜to wishâ€™ or â€˜to be willingâ€™, the bondage through which the corrupt will subordinates the flesh to sin.
2.1-5 The language of governance and sovereign rule in these lines reinforces the connection between the chronicles in canto x and the allegory of the temperate body in cantos ix and xi; see ix.1.4n.
His: its
His: On the use of â€˜hisâ€™ as a neuter pronoun, see ix.1.8n.
2.3 â€˜And permits her that ought to wield the scepter [reason] to do soâ€™.
banket dight: serve a banquet
Attempred: blended, moderated
cremosin: crimson
windowes of bright heaven: Echoing the biblical account of Noahâ€™s flood, which began when â€˜the windowes of heaven were openedâ€™ (Gen 7:11).
behight: ordered

St. 5 Malegerâ€™s â€˜wicked bandâ€™ is modeled in part on the strana torma who attack Ariostoâ€™s Ruggiero (OF 6.61.1). More broadly, the seige of Almaâ€™s castle reflects an allegorical tradition reaching back through medieval texts such as The Castle of Perseverance, Piers Plowman, and the Ancrene Riwle to Philo Judaeus in antiquity, in which deadly sins beseige the soul by way of the senses.
villeins: serfs
villeins: See 1.9n; these serfs owe their fealty to mortal sin.
exceeding feare / Their visages imprest: 'their faces imprinted surpassing fear' on the beholder.

St. 6 In contrast to the earlier emphasis on the â€˜huge and infinite . . . numbersâ€™ of the attackers (5.6) and the later emphasis on the disorder of a â€˜monstrous rablementâ€™ (8.1), the troops are here carefully enumerated and disposed into an order that both mimics and parodies the organization of the body, so that â€˜each might best offend his proper partâ€™ (6.3).
steades: positions
offend: attack
offend: In biblical usage, to sin against or cause to sin.
his proper part, / And his contrary object: The yoking of these phrases, apparent opposites that function as synonyms, suggests a mirroring between the troops and their objects of attack.

deface: destroy, as at arg.4, but now also echoing the â€˜fowle and ugly . . . visagesâ€™ of 5.8-9, which disfigure with fear the faces they oppose, making them reflect their opponentsâ€™ ugliness. As the troops become more orderly in their address to the organized body (â€˜As every one seemâ€™d meetest in that caceâ€™), so the defenders of that body become more â€˜monstrousâ€™ (8.1) in response to their attackers.
Seven of the same: Seven suggests the deadly sins.
the Castle gate: The mouth; see ix.23 and ix.23.3n.
closely: covertly
The other five: Five suggests the senses; cf. Ancrene Riwle 21, â€˜The heartâ€™s wardens are the five senses: sight, hearing, speaking, and smelling, and every limbâ€™s feelingâ€™.
pyle: castle
arrett: entrust
arrett: See OED (s.v. â€˜aretâ€™ 4) and glossary, and cf. viii.8.1, â€˜The charge, which God doth unto me arrettâ€™.

Tâ€™assayle with open force or hidden guyle: This phrasing will be echoed by Jove in the Mutability cantos when he asks the assembled pantheon whether they should resist the assault of the Titaness â€˜by open force, or counsell wiseâ€™ (TCM vi.21.8), and again by Satan in Paradise Lost when he asks the demons in hell whether they should assault heaven through â€˜open Warr or covert guileâ€™ (2.41).
apply: put into effect
importune: urgent; persistent; grievous
there their: See 6.3-4n.

note.p: St. 8 Spenser draws in a broad way on classical and medieval pictorial traditions that associate sins and senses with specific animals, as well as on natural histories and bestiaries that retail proverbial lore about the special attributes of different animal kinds. The bestiaries, because they amass references from widely diverse sources, provide a store of anecdotes, judgments, and observations at once copious, random, and contradictory enough to justify almost any associative link. An additional layer of complexity arises from the allegorical emphasis on animal shapes as â€˜portrayingâ€™ temptations (11.7); because this technique tends to translate all five senses into visual terms, it cuts against the system of classification that disposes the allegory.

A troop of animal-headed monstrosities appearing in Ariosto (see st. 5n) is taken by Harrington to represent the seven deadly sins (80). Spenserâ€™s rablement is associated rather with the senses, which in st. 8-13 follow the traditional sequence based on Aristotle, De anima, 2.6-12.

div.note: 8.3-4 Spenserâ€™s owls, dogs, and gryphons may correspond to the â€˜lawlesse lustes, corrupt envyes, / And covetous aspectsâ€™ of lines 8-9: dogs are associated with envy and gryphons with covetousness (Carroll 1954: 99, 105). Owls are not noted for lawless lust, but they are associated with noctural activity generally.
beckes: beaks

Lynces eyes: The lynx (for which Spenser gives the Italinate form) is proverbially sharp-sighted (see Ripa 1603, s.v. â€˜Visoâ€™, and Harvey, Speculum Tuscanismi, in Familiar Letters: â€˜Not the like Lynx, to spie out secretesâ€™). The Greek hero Lynceus was said to have preternaturally sharp vision (Apollodorus 1.7.8-9, 3.10.3; Hyginus, Fabulae 100).
bow and arrowes: Cupidâ€™s weapon of choice, conventionally figuring looks that penetrate the heart.
lawlesse lustes: See 1 Pet 2:11, â€˜fleshlie lustes, which fight against the souleâ€™.
withhault: pseudo-archaic 16th century form of â€˜withheldâ€™
engins: either machines of combat or deceptions, instruments of â€˜open force or hidden guyleâ€™ (7.4)
Beautie, and money: Corresponding to Guyonâ€™s two chief adversaries, Acrasia and Mammon.
lent: brought to bear

assignment: 1596 revises to â€˜dessignmentâ€™ (enterprise, undertaking), which seems more apt than any attested sense of â€˜assignmentâ€™, the passivity of which sits uncomfortably against the force of the verb phrase â€˜makes againstâ€™. Cf. Othello 2.1.21-22: â€˜The desperate Tempest hath so bangâ€™d the Turks, / That their designment haltsâ€™.

10.3-5 As with the sense of sight, Spenserâ€™s animal associations for hearing seem partly conventional and partly the product of â€˜straunge differenceâ€™. His â€˜Hartsâ€™ coincide with Harvey, Speculum (â€˜A vultures smelling, Apes tasting, sight of an Eagle, / A Spiders touching, Hartes hearing, might of a Lyonâ€™), but where Spenser has â€˜wilde Boresâ€™, Ripa (who does mention vna Cerua, a doe, s.v. â€˜Vditoâ€™) refers not to boars but to lâ€™orecchia dâ€™un Toro (â€˜the ears of a Bullâ€™). Snakes are linked to backbiting and slander in Ancrene Riwle (36).
10.6-8 The evils that assault the sense of hearing resemble those in Ancrene Riwle: foul speech, heresy, lying, backbiting, and flattery (35).
crakes: boastings
assayd: put to the test

11.4-5 Note that where Harveyâ€™s Ape (10.3-5n) embodies the sense of taste, Spenser associates apes with smell. Spenserâ€™s â€˜Puttockes,â€™ or buzzards, do on the other hand answer to Harveyâ€™s vulture. The link to â€˜houndesâ€™ is proverbial because of their function in the hunt.
abusions: impostures; also the English translation of catachresis, or perversion of terms
grysie: grisly
grysie: From OE â€˜griseâ€™, to shudder with fear. See glossary.

12.4-5 Oystriges are said by Caxton to eat iron (Myrrour of Worlde 1481: 2.16.101). Toades were thought to be poisonous: see Shakespeareâ€™s Duke Senior on â€˜the toad, ugly and venemousâ€™ (As You Like It 2.1.13).
luxury: From L luxuria prodigality; Spenser anticipates later usage (for 16th-century senses, OED records only â€˜lasciviousness, lustâ€™).
unthriftie waste: As Hamilton 2001 notes, embodied in the â€˜waistless swineâ€™ of lines 5-6.

St. 13 Touch, the bulwark so sensitive it cannot be named in the text. Snails were a common image for extreme sensitivity: see Shakespeare on â€˜the snail, whose tender horns being hit, / Shrinks backward in his shelly cave with painâ€™ (Venus and Adonis 1033-34). Cf. Harvey on â€˜A Spiders touchingâ€™, 10.3-5n. â€˜Urchinsâ€™ are hedgehogs (porcupines).
hew: shape

13.5-8 Although snails and hedgehogs respectively suffer and inflict pain, the weapons 'Cruelly' employed by the fifth troop are all pleasurable sensationsâ€”except, perhaps, â€˜stinges of carnall lustâ€™. In Book III we will learn that to Paridell, â€˜nothing new . . . was that same paine, / Ne paine at allâ€™ (ix.29.6-7), and that Cupid, in addition to wounding the rest of the pantheon, â€˜Ne did . . . spare sometime to pricke himselfeâ€™ (xi.45.3).
effort: power
Ordinaunce: ordnance, artillery

play: The grammatical subject may be either â€˜troupesâ€™ or â€˜Ordinaunceâ€™; the general sense either way is of heavy weaponry brought to bear on all five bulwarks, with the added suggestion that the rabblement enjoy their work.
decay: destruction
assay: Cf. 11.2.
peece: fortress; work of art
assieged: besieged
ward: garrison
stonds: defensive positions

two brethren Gyauntes: The hands (Gilbert 1955); in a passage allegorizing the body as a dwelling, Eccles 12:3 refers to â€˜the kepers of the houseâ€™, identified in the Geneva gloss as â€˜The hands, which kepe the bodieâ€™. See â€˜Extremitiesâ€™ at ii.arg.3.
mayne: Also the heraldic term for â€˜handâ€™.
pretend: attempt
Carle: villain, with a suggestion of low birth
remercied: thanked
remercied: From the Anglo-Norman and Middle French remercier. Echoing â€˜recomfortâ€™ to emphasize the reciprocity between Alma and Arthur.
glitterand: glittering
dight: dressed
glitterand: See vii.42.1n.
hent: took
conge: a formal leave-taking
behight: commanded
thee: thrive (an archaism)
gent: valiant and courteous; well-born
18.1-2 See Virgil, fundunt simul undique tela / crebra nivis ritu (â€˜at once from all sides they shower darts as thick as snowflakesâ€™; Aen 11.610-11 ).

18.4-9 See Virgil, rapidus montano flumine torrens / sternit agros, sternit sata laeta boumque labores / praecipitisque trahit silvas (â€˜the rushing torrent from a mountain-stream lays low the fields, lays low the glad crops and labours of oxen and drags down forests headlongâ€™; Aen 2.305-7); and non sic, aggeribus ruptis cum spumeus amnis / exiit oppositasque evicit gurgite moles, / fertur in arva furens cumulo camposque per omnis / cum stabulis armenta trahit (â€˜Not with such fury, when a foaming river, bursting its barriers, has overflowed and with its torrent overwhelmed the resisting banks, does it rush furiously upon the fields in a mass and over all the plains sweep herds and foldsâ€™; Aen 2.496-99).
vowes: prayers
his headlong ruine may sustayne: â€˜May withstand the force of the waterâ€™s descentâ€™; â€˜may bear up against the husbandmanâ€™s fallâ€™.
hayle: â€˜A storm, shower, or volley of something falling like hailâ€™ (OED)

raskall flockes: Varying senses of the adj come into play: applied to persons generally, it means â€˜forming or belonging to the rabble or the lowest social classâ€™ (OED); applied to soldiers it means â€˜belonging to the lowest rank, commonâ€™; applied to animal flockes it means â€˜young, lean, inferiorâ€™. Cf. â€˜raskall routsâ€™, ix.15.4.
before: under his stroke

19.4-5 Echoing the simile at ii.2.6-7 that compares Ruddymane to â€˜budding braunch rent from the native tree, / And throwen forth, till it be witheredâ€™, these lines complete a seasonal cycle in the imagery of the passage, from winter (18.2) through summer and harvest (18.4-9) to late autumn as it passes back into winter. See SC Sept 49 gloss: â€˜the tyme of the yeare, which is in in thend of harvest, which they call the fall of the leafe: at which tyme the Western wynde beareth most swayeâ€™. Given the association of Maleger and his troops with mortality, it is not surprising that the imaged cycle elides spring and doubles the end of the year. Note also that while â€˜flockesâ€™ dehumanizes the troops, â€˜locksâ€™ anthropomorphizes the trees.

19.7 Spumador: golden foam (Ital spuma foam + dâ€™oro of gold). Cf. the echo of spumeus from the Virgilian allusion above (18.4-9n), which reflects a common Virgilian epithet for horses in battle (e.g. Aen 6.881, spumantis equi), and may therefore associate Spumadorâ€™s â€˜fierceâ€™ disposition with the passions embodied in Malegerâ€™s troops; see iv.2.2n for the conventional association in Spenser between the horse and the riderâ€™s passions. Such hints throughout the episode suggest one reason for Arthurâ€™s difficulty in combating the threat represented by his allegorical opponent.

19.8-9 These lines conflate the Solis equi of Ovid (Met 2.154, 162) with the horses of Aeneas in Homer (Il 5.263-73). See Lotspeich 1965, s.v. â€˜Laomedonâ€™. This mingled genealogy offsets the glory of descent from â€˜heavenly seedâ€™ with darker hints: Laomedonâ€™s horses were originally given to Tros by Zeus as recompense for the kidnapping of Ganymede; the horses of the sun in Ovid are invoked at the moment of PhaÃ«tonâ€™s fall; Laomedon is said to have cheated Hercules out of the horses given by Zeus, promised as a reward for the rescue of Hesione (Met 11.211-215); and Aeneas inherits horses through the purloining of their siresâ€™ seed: á¼µÏ€Ï€Ï‰Î½ oÏƒÏƒÎ¿Î¹ ÎµÎ±ÏƒÎ¹Î½ á½‘Ï€á¾½ Î·Ï‰ Ï„á¾½ Î·ÎµÎ»Î¹Î¿Î½ Ï„Îµ, / Ï„Î·Ï‚ Î³ÎµÎ½ÎµÎ·Ï‚ ÎµÎºÎ»ÎµÏˆÎµÎ½ Î±Î½Î±Î¾ Î±Î½Î´ÏÏ‰Î½ á¼ˆÎ³Ï‡Î¹ÏƒÎ·Ï‚ (hippon ossoi easin hupâ€™ Ä“Å tâ€™ Ä“elion te, / tÄ“s geneÄ“s eklion / tÄ“s geneÄ“s eklepsen anax andrÅn HagchoÄ“s; â€˜from this stock the lord of men Anchises stoleâ€™; Il 5.268-9).
Laomedon: a king of Troy, grandson of Tros and father of Priam
yode: went

a Tygre swift: Medieval and early modern bestiaries inaccurately derived the name â€˜tigerâ€™ from the word for â€˜arrowâ€™ in Greek and other languages, â€˜in reference to the celerity of its springâ€™ (OED). See White (1954: 12), Woodbridge (1993: 29), Topsell (1967: 1.547-8).
subtile substance and unsound: Rarefied and insubstantial stuff (cf. ix.15.9, xi.30.3).
21.1-4 See 20.4n on the supposed etymological connection of â€˜tigerâ€™ and â€˜arrowâ€™. For arrows representing the assault of sin upon the upright heart, see Ps 11:2 and Eph 6:16.
the Indians: See SpE â€˜visual artsâ€™ Fig. 1 for a reproduction of Indian with Body Paint from The Drawings of John White, 1577-1590.
their . . . their: there . . . there
tine: hurt
leane and meagre: Playing on the sound of 'Maleger'.
as a rake: Proverbial: cf. Chaucer, CT Gen Pro 287, â€˜As leene was his hors as is a rakeâ€™.

a dryed rooke: â€˜A heap or stack of combustible material, esp. when to be used as fuelâ€™ (OED s.v. â€˜ruckâ€™). See the story of Maleager in Ovid (arg.4n), and the â€˜raging flameâ€™ with which Impatience is armed (23.9).

as cold and drery as a Snake: See Virgil, frigidus in pratis . . . anguis (â€˜the cold snake in the meadowsâ€™; Ecl 8.71); White: â€˜Now all Serpents are cold by natureâ€™ (1954: 186); also Woodbridge (1993: 195). The combination of cold and dry humors associates Maleger with melancholy.

canvas thin: Not the thicker fabric used for sailcloth, but the coarse and lightweight material worn by Shakespeareâ€™s â€˜hempen home-spunsâ€™ (A Midsummer Nightâ€™s Dream 3.1.77). Together with Malegerâ€™s belt of â€˜twisted brakeâ€™ and his resemblance to a stack of kindling, this garment suggests the image of a scarecrow.
twisted brake: bracken, ferns

22.8-9 Malegerâ€™s helmet-skull confirms the suggestion running throughout the description that he personifies â€˜the bodie of this deathâ€™ (Rom 7:24), glossed in the Geneva Bible as â€˜This fleshlie lump of sinne and deathâ€™; cf. 20.9. Rollinson takes exception to this view in SpE (s.v. â€˜Malegerâ€™). The helmet may also allude to the myth of Antaeus, who roofed a temple to his father, Poseidon, with the skulls of defeated opponents. Boccaccio cites Fulgentius on Antaeus as â€˜lust of the fleshâ€™ (libidine ex carne; Genealogia 1.14).
Maleger: See arg.4n.

other: One of two (OED; see II.iv.4.3-4, â€˜Her other leg was lame, that she noâ€™te walke, / But on a staffe her feeble steps did stayâ€™, where there has similarly been no mention of â€˜oneâ€™ leg to precede the â€˜otherâ€™.) Upton suggests that in both passages, Spenser is playing on Homerâ€™s description of Thersites as ÎµÏ„ÎµÏÎ¿Î½ Ï€Î¿Î´Î± heteron poda lame in one foot (lit. â€˜the other foot of twoâ€™), signifying â€˜left footâ€™ (Il. 2.217). Spenser is saying, more or less, that the lameness of Occasion and Impotence makes them â€˜heteropodsâ€™.

Impotence: From L impotentia lack of power. Latin usage associates power with self-mastery; as lack of self-control, 'Impotence' suggests a condition almost opposite to its modern meaning. Her kinship with Occasion signals a deeper connection between the two episodes: to cope with Furor, Guyon needs the Palmerâ€™s aid to solve the riddle of uncontrolled strength that turns to weakness. This motif begins with Mortdant and Amavia in canto i: â€˜The strong it weakens with infirmitie, / And with bold furie armes the weakest hartâ€™ (57.7-8).

Impatience: From the L impatienta failure to bear suffering. Although impotence and impatience suggest an etymological contrast between active doing and passive suffering, their alliance in this episode reflects a common ground: impotence, construed not as the inability to do but as the inability to refrain, is in good company with the inability to suffer passively.
raging flame: Cf. Pyrochlesâ€™ shield and motto at iv.38.
felly: fiercely
quarrell: â€˜A short, heavy arrow or bolt with a four-sided (typically square) head for shooting from a crossbow or arbalestâ€™ (OED)

to him . . . at him: The mirroring language may imply that at this stage of the combat Arthur (like the beseiged castle, earlier; see 6.3-4n) bears some resemblance to his foe. The retaliatory motive mentioned in the next line may reinforce this suggestion.
raught: reached
hide: i.e. â€˜hied,â€™ past tense of â€˜hie,â€™ to hasten
26.2 This hyperole assumes the extromissive theory of vision that coexisted with intromissive theory in early modern England.

26.6-9 Spenser would have found descriptions of Tartar horsemen shooting backward while fleeing in Mandeville (1964: 237-238) and in Marco Polo (1958: 101). Maleger fleeing while turning to face his pursuer may extend the pattern of mirroring between opponents in this canto (see 6.3-4n and 25.2n).
27.2 Insofar as the knight is â€˜greedyâ€™ he may be drawing â€˜nigh toâ€™ his foe as well in resemblance as in pursuit.
27.3-4 Marco Polo (see 26.6-9n) refers to the Tartars as â€˜occasionally pretending to flyâ€™.
St. 28 See Guyonâ€™s discovery in canto iv that to restrain Furor he must â€˜bindâ€™ Occasion (st. 11-14), followed by Pyrochlesâ€™ insistence on releasing her (v.17-19).
St. 29 See Furorâ€™s â€˜rude assaultâ€™ upon Guyon (iv.6-9) and later Pyrochles (v.22-23).
lent: leaned
rude: ungentle, harsh
gryesly graplement: grisly grappling
gryesly graplement: OED records no other instance of graplement.
29.8-9 See the squireâ€™s previous defense of Arthur at I.viii.12.7-9.
St. 30 The narrator here treats Arthurâ€™s vulnerability as a generic condition (â€˜life unsoundâ€™, line 3) rather than an individual character flaw.
30.4-5 Echoing the Geneva gloss to 2 Cor 5:1: â€˜After this bodie shalbe dissolved, it shalbe made incorruptible and immortalâ€™.
prowest: superlative of prow, valiant, worthy
Britayne land: Wales and Cornwall, â€˜the place in southwestern Great Britain from which the Briton characters enter Faerylandâ€™ (Erickson 1996: 87).

30.9 As an instance of divine grace extended to fallen mortals (â€˜thing on groundâ€™, â€˜may never standâ€™), the squireâ€™s intervention reiterates on a smaller scale the general significance of Arthurâ€™s five eighth-canto appearances in the poem, this time applied to Arthur himself.
Jade: OED glosses this instance under n.1, 2. â€˜A term of reprobation applied to a womanâ€™.
behinde invade: attack from behind
31.6-9 Compare the revivals of Cymochles (vi.27) and Guyon (viii.53). Athurâ€™s 'Revivyng thought', or animating principle, is Praysdesire (ix.38.7, 39.8).

St. 32 The simile compares resurgent Arthur to a volcanic eruption, thought to result from fire trapped underground. Platoâ€™s Phaedo talks about an underground river of fire (â€˜Pyrephlegethonâ€™) that feeds volcanoes through a system of cold and warm waters (Phaedo, 113 b3-5); Lucretius too believed that subterranean fires akin to furnaces are source of volcanic activity (he thought winds drive the flames up in eruptions; De Rerum 6.680-703); finally, German geologist Georgius Agricola in his work De re Metallica argued that chemical vapors erupted under extreme pressure and spewed flames of basalt and mountain â€˜oilâ€™ (12.566). The theory of the elements holds that each of them naturally gravitates toward its â€˜native seatâ€™: see Ovid, ignea convexi vis et sine pondere caeli / emicuit summaque locum sibi fecit in arce (â€˜the fiery weightless element that forms heavenâ€™s vault leaped up and made place for itself upon the topmost heightâ€™; Met 1.26-7).

infest: 1596 and 1609 give 'unrest'. The use of infest as a noun meaning 'outbreak' or 'attack' is without known precedent in sixteenth century English but not without justification in context. The 1596 revision is not necessarily authorial.
his: Malegerâ€™s
caytive bands: bonds of captivity
caytive bands: Cf. Archimagoâ€™s escape from â€˜caytives handesâ€™ at i.1.7.
touzd: past tense of â€˜touseâ€™, â€˜of a dog: to tear at, worryâ€™ (OED)
33.4 It is unclear how the â€˜curresâ€™ of line 3 have acquired â€˜handsâ€™.
his hands / Discharged: Maleger lays his bow and arrows aside, the verb â€˜dischargedâ€™ wittily transferred from the action of shooting an arrow to that of discarding the weapon.
quarâ€™le: quarrell
quarâ€™le: See 24.8n.
marle: earth
33.9 Arthur was prone when Maleger dismounted: â€˜his foe flatt lyingâ€™ elides â€˜his foe who was then flatt lyingâ€™.
St. 34-46 Arthurâ€™s combat with Maleger is modeled on Herculesâ€™ wrestling with Antaeus. See Lucan (Pharsalia 4:680-739).
manhood meare: unaided manhood
weened: believed, expected
35.3-4 A parody of the resurrection; also of the resurgences of Guyon (viii.53) and Redcrosse (I.xi.53).
bend: apply

35.7-9 See Aen 12.897-98, where Turnus hurls at Aeneas â€˜a giant stone and ancient, which haply lay upon the plain, set for a landmark, to ward dispute from the fieldsâ€™ (saxum antiquum, ingens, campo quod forte iacebat, / limes agro positus litem ut discerneret arvis). As a literary landmark, this stone links Arthur to Turnus at the moment when the doomed heroâ€™s strength is leaving him. Virgil in turn is recalling two distinct moments from the Iliadâ€”one in which Diomedes wounds Aeneas (5.302-4) and a second in which Aeneas prepares to hurl a boulder at Achilles (20.283-87)â€”and is combining these with the famous dream-simile from the scene of Hectorâ€™s defeat (22.199-201). One effect of this complex allusive network is to link Arthur at this moment to heroes on the brink of defeat. Another is to linka him to a series of reversals: Aeneas as the target of a stone; then Aeneas hoisting a stone to throw it at Achilles; then Aeneas as the target once again, with Turnus taking his place hoisting as he re-experiences Hectorâ€™s sense of dreamlike unreality in flight from Achilles. This series of reversals echoes hints throughout this canto that link Arthur to Maleger, and suggests that on closer examination, the epic â€˜land-markeâ€™ will indeed become a â€˜signe of sundry wayâ€™.
sundry way: fork or crossroads
meant decay: intended destruction
souse: the act of swooping to strike

souse: OED cites Spenser as the first instance of this sense, which it speculates may be due to confusion with the sense, â€˜The act, on the part of a bird, of rising from the ground, as giving the hawk an opportunity to strikeâ€™. Given this cantoâ€™s persistent tendency implicitly to identify attackers and their targets, it is tempting to speculate that the â€˜confusionâ€™ is deliberate.
sternely: fiercely
37.8-9 The internal rhyme adds a weirdly comic note to the nightmarish quality of the moment.
nathemore: a Spenserianism, â€˜never the moreâ€™
in amaze: A favorite pun in Spenser: in amazement and in a maze.
aery spirite: A spirit made of airâ€”not the proper element for Maleger, but Arthur is in a state of shock from which he must recover in order to interpret correctly what he is beholding.
hellish feend raysd up through divelish science: See I.v.32-44 where Duessa takes Sansfoy to hell to seek Aesculapiusâ€™ medical skill (40.1: â€˜Such wondrous science in mans wittâ€™).
St. 40 For a possible answer to the stanzaâ€™s series of riddles, see 22.9n, above. There are seven riddles, a number associated with the body (see ix.22n).
appeach: accuse
40.8 For the parodox of strength through weakness, see 23.8n.
Give over to effect: give up trying to accomplish
Mordure: See viii.21.6n. The swordâ€™s name, evoking a vocabulary of death (murder, mordant, mors), may suggest a reason for its inability to wound Maleger.
exprest: literally, pressed out
wrest: a twisting or wrenching motion
wrest: A reminder that Arthur has resorted to â€˜wrestlingâ€™. Antaeus forced strangers passing through his kingdom to wrestle him.

his mother earth: Antaeus derived strength from the earth because Ge was his mother; Maleger derives strength from the earth because earth is metonymically the origin of human mortality, and the mortal weakness of the flesh is Malegerâ€™s strength (see 44.6-45.6).
Joves harnesse-bearing Bird: the eagle, bearer of Joveâ€™s thunderbolt
quarrey: prey

43.5 A suggestive line insofar as Arthur is combatting, in Maleger, the consequences of the Fall of Man, experiencing a second fall so that he can double back to imitate the undoing of the first by means of divine grace.
travell: travail

this lifelesse shadow: FE corrects â€˜hisâ€™ to this, presumably to retain the latency of the sense, suggested throughout the episode, in which Maleger is indeed Arthur's â€˜shadow of deathâ€™ (Ps 23).
mayne: physical force

44.6-45.6 In remembering that had bene sayd, Arthur is recalling the myth of Herculesâ€™ combat with Antaeus, interpreted in Medieval and Renaissance literature as his victory over the lusts of the flesh (see 22.9n).
with usury: with interest
scruzd: Coined by Spenser; OED suggests that it combines the verbs â€˜screwâ€™ and â€˜squeezeâ€™, which would suggest a wringing motion.
three furlongs: three-eighths of a mile
three furlongs: Originally, â€˜furlongâ€™ signified the length of a furrow in a plowed field.
standing: stagnant
standing: See Shakespeareâ€™s reference to â€˜a sort of men, whose visages / Do cream and mantle like a standing pondâ€™ (The Merchant of Venice 1.1.88-89).
th'one of them: Impatience, â€˜armâ€™d with raging flameâ€™ (23.9)
47.6 Imitating both Pyrochles at vi.42 and the Gadarene swine possessed by demons at Mark 5:13.
conquerour: Cf. I.xii.6.1n. The term associates Arthur with Christ.
49.5 Cf. 1.5, â€˜Their force is fiercer through infirmityâ€™, and 40.8, â€˜most strong in most infirmiteeâ€™.
despoyled: undressed
despoyled: Contrast the image of Verdant disarmed and recumbent in the Bower of Bliss, attended to by Acrasia, xii.72-80.

through . . . through passing (by . . . passing through 1596): 1590 is infelicitous but not incoherent; the compositor may have misread copy already marked for the revision effected in 1596. An ethical question in play throughout the canto is whether the â€˜Palmers governaunceâ€™ leads Guyon to pass through perils on his journey or demands that he pass by them (cf. Milton on the importance of confronting vice, vii.19.1-2n).
Acrasy: See i.51.2-4n on the etymology of the name, which associates Acrasia with Impotence as lack of self-control (see xi.23.8n) and opposes her to â€˜Palmers governaunceâ€™.

St. 1 The unmistakably erotic connotations of the language in this stanza are difficult to reconcile with an allegorical program in which Arthurâ€™s victory over fleshly lust in the person of Maleger provides a â€˜foundationâ€™ for Guyonâ€™s capture of Acrasia.
frame: structure; system

frame: Cf. Daniel (1930): â€˜All verse is but a Frame of Wordsâ€™ (Defense of Rhyme 88-89). The â€˜frame of Temperaunceâ€™ is Almaâ€™s castle, hence the human body, â€˜risingâ€™ in triumphant contrast to the ups and downs of Maleger in the preceding canto (see the pun on â€˜in descentâ€™ at ix.1.5); it is also the allegorical architecture for the Legend of Temperance, which attains full articulation as the narrative approaches its conclusion.
adorned: decorated with honors, perhaps crowned
pricke: acme
highest: May be a transferred epithet, although it works as a modifier for both â€˜prickeâ€™ and â€˜prayseâ€™.

Formerly grounded: Arthurâ€™s defeat of Maleger in the previous canto â€˜groundsâ€™ the House of Alma by overcoming the death inherent in its â€˜goodly workemanshipâ€™, which â€˜must turne to earthâ€™ (ix.21.8-9). The pun in â€˜groundedâ€™ suggests that Malegerâ€™s Antaeus-like resurrection is opposite-yet-identical to the Houseâ€™s demise.
bountyhed: goodness
bountyhed: L bonitatem.

Now comes . . . sensuall delights: Point and pricke can be synonyms; the alliterative language here suggests a bodily allegory in which the highest praise is pinpointed within the greatest peril at the sensitive tip (glans) of the penis. This passage may be recollected in section 28 of Whitman's â€˜Song of Myselfâ€™, on the sense of touch (â€˜the treacherous tip of meâ€™, line 3).

note.p: The chief literary model for Guyonâ€™s voyage is found in Homer, Od 12. Spenser cites Ulysses in FQ Letter as Homerâ€™s exemplary â€˜vertuous manâ€™, a conventional assessment that accords with Natale Contiâ€™s interpretation of Ulysses in Mythologiae 9 as the rational soul embattled on the one hand by emotions like fear, anger, or grief, and on the other by sensual pleasures (814-15). Harvey offers a similar assessment when he mentions his plan to read Leicester â€˜suche a Lecture in Homers Odysses, and Virgilâ€™s Ã†neadsâ€™ before his Lordshipâ€™s travel abroad that he will need no further instruction (Letters 5.162-70). Other antecedents for Guyonâ€™s voyage include Virgil, Aen 2-3, and medieval accounts of the voyage of St Brendan (e.g. in Legenda Aurea; see Var. 2.448-49). The most immediate antecedents are Tasso, GL 15 and Richard Edenâ€™s 1555 translation of Peter Martyrâ€™s Decades, one of the earliest and most widely circulated accounts of new world exploration.

Read (2000) notes that â€˜there are times when perils of the kind described in the Decades offer more immediate and vivid models than could be found in Spenserâ€™s traditional sourcesâ€™ (96), but the modeling at work in Spenserâ€™s use of exploration narratives is far more indirect than in Tasso. In GL Carlo and Ubaldo travel through clearly identified Mediterranean and Atlantic topographies, and their voyage includes an explicit prophecy of the Christianization of the heathen New World, complete with an apostrophe to Christopher Columbus. Guyon and the Palmer, by contrast, encounter literary rather than geospatial landmarks, in keeping with the redefinition of â€˜placeâ€™ introduced in the proem to Book II, where voyages of exploration are introduced as a trope for reading. Guyonâ€™s voyage with the Palmer develops the trope in some detail.

div.note: the third Morrow: The scriptural resonance of this phrase (Matt 12:40, â€˜For as Jonas was thre days, and thre nights in the whales bellie: so shal the Sonne of man be thre dayes and thre nights in the heart of the earthâ€™) amplifies the connotations of the cantoâ€™s opening declaration (â€˜Fayrely to riseâ€™) and reinforces the link between Arthurâ€™s victory over the son of the earth and Guyonâ€™s pending encounter with the temptations of the flesh.

2.5 Spenserâ€™s image recalls two moments in the Aeneid. In the first, Aeneas, having just buried his nurse Caieta, sails past Circeâ€™s island as splendet tremulo sub lumine pontus (â€˜the sea glitters beneath [the moonâ€™s] dancing beamsâ€™; 7.9). In the second, Aeneas as he contemplates the approach of war in Latium magno curarum fluctuat aestu (â€˜tosses on a mighty sea of troublesâ€™; 8.19), turning his thoughts sicut aquae termulum labris ubi lumen aÃ«nis / sole repercussum aut radiantis imagine lunae / omnia pervolitat loca (â€˜as when in brazen bowls a flickering light from water, flung back by the sun or the moonâ€™s glittering form, flits far and wideâ€™; 8.22-24). Ariosto picks up this image to describe Orlandoâ€™s distracted mood just before he abandons the siege at Paris to go in search of Angelica: qual d'acqua chiara il tremolante lume, / dal sol percossa o daâ€™ notturni rai, / per gli ampli tetti va con lungo salto / a destra et a sinistra (â€˜[his thoughts] were like the tremulous gleam which a limpid pool gives off under the rays of the sun or moon--high and low, to right and left it fans outâ€™; OF 8.71, trans. Waldman). Spenser at first appears to be moving the image back toward its more serene initial context, but the intervening traces of mental disquiet reappear in the immediately following lines.
acquight: aquit
acquight: Includes the sense of deliverance by paying or cancelling a debt.
Gulfe of Greedinesse: Based on Homerâ€™s Charybdis by way of Virgil and Conti (Od 12.101-110, 234-59; Aen 3.420-32, 555-67; Myth 748-51).
hideous: immense

4.1-2 Spenser replaces Homerâ€™s Scylla and her monstrous anatomy with a magnet (L magnes), masculine in gender and only residually shaped like a body. See â€˜the rock of the Adamantâ€™ in Huon of Bordeux (ch. 109).
Depending: hanging down

rift: The use of â€˜riftâ€™ to signify a projecting edge rather than a fissure is unusual, but characteristic of Spenser. Compare the rhyme-word clift, which is Spenserâ€™s preferred form of â€˜cliffâ€™ even though it is also a variant form of â€˜cleftâ€™. For the pairing of these terms, see e.g. Eden, â€˜The ryftes and clyftesâ€™ (1555: 134), or Holinshed (1965:1:217), in a passage Spenser remembers at III.iii.8-9, describing a â€˜rift or cliftâ€™ near the shore of â€˜a little rockie Ile in Aber Barrieâ€™. Compare also the â€˜ragged breachesâ€™ hanging down at II.vii.28.3.
wawes: waves (archaic)
wawes: Cf. Coverdale (1535: Jas 1.6), â€˜For he that douteth is lyke the wawes of the seeâ€™.
5.7-8 See Prov 1.12, â€˜We wil swallowe them up alive like a grave even whole, as those that go downe into the pitâ€™.
Tartare: Tartarus, the region of the classical underworld Hades specifically reserved to the damned.
ruinate: collapse
ruinate: From L ruo to hurl down. With â€˜brokeâ€™, suggesting financial ruin.
exanimate: lifeless
exanimate: From L ex out + anima breath, with a possible play on animus soul.

7.6-9 Echoing 1 Tim 6:9, â€˜For they that wil be riche, fall into temptation and snares, and into many foolish and noysome lustes, which drowne men in perdition and destructionâ€™. See also 1 Tim 1:19, â€˜Having faith and a good conscience, which some have put away, and as concerning faith, have made shipwracke.â€™
blent: obscured, destroyed
Reproch: disgrace, infamy
Meawes: the common gull
Seagulles: Proverbially greedy; see Nashe 1599 (Lenten Stuffe 60), â€˜That greedy seagull ignorance is apt to devoure any thingâ€™.
Cormoyraunts: A large, voracious seabird, proverbially a figure for gluttony, greed, or the rapacity of userers. See Chaucer, â€˜The hote cormeraunt of glotonyeâ€™ (PF 362).
thrift: savings

drift: â€˜Floating matter driven by currents of waterâ€™ (OED); see Hakluyt 1907 â€˜Foure leagues from the lande, you finde . . . many drifts of rootes, leaves of trees, [etc.]â€™ (Voyages 3.249). Here the context suggests an accumulation of such flotsam, or the place where it accumulates.
lustfull luxurie: excessive indulgence, especially sexual excess
reliques: remnants; memorials
counselled: With a pun, counsel- led.

Ferryman: See Conti (Myth 170): â€˜Godâ€™s goodness is the source of our hope and of the joy that is the vehicle which ferries us across those troubled watersâ€”that is, Charonâ€™. The Ferryman enables Guyonâ€™s boat to â€˜applyâ€™ (steer) a â€˜courseâ€™ as opposed to being â€˜drivenâ€™ to a â€˜driftâ€™ (8.9).
fordonne: ruined or destroyed
seeming now and then: â€˜appearing now here and then elsewhereâ€™
certein wonne: fixed dwelling
stragling plots: wandering pieces of land

wandring Islands: Mentioned earlier at i.51 and vi.11.3-4; cf. Homerâ€™s Ï€ÎµÏ„ÏÎ±Î¹ ÎµÏ€Î·ÏÎµÏ†ÎµÎµÏ‚ petrai epmrephees overhanging rocks (Od 12.59). On floating islands see Herodotus (Histories 2.156), Pliny the elder (Natural History 1.17) and Pliny the younger (Letters 8.20).
many a: disyllabic, â€˜man-yaâ€™
recure: recover
St. 13 For the story of Latona giving birth to Apollo and Diana on the isle of Delos, see Ovid (Met 6.186-91) and Virgil (Aen 3.73-77); also Conti (Myth 838, 840).
traveiling that way: traveling; travailing, in labor
temple: â€˜honorâ€™ 1596
herried: praised, glorified

14.2 The purposive forward progress of the voyagers combines two motifs that recur throughout the episode. One is a contrast between linear progress and â€˜wanderingâ€™ in illusion; the other links temperance to timing, as the voyagers resist delay but pause to deliberate.
fleet: float
touchen: For a ship, to call in passing; for a man, to have sexual contact.
skippet: skiff
can: did

cause: Plays etymologically and homophonically with case, cosa, and chose, echoing the Wife of Bathâ€™s â€˜bele choseâ€™ (CT Wife of Bath D 510) and sustaining the double-entendre of â€˜to touchen thereâ€™.
light: quickly
sort: manner
bord: accost; nautical sense, â€˜come alongside to attackâ€™; also â€˜jestâ€™
purpose diversly: make small talk
bord: See Shakespeare, Twelfth Night (1.3.56-7): â€˜â€œAccostâ€ is front her, board her, woo her, assail herâ€™.
wite: blame

St. 17-20 The mermaids, the â€˜quickesand of Unthriftyheadâ€™, and the â€˜Whirlepoole of decayâ€™ form a series analogous to PhÃ¦dria, the Gulfe of Greedinesse, and the Rocke of Reproch. There are distinctions to be made (e.g., greediness is a moral condition that incurs shame, whereas unthriftyhead is a behavior that leads to decay), but as the monsters and water-hazards proliferate there is also a sense of redundancy, reminding us that all the moral threats in this canto are forms of excess. At times the allegory itself seems in this way to be infiltrated by the forces it seeks to demonize. On a formal level, this tension plays out the ethical distinction between â€˜passing throughâ€™ and â€˜passing byâ€™ perils (see arg.1-2n).

17.2 The awkward caesura after â€˜himâ€™ recapitulates within the line Guyonâ€™s experience of his ferry ride, interrupted by an unscheduled stop and an unwanted invitation to dally, even as PhÃ¦dria renews her effort to delay â€˜their gateâ€™ (see 14.2n).
gate: path or journey
avyse: look around, take thought
avyse: Contrast this well-advised pause with PhÃ¦driaâ€™s attempt to delay the voyage.
safety: trisyllabic
17.9 See Circeâ€™s description of the Sirens in Homer (Od 12.37-54).
the narrow way: Matt 7:14, â€˜the gate is streicte, and the way narowe that leadeth unto lifeâ€™.
discoloured: With a pun on â€˜discolour-redâ€™.
Unthriftyhed: Cf. 8.8, â€˜lost credit and consumed thriftâ€™.
mesprize: mistake
mesprize: From Fr mÃ©prise, from prendre â€˜takeâ€™.
hazardize: predicament
hazardize: A nonce-word for which OED records no other instance.
recurâ€™d: recovered
backe recoyle: drive or force back
doole: grief
earnest: â€˜heedfulâ€™ 1596
21.3 They reach (â€˜fetchâ€™) the far end of the â€˜narrow wayâ€™ (18.4) that separates the whirlpool from the quicksand.

21.7-9 The land- and seascape of Guyonâ€™s voyage is frequently imbued with affective states proper to the moral hazards signified. Conti cites classical interpreters who rationalize Scylla as a promontory shaped like a woman, with caves whose roaring sound resembles howling dogs (Myth 748-49); Spenser, who follows a similar impulse at 4.1-2 (see note), nevertheless sustains a residual or figurative animation of the seascape.
guise: customary manner
Outragiously . . . enraged: See OED s.v. â€˜outrageâ€™: â€˜In English often reanalysed as out prefix + rage n., a notion which affected the sense developmentâ€™.

horrour: (L horrere to bristle, shudder) can describe both the action of the waves and the voyagersâ€™ response; likewise â€˜reareâ€™ can describe the upsurging of the water or the upsurge of emotion of those who witness it.

living sence: Cf. pr.2.1 (â€˜with better sence advizeâ€™) and pr.4.4 (â€˜his sence . . . too blunt and baceâ€™), linked to the figure of reading as a voyage of discovery; and 26.1, where â€˜living senceâ€™ is corrected by â€˜the Palmer well avizâ€™dâ€™.

St. 23-24 Spenserâ€™s principal sources for these stanzas are Pliny Naturalis Historiae, Gesner, Historiae animalium. vol. 4, and Olaus Magnus Historia de Gentibus Septentrionalibus. For detailed discussion see Var 2.359-64; SpE reproduces a sampling of Gesnerâ€™s woodcuts (â€˜natural historyâ€™ figs. 1-3).
23.2-5 Dame Nature as artist with â€˜cunning handâ€™ mirrors the poet: his â€˜pourtraicts of deformiteeâ€™ are her deformed portraits (â€˜fowle defectsâ€™).

Spring-headed Hydres: The Hydra was a serpent whose heads when cut off would sprout again; see Theatre 12.13 on the Hydraâ€™s â€˜seven springing headsâ€™. In the second of his twelve labors, Hercules slew the monster by cauterizing its neck-stubs before new heads could grow (Virgil, Aen 6.576-77; Ovid, Met 9.68-74). The notion of the Hydra as a sea-beast may derive from Boccaccio, Genealogia 13.1 (Gesner 4.457-60).

sea-shouldring Whales: A phrase famous for the response it elicited from John Keats, who when he read it as a schoolboy was said to have sprung up from his seat to imitate the Whalesâ€™ action (Clark 126, qtd Var 2.360).

Scolopendraes: Sea-serpent reputed to cast up its entrails to eject the hook after swallowing bait (Gesner 4.839). P. A. Robin traces confusions regarding this creature in natural histories from Aristotle to Rondelet (Animal Lore in English Literature 120-22, excerpted in Var 2.360-61).
Monoceros: accented on the first and third syllables
immeasured: immense (not previously recorded in English)
Monoceros: The narwhal, a tusked Arctic whale (Gesner 4.547).
24.1-2 The walrus, a.k.a. â€˜morseâ€™ or mors marine (L mors death).
Wasserman: Ger â€˜water-manâ€™ (not previously recorded in English).

Sea-satyre: If there are mermaids and mermen, then it stands to reason that there must also be mer-satyrs; Gesner reproduces a drawing of one (7.4.999), and mentions reports from fishermen who have heard human cries before a storm at sea (Lemmi in Var 2.363).
Huge Ziffius: From Gk Î¾Î¹Ï†Î¹Î±Ï‚ xiphias, swordfish (Gesner 4.1049).
Rosmarines: either the walrus (mors marine) or the sea-horse, said to climb out of the water to graze on promontories.
enrold: rolled up
enrold: Cf. IV.iii.41.5, Gnat 257.
bugs: i.e. bugbears, bogys, bugaboos
bugs: From Welsh bwg ghost, hobgoblin.
entrall: entrails

St. 26 The Palmerâ€™s reassuring demystification of sea-monsters enacts the skeptical and rationalizing impulse implicit in many interpretations of Homerâ€™s monsters and marvels. In the present episode this impulse plays against the recurrent tendency of Spenserâ€™s imagery to animate the seascape (see 21.7-9n).
vertuous: potent; magical; imbued with moral virtue

26.6-7 See Exod 14:16, where Moses divides the Red Sea with his rod; Matt 8:26, where Christ calms the sea; 2 Kings 2:14, where Elisha crosses Jordan with Elijahâ€™s mantle; Virgil, Aen 1.142-3, where Neptune calms the sea; and Tasso, GL 14.73, where Ubaldo wields a similar magic wand.
Tethys: originally a Titaness and sea-goddess; here a name for the sea

St. 27-29 Recalling Duessaâ€™s cameo in the role of distressed maiden in the first episode of Book II. The play on â€˜seemelyâ€™ (comely) and â€˜seemedâ€™ (27.6, 8) points to the mingling of erotic and chivalrous motives that imperils the knightâ€™s judgment in both episodes, as the Palmer explains at 28.9.
streight: immediately, with an ironic glance at Guyonâ€™s instruction to steer the boat off-course
streight: See 29.5-6, where the line-break unfolds the pun.
know: in this context suggesting both to apprehend and to have carnal acquaintance

28.7-8 See st. 26n. The compressed syntax, asserting that the maid is not a real woman but â€˜onely womanish fine forgeryâ€™, echoes the Palmerâ€™s dismissal of the sea-monsters at 26.2, and implicates the process of personification in a kind of reverse derivation: if English obtains the adjective womanish from the noun woman, allegory here converts the adjective back into a noun and then embodies the noun in a fictional referent.
courage: heart
courage: From L cor heart.
embosome: implant
embosome: The maid's â€˜baytâ€™ implies a hookâ€”taken not into the mouth, but into the heart and mind, as the phrase â€˜embosome . . . in your mindâ€™ indicates.
stayed: firm, well-supported
bayt: rest, with a punning reference to its rhyme-partner in the second line

St. 30-32 Spenserâ€™s Mermayds (30.2) derive from the Sirens in Homer (Od 12.39-54, 165-200), but many details in his account come from later sources, including Virgil, Ovid, Pausanius, Boccaccio, and Conti. Homer does not specify the bodily form of the Sirens. Genealogia 7.20, Myth 645, and T. Cooper refer to them as mermaids; Pausanius and Conti also represent them as winged and birdlike.

30.2 Hamilton 2001 notes the emphasis placed on still by the enjambment here, together with its repetition as a rhyme-word at mid-stanza. Stillness is both the temptation the Sirens offer and the fate they threaten: sailors wooed to sleep by their song never awaken (see Conti Myth 642: â€˜they would lull them [sailors] into a very deep sleep. And once these sailors were asleep, they would toss them into the sea and kill themâ€™). Cf. the pun on bayt in st. 29.

30.2-6 Echoing Virgilâ€™s description of the bay (â€˜a haunt of Nymphsâ€™) where Aeneas and his men take shelter after the opening storm in the Aeneid, the prelude to his encounter with Dido (1.157-73).
30.7-9 Implying that the theater â€˜tradesâ€™ in illusion and is therefore â€˜deceiptfullâ€™, analogous to â€˜womanish fine forgeryâ€™ (28.8).

five: In classical accounts, two or three, expanded to five presumably to correspond to the senses, to which they appeal (cf. â€˜a straunge kinde of harmony; / Which Guyons senses softly tickeledâ€™, 33.6-7, and the repeated emphasis on the senses in the proem).
trade: â€˜course, way, or manner of lifeâ€™ (OED)

31.1-2 Pausanius relates that the Sirens â€˜were persuaded by Hera to compete with the Muses by singingâ€™ (Desc 9.34.3), though his Sirens are avian rather than piscine in form. (His version may reflect the influence of Ovid, Met 5, in which it is the Paeonian sisters rather than the Sirens who compete with the Muses in song; they are transformed into Magpies.)
thâ€™Heliconian maides: the Muses
moyity: half
surquedry: presumption
hew: form
applyde: addressed

applyde: Also â€˜adaptedâ€™, because the Sirens were said to â€˜pick out the precise melody that each man would enjoy hearingâ€™ (Conti Myth 644). Thus in the following lines, the Sirens sing directly to Guyon: â€˜O thou fayre sonne of gentle Faery, / That art in mightie armes most magnifyde / Above all knightsâ€™.
magnifyde: praised

32.7-9 The temptation offered by the Sirens is variously glossed as wisdom, voluptuous pleasure, sloth, or flattery. Spenserâ€™s Sirens, like Despair (I.ix) and PhÃ¦dria when she sings Cymochles to sleep in canto vi (15-17), offer rest to the weary (see 30.2n).
St. 33 The sea, surf, and west wind accompany the song of the Mermaids to make up a four-part harmony comprised of alto (mermaids), treble (Zephyrus), tenor (surf), and bass (sea).
33.3 The trochaic substitution in the fourth foot of this line, combined with the length of the preceding syllable â€˜wavesâ€™, creates a striking metrical imitation of â€˜waves breakingâ€™.
Meane: an intermediate part in polyphonic music; measured: made proportional
Zephyrus: the west wind
Zephyrus: Zephyrus also wafts through the Bower of Bliss, where he appeals to the senses of sight and smell (v.29.8-9).

34.1-4 Ulysses had to be boundâ€”twice overâ€”to the mast of his ship; the contrast is heightened when Guyon and his Palmer pass the Mermaidsâ€™ bay at mid-line with barely a caesura, and are already â€˜descryingâ€™ something else by the end of line threeâ€”their forward momentum further emphasized by the enjambment of â€˜gan descry / The landâ€™.
leveled: aimed
a grosse fog: One of the details Spenserâ€™s episode has in common with the Celtic Legend of St. Brandan (see st. 2-41n).
desert: uninhabited (â€˜desertedâ€™) region

34.5-9 The final lines suggest a return to primal chaos; Hamilton 2001 notes the etymological pun in Universe, from L unus one and vertere to turn. Lines 5-7 amplify the disorienting effects of the fog with contortions of the syntax. The sense is, â€˜With his dull vapour, a grosse fog has over spred that desert and enveloped heavens chearefull faceâ€™.
heavens chearefull face enveloped: Cf. the Wandring Wood, â€˜Whose loftie trees yclad with sommers pride, / Did spred so broad, that heavens light did hideâ€™ (I.i.7.4-5).
wastefull: causing â€˜devastation, desolation, or ruinâ€™ (OED)
For: eliding â€˜for fear ofâ€™

St. 36 Cf. the â€˜Owles and Night-ravensâ€™ haunting the entryway to Mammonâ€™s cave (vii.23 and notes), accompanied by â€˜sad Celenoâ€™ (the leader of the Harpies, according to Virgil). For details in this stanza, T. P. Harrison (1956: 64-65) suggests both Gesner (3.524-26) and Magnus (692) as likely sources (see st. 23-24n).
36.1-2 Cf. Rev 18:2 on the fallen Babylon as â€˜a cage of everie uncleane and hateful byrdeâ€™.
unfortunate: omens of misfortune
ill-faste: ill-faced, ugly.
ill-faste: Malegerâ€™s â€˜first troupeâ€™, sent into battle against the bulwark of sight, includes â€˜some . . . Headed like Owlesâ€™ (xi.8.1-3).
trump: trumpet
drere: dreariness, gloom
Strich: screech-owl
Strich: Hamilton 2001 notes that it is also called the â€˜lich-owlâ€™ (â€˜lichâ€™ = corpse) â€˜because its cry was supposed to portend death in the houseâ€™ (OED).
whistler: a nocturnal bird of ill-omen
whistler: This is the first use recorded in OED. On â€˜the Seven Whistlersâ€™ as birds of ill-omen in English folklore, see The English Dialect Dictionary, 19-20.338, s.v. â€˜Sevenâ€™.

hellish: Virgilâ€™s Aeneas encounters the Harpies among many other monstrous apparitions at the mouth of hell (Aen 6.289). They are â€˜prophets of sad destinyâ€™ because they foretell hardship to Aeneas and his men (3.245-58).

37.1-3 The deflating effect of the adversatives (â€˜Yetâ€™, â€˜butâ€™) in line 3, like the mention of rowing in line 4, suggests that fear, for all the verve of the phrase â€˜fild their sayles with fearâ€™, actually has little propulsive force of its own.
stifly: steadfastly
37.7-9 The Palmerâ€™s exhortation to Guyon echoes Unaâ€™s words to Redcrosse as they approach her parentsâ€™ usurped kingdom (I.xi.2.1-2).
sacred: accursed

sacred: A Latinism illustrated by Virgilâ€™s auri sacra fames (â€˜accursed hunger for goldâ€™; Aen 3.57) and mentioned in A Vewe when Irenius reports the ancient name of Ireland to have been â€˜Sacra Insula, taking /sacra for accursedâ€™ (3725-26). Also found in Livy and Horace. See Shakespeare, Titus Andronicus 2.1.120-1, â€˜our empress, with her sacred wit / To villainy and vengeance consecrateâ€™.
crooked: curved

39.1-2 As Aeneas and his men sail past Circeâ€™s island, they hear gemitus iraeque leonum / vincla recusantum et sera sub nocte rudentum, saetigerique sues atque in praesepibus ursi / saevire, ac formae magnorum ululare luporum (â€˜the angry growls of lions chafing at their bonds and roaring in midnight hours, the raging of bristly boars and encaged bears, and howls from shapes of monstrous wolvesâ€™; Aen 7.15-18).

According to Ovidâ€™s Macareus, the animals did â€˜rush on us, filling us with terrorâ€™ initially; he continues, â€˜But there was no need to fear them . . . Why, they even wagged their tails . . . and fawned upon usâ€™ (Met 14.254-58).
upstaring: standing on end
upstaring: Cf. the â€˜heares / Upstaring stiffeâ€™ of Trevisan, I.ix.22.2-3.

40.1-6 For literary precedents to the Palmerâ€™s staff, see 26.6-7n. The staff protects Guyon as the magical herb moly protected Odysseus and his men from Circeâ€™s powers (Od 10.287-94). In Tasso, Ubaldo subdues Armidaâ€™s threatening beasts with a verga aurea immortale (â€˜everlasting staff of goldâ€™; GL 15.49.5).
