them selves: An intensifier, but may also suggest that the beasts fear themselves, like Archimago at I.ii.10.7-8.

41.3-8 In Homer it is Mercury who gives Odysseus the herb moly as an antidote to Circeâ€™s charms (Od 10.276-309; see 40.1-6n); later, Homer describes the god using Caduceus to lead dead souls into the underworld (24.1-5). Virgil ascribes to Mercuryâ€™s staff power over the living and the dead (Aen 4.242-4). Mercury is the messenger god, said by Conti to represent divine reason and wisdom (Myth 369-70). None of these sources mention what kind of wood the Caduceus was made of.
Stygian realmes: the infernal regions
Stygian: from Styx, one of the rivers that bound the underworld.
Orcus: another name for Dis or Pluto, the god of the underworld
vertue: power
vertue: Cf. 26.6.

Bowre of Blisse: See the description at v.27-35 and notes. Spenserâ€™s Bower condenses two Homeric sites, the island of Circe (Od 10) and the garden of Alcinous (7.112-32), combining these with the history of the corresponding topoi, the enchanted isle and the locus amoenus. Cf. the islands of Ariostoâ€™s Alcina (OF 6.19-25) and Tassoâ€™s Armida (GL 15.53-66, 16.1-26), and the garden of Trissinoâ€™s Acratia (ILG Books 4 and 5; see Kostic 1969: 297-301 and Var 2.443-44). These literary places are at once similar and opposed to the biblical garden celebrated in the Song of Solomon: â€˜My sister my spouse is as a garden inclosed, as a spring shut up, and a fountain sealed upâ€™ (4.12). Spenser plays on this topos with a light touch in Am, apostrophizing his belovedâ€™s bosom as â€˜the bowre of blisse, the paradice of pleasureâ€™ into which his thoughts have, like Guyon in st. 63-69, been â€˜too rashly led astrayâ€™ (76.3, 6).

42.3-4 These lines define the Bower as a â€˜choyceâ€™ locus of art, and hence a â€˜placeâ€™ in the textual and rhetorical as well as the spatial sense (see ix.1.9n). As a topos, it has been singled out by the most skillful mimetic artists living. Cf. the description of PhÃ¦driaâ€™s island in canto vi as â€˜a chosen plott . . . As if it had by Natures cunning hand, / Bene choycely picked out from all the restâ€™ (12.1-4). The recollection of this motif now, with the destruction of the Bower impending, evokes Gen 13:11, â€˜Then Lot chose unto him all the plaine of Jordenâ€™, especially in conjunction with the preceding verse: â€˜So when Lot lifted up his eyes, he saw that all the plaine of Jorden was watered every where: (for before the Lorde destroyed Sodom and Gomorah, it was as the garden of the Lorde . . . )â€™.
42.5-7 The place where all sweet things come together, with its mingled appeal to â€˜senseâ€™ or â€˜fantasyâ€™, is the locus amoenus, a topos traced by Curtius (1953: 195-200). See 42.2n.
aggrate: gratify

42.8 This line covertly identifies Spenser himself as the artist of the Bower by inflecting the familiar pun on his ancestral name (De Spencier) as a nominalized verb of sexual release: What Shakespeare in sonnet 129 would call â€˜thâ€™expense of spirit in a waste of shameâ€™ is here the dispense of pleasure in an erotic fantasy. (For other instances of this play on the poetâ€™s name see Cummings 1971: 95 and CV H.B. 5.3, along with FQ II.i.36.1-3, II.ix.29.1, V.i.7.5, and notes.) The emphasis on copiousness alludes in part to the fact that, at 87 stanzas, this is by far the longest canto in the poem.
affluence: profusion
enclosed: Cf. Song Sol 4:12 and 42.2n.

43.4, 8-9 The weakness of the fence and insubstantiality of the gate suggest that they may be intended less to prevent trespass than to provoke it. The Bower is a hortus as much inconclusus as conclusus.
Nought feard theyr force: â€˜The force of the beasts was not at all fearedâ€™.
fortilage: fortress
fortilage: An ironic term for the invitingly ill-defended Bower.
efforced: forced open or gained by force
efforced: The language throughout this stanza flirts with the distinction between â€˜pleasureâ€™ and â€˜batteryâ€™.
St. 44-45 The â€˜famous historyâ€™ of Jason and Medea is told at length in Ovid, Met 7 and Appolonius Rhodius, Arg 3. Medea is Circeâ€™s neice.
yvory: This detail may come from Trissino, ILG 5.165, although the common source for both writers is likely to be the gate of false dreams in Virgil (Aen 6.693-96).
ywritt: drawn, incised
ywritt: Cf. viii.43.3, where the portrait of Gloriana is â€˜writtâ€™ on Guyonâ€™s shield.

44.5-6 Medeaâ€™s â€˜mighty charmesâ€™ are potions made up from magic herbs; â€˜her furious loving fittâ€™ is the overwhelming passion for Jason that compelled her to betray her father, King AeÃ«tes, by helping to ensure Jasonâ€™s â€˜conquest of the golden fleeceâ€™ in return for his promise of marriage. According to Conti, â€˜The ancients made up . . . the things that they said about Medea to encourage us to keep our feelings in check, and to try to live a decent life. Other writers thought that Medea was a criminal and an indecently passionate woman. For in fact she betrayed her parents, her kingdom, and her native land because she lusted after Jason and had an insane longing for himâ€™ (Myth 489).

44.7 Jason later set Medea aside to take a new bride, CreÃ¼sa. Conti, in the passage quoted above, continues: â€˜And she sought after this stranger, this treacherous impostor, this man who had a habit of forgetting what people had done for himâ€™ (Myth 489). The phrase â€˜falsed faythâ€™ may recall Chaucerâ€™s accusation against Jason in LGW: â€˜Ther other falsen one, thou falseste twoâ€™ (1377).

44.8-9 These lines jump back to the beginning of the story: Jason gathered the finest young warriors in Greece to sail in quest of the golden fleece. Aboard the â€˜venturousâ€™ ship Argo, they sailed across the Black Sea to the kingdom of Colchos, ruled by AeÃ«tes.

Ye might have seene: This is the first in a series of ekphrastic passages that will carry through Book III, all marked by references to trompe l'oeil verisimilitude. Spenser is consistently skeptical about the mimesis of appearances: the value of sensuous appeal in art is questioned in the proem to Book II and in the exchange between Guyon and Arthur over the image of Gloriana â€˜so goodly scordâ€™ on Guyonâ€™s shield (ix.2-3), and the same appeal to (and power to deceive) the senses is the stock in trade of the 1590 poemâ€™s major villains, Archimago, Duessa, Acrasia, and Busirane. Interestingly, Conti remarks that to some writers, â€˜Medea represented Art, the sister of Circe or Nature; for Art tries its best to imitate Nature, and the closer it gets, the better art it's supposed to beâ€™ (Myth 489). For Spenserâ€™s introduction of this motif as a keynote of Book II, see the notes to the proem, st. 4 and 5.
fry: foam

45.3-4 Here the force of mimetic illusion is seen as blurring the distinction between represented content (nature) and the medium of representation (art), a metamorphosis in which the medium and the thing represented seem to turn into each other. See Introduction, 00.
sprent: sprinkled
45.6 In the course of her â€˜furious loving fittâ€™ Medea dismembered her brother Apsyrtus, casting pieces of his body into the sea to slow the kingâ€™s pursuit when she fled with Jason.
vermell: vermillion
45.9 Still experiencing love as a â€˜furious . . . fittâ€™ when Jason abandoned her, Medea sent his new bride CreÃ¼sa a poisoned robe that burned her to death.

red: As writing, carving, and painting are all comprehended in the verb ywritt (44.4n), so reading, seeing, and interpreting are all compounded in the verb read (cf. the puns in the rhyming pair â€˜discoveredâ€™ and â€˜measuredâ€™, pr.2.4, 7).
46.2-3 Cf. the weakness of the fence enclosing the garden (st. 43).
looser: too loose
46.9 Cf. Idleness, who â€˜greatly shunned manly exerciseâ€™ (I.iv.20.2).

St. 47-48 Both the name Agdistes and most of the detail in these stanzas derive from Conti (Myth 243-245), but the â€˜celestiall powreâ€™ contrasted with the Genius of the Bower also has much in common with Contiâ€™s Mercury (361-71), who in turn is associated with the Palmer (see 41.3-8n). According to Conti, Mercury was in charge of re-embodying â€˜souls who had completed their stay in the Elysian fieldsâ€™ (368), and was identified with â€˜God's will . . . insofar as it brings things to life or sends them off to burial or the underworldâ€™, and â€˜with that divine power implanted by the gods in menâ€™s minds, the power that wonderfully puts all our human activities in perspective and keeps them from falling apart. And since the ancients thought that this power is the source of our dreams, they said that Mercury was in charge of dreamsâ€™ (371). Elsewhere Conti does use the phrase â€˜celestial powerâ€™ to describe Genius (901). He derives the name â€˜Geniusâ€™ from L gignendo, â€˜bringing forthâ€™ (244). (For a more extensive canvassing of sources for Genius in both his guises, see Var 2.375-76.)

47.8-9 Spenser is one of the earliest writers in English to use the word self as a substantive rather than a pronoun or adjective (see Am 45.3, â€˜in my selfe, my inward selfe I meaneâ€™). The description in these stanzas suggests links to L ingenium (lit. â€˜genius withinâ€™) and English inwit, but these (though often personified by medieval writers) are faculties rather than entities. Spenser follows Conti in treating the self as a spirit distinct from the person it supervises, and consequently stresses the paradoxical way in which the Genius-self is non-identical with the â€˜weâ€™ whose self it is, who can â€˜perceiveâ€™ its indwelling presence but cannot â€˜seeâ€™ it directly. Spenser differs from Conti in treating this spirit as a generic or collective presence, â€˜our Selfeâ€™, inhabiting the individual (â€˜him selfeâ€™).
porter: gatekeeper
devizd: appointed; perhaps also designed; feigned; conceived or imagined

porter: See Chaucer, CT Second Nun G 2-3, â€˜Ydelnesse..porter [v.r. poter] of the gate is of delicesâ€™. Porter comes from the n. port â€˜gatewayâ€™, but insofar as this Genius leads, or misleads, his title may also owe something to the verb meaning â€˜conveyâ€™.
devizd: Cf. i.31.8: â€˜That deare Crosse uppon your shield devizdâ€™.
for more formalitee: as an emblem of office
Mazer: a maple goblet

Mazer: Cf. SC Aug 26, â€˜A mazer ywrought of the Maple warreâ€™; also the goblets of Duessa (I.viii.14.1-5) and Acrasia (II.i.55). Circe enchanted her victims by offering them â€˜a potion in a golden cupâ€™ (Od 10.316). In a Christian context such cups of enchantment parody the Holy Grail and the wine of the Eucharist (a reference anchored here by â€˜sacrifideâ€™). Given Spenserâ€™s fondness for the pun in â€˜amazeâ€™, the sense of maze as â€˜bewilderâ€™ is probably also present.
sacrifide: consecrated

And broke his staffe: Already showing Guyonâ€™s responses verging on the excessive; see 57.3-6n. The Porterâ€™s staff with its powers of illusion is opposed to the Palmerâ€™s 'mighty staffe, that could all charmes defeatâ€™ (40.3).

charmed semblants sly: Cf. 48.6, â€˜guilefull semblants, which he makes us seeâ€™. â€˜Slyâ€™ (cunning) may describe either the semblants or the act of conjuring themâ€”or both. The Bowerâ€™s Genius personifies an aesthetic technique that uses suggestion to elicit erotic fantasiesâ€”a technique that is on offer in the present canto as early as its first stanza and recurs frequently in the descriptions of the Bower. See 45.3-4n on the temptation presented by the ornamentation on the ivory gate.

St. 50 The syntax implies a deferred main clause that never in fact arrives: the travelers behold a plain whose ground, mantled and beautified . . . . The suspension of sense amid sprawling ornamentation anticipates the fate of Verdant with his â€˜ydle instrumentsâ€™ (80.1).

her mother Art: By introducing Art as the mother of Flora, Spenser inverts the aesthetic theory Polixenes will later espouse in The Winterâ€™s Tale (4.4.88-97): in the Bower of Bliss, Nature is created by Art. (The flowers may be artificially created by the kind of cross-breeding Polixenes defends; they may also be flowers of rhetoric.) Nature is also denigrated by Art, the comically officious mother of the bride who insists on â€˜too lavishlyâ€™ adorning her not-pretty-enough daughter. For Nature as artist-manque, see 23.2-5.

50.8-9 The concluding shift from past tense (â€˜Did decke herâ€™) to present (â€˜forth . . . she comesâ€™) reinforces the loss of orientation in the face of spectacle that is implicit in the failure of syntactic closure. The travelers are rendered passive (â€˜they beholdâ€™) by a display of excess that takes over both energy and initiative as it comes forward to greet them.

Joviall: â€˜Under the influence of, or having the qualities imparted by, the planet Jupiter, which as a natal planet was regarded as the source of joy and happinessâ€™ (OED). Ironic in the present context insofar as Joveâ€™s usurpation ended the golden age of Saturnâ€™s reign and thereby initiated seasonal change (Ovid, Met 1.113-18).
lovely: lovingly

51.5-9 See Chaucer, PF 204-6: â€˜Thâ€™air of that place so attempre was / That nevere was ther grevaunce of hot ne cold; / There wex ek every holsom spice and grasâ€™ (also Tasso, GL 15.53-54, and Homer, Od 4.567-69, 6.43-45). The language of these lines (â€˜intemperate . . . moderate . . . attempredâ€™) suggests that the Bower presents Guyon with a simulacrum of the virtue he espouses.

51.8-9 Given the tendency of the diction throughout the stanza to half-animate and half-personify the locus amoenus, the secondary senses of â€˜disposdâ€™ as â€˜put into a favorable moodâ€™ and â€˜spiritâ€™ as â€˜disposition, or temper existing in, pervading, or animating, a person or set of personsâ€™ (OED) are also in play.
disposd: arranged
disposd: Cf. â€˜Words well dispostâ€™ (viii.26.7).
spirit: breath

St. 52 The set of competing loci amoeni listed in this stanza are all (except Parnassus) contaminated by associations of lust and violence. The allusions to these places are likewise shot through with misdirection, as if imitating the Bowerâ€™s technique of seduction-by-distraction.

52.1-3 Rhodope, â€˜the pleasaunt hillâ€™ where Orpheus sang (Met 10.86-105), is also the place where he was later dismembered (11.39-43); Ovid twice calls Orpheus Rhodopeius (â€˜Rhodopeanâ€™, 10.11-12, 50). Spenserâ€™s version of the background story about the nymph may derive from the treatise Libellus de Fluviis, once attributed to Plutarch, which reports that she bore a â€˜gyaunt babeâ€™ fathered by Neptune and then arrogated to herself the name â€˜Junoâ€™, commanding the gods to worship her. She was punished by being turned into the mountain.

Thessalian: Tempe is the valley where Apollo pursued Daphne, whose transformation into the laurel is the prototypical metamorphosis in Ovid (Met 1.452-567). Spenser compresses the narrative, in which it was technically Cupid who gored Apolloâ€™s heart with love: he shot Apollo with a golden-tipped dart to kindle love, Daphne with a lead-tipped dart to inspire flight.
Mount Ida, near Troyâ€”where Venus and Anchises conceived Aeneasâ€”was also the setting for the infamous judgment of Paris, which gave rise to the Trojan War (see vii.55 and notes).
repayre: retire
Eden selfe: See Gen 2:8, â€˜And the Lord God planted a garden Eastwarde in Edenâ€™, and the Geneva gloss: â€˜a place . . . moste pleasant and abundant in all thingsâ€™.
53.4 See Prov 4:25, â€˜Let thine eyes beholde the right, and let thine eyeliddes direct thy way before theeâ€™.

53.6-9 The vegetation growing up around this â€˜gate, / No gateâ€™ seems to have its arms at once wide open (â€˜did broad dilateâ€™) and closing in all around (â€˜claspingâ€™). Cf. the ambiguities in Spenserâ€™s description of the first gate (st. 43). The alliteration in the final line very nearly turns the branchesâ€™ â€˜wanton wreathingsâ€™ into wanton writhings (an example of the aesthetic technique mentioned in 49.9n).

St. 54 See 51.8-9n on the tendency to half-personify the landscape, which at times intensifies to more than half. At such moments the resulting vegetable fantasia starts to resemble an anamorphic orgy. Cain (1978: 92-93) notes echoes in this and the following stanza of New World reports describing the mines of Peru and the gardens of the Incas. The same lines also contain echoes of the Garden of Proserpina in canto vii.

Hyacine: Hyacine in 1590 gets corrected to Hyacint, perhaps not by the author. The hyacinth is â€˜deepe empurpledâ€™ because it springs from the blood of Apolloâ€™s beloved companion, whose name it bears. See Ovid: ecce cruor, qui fusus homo signaverat herbas, / desinit esse cruor, Tyrioque nitentior ostro / flos oritur formamque capit, quam lilia, si non / purpureus color his, argenteus esset in illis (â€˜behold, the blood, which had poured out on the ground and stained the grass, ceased to be blood, and in its place there sprang a flower brighter than Tyrian dye. It took the form of the lily, save that the one was of purple hue, while the other was silvery whiteâ€™; Met 10.210-13).
54.7-9 The progression from purple through red to green shows the fruit un-ripening as if in coy retreat from the solicitation described at mid-stanza.
Rubine: ruby
Emeraudes: emeralds
55.1 Cf. the apples of the Hesperides in Proserpineâ€™s Garden (vii.54-55).

55.3-4 As the fruit goes from being metaphorically to literally artificial, the figurative suggestion of a coy retreat from the hands and eyes of â€˜covetous guestâ€™ also becomes explicit. The subtextual allusion would seem to be to Midas and Tantalus (see vii.58-60 and 59.5-9n, and the provocations implied in the description of the Bowerâ€™s outer gate, st. 43 and notes).
rich load: Grapes made of gold would indeed be much heavier than edible grapes.
Cf. the â€˜looser garmentâ€™ of Genius (46.7-9).
Cup of gold: Cf. the â€˜mighty Mazer bowle of wineâ€™ set beside Genius (49.3).
sappy: succulent

56.3-6 The delicacy with which this â€˜comely dameâ€™ bursts the grapes in her â€˜fine fingersâ€™ creates a remarkably juicy imageâ€”one that will be remembered by Milton when Eve crushes fruit to prepare refreshments for the angel Raphael in Eden (PL 5.344-47), and by Keats in â€˜Ode on Melancholyâ€™: â€˜him whose strenuous tongue / Can burst Joyâ€™s grape against his palate fineâ€™ (27-28). The line-break, â€˜with fulnesse sweld, / Into her cupâ€™, admits of a momentary impression (or â€˜guilefull semblantâ€™, 49.9n) that the juice swells into the cup without assistance.
scruzd: squeezed
daintie: nice, delicate, but also delightful, as at 58.1
breach: â€˜the action of breakingâ€™ (OED)

breach: Perhaps also the delicate parting of the fingers, which prevents any â€˜fowle empeachâ€™ (hindrance) of the â€˜sappy liquorâ€™ on its way into her cup. The slight hindrance offered by the enjambment of lines 4-5 (itself a â€˜daintie breachâ€™) is sufficient to evoke another false semblant or two (49.9n) from the associations clustering around the phrase â€˜daintie breachâ€™; cf. â€˜Their dainty partesâ€™, 63.9).
without foul empeach: without making a mess

empeach: There is also a pun on â€˜peachâ€™. Gerard (1597) describes the red peach as â€˜very like to wine in taste, and therefore marvellous pleasantâ€™ (1448). His description of the white peach is suggestive enough to gloss the florid polymorphous sexuality of the fruit in Spenserâ€™s Bower: â€˜The fruit or Peaches be round, and have as it were a chinke or cleft on the one side; they are covered with a soft and thin downe or hairie cotton, being white without, and of a pleasant taste; in the middle whereof is a rough or rugged stone, wherein is contained a kernell like unto the Almond; the meate about the stone is of a white colourâ€™.
guise: custom

57.3-6 Cf. 49.7-9; this time, Guyon doesnâ€™t just overturn the cup â€˜disdainfullyâ€™, he shatters it â€˜violentlyâ€™. The joke in â€˜Excesse exceedingly was wrothâ€™ may implicate the knight insofar as his response to Excesse is excessive. Cf. Milton, Comus 651-52 and the interlinear scene direction following 813, where the brothers cast down the sorcererâ€™s cup and shatter it.

Excesse: Her name and office as sommelier recall Eph 5:18: â€˜be not drunke with wine, wherein is excesseâ€™. At Matt 23:25, Jesus denounces the scribes and pharisees as hypocrites, â€˜for ye make cleane the utter side of the cup, and of the platter: but within thei are ful of briberie and excesseâ€™. The Geneva glosses â€˜excesseâ€™ (which translates the Gk Î±ÎºÏÎ±ÏƒÎ¹Î± akrasia) as â€˜intemperancieâ€™.
57.8-9 Since the porch of Excess is not really a gate but only like one (53.6-7), it remains unclear whether she suffers Guyon and the Palmer to â€˜passeâ€™ by or through (see arg.1-2n).
daintie: Cf. 56.4.
58.2 The characteristic action of the Bower.
sober: solemn, serious; also, because he has just refused the wine in st. 57, not drunk

58.2-4 We are told at 53.2-3 that Guyon â€˜suffred no delight / To sincke into his senceâ€™, but here again the syntax fosters a â€˜guilefull semblantâ€™ (49.9n) in which all pleasures seem to abound plenteously in the knightâ€™s sober eye, where they enjoy a happiness unmarred by jealousy or rivalry. The awkward implication would be that Guyon, in reasserting the sobriety of his eye and repudiating the pleasures that have abounded there, is enacting envy of â€˜others happinesseâ€™.

painted: In literary usage, commonly used to mean â€˜brightly coloured or variegated, as if paintedâ€™ (OED), but the artificiality of the Bower leaves open the possibility that they are literally colored with paint. See also 50.6n for the possibility that the flowers, like the â€˜streakâ€™d gillyvorsâ€™ disdained by Perdita (â€˜no more than were I paintedâ€™) in The Winters Tale (4.4.82, 101), are artificial in that they are hybrids.

58.7-9 Translating Tasso, GL 16.9.7-8: e quel che â€™l bello e â€™l caro accresce a lâ€™opre, / lâ€™arte, che tutto fa, nulla si scopre. Ironically, the art that â€˜appeared in no placeâ€™ concludes a list of all the features that the â€˜Paradise . . . doth offer to his sober eyeâ€™. The motif of offering modulates into that of display alternating with concealment: see st. 54-55, 63-66 and notes.
christall: streams
aggrace: grace; add grace to

St. 59 Cf. Ovid, simulaverat artem ingenio natura suo (â€˜Nature by her own cunning had imitated artâ€™; Met 3.158-9). Spenserâ€™s stanza is based on Tasso, GL 16.10. Spenserâ€™s stanza dilates the first half of Tassoâ€™s, amplifying both the resentment of the competitors and the paradox whereby their conflict inadvertently yields harmonyâ€”a parody of the classical commonplace of concordia discors, or harmony in discord. On the paragone of Art and Nature, see Hagstrum (1958: 81-88), SpE s.v. â€˜nature and artâ€™, and 50.6n, above. Fairfax, translating Tasso in 1600, shows the influence of Spenserâ€™s stanza.
wantonnesse: affectation, naughtiness, playfulness, or extravagance
ensude: followed; imitated the example of
repine: complain
in fine: in conclusion

St. 60-68 Based on Tasso, GL 15.58-66. The substitution of a fountain for the pool in which Tassoâ€™s damsels bathe may reflect Acrasiaâ€™s â€˜fountain of concupiscenceâ€™ in Trissino, (ILG 5.520-00; see Var 2.444). Tassoâ€™s maidens swim and display themselves but do not â€˜wrestle wantonlyâ€™ (63.8)â€”an elaboration so tempting that it resurfaces in Fairfaxâ€™s translation of the passage from Tasso. On the verbal differences between Spenser and Tasso, see Pollock (1980).

fountaine: Recalling the fountain at I.vii.2.8-7, also associated with lust. Contrast the antithetical well at II.ii.3-10, so â€˜chaste and pureâ€™ that it won't wash the blood off Ruddymaneâ€™s hands, and the sister-bride in the Song of Solomon, described as â€˜a spring shut up, and a fountaine sealed upâ€™ (4: 12).

overwrought: Not recorded in OED. Presumably, as Hamilton suggests, â€˜wrought all overâ€™, with the added suggestion that the ornamentation is overdone. There is also the suggestion that the implicitly phallic fountain mirrors the language of the passage, so insistently â€˜overwroughtâ€™ with the â€˜curious ymagereeâ€™ of those guilefull semblants the Bowerâ€™s Genius makes us see (49.9n). Insofar as these semblants are latent and fleeting fantasies thrown off by the diction, imagery, syntax, sounds, and rhythms of the verse, they also remain only half-seen. (See 58.7-9n on the motif of display yielding to concealment.)
wanton toyes: amorous dallying; playful caresses
embay: bathe, soak

60.9 The phrase â€˜liquid joyesâ€™ melts the pleasures depicted on the fountain into the waters coursing through its channels. In simultaneously desubstantializing the water (â€˜liquidâ€™ becomes an adjective) and half-substantializing the joys, the phrasing here may offer a gloss on the â€˜sappy liquorâ€™ of 56.3 (cf. I.vii.7.2, II.v.28.5). The liquidity of these joys is further insinuated by the rare substitution of a comma for the expected full stop at the end of the stanza.

St. 61 Cf. st. 59, v.29, and notes. With its trompe lâ€™oeil imitation of nature, metallic ivy with anthropomorphically lascivious arms, and faux crystal teardrops, this tableau brings together several of the principal motifs in the canto, including the half-animation of the landscape, the paragone of art and nature, and the evocation of sexual fantasies.
Low: Implies a homophonic deictic â€˜Loâ€™.
fearefully: Becomes â€˜tenderlyâ€™ in 1596 and 1609.

for wantones: A recurrent term in the description of the Bower, its senses fluctuate among lasciviousness, naughtiness, affectation, luxury, insolence, extravagance, recklessness, and caprice, none of which seems an obvious motive for tearsâ€”but see Acrasiaâ€™s faux pity and moist eyes at 73.9 and 78.3-9. The water droplets on the ivy at once simulate post-coital triste and insinuate the motives of a predatory mock pietÃ¡.
three cubits: ancient unit of measurement based on the length of the forearm, variable but typically 18-22 inches
three cubits: Three of these make neither a great â€˜depthâ€™ nor a great â€˜hightâ€™.

62.6-9 Parodic echoes of Rev 4: 6 (the â€˜sea of glasse like unto cristalâ€™ with Godâ€™s throne in the midst) and 21:11 (the New Jerusalem â€˜shiningâ€¦like untoâ€¦a Jasper stone cleare as cristalâ€™).

sayle: In architecture, â€˜to project from a surfaceâ€™ (OED). The upright fountain with its â€˜Infinit streamesâ€™ and â€˜ample laverâ€™ combines a number of opposites: the motions of welling and falling, depth and height, motion and stasisâ€”this last an ironic anticipation of the moment when the voyager Guyon will â€˜slacke his paceâ€™ in response to the temptations in the fountain (68.4; see 14.2, 17.2, where the motif of slowing forward progress with delay prepares for Guyonâ€™s slacking of his pace).
margent: edge (margin)

Laurell trees: See 52.4-5n. Daphne, fleeing Apollo, was transformed into the laurel, â€˜meed of mightie Conquerours / and Poets sageâ€™ (I.i.9.1-2). These laurels seem to remember their origin in Ovid, insofar as they continue to â€˜defend / The sunny beamesâ€™, but their â€˜shadyâ€™ defense has been co-opted by the Bowerâ€™s strategic deployment of reluctance as provocation (see st. 43 and notes).

63.6-9 The spectacle in which the maidens â€˜seemed to contendâ€™ simulates in a playful vein the paragone of Art and Nature, â€˜striving each thâ€™other to undermineâ€™ (see st. 59 and notes). C. S. Lewis notoriously (and dismissively) referred to the damsels as â€˜Cissie and Flossieâ€™ (1936: 331), but as aquatic wrestlers they might answer to â€˜Guyonâ€™, from the Edenic river Gihon (Hebrew GiÄ§Ã´n, interpreted as â€˜Bursting Forth, Gushingâ€™), and gyon, glossed as â€˜wrestlerâ€™ in The Golden Legend (see SpE s.v. â€˜Guyonâ€™, Fowler 1960, and Snyder 1961). Their spectacle thus combines exhibitionism and homoeroticism with narcissism (Guyon is beholding a displaced image of his own desire), and in this respect it resembles the song of the Sirens, who according to Conti adapt their song to reflect the desires of the listener (see 32.2n). Cf. the hermitâ€™s description in Tasso of Armida bending over Rinaldo sÃ¬ che par Narciso al fonte (â€˜so that she resembles Narcissus at the springâ€™; GL 14.66.8). Much as the Bower itself parodies temperance (51.5-9n), the wrestling damsels parody Guyonâ€™s binding of Furor (iv.6-15), Arthurâ€™s defeat of Maleger (xi.41-46), and with these, the theological topoi on which they are based: that of wrestling against â€˜spiritual wickednessesâ€™ (Eph 6:12) and of Christ as â€˜an holy wrastelerâ€™ (Caxtonâ€™s phrase, fol.clviv).
ne carâ€™d to hyde: On the motif of alternating concealment and display in this and the following stanzas, see 58.7-9n.

Their dainty partes: See 14.8, 15.3n and 56.4n. These maidens exposing their dainties are contrasted specifically to the pair Arthur and Guyon court in the parlor of Almaâ€™s castle (their antithesis is Shamefastnesse, representing Guyonâ€™s desire for modesty), and more generally to the allegory of the temperate body, which modestly â€˜avoidsâ€™ the genitals in favor of the parlor-heart (see ix.32-44 and notes).
plong: plunge
as over maystered by might: Cf. Guyon â€˜maystering his mightâ€™ (53.5), and the interplay of provocation with defense at the Bowerâ€™s outer gate, st. 43 and notes.
unhele: uncover
amarous: amorous
amarous: The spelling might also suggest L amarus bitter (cf. Virgil, amores . . . amaros, â€˜the bitters of loveâ€™; Ecl 3.109-110).
that faire Starre: Venus, the morning star
His: On â€˜hisâ€™ as neuter pronoun, see ix.1.8n.
the Cyprian goddesse: Venus.

the Cyprian goddesse: Conti relates, â€˜Right after she was born, they say that Venus emerged from the sea and used both her hands to wring the sea water from her hair and faceâ€™ (Myth 315). He goes on to quote Antipater of Sidonia on the beauty of Apellesâ€™s portrait of Venus â€˜rising from the seaâ€™.

Oceanâ€™s . . . froth: The froth is â€˜fruitfullâ€™ because it derives from â€˜the genitals of Heaven, which Saturn cut off and threw into the sea. [Venus] . . . was conceived from the foam that crests the water, a foam that was created when Saturn hurled the genitals into the seaâ€™ (Conti, Myth 314).
Whom such when Guyon saw: I.e., the simile comparing these damsels to the birth of Venus expresses Guyonâ€™s perception: the birth is occurring in the beholderâ€™s eye.
65.9 Cf. â€˜her guilefull bayt / She will embosome deeper in your mindâ€™, 29.2-3 and 29.3 note; also 58.2-4 and note.
guise: appearance
guise: Given their own nudity, OED sense 4, â€˜condition with regard to dressâ€™, has some relevance.
66.3-67.9 On the motif of alternating concealment with display see 58.7-9, 60.6, 63.8, and notes.
avise: look at
bewrayd: revealed (often with the sense of divulging a secret)
St. 67 Translating Tasso, GL 15.61.
lockes: tresses
lockes: With the addition of â€˜lookers theftâ€™ (not present in Tassoâ€™s Italian) punning on locks that take keys.

68.1-3 See ix.41-44 on the blushing of Shamefastness. The interplay here of blushing and laughing (associated with PhÃ¦dria at vi.3.3-9, 6.7, 7.6-7, and xii.15.4) parallels the alternation of concealing with displaying. Both in turn align with the forward/froward pair introduced in the first episode of Book II (see i.34.7-9, i.37.1, and notes). Tassoâ€™s damsel likewise exhibits both pleasure and shame: a lor si volse lieta e vergognosa (â€˜from them she turns away pleased and ashamedâ€™; GL 15.61.9), but does not laugh.
corage cold could reare: could arouse (literally, erect) unaroused sexual appetite
corage cold could reare: Guyonâ€™s â€˜paceâ€™ may slacken, but his libido is as taut as a piano-wire.

69.3-4 Undistracted forward progress has been a keynote of Guyonâ€™s journey in canto xii, but travel in the landscape of Faeryland is rarely linear: having entered the Bower of Bliss twice already (st. 50 and 57-58), the knight and his Palmer only now â€˜come nighâ€™. The repetition of â€˜Nowâ€™ emphasizes that they are verging upon â€˜point of that same perilous sted, / Where Pleasure dwelles in sensuall delightsâ€™ (1.7-8).
Acrasia: For the derivation of the name, see II.i.51.2-4, xii.57.6, and notes.
all our drift despise: disregard or disdain our entire scheme
attonce: at once
read: guess, conjecture

note.p: 70.9 The Bowerâ€™s all-inclusive harmony combines vocal and instrumental music with sounds of apparently natural origin; see st. 59n on the paragone of Art and Nature, here seemingly reconciled. Appearances may be deceptive, however: in the episode from Tasso that Spenser is tracking closely in these stanzas, we are told that Lâ€™auro, no châ€™altro, Ã¨ de la maga efetto (â€˜the breeze itself, not to speak of the rest, is made by the sorceressâ€™; GL 16.10.5); see below, 72.1-2: 'There, whence that Musick seemed heard to bee, / Was the faire Witch herselfeâ€™. The stanza in Tasso that stands behind Spenserâ€™s 70.8-71 is 16.12, but in Tasso there are no voices and instruments.

Spenser seems to combine Tassoâ€™s stanza with two later descriptions of the enchanted forest that do mix human and natural music (18.18, 24). Those illusions are explicitly demonic, however, whereas the windâ€™s harmonizing in this stanza is ambiguous (caso od arte, â€˜chance or artâ€™). Tassoâ€™s a prova (â€˜in contestâ€™) does imply competition, but his birds are competing with each other, not with Art. Contrast vi.24-25, where PhÃ¦dria joins in the song of the birds, but â€˜would oftentimes . . . strive to passe . . . Their native musicke by her skillful artâ€™ (25.2-4). The presence of art in the harmonics described by Tasso at 16.12 is not explicit, but is implied in the formal patterning of the interchange of birds and breezes.

div.note: St. 71 The elaborate patterning of this stanza, inspired by the interchange of birds and wind in Tasso, is clearly meant to imitate the music it describes, as Hughes (1750) observes: â€˜an Imitation of Tasso, but with finer Turns of the Verse: which are so artificial, that he seems to make the Musick he describesâ€™ (Var 2.385-6). John Hollander, in SpE s.v. â€˜musicâ€™, observes that â€˜Stanza 71 represents this blended music with remarkable skill, punning on base and meet, troping the interlocking of rhyme and the intertwining of syntax as the relations of vocal and instrumental polyphony in the Elizabethan â€œbrokenâ€ (mixed) consortâ€™ (483).
shrouded: took shelter
shrouded: The additional sense of putting a winding-sheet on a corpse for burial does add an ominous note; cf. I.i.8.2-3.
attempred: Cf. â€˜disposdâ€™ (51.8 and note).
Angelicall . . . divine: See the â€˜heavenly noise / Heard sownd through all the Pallaceâ€™ when Una and Redcrosse celebrate their betrothal (I.xii.39.1-2).
a new Lover: glancing implicitly at his predecessor, Mortdant (i.51-55).

St. 73 The description in this stanza derives from Lucretius by way of Tasso. Its Lucretian origins connect the stanza with the love of Mars and Venus invoked repeatedly in Spenser (see I.pr.3.7-9 and note). Lucretius begins De Rerum with an invocation to Venus that includes a prayer for peace, which she can grant because Mars succumbs to her charms (1.33-40). Tasso echoes the Lucretian invocation in his description of Rinaldo alseep in Armidaâ€™s lap (GL 16.18.7-19). In translating Tasso with the phrase â€˜her soft breastâ€™, Fairfax will chasten the Latin gremium and Italian gremio, which can mean either lap or breast, whereas Spenser (at 76.9) will prefer the more sexually suggestive â€˜lapâ€™.

73.3-4 In Lucretius, Mars feeds his eyes on Venus. Tasso gives the metaphor a paradoxical turn as Rinaldo consumes himself while feeding his gaze on Armida. Fairfax slightly softens this paradox. Spenser by contrast sharpens the paradox while shifting it from Verdant to Acrasia â€˜seeking medicine, whence she was stongâ€™. At the same time, Spenser detaches the paradox from the trope of feeding, which he also shifts to Acrasia, giving it a decidedly predatory rather than self-destructive turn: Latin pascit and Italian pascendo give way to the animalistic and more violent depasturing, which means not just feeding on but utterly consuming. At this point the reversal (and transvaluation) of Lucretius is complete, having proceeded by way of an intertextual troping that enacts the figure of hypallage or exchange, nicknamed by Puttenham â€˜the Changelingâ€™ (see 45.3-4 and note).

73.6-7 Upton proposed that the â€˜lipsâ€™ and â€˜eyesâ€™ in these lines were transposed in printing, and that the correct reading would have Acrasia sucking the knightâ€™s soul out through his parted lips (Var 2. 387-88). Alternatively, the transposition of lips and eyes may simply extend the work of hypallage described in the preceding note. Lucretius describes Marsâ€™s breath hanging upon Venusâ€™s lips, an image that almost suspends the act of respiration in the luxuriance of the kiss. Tasso imagines Rinaldo sighing, with the transfer of his soul into Armida represented as a simile or impression. Spenser literalizes the transmigration of the warriorâ€™s soul while transferring the action to Acrasia: not his sighing but her sucking carries his soul into her.

73.9 This line completes the stanzaâ€™s remarkable fantasy of erotic hypallage: Rinaldoâ€™s sigh now reappears as Acrasiaâ€™s, and the as if of similitude travels with it, reappearing not as the impression that the knightâ€™s soul leaves him, but as the mocking suggestion that Acrasia pities him: poor baby! This sexualized mock pietÃ¡, like other details in the passage, parodies Venusâ€™s relation to Adonis in Malecastaâ€™s tapestry (III.i.36-38) and to â€˜her deare brood, her deare delightâ€™ (III.vi.40.4) in the Garden of Adonis episode.

St. 74-75 This carpe diem lay, a counterpart to Phaedriaâ€™s siren song at vi.15-17, is based on Tasso, GL 16.14-15. Tassoâ€™s singer is a male parrot. Fairfax changes the birdâ€™s sex; he also chastens the flowerâ€™s nudo . . . sen (â€˜naked breastâ€™) to the less vivid â€˜beautiesâ€™. Spenser leaves the singer unspecified, but captures the sense of sen with â€˜bared bosomeâ€™. His translation is so close, and so inspired, that it must have set a daunting precedent for Fairfax (see the exchange on this subject between Hazlitt and Lamb, Var 2.289). Spenserâ€™s striking innovation is the closing phrase â€˜equall crimeâ€™, which makes the pleasure more salacious than in Tasso, since the consciousness of sinning seems to constitute a distinct pleasure in its own right (cf. â€˜pleasant sinâ€™, 77.2.)
74.1 Cf. vi.14.9, â€˜The whils with a love lay she thus him sweetly charmdâ€™.
74.4-8 On the motif of alternating concealment with display see 58.7-9n. In mingling the motives of bashfulness and exhibitionism, the rose behaves like the damsels bathing in the fountain at st. 66.

75.5 Three successive y-a combinations in this line mark syllabic elisions (man-ya Lad-yand man-ya). In this way the line gathers extra syllables â€˜whilest yet is timeâ€™ even as it also inserts a comma to preserve the impossible caesura following Ladyâ€™. The caesura tries to hold the Ladies and their Paramours apart as the elision runs them promiscuously together.
deflowre: Another distinctive touch, not found in Tasso. The implication is that since time will eventually pluck the virginity of â€˜mortall lifeâ€™, we might as well get there first.

76.7 As the forward march of knight and palmer turns stealthy, the syntax of the line calls awkward attention to the â€˜covertâ€™-ness of their approach by foisting onto them the agency of the verb â€˜displayâ€™, which properly belongs to Acrasia. Unlike the maidens in the fountain (66.1), she does not see Guyon seeing her, but the description in the following stanza makes it clear that she actively solicits the viewing eye.

76.9 Cf. st. 73n. Tasso writes nel grembo molle / le posa il capo (â€˜in her soft lap / he rests his headâ€™); Spenser transfers the softness (across the line-break, as it were) from the lap to the action of arranging the head.

St. 77 The â€˜vele of silke and silver thinâ€™ worn by Spenserâ€™s Acrasia comes not from Tasso but from the description of Venus in Chaucer, PF 265-73. Spenserâ€™s description of the Bower more than once echoes Chaucerâ€™s description of the garden outside the Temple of Venus (see 51.5-9 and note). Chaucerâ€™s lines on Venus derive in turn from Boccaccio, Tes 7.65. On Spenserâ€™s use of both passages, see Anderson (2008: 137-39), who notes the resurfacing of Boccaccioâ€™s sottil in Spenserâ€™s subtle web. See Ariostoâ€™s description of the gown in which Alcina greets Ruggiero, also described as suttile (OF 7.28.4-8).
As faint through: Hints at the posed quality of the tableau.
dight to: prepared for
pleasant sin: Cf. â€˜equall crimeâ€™ (75.9).

77.7 Arachne was also present in Mammonâ€™s cave (vii.28.7-9). The spider was associated with the sense of touch (cf. Harvey, Speculum Tuscanismi, in Familiar Letters, and xi.13.3), but Acrasiaâ€™s veil seems woven to entangle the gaze.
77.8-9 Gossamer, woven by the balloon-spider, though Spenser seems to think it is made of sun-dried dew.
bare to ready spoyle: See st. 43 and notes. The Bowerâ€™s structures and its anamorphic vegetation (insofar as these may be distinguished) consistently mimic the motives and postures of Acrasia.
nâ€™ote: â€˜ne moteâ€™, i.e. could not
languor: weariness, resulting from sexual exertions
languor: Spenserâ€™s syntax associates the drops of perspiration rather with the lassitude that accompanies them than with the â€˜sweet toyleâ€™ which produces both.
Few drops: â€˜distildâ€™ and compared to â€˜Nectarâ€™, Acrasiaâ€™s drops of perspiration recall the â€˜sappy liquorâ€™ that Excesse â€˜scruzdâ€™ into her golden cup at 56.1-6.

78.6-9 Although Acrasiaâ€™s eyes moisten â€˜their fierie beamesâ€™, they do not quench the flames those beams kindle when they pierce the hearts of observers; rather they seem to intensify the brightness of those beames. This description catches up and summarizes a motif introduced in Guyonâ€™s opening encounter with Duessa, formulated again in the brothers Pyrochles and Cymochles, and repeated with variations throughout Book 2: fire and water seem to be opposites, but the irascible and concupiscent passions associated with them are mutually reinforcing (see i.34.7-9n).
deface: literally undo, unmake

deface: The emphasis in the following lines on the knightâ€™s â€˜sweet regardâ€™ and â€˜well-proportiond faceâ€™ as a visual map of the good qualities and budding prospects going to ruin in Acrasiaâ€™s embrace suggests a pun on de-face: the knightâ€™s identity is being obliterated.
hong upon a tree: Like trophies taken in battle. Cf. I.v.5.7-9, V.v.21.7. In SC Dec 141, Colin Clout hangs up his shepherdâ€™s pipe on a tree because he has failed in love.

moniments: L monumentum (from monere, to remind) refers not only to statues and tombs, but also to written records and works of literature; their erasure here contrasts with Arthurâ€™s discovery of Briton moniments in the chamber of Eumnestes (ix.59.5-6).
raâ€™st: razed, scraped out;
raâ€™st: Echoing deface: the coat of arms has been eradicated from knightâ€™s escutcheon as his face and his memory of himself fade away.
spend: expend
spend: For the punning reference to orgasm, see 42.8 and note.
blend: blind; obscure; mingle or combine (i.e., with Acrasia)
blend: Cf. iv.7.7, iv.26.3, vii.1.4, and notes.

a subtile net: The counterpart to Acrasiaâ€™s veil (see st. 77 and notes), the Palmerâ€™s net derives from the snare â€˜fine as spiderâ€™s websâ€™ (Î·Ï…Ï„á¾½ Î±ÏÎ±Ï‡Î½Î¹Î± Î»ÎµÏ€Ï„Î±, Ä“utâ€™ arachnia lepta) that Hephaestus uses to catch Aphrodite and Ares in the act of adultery (Homer, Od 8.280; cf. Ovid, Met 4.171-89). It thus catches up both the reference to Arachne (77.7) and that to Venus disarming Mars (st. 73). The adjective suggests both the thinness of the material and the skill with which it is woven.
formally: â€˜according to the principles of art or scienceâ€™ (OED)
fowler shame: Punning on the meaning of fowler as a hunter who uses nets to catch wild birds.
opprest: subdued
distraine: tear apart
Verdant: â€˜green with vegetationâ€™
Verdant: See 73.4 and 79.8-9 for implication that Verdant is Acrasiaâ€™s pasturage. His name contrasts him to Mortdant (i.49.9), whom he has just avoided becoming.

St. 83 Guyonâ€™s destruction of the Bower echoes Josiahâ€™s destruction of the images, places, and implements of idolatrous worship (along with the â€˜houses of the sodomitesâ€™) surrounding Jerusalem, described at 2 Kings 23:4-16. See also Isa 13.9: â€˜Beholde, the day of the Lord cometh, cruell, with wrath and fierce angre to lay the land waste: and he shal destroy the sinners out of itâ€™. Spenser here departs significantly from Tasso, where Armida herself summons infernal powers to destroy her garden and palace (GL 16.68-69).
the tempest of his wrathfulnesse: The echo of tempest in temperance may suggest the irony of Guyonâ€™s intemperate wrath.

deface . . . race: This rhyming pair connects Guyonâ€™s destruction of the Bower to the erasure of Verdantâ€™s knightly demeanor and coat of arms at 79.4 and 80.4. If, as Aquinas argues, â€˜all irascible passions arise out of concupiscible passionsâ€™ (Summa I, qu. 81, art. 2, ad. 1; cf. i.34.7-9n), then Guyonâ€™s rampage may be an alternative response to the sexual arousal brought about by the scenes he has witnessedâ€”a means of refusing to â€˜spendâ€™ in the way Verdant has done (80.8). This would properly oppose his counter-orgasmic destruction of the Bower to its creation, encoded in the phrase â€˜poured forth with plentifull dispenceâ€™ at 42.8 and would complete the physical allegory of male arousal begun in st. 1 (see st.1n and 1.7-8n). It would also link his destruction of the Bower to his aborted attack on the Redcrosse knight in canto i.
Cabinets: bowers or summer-houses
race: As Verdantâ€™s shield was â€˜fowly raâ€™stâ€™ at 80.4.

sorrowfull and sad: As there is no mention of shame, it remains unclear whether Verdant or Acrasia regret Guyonâ€™s behavior or their own. This ambiguity will surface at 86.4-5, when some of the men restored to human form exhibit â€˜inward shameâ€™ while others exhibit â€˜wrath, to see their captive Dameâ€™.
84.4-5 Described in st. 39-40.
84.9 Not the only time a character in the poem requests a gloss: see I.iii.32.8, where Archimago inquires of Una (no doubt with some nervousness) â€˜what the Lyon mentâ€™.

St. 85-87 Acrasiaâ€™s prototype in turning men to beasts is Homerâ€™s Circe (Od 10), but as Hamilton 2001 notes, it is Conti and not Homer who suggests that the menâ€™s animal shapes reflect the passions that dominate their minds (Myth 476). In Homer, Circeâ€™s victims retain human intelligence, transformed in body only. Whitney (1586), following Conti, reports that Circeâ€™s menagerie prefer to retain their animal forms: â€˜when they might have had their former shape againe, / They did refuse, and rather wishâ€™d, still brutishe to remaineâ€™ (82). In Spenser, the â€˜sad end . . . of life intemperateâ€™ (85.6) is evidently reversible, but both this end and its reversal seem provisional; Spenser neither follows Homer nor hews to the Conti-Whitney revision, but splits the difference between them.
85.3 Continuing the implication that Acrasia devours the humanity of her lovers (see 82.8n).

Grylle: From Gk Î³ÏÏ…Î»Î»Î¿Ï‚ gryllos hog. Derived from Plutarchâ€™s satiric dialogue â€˜Beasts Are Rationalâ€™ (MoraliaI 986B), in which one of Ulyssesâ€™ companions named Gryllus declines to reclaim his human form, arguing that beasts are in fact more temperate than men. For the subsequent history of Plutarchâ€™s Gryllus in texts by Gelli, Machiavelli, and Petrus Costalius, see SpE s.v. â€˜Grillâ€™; on the pertinence for Book II of the tradition of philosophical skepticism embodied in Gryll, see Loewenstein (2007).
87.8 Echoing Rev 22:11, â€˜he which is filthie, let him be filthie stilâ€™, and 2 Pet 2:22, â€˜the sowe that was washed, [is returned] to the wallowing in the myerâ€™.

87.9 Cf. 83.4, the tempest of his wrathfulnesse: Temperance includes good timing, grasping the moment as opposed to seizing the day. The Palmerâ€™s emphasis on timing thus implicitly contrasts Acrasiaâ€™s carpe diem topos (st. 74-75) with that of binding Occasion: as Kiefer observes, Occasion in Renaissance portrayals acquires maritime imagery previously associated with Fortuna because â€˜seizing the tide was regarded as parallel to the idea of seizing the forelockâ€™ (1979: 21). Cf. iv.4.5-8.
